file: HOT - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 23March2011 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: According to the Fortune magazine survey of Most Admired Companies, we are ranked at number  eight worldwide in the Social Responsibility category, and we continue to apply conservative  accounting and keep a clear focus on proactive risk management. So, ladies and gentlemen, we’ve  made our homework, I would say.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In December ‘10, Leighton sold 35% of its Leighton India subsidiary to the Indian Welspun Group.  The strategic collaboration with the local partner now opens up additional potential markets and  profits. We thereby expanded our opportunities in the rapidly growing infrastructure markets of  India, for example, in water and energy supply and in the oil and gas business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Social Infrastructure segment generated earnings above budget from its operating project.  Additionally, the segment profited from the sale of five projects in which no equity stake was       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Please turn to page eight before and to HOCHTIEF Europe. HOCHTIEF Europe mainly conducts  the core construction business in European countries and also operates as an international general  contractor and construction service provider outside of Europe. The division continued its strategy  in ‘10 to further expand into these markets, such as the Gulf state and Eastern Europe, but also in  innovative market segments such as offshore wind farms and green buildings.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s have a look at the figures. New orders went down by 18.5%. However, the large portion of our  ‘09 new orders figure related to the €1.3 billion contract awarded in ‘09 for the construction of the  8.5 kilometer Barwa Commercial Avenue Shopping Boulevard in Qatar. Our focus on highly  profitable markets was rewarded in the energy sector with large contracts with offshore wind farms.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Additionally, we have announced that we are actively looking for M&A opportunities in the Indian  construction market and the offshore wind park construction market. But on these items, we will  provide you with greater detail once we are more advanced. Now, let’s move to the Real Estate  division on page nine.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: HOCHTIEF Services concentrates on facility management and energy management services. New  orders develop positively. Among other things, this resulted from growing interest in outsourcing  projects and energy contracting solutions. Moreover, we were able to renew several large orders in  the division. Thus, new orders were clearly above prior year value with an increase of 44.5%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Additionally, HOCHTIEF Concessions’ activities had a high intrinsic value. The value of portfolio  twice a year on the basis of the discounted cash flow method. The total net present value of our  Concessions portfolio amounted to €1.68 billion at the end of ‘10 compared to €1.6 billion the year  before. At the end of last year, our Concessions portfolio comprised stakes in six airports, seven  roads and tunnels, 17 projects in the social infrastructure segment and two geothermal power  plants.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Growing on vast resources of expertise, a new division is going to focus on dynamic and high-yield  market segment, such as the energy supply of the future, improvement of transport, infrastructure,  construction and operation of sustainable buildings in emerging markets. Please turn to slide 19  now.

file: HOT - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Yeah, thank you, Lars. I would like to step up, get a bit closer to you. I feel much more comfortable standing up
texts.text: In addition to the three operational divisions, we have only the Airport business, which is an asset for sale, which  is different to this regard. And to increase the collaboration, the understanding and the use of know-how and  resources and competence in the group, we've established a group executive committee where the CEOs meet on a  monthly basis. And as a result of this, you see an increase in projects, which they follow together, whether that is  tunnel – tunneling competence where Hochtief Europe goes to the U.S. or whether it's offshore wind park,  offshore Cape Cod, where the European offshore people go to Flatiron to pursue with the Cape Cod wind farm  projects, or whether it's a construction of a bridge in Hong Kong where American people go to Hong Kong to help  Leighton to do construction work on the bridge.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: Thanks, Peter. I think you will get some questions on some of these things later. Let's talk about which way we go  with the company. There are three strategic initiatives; energy, traffic infrastructure and urbanity. And I would  like to go quickly through all three areas to give you an idea where we are and where we want to go with those.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: And that brings us to the next point, that we have decided to take interest, financial interest, in wind park, when  they are at the very early phase of development. Before, actually, there is the governmental approval, because we  see that the current developer struggle with issues which were not properly resolved at these very early phases,  which is actually to come up with a equipment which is suitable of installing with exact locations, the geological  conditions at the exact location of each pile; and the decision on the way how to actually put the foundation in  place, which kind of foundation you need to use and how many days you want to actually install; and what is your  harbor you're going to use and how do you bring the equipment to the harbor and from the harbor to the location  you want to build.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: And those are all the questions we can answer from our experience in the construction industry and in this  particular industry. And that will take out a lot of risks which now is calling – which now is causing three-digit- million costs of delays. And which for comparably a little money, can be fixed at the very, very early phase. And  that is where we want to step in, want to spend that money, get the approvals, and then sale of the right into this  wind farm to developers.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: We are prepared to take it from there to the next level of installation. We've come up with a joint venture with  Ventizz as a company, and our target initially is to acquire six of those wind farm rights. At the same time, we  continue to push technology to be able to put foundations into the grounds, not by ramming, but by boring to  reduce the noise level substantially, and we have a few other ideas.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: That is the one side of energy. I want to give you some ideas on what we do elsewhere. Australia is very much  driven by the energy industry, in particular since Japan now has shutdown all but one nuclear power plants. They  need to switch to a different energy carrier, which is gas. The gas needs to come from somewhere, and it comes  from Australia, which results in a huge wave of development of liquefied natural gas plants in Australia, which  were in the pipeline for quite some time but now actually constructed.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: The latest one is the Wheatstone fields driven by Chevron, which owns more than 70% in the development, and  which is a AUD29 billion development. At the North West coast of Australia, Leighton has now has three contracts  relating to that development for civil construction work.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: As Leighton, the affiliate of Thiess, we built a power tunnel for the city of Sydney, 3.2 kilometers, AUD107 million,  where we again show that in the group we have technology which will be needed here in Europe and in particular  consumers, you cannot avoid – in particular in regions like Northern Australia and the rural area, that you need to  cross densely populated areas where people and communities will not accept high lines, but they will insist on  sub-ground developments. And one of them is that you put a power tunnel into the grounds. Flatiron have just  built 250 kilometer of high-voltage transmission, and we have established a joint venture with COBRA for the  transmission challenges here in Germany.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: Leighton continues to be extremely active as the world's largest mining contractor to dig out coal out of the earth  in Australia, and there are some impressive new contracts. And on top of this, we expand our service to manage  energy, mainly in real estate and property. And you can see here, just in Germany, we have about 130 projects  where we do energy management for our customers and we achieve 115,000 tons of carbon savings. We have some  of the customers who based the reporting on the energy saving and CO2 saving reports we do for them.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: If we put together and add up the work we already now have in energy in our group, we realize that it's a €4.9  billion workload – and not workload actually, performance item, which is in energy work in 2011. And we have  now come up with a target, as we will support this by respective programs to grow that part of our workloads, the  energy-related work, by 40% up to 2016.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: And Turner continues to be the number one general builder in the U.S. And Turner is more focused on  institutional building. And as recent examples, we have listed here the Whitney Museum of American Arts in New  York or the Mercy Westside Hospital, which has 250 hospital beds. And Turner is basing its development very  much on certification on green buildings and have expanded its activities now also to India where they have  established a joint venture to develop city quarters and part of the cities.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: And if you travel on some of the German highways, you'll realize that. For example, at the A45, there's a huge  number of bridges where you now need to reduce your speed to 60 kilometers per hour because they're no longer  able to allow higher speed. And the result is those bridges were built 30 years ago, designed for commercial traffic  with a load of 20 tons, we now have 40 tons crossing the bridges and they are no longer stable to do this. And if we  have the heavy trucks, the newly-developed heavy trucks, it will be 48 tons. And that will result that our bridges,  which were designed for 50 to 70 years of life, they're only 30 years of life. And that is a huge challenge in terms of  cost and traffic burden.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: And this is just Germany. If you translate this to countries where you have increased traffic because of increase in  population, you start to realize the size of the challenge. And on top of all of that, we not only have people moving,  we have heavy freight moving. And then, we go to Australia, where you have 500,000 kilometers of distance  between a coal mine and harbor and you need to bring all these coals to the harbor. So, for each new mine, you

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: And we believe that Hochtief is, with its experience, with its cover in terms of locations and with its experts, is best  suited to response to these challenges. And as part of this answer, we've got the 58 kilometers between Ulm and  Augsburg to increase the lanes for the Autobahn A8. We are building the Firth of Forth bridge in Scotland. We are  building two tunnels crossing the River Thames, each 8 kilometers. And we are, in the U.S., underway to renovate  Route 5 and the access road to the Golden Gate Bridge with a PPP project.

texts.speaker: Frank Stieler
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board, Hochtief AG
texts.text: We extend the Bidbid-Sur highway in Oman with 75 kilometers. And part of our efforts, research work around the  world, is to respond to the question I addressed, so how can we make bridges more resistible from additional  loads to avoid that the concrete is cracking, water comes in and the structures get destroyed.

file: HOT - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 28February2013 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter-Wilhelm Sassenfeld
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Labor Director, Hochtief AG
texts.text: Yes, it's a strong improvement to prior year. Yes, it is on operational guidance level and please also keep in mind  the extraordinary effects we have in here, positive effects, sale of Thiess Waste Management at Leighton, but also  write-downs on BrisConnect, Al Habtoor Group, Macmahon and also the compensation for the former CEO here.

texts.speaker: Peter-Wilhelm Sassenfeld
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Labor Director, Hochtief AG
texts.text: Leighton finished and hand over in 2012 these weak loss-making projects, Victorian Desalination and Airport  Link. Then they have started, let's say, to recovering cash and to reducing net debt, not just through our  emphasizing, let's say, the management in the risk and the core business, but starting to sell non-core assets. Last  year, they sold Thiess Waste Management and they were very, very profitable and very successful. And I will  explain to you that they continued this year 2013 with this strategy.

texts.speaker: Peter-Wilhelm Sassenfeld
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Labor Director, Hochtief AG
texts.text: Regarding service solutions. Service solutions include facility and energy management. Obviously this is a  segment that is reliably successful with stable margins and a low capital intensity. We are in the top 10 in  Germany, but if we want to be, let's say, more profitable, we need to increase our investment in this activity. And  we thought that it is not our core business activity, that's why we are committed to sell this activity. We are going  to do it and if you ask us what is the completion for to achieve this, we can explain to you that we are going to do it  and as soon as possible. We are very committed. We are starting the process and we want to do it as soon as  possible.

texts.speaker: Peter-Wilhelm Sassenfeld
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Labor Director, Hochtief AG
texts.text: Infrastructure solutions. Infrastructure solutions is a merge between [indiscernible] (31:46) infrastructure and  then energy and infrastructure solutions plus international project solutions. We started the merge in January and  then we are analyzing this company, because as you can realize for us we are – it is a very very important core  business. We have very very important challenges for this year for the months to come. But first, we have to  streamline our organization. We have to adopt our organization to the current risk in the different countries we  are working. We want to do this in the next months together with our team and we are going to focus more in  profitability and in cash collection.

Contract mining is a volume-driven business, and in this context, it is worth noting  that Australia's coal exports continued to grow during 2013. texts.text: When we talk about efficiency, as we've talked about in any number of occasions now, we recognize that we've got  a structural cost problem within the firm that we need to address. texts.speaker: Iain James Mackay
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, HSBC Holdings Plc
texts.text: Thirdly, you see the full effects in 2014 to '19 of capital reductions and again, the actions that we will continue  around data cleansing, around collateralization of certain positions, around the runoff of portfolios and aggressive  management. texts.speaker: Iain James Mackay

texts.text: That said, there's a lot to do and this is not simply [ph] flipping the coin (29:06) and turning the thing around  quickly. texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: If we then go over to Europe, Asia-Pacific, yes, sales went down 8%. We normally in this business talk a lot about  the weather. We can't avoid that. But I've already said that, what happened in Europe and a lot of you have seen  that. While we were pleased to see that in Europe, we have been able to grow a lot in the dealer channel. That has  been one of main focus areas, not only Europe, even in Americas. And we have done that to see if we can even sell  more of our global premier brand, Husqvarna.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: So there, we've seen the all activities we have had in the dealer channels. We have launched what we call  commercial order that we start to work with more professional products, both when it comes to ride-on products  as well as lawn mowers and trimmers. So far, that launch of that new segment for us has been very successful,  mainly in the dealer channel and under the Husqvarna brand.  Retail channel, on the other hand, mainly driven by watering due to 95% all the watering products under the  Gardena brand are sold via this retail channel; of course it has been effective. Then of course a little bit effective in  Latin – Europe as well here, when it comes to Italy, Spain, and Portugal. So that of course is not only the weather  impact, more the economic situation down there.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Robotic mowers, yes, lawn grass is growing, once again a record year when it comes to robotic mowers.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And then going over to Americas, yes, 11% adjusted currency effect on net top line here, mainly driven in U.S. and  Canada and Latin America, but mainly in U.S. But all have had growth in Americas. But what you're seeing here,  for a very, very good spring, especially in U.S., a slowdown in the beginning, mid-June. We, of course, follow the  weather very well. We normally look on the weather forecast twice a day worldwide. The last six, eight weeks have  been extremely warm and drought in U.S., all the states, about 100 degrees Fahrenheit. It's roughly 40 degrees. Of  course, that have effected a little bit now that the sales dropped when it comes to lawn mower and ride-on  products in U.S. in the second part of the quarter here.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: We have increased the market shares in some areas. There was a question last time if we have lost market share  when it comes to the tractors due to the debacle we had in Orangeburg. Yes, we had it last year. But we see now  they're coming back again here. This hard work has had effect on us here. We talk about a about the listings here.  We said that we have been able to convince our customers to believe in us, that we solve this problem, and we've  seen the effect this year. The sales have grown a lot and we've been able to supply them. Extremely good work in  Orangeburg. That effect will work with that factory in itself. Of course, have had a lot of spillover effect in other  sectors in the group as well to be more flexible. You can see that in the inventories, we have been more flexible to  go up and down here when it comes to the weather conditions here. Very good improvement when it comes to that  here, and a little bit effect of this problem we had in U.S. last year. EBIT increased as a result of higher sales and  lower production costs.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Thank you, Ulf. So summing up this here, we had flat sales since last year, a very strong demand in U.S. market as  well as for us, the weather in Europe and in the end of the quarter even in U.S. It's very important to understand  this when it comes to the watering here, what works here. The shift between watering products and the grass need  more water vis-à-vis as it is today is roughly two-and-a-half, three weeks. If it should be dry out now in Central  Europe mainly, it takes roughly three weeks and the grass is brown. And then if it starts to rain, which is again, so  here we need to be really flexible.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: So today, we can see it's good to have both watering as well as lawn and garden lawn mowers. If the sales in the  dealer channel with the Husqvarna brand, I mean, extremely good robotic mower, as well as other wheel products,  have been extremely good when it comes to this weather.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: On the other hand, the high margins mainly in the Central Europe have been heavily affected by the weather in  our result, top line.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And then to discuss the future. The weather, that's something we have to live with and be flexible. And we are  working on that to be even more flexible; then what happen in the future, I don't know, with all these information  we have every day in newspapers, as well in the news in TV here.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Electric order products will change into battery as well. That's the reason why we have launched a range of battery  products under the Husqvarna brand last year for – so to sell this year, and we'll continue that work to focus on  that. We've been more, even when it comes to battery products, on ride-on and even on walk-behind products.  That give us more focus.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Then we have changed a little bit, that we collect all, let's say, lawn mowers and ride-on products into one  category. This is a lot of synergies, lot of technologies. Cutting equipments are more or less the same. It has more  people to focus on this and we'll be more efficient when it comes to focus on new products in the future.

file: HUSQ.B - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 19July2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Watering products, which suffered heavily from the heavy rainy season 2012, is more or less on an unchanged  level versus last year, partly due to trade inventory overhang from last season into this year. I think it's worth  to  remember also the rain will start down in Europe beginning of this quarter.

texts.speaker: Ulf Liljedahl
texts.profession: SVP, Head-Group Staff Finance, IT & IR, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: If we then look at some of the positives, there is a price mix effect. You have heard from Kai, if we take the produ ct  mix specifically in Europe starting with watering, we don't have any effect. I mean, the quarter two started off, as  you know, last year, watering's okay, and then we had a stop based on a pretty rainy summer. The reverse, you  could say, had happened this season here. It has been a very weak start when it comes to watering, but ending up  slightly better. So – but watering is not year-over-year in the quarter giving any effect.

texts.speaker: Ulf Liljedahl
texts.profession: SVP, Head-Group Staff Finance, IT & IR, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And then we have a portion of savings. We both have the initiatives related to the COGS initiative, savings in  material, not least. And we also had the saving program, the restructuring program that we have some of the  savings attached to the cost of goods sold. I would come back later on and summarize some on that. But in  essence, they contribute with some 0.7 percentage points. So, there you have in essence the bac kground here to  the deterioration. We have some positive that we are quite pleased with, but they are not enough to offset the  effects and the under-absorption in essence. I mean, I think that is the main conclusion here.

file: HUSQ.B - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 16July2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Moving over to Americas, all-in-all, 4% with quite a variation though from a very negative view up in the North  Canada, weather-driven, and a very late start of the season up in Canada, whereas U.S. obviously then is above  that average, equally Latin America above that average number of the 4%.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: It's a word of caution because we have had now 7% for the quarter two respectively, the first half year sales  increases. I'd like to draw your attention to the fact that last year quarter three was – we had a prolonged season  in North America compared to an average season on one hand, and we had a drought or a high pressure that  stayed for quite some time over the Continental European space during July until August last year, which led to  over average water sales. So compared to a more average season, we had two things that stood out positively in  quarter three last year, and what we've seen so far from the start of quarter three, it's more like an average quarter,  and I do not have the visibility of how the total quarter will look like.

file: HUSQ.B - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 18July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And let me also just make one comment around the season and the weather. Yes, it was indeed a bit cold, a bit  slow at the beginning of the quarter, but let me summarize the quarter two, there was no real weather impact at all  irrespective of whether we are looking at North America or Europe. But it was true, it was colder at the beginning  and particularly in the North, and there are, of course, specific markets that has been burdened by weather like  Russia who had snow all the way into June actually.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Moving over to Gardena Division, very strong and actually had the backdrop of the dry weather particularly in  June. So, Continental Europe, 11% up driven by primarily the watering category, but also categories like robotics,  like the smart – the combination of robotics and irrigation, also driven by hand tools. They have all performed  quite well actually.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Now, a little bit the disappointing part, not necessarily in terms of sales, moving on to Consumer now, it's up 9%.  So, how do you interpret the 9%? Well, actually, it says less about this quarter, more about last year's quarter two  which was under average. It was really difficult from a weather perspective in North America in 2016. So, if this is  what I would describe a normalized sales situation from a burdened quarter by weather last year. So, 9% in itself  is nothing spectacular. Actually, we would almost have expected more. It has been a very competitive retail  space, a lot of campaigns, and it's also a combination where we have had for us a bit of an unfortunate product  mix, as well as a geography mix with Europe a bit declining and North America then all very average growth.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Really going forward, I would say the measures are solid. They are firm, may that be cost-efficiency  improvements or may that be adding new products in the pipeline for listings in the future. So, we are still very  confident about that. We will see the improvement. But we have to accept that it will be slower. The target  remains, the 5% target remains, there is no hesitation around that.

But I would say still on the overall scheme of things, it has been a good quarter in respect for demand.

Great numbers, of course, and we see then the operating income  improving absolute numbers, but being somewhat lower from a margin perspective.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn

Good growth in all regions and particularly the dust and slurry segment is doing fine, but  it's throughout doing pretty good.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

The operating  income and operating margin have increased in spite of actually loss of 8% in net sales.

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And, of course, as I said, heavily attractive economic situation mainly here in southern part of Europe as well as  the northern part likely. And then we have the weather impact. texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And then, we have a U-cut steering solution for tractor. That's a little bit that we – take a little bit from this rider  here. texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Then of course, we have a lot of new products like electric hedge trimmers, and we continue with this oldest  sprinkler system and all this automatic sprinkler system as well. texts.speaker: Hans Emanuel Linnarson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Then summing up quarter three here, as we said, higher operating income but sales declined 8%. We normally  talk about weather. And then, of course, as you know, the currency situation is  something we have to live with as well here.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: With that, I take the opportunity to move over to Europe and Asia Pacific. As you see, the increase was 8%. Yes, I  think it in general, I didn't make the comment initially, but I maybe should have; it has been a very favorable  season, quarter three, in both Europe as well as in America. So it has – also we had a period of dry weather in  Europe, which has supported good watering season. And the watering products have an over average gross  margin. So that obviously contributes to the result improvement as well.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Now moving over to North America, which I guess, is of high interest for you. We had a fantastic sales  development with 20% comparable currencies. Again, prolonged season, favorable weather conditions; last year  was also a year of drought. So the reference in that respect maybe is artificially somewhat lower. But the big issue  here is of course that we didn't manage to get the scale advantages from that sales increase.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And with that, I'll take the opportunity to move over to talking a bit about the accelerated improvement programs.  And when I do that, I want to emphasize that we are talking about forest and garden. So please, that's not  encompass the Construction. The focus is forest and garden, because this is where we have the issues to address  that I will talk about.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: I will soon show a picture showing that we have raised the bar from 20% to 30% to the Group in terms of  reduction of platforms. But really, in the retail, the question is rather a number of 40%, 50% complexity reduction  than anything else. To reap the full benefits of the scale advantages, we need to install, to be competitive in that  business, our money. So we're talking about reducing brands, yes; platforms, yes, and stock-keeping units.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Again, understanding – I think it is important to emphasize; this is not only about the product and the product  cost, the COGS. It's also bringing costs throughout the whole company. I mean by doing this complexity reduction,  we are enabling taking out cost all the way from supplier interactions to sales and marketing.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Also, under operational excellence, we intensify our efforts to take out material price reductions; direct material  price reductions. If you look at the component purchases as share of the revenues, it's about 42%, excluding raw  materials, because that's much more commodity-driven and much more difficult to deal with.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And the target we have set out to do here is to versus the same reference, end of 2012, take out 10% until end of  2015. So we are quite specific here about that. That is a combination of purchasing and R&D. So it's not one of the  two, it's the combination. Some of them – of those percentage points can be realized through smarter  negotiations. But in many of the cases, we need to do redesign to actually facilitate that cost reduction. So it's a  combination of the two.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Yes, there are some differences related to Europe and North America, and you have fundamental changes in the  way that agriculture might be more important. You might have a palm, olive plantations, and you have  commercial weed to deal with, which bring some differences in the products. And yes, we do need to respond to  that, but I think we're talking about modification to a large extent of products that fundamentally can be used in a  beneficial way in those markets.

We're talking about SEK 100 million, and was an asset purchase, but it's one of the leaders in the  micro-irrigation area and that's particularly what we were looking for. They're also active in mobile watering, and  they are among the top three in Australia in this area, and they will become a part now of the Gardena division  going forward.

There are a lot of dry gardens down in Continental European space.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking into the divisions, Husqvarna, yeah, you could say maybe a bit of a disappointment in the quarter from a  result point of view, but from a sales point of view, it's okay, it's plus 3%. I would like to emphasize particularly  North America and then early selling of the winter products, the snow throwers, the snow-blowers, which is good  from a sales point of view but not necessarily supporting us in the mix, overall mix. And you will also know that  some of the profit pools are not as pronounced in the quarter three and the second half of the year as they are in  the first of the half of the year.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, that's what we're talking about and the reasons you heard me mention why we do that. So, that's all clear. And  why do I not communicate this as a program then? Well, the reason is because of the fact it's going to be very  detailed if I start to do that, because then I will have to tell you exactly the cost reduction elements, the market  investments per division, et cetera, and you will all ask how much it's going to be into various divisions and why,  et cetera. And it is not a level of detail that we think is feasible for the external communication and such.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, that's why we avoid talking about this as a program. But, of course, we are maintaining good practices from the  accelerated program and putting it into this kind of environment as well going forward. To safeguard that, we  have this under control.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Ytterberg
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Gross income, in the quarter, some SEK 110 million better than last year. First of all, [indiscernible] (20:47) into it  a positive product mix, especially then related to the watering products with the dry weather down in Central  Europe, but we should not remember [sic] this was not achieved only by the weather; it was also a result of a  continuous good work on increased points of sales out in the Gardena Division for some 12, 24 months now, and  also an achievement actually to produce what was needed in this situation.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

Also quite satisfactory for us was that we got an Innovation Award at Lowe's a couple of weeks ago, which we are  quite glad to see, of course.

file: HUSQ.B - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 19October2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: But let us start in the ordinary procedure in summarizing the quarter three. So, you have all seen; you have all  heard about the long, warm and dry summer, which of course, affected the demand particularly for the Husqvarna  Division which has affected us quite a bit. On the other hand, divisions like Gardena has thrived from the same  element, of course, and we will see that in their P&L very clearly.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: So, we have a weather impact which is of course important and sizable. But I also want to be clear about that we  also have another effect that is where we are imbalanced previous years. The efficiency program has really  delivered quite substantial improvement and which has balanced the addition of costs we're taking for the  profitable growth initiatives. This year we have come into an imbalance between them and get back to that as well  which has burdened the P&L.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And then back to the imbalance between the cost additions and the efficiency program which doesn't make up.  Altogether for the period of year to date nine months, 14.1% operating margin versus 16.3% than last year.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Ytterberg
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Okay. As Kai said, operating income over around half of last year's third quarter was already communicated  September 18, and also the effects of the divisions and groups related then to the weather in Central and  Northern Europe as well as the challenges we still have in Consumer Brands.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: The third element here is to restore the balance of what you've heard us talked quite a bit about, what did not  work out this year which we have done pretty well actually if we're talking about the preceding years which is to  have the balance between the efficiency improvements and the additional costs. So, we will reduce the cost  addition somewhat. But we will try to ramp up so that balance is on the right side.

It's an initiative [ph] by UN Global Compact IMSaT (30:40) demonstrating company's ambitions to  share in the green path to maintain the temperature increase below 2 degrees of humankind impact. So, you can  say it's our share of that. And the two targets we have actually set up is minus 10% versus 2015 in terms of  intensity of CO2. And in absolute terms, 33% reduction of CO2 equivalents by 2035.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Ytterberg
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: So, these are the two targets we have committed to and we are talking about reductions throughout the entire  value chain, from the suppliers to the use of the products. And you will realize that including the use of the  products also means we are actually living with the product [ph] ranges (31:36) we have. And that's also why we  have an intensity target in the shorter period of time and an absolute target for the longer range here. But this is  going to impact, of course, throughout the company and it's a change that is not necessarily new, but it's really  important that we bring this to consistency throughout the whole company.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Ytterberg
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And it will have an impact, may that be in terms of product developments and you heard me talk about the battery  ranges, we are expanding it. Actually, I want to emphasize, we are accelerating that a lot. And that will help, but  also the petrol-based products are undergoing new technology to reduce emissions in various ways.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Ytterberg
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Transportation, of course, an important area and just to stay with example, which is very relevant right now, the  Orangeburg warehouse. We are actually reducing seven warehouses in the region to one adjacent to the plant.  And we're taking out, to give you a figure, some 330,000 kilometer of transportation with trucks, just to give a  magnitude of what's going on with one single change there.

texts.speaker: Jan Olof Ytterberg
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: We are making also more regional production in order to support it to reduce transportation and the packaging as  such, can also be more volume-efficient and optimized. Manufacturing, increase of renewable energy sources  and solar being introduced at some sites. Sourcing, including and embedding our suppliers into this, we're starting  to audit their efforts because they need to share in here with our endeavors and ambitions. So, it's a couple of  tough targets. We don't hesitate. We think it's important as a company with a lot of petrol legacy, we need to take  our share of this and stay to the green path. So, it' a journey, it's very aspirational. We have good activities, but  we would need to define a lot more going ahead.

texts.speaker: Henric Andersson
texts.profession: President-Construction Division, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And as I said, we have finalized this here yesterday. So, the system albeit around the process steps. texts.profession: President-Construction Division, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: And then, at the same time, we also acquired a Soff-Cut, which is basically the second to last process there. texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: Now, just before we get to the question, I just want to take some other type of data point here and to share with  you and that is actually sustainability and Sustainovate, which is the terminology we use when we talk about  integrating sustainability into our way of being.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: We have set the target of reducing the intensity of CO2 with minus 10% until 2020. That was done based on the  reference of 2015, if I remember correctly. Actually, we are at minus 24%. texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: So, I think that's a great result, which shows that if we take this seriously, and I want to be very clear about that,  just to give you another data point, if you look at energy and the share that comes from renewable energy  sources, we are almost at 60%. texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB
texts.text: So, we are taking some big steps to really put this on the agenda. And some of you will recall that we committed very clearly to the scientific-based  targets and the green path some few years back.

texts.speaker: Kai Bertil Wärn
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Husqvarna AB

So, I think that's an important statement. And we see market leadership,  when we talk about that, of course, it's technology innovation, but it's also increasing this aspect that becoming  important, so.

file: IAGL - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 11May2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. As we had anticipated, Q1 has been a difficult quarter for the main  European network carriers and also for IAG. Fuel cost increases have been significantly aligned with: firstly, the  unwinding of hedges, the high fuel international prices, and the impact of emission costs through the quarter.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So now the previous high watermark we had reached in Q1 2009 has been clearly surpassed on a global economic  growth environment, which is not clearly a very powerful one, especially in the European space. We have  implemented further fuel surcharge increases in Q1, and these have largely been stuck. Capacity discipline at both  sides of the Atlantic has probably very much to do with this improvement in pricing power and our ability to offset  a significant part of our fuel cost increases.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, on the cost side, year-on-year cost comparisons in this quarter are adversely affected by fuel cost increases,  which also remains significant through the rest of Q2, and receding probably further on through H2. The  strengths of sterling and U.S. dollar have also impacted negatively, I would say, by around 1.4% the cost increase  of the period. Finally, a series of one-offs and accounting changes that we'll explain through the following slides  have contributed to apparent increase in non-fuel unit cost that will show significantly lower on a like-for-like  basis.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: This quarter, the fuel cost rise has been exacerbated by emission trading cost, stronger U.S. dollar and hedges  being exercised at similar levels to market prices. The fuel bill for the quarter has been very much aligned to our  anticipated figure of €1.4 billion. Recent reduction in international fuel prices related to higher inventory levels in  the world and a reduced geopolitical tension may result, if they consolidate, in a reduction of the fuel bill, although  partially compensated by a stronger U.S. dollar against the euro.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, this is the chart that we usually are using to reflect the sensitivity of that quarterly forecast of our fuel bill. We  are maintaining, as a base case, an estimate of $1,080 per tonne of kerosene and $1.3 per euro for the rest of the  year, but showing at the same time the sensitivity through the different assumptions that we could be making on  fuel performance and the dollar rate.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: We continue to execute our hedging policy, and our aim is not to speculate over fuel prices or ForEx levels. We are  currently 71% hedged for the remainder of the year and 55% hedged for the next 12 months. The graph shows the  sensitivity to changes in the market price of kerosene, which would result in plus or minus €17 million for each  $10 per metric tonne of change in the price of kerosene at constant U.S. dollar terms.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Also significant, the Avios new accounting. We have begun different accounting for our treatment of flat fees  collected in lieu of taxes, fees and charges under the Avios program. These increased non-fuel unit cost by 0.5%  and, over time, is expected to be netted through additional revenues.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Finally, this is a very interesting chart. We think we're trying to reflect, at an EBITDA level, the ways and intensity  in which we have been offsetting the cost increases of the quarter, especially paying attention on the fuel cost  increases. As you can see, a very strong unit revenue recovery. Under the summary, we have been able to offset up  to around 73% of the cumulative price impact in both fuel and other costs through price increases and mix  improvements, representing a very high proportion on a weak seasonable demand period for a year.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy De Lome Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: At the current oil price and euro/U.S. dollar exchange rates, we'd face a fuel cost increase this year of over €1  billion. Although, as we mentioned several times, this year-over-year impact should be less severe in H2, and  maybe we'll be benefiting from, if it happens, a consolidation of reductions on the fuel international pricing.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So we are going to talk about trends. Current trading is in line with our expectations. And for year 2013, excluding  Vueling, we expect to reduce group capacity by 1.8%. And we are keen in keeping our non-fuel unit cost guidance  flat for the full year versus the full last year.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So as initial savings, we are counting on 3% unit labor cost reduction for this year, for the case of Iberia. We will  get some fuel tailwinds as I was explaining before. And we are also counting and targeting  that the cash flow – operating cash flow for the second half of the year would be at least neutral. For the full  transformation plan, basically, operating result turnaround of €450 million improvement in margins will be  expected between year 2012 and year 2015.

texts.text: The more, I would say, cautious cut scenario will be based on lease returns, accelerated retirals, and contractually  allowed postponements of new deliveries. So, this shows how flexible our fleet such it can be to adapt ourselves to  the new demand patterns that we'll be facing in the different segments of our network.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, changing now to the cost side. The first chart has to do with overall unit operating cost behavior. So, on the  left-hand side of the chart, we can recognize the performance against the first year comparison. So, quarter-to- quarter, the second quarter shows a total fuel plus non-fuel behavior performance of only 0.5% improvement.  This means a very powerful message related to we've been able to offset nearly 100% of the fuel cost impact, the  negative fuel cost impact through reductions in costs in other, I would say, areas of the cost structure of our  business.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: If we make the comparison on a two-year exercise, and we make it on a 12-month rolling basis, we also recognize  represent a very significant improvement taking into account the inflationary pressures that we have been  suffering through these later months. So, we'll go through on a more detailed comparison on our different, I would  say, lines of costs. In the case of fuel costs, we're showing in this chart the bridge chart of how fuel costs have been  developing since last year, second quarter, and then into this year, second quarter.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: We have a modest increase having to do with volume. After that, we have a very significant increase, €470 million  have to do with market prices, which has been partially offset because of currency weakness, the dollar, and  because of the fuel hedges. So, the net figure for the second quarter of this year accounts for €1.25 billion. So, for  the Q2, 72% of the consumption was hedged. And the other fuel price paid after hedges was $925 per metric ton of  kerosene.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: If we go to the next chart, and we show how we see the full year, we are still sticking to this €5.2 billion figure for  the whole of year 2011 and this assumption has been made at a spot rate for the rest of the year of $1,070 per  metric ton. So, we also have these sensitivities of how this final figure would be if the fuel market prices would  range for the remainder of the year between $600 per metric ton to $1,400 per metric ton. So, the range of final  fuel bill will be between €4.8 billion in the more favorable environment to €5.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, if we come to the next slide, we are here showing the sensitivity that our fuel exposure is having to market  prices. So, as a whole now, we will be showing that if market prices move up or down $10 per metric ton of  kerosene, our operating results would be moving by plus/minus €8 million on a relative basis.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Our hedging, I would say, pattern has been evolving, and now we have 67% hedged of the second half. And it splits  between 73% for the third quarter and 61% for the fourth quarter. And on the, I would say, 12-month forward  basis, we are now hedged by 50% of our expected fuel consumption. So, the average levels – the average prices of  our hedges for the remainder of the year are in the range of $900 to $950 per metric tonne of kerosene.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And this has rendered this very significant improvement in the quarter that are also showing in this 2-year, 12- month rolling base comparison in which basically we're only showing a unit cost improvement of around 1%. Of  course, these unit ownership costs will increase in the future through the addition of the new fleet in which we are,  I would say, committed. But, at the same time, then, we'll be achieving very significant reductions in fuel  consumption and maintenance costs that will more than offset, I would say, the negative implication in our unit  ownership costs.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And then, we are seeing a very significant revenue improvement above the disruption one that more than offsets  the fuel cost negative impact that we are suffering. So, the basic message here is that through fuel surcharges;  through all the pricing movements that we have been able to implement through these last months; through our  mix improvement, and especially the strength of the premium segments of our traffics, we have been able to more  than offset the fuel cost impact that we have been suffering in the quarter. And then, on top of that, we have other  cost improvements by more than €130 million for the quarter that have allowed us to reach this €531 million  EBITDAR result for the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: In terms of the rest of the environment in which we are moving, what we can say is that our basic outlook remains  unchanged. Our long haul business is stable with still strong performance in the premium segments, especially in  this long haul area. We have to restate, again, that our short haul business remains highly competitive, especially  in some areas as the Madrid [ph] catch in (39:29) area, and that the cargo business has – we feel it has now  reached a plateau. So, we have to recognize that the comparisons through the remainder of the year's second half  will be more difficult.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: The second half of last year was strong. And we also have to recognize that through the next quarters, we will  continually and gradually unwind and use our fuel hedges. So, this means that if the fuel market prices remains  high, our fuel bill will continue growing. So, we still will remain very focused in maintaining a strong performance,  both in unit revenues, especially in the markets in which we are leaders, and also in positive performance on our  non-fuel cost base.

file: IAGL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 3August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: William M. Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: The environment in Spain has deteriorated significantly. The macroeconomic conditions are worse than expected  and expected to be significantly worse through the period of the plan. And the environment has been further  damaged by action by the Spanish government to increase charges at the airports in Spain. And as Enrique said,  despite the recent reduction in the price of oil, the benefit of that has not been seen in Iberia as a result of the  weakening euro versus the dollar. So, some of the tailwind that you would have expected to see from the lower oil  price has been offset by the weakness of the euro.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So again here, ex-fuel cost per ASK, significantly down from the first quarter when, if you remember, we had the  capacity reduction, but we didn't have the cost getting out of the structure of the company. So now we are getting  the costs out of the structure of the company gradually. So as you have read probably, 1,700 people have left now  Iberia to the first seven months of the year, and we will be getting to 2,400 people by the end of the year. So that's  good news the plan is being implemented and it will be shown in terms of costs.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Cost per ASK as a whole, apples-with-apples, minus 2.1%. Of course, this has to do a lot with fuel. Fuel is a big  help in this respect. But even without fuel, apples-with-apples, we are beginning to get where we need to get which  is remember, this flat or better performance that we were targeting for the year. And we're sticking to our target.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: In terms of RPKs, so we are seeing passenger figures holding despite, I would say, the capacity reduction in the  premium segment, so load factors there are significantly up. We are seeing RPK figures falling with capacity. If we  were to draw capacity, it will be very similar. This has to do more with the way Iberia is playing with pricing in the  non-premium, which is about targeting higher yields and accepting certain, I would say, reduction in terms of load  factors. So this is bringing this line down in terms of non-premium.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Of course fuel is helping. Employee cost should be lower than that, but it's a big, big change against the first  quarter. Supplier is on the negative and that's good news. Ownership is absolutely zero and on a combined like- for-like, we are slightly below zero, minus 0.2%. So this is a chart that we are following consistently, because we  want it really on the negative side or at least on the zero side.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And the way we have hedged the fuel for the rest of the year, which is becoming very flat in terms of the  vulnerability to increases in market prices is becoming lower and lower, so the €5.7 billion is becoming to be, well,  let's say, a quite trustable figure for the full year.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: We can talk a little bit about current trading, which I said already is in line with the recent trends. We can talk a  little bit about our growth pattern. Again, we've said we expect to grow group capacity by 5.2% including Vueling  and the reduction of 2.4% excluding Vueling. And we want to say that we are going to stick to our non-fuel target  in terms of non-fuel unit cost flat. And this is excluding Vueling because we know that Vueling would be an easy  enabler to reach that target.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Cruz de Llano
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Vueling Airlines SA
texts.text: In terms of the EBIT bridge from last year, very quick, on the left hand side last year's Q2 EBIT €12.1 million.  Fuel, dollar and hedging, also CO2 included in there as well, a small positive effect, €4.4 million. Definitely a good  performance on new routes and especially in some of the existing routes, €15 million contribution. Inflation and  others, some of the costs associated with additional costs that go up every year are due to inflation, and some  other issues such as the ATC strike that we've had which we have had to incur some additional cost, negative  impact of €13.9 million. But as usual, Vueling continues to drive through its cost reduction program additional  cost reductions in this case, €6.2 million additional cost reductions during the mont h or during this second  quarter.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Cruz de Llano
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Vueling Airlines SA
texts.text: On cost reduction, we set out ourselves this year with a target of reducing cost by €17  million, maintaining our  unit cost, ex-fuel cost. Q2 results, as I mentioned to you before, minus 3% on ex -fuel cost and we've already  captured €14 million out of the €17  million during the first semester. So good track on further reducing, taking  cost out of the business.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So these figures relate to these ones – passenger unit revenues. We've been keeping them, on a like-for-like pre- Vueling exercise, positive. And that's another message that we were very clear about. So it's growth. It's keeping  our unit revenues flat. And it's reducing our ex-fuel and, by the way, also our fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So ex-fuel unit costs have been coming down on a like-for-like again by 2.5%. There is a couple of effects that are  blurring a little bit how we understand the figures, and I want to go through them first. So it's the ForEx. So we  have a combination of weak dollar and strong sterling. As a whole, on net basis, they are bringing down the figures  of revenues and unit revenues and then, again, bringing down our figures of costs and unit costs.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Again, the other big news for the quarter and still for the year has to do with fuel and non-fuel efficiencies. In the  case of fuel, we are seeing, of course, the negative volume effect but the price plus efficiency, very positive effect in  the second quarter. So we have kerosene prices being low, even lower than we expected. Kerosene is still being  lower than we expected. But we have something in the range of 2% or even slightly more than 2% of lower fuel  costs related to efficiency, so this new fleet and new procedures, especially in Iberia. So good news on fuel and also  good news in other non-fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So let's try to drill a little bit more on the cost elements, and especially, first of all, in the ex-fuel cost element. So  first of all, we see the reported figure is minus 4.4%, but this is including both Vueling and the positive effect on  the cost side of a weaker dollar. So if we try to make a like-for-like exercise, the minus 4.4% comes to minus 2.5%,  which is again very much in line with what we have been messaging and with what we have been targeting on this  area.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So this means, imagine, we are getting less revenues – less freighter-related revenues but less freighter costs. The  less freighter costs are here. So good improvement, minus 2.5% like-for-like, and very much aligned with our  targets.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Fuel. Fuel is also a source of good news and not only because of the kerosene prices. So this chart – sometimes I  find it difficult to explain, and when I come back and say, okay. So this, for example, is the average price after  hedge that we had last year, okay. And this is the improvement that we would have into this year third quarter if  the market spot prices were to stay at $965 kerosene per tonne.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: The other good news behind fuel is operational improvements. As I told you, they are not in this chart. They are  on top of this potential, I would say, price saving, and they have to do with new fleet. So it's A380s, 787s, it's 330s  in the case of Iberia, and operational procedures in taxiing and approaching that will be benefiting Iberia.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So we are already trimming capacity for the fourth quarter and presumably into the first quarter next year by 3%.  This is being done on a type of frequency reduction type of scenario. So we're not canceling routes. We are not  stopping destinations. It's just trimming gradually our capacity through frequency type of adjustments on a type  of spread basis.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So we've introduced a new feature in the outlook weather chart that we've shown you before. But that's the only  thing that has changed and I think has changed for the positive. We have Steve Gunning, our CEO of IAG Cargo,  with us today. So if anybody has any cargo specific questions, I'm sure Steve will be pleased to address those later  on.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: We're really now seeing the benefit of new aircraft but what's important to point out is we're not just seeing  benefit from new aircraft in terms of our fuel efficiency, fuel saving programs that British Airways has, and indeed  Iberia has, and I'll show you an Iberia chart in a moment highlighting a different issue, these initiatives are paying  off as well, simple initiatives. We're looking at single engine taxi on twin engine aircraft. So we're taxiing out with  one engine, starting the second engine closer to take-off. Particularly at Heathrow, where we tend to have long taxi  times, that makes a difference. Taking weight out of the aircraft; any weight that we can remove from the aircraft  makes a difference.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So you can see the underlying fuel initiative benefits and then the benefit that we're getting from new aircraft. And  remember, at the end of Q2, we only had six A380s and six 787s. So as we expand the new aircraft fleet, we will  see further and further improvement here. We're just reviewing the forecast here to take into account the actual  capacity, bearing in mind that we are making some adjustments, but I would actually expect that to improve  beyond what we're seeing there. So real benefit on fuel coming through initiatives that we're taking and through  aircraft.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: But we are looking at the overall scenario and being very confident that while the environment is not easy, it's an  environment which we believe we can manage because of the flexibility that we have within the business and  because we're prepared to move quickly to adapt our business to what we see as either threats or opportunities in  a way that maybe some others are taking a bit longer.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the other side, we are mentioning again, as usually, that our ex-fuel unit cost performance for the same quarter  has been minus 6.9%, so an improvement of 27%. And again, we are showing that in real terms, in reported terms,  it's a plus 3.2%.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are going to be talking much more about ex-fuel cost performance in the following chart, but as a whole you  see a lot of greens there, a lot of blue ones there. The capacity impact of course has to be red, because we are  increasing all the time. But the quality of those costs in terms of unit cost performance is very much green. We are  going to be talking specifically about that point in the following chart.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And this is how the fuel bill will be looking like in the next quarters. Remember, it's very important how the  pattern of improvement in fuel costs is going to be accelerating in the next quarters. We said Q2, and that has  been a headwind that we have been going through in this quarter. Because of the way the hedges were unwinding  through the calendar year, Q2 looked not very good, and in fact it had, in terms of hedging dollar, a negative  impact against us. We thought it was going to be 4.2 or so it has been about 3. So a plus 3 instead of a plus 4.2 or  so we forecasted last quarter. But this is getting better and better through Q3, Q4 and then the following year. So  you see Q3 we are getting into again positive, so positive means saving territory, minus 5% savings in unit terms.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This chart is not regarding the operational improvement. So sometimes you will see figures that improve these  ones because of the operational improvement that we are getting through new seats and new procedures. This is  just price. But then the minus 5% will be getting to minus 16% by the end of the year. And then the 20%s and  25%s will be something probably more common through next year. So this is a little bit of, look, there is more to  come. Because of hedges and because of dollar, we are not having this big windfall positive impact. But that has  allowed us to focus on non-fuel cost homework, and in some ways, that's something that's going to be helping us  in the long run.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then the green one is the other way round, flying to the west. So, again, we would be saying flying to the west  out of the euro base is expensive, so it should be dampening bookings, and that's what we have seen in the first  quarter. And then there is still some type of shaky performance through Q3 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So this big dip in the blue is happening in most of the consumer-related business in the U.S., with the only  exception of restaurants. So all these savings that the U.S. people are getting because of fuel savings and more  dollar related money in their pockets, they haven't been spending it. That seems very strange. Okay, but it shows a  little bit what's happening with currencies and why we need to bring the figures both in constant currencies but  also in that context.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And then, these renewals plus growth positions are not going to be disturbing the pattern of growth that we have  for the group and that's the one we had for Iberia and we announced one year ago. So we were saying the long- term average growth trend for Iberia should be also, as in the case of British Airways, 2% or 3%. In this case, we  were mentioning 2%. And, of course, after these big prices adjustments that we did through 2011 and 2012, we will  be recovering those routes that now are going to be profitable again. What we are showing now is the green one.  So we are going to be accelerating, but just only mildly, the long-term pattern of growth for Iberia. And this will be  considering the new additional five A330s that we will be using in the next three years for this purpose.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, guidance. Guidance for the full year, in terms of operating profit, we are retaining the guidance. We are  reconfirming you that we are going to be getting this €2.2 billion plus, on a fuel bill scenario that we still are  rounding in the range of €6 billion and with a capacity growth for the calendar year that will be getting to around  5.2%. And that's basically it.

texts.text: So, basically, the two significant changes in respect of former quarters had to do, on one side, with Europe.  Europe, the minus 6.5% is slightly worse than last quarter, the first quarter of the year, and again, I have to come  back to these main type of negative impacts, of disruptions of ATC, of weather and strikes, okay. That has been  causing a non-optimal I would say performance and management of our short- and medium-haul networks,  especially for Vueling and for British Airways.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

Vueling has been very heavily hit by all these  disruptions, all these crisis, ATCs all these weather things, all the Barcelona Airport type of difficult management.  And finally, about their own growth problems because they are now going beyond their 110 number of aircraft in  their fleet and that is creating new threats, new challenges and the company is really now fighting and convinced  that they are going to be able to resolve.

So materials have actually increased their travel, but overall, as a sector, that has reduced.
