texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: We have to refer also to ex-fuel unit cost, and then again, this time I have to mention some exceptional  circumstances so this shows disruption on the long holiday, on the long weekend end of May, it's probably – it's a  very above high profile one that we need to mention. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Of covering fuel costs, again, as we announced, that provides the net price after hedges, positive impact is there  and it's very relevant. texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, this is a little bit about it. texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, we continue to make good progress on our non-fuel unit costs. We're on track to achieve our stated target of  1% reduction in non-fuel unit costs per annum. texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And just to give you some figures for the year-to-date, because I think they do demonstrate just how challenging  the environment is. To the end of July, there were 6.3 million flights operated through the EUROCONTROL  airspace. That's an increase of 3.5% over 2017, with a total of 11.9 million minutes of en-route delays, that's a  126% increase on 2017. 2017 for the full year was a 9.3 million, so we're already at 11.9 million seven months  against 9.3 million for the full year. And 54% of that was the direct result of air traffic control capacity and 18%  was as a result of industrial attributes. So, in total, the vast majority of these delays are being encountered  because of inefficiency within the ATC system in Europe.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: On the cost side, we've been achieving 1.4% non-fuel cost increase, which has to do basically with the disruption  that Vueling has created in terms of impact on costs and we'll go through the different cost lines later on. It has to  do also with the increasing relevance of some positive businesses as the case of British Airways Holidays, which,  as you will see, have a positive impact on our revenue lines, other revenues, non-passenger revenues, but also  impact on the cost side.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: The fuel costs, and I will go through them with more details in the following slides, have been improving very  significantly the performance of the group, with a price effect exceeding €400 million. On the rest of the ex-fuel  costs, we have special chart that we will go through. We have some ups and downs, very significant improvement  in employee unit costs and that's something that we are going to see again through Q4. It has to do with these  new initiatives that we are undertaking across the board in the different companies, especially this time, British  Airways and Iberia, and that will be rendering benefits already, I would say, through Q3, but especially Q4 and  next year.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, if we can go to the next slide now and talk a little bit with more detail on the ex-fuel unit cost performance.  Again, as I've just announced, a significant positive performance on employee unit cost across the group. So, it's  the British Airways, it's Iberia, it is especially Aer Lingus and Aer Lingus because of two positives that they are  bringing. On one side, their own non-fuel employee unit cost reductions, but also averaging down the mix of the  whole group. The exception is Vueling, and the Vueling deterioration in employee costs has to do basically with  disruption and with the additional buffering in terms of resources that the company had to undertake to deal with  this disruption impact.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Engineering has been affected because of basically two issues; on one side, additional wet lease, buffering  resources for Vueling; but also, a change – a gradual change in the model through which we are contracting third- party engineering works for the group, especially for British Airways. So, that's going to be entering into a  probably more stable model, switching into a pay-as-you-go, which is based on accruals, and switching out of a  time-and-materials model, which is basically upon cash. But the switch between one model to the other will be  creating a little bit of volatility on that cost line. So, selling is improving because of efficiency and because of new  contractual agreement with some of our distribution suppliers.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: If we switch to fuel costs, again, it has been a very positive performance in terms of market fuel prices, when we  compare it with Q3 year 2015. There is a constant-currency improvement of around 22%, and that's bringing  some important sales to the total unit cost line.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: What we are seeing for the quarters coming into year 2017 and Q4 is, even at today's prices, which are slightly  higher than a quarter before, a consistent reduction in fuel unit costs into Q4 2016 and 2017. 2017, probably, at  today's prices, would be showing an average unit fuel cost reduction in the range of 10% to 11%. So, there's still  some headroom for improvement on the fuel for the next months and quarters to come.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, this is also a strong performance for the group in Q3. On the cost side, the total constant currency non-fuel  unit cost increase account for 2.5%. Again, here, we have to mention that if we carve out the costs that are not  related to ASKs, so in this quarter especially Iberia third-party MRO business, we will be getting to an underlying  non-fuel unit cost increase constant currency terms of 1.4%

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: When we bring into consideration the performance of fuel, our total unit cost has been decreasing in constant  currency terms by 0.3%. So combining total unit revenues and total unit costs, our operating profit margin has  been improving by 3.4 percentage points through Q3 in respect to the same period in last year. And even if we  don't consider the fuel cost improved savings, so operating profit before fuel costs have also increased by 1.7% if  you compare them with the same result in 2016.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Fuel costs in terms of price has also been still a tailwind for our performance in this third quarter. And then on the  ex-fuel cost side, we'll be mentioning in the following chart impacts having to do with our employee cost, our  supplier cost and our ownership cost. As a whole, together with this positive foreign exchange currency  improvement of €37 million is how we explain the €215 million.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So if we change into the next slide and get into the fuel scenario. Basically what we're seeing for Q4 is still a mild  improvement in euro terms at actual market prices of fuel and also in the value of the dollar. And this mild  improvement in euro terms will also probably be the question for the first quarter in 2018. Since then, we will be  seeing a more breakeven situation against the similar periods on year 2017. So, basically, what we have to say is  we are hedged for the last quarter of the year at 84%.And we are seeing a total fuel bill for the year, which will be  close to €4.6 billion.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: British Airways has been basically flat, slightly negative, 0.5%, to Q3, also affected by hurricanes and weather  disrupting conditions through basically August and September. What we are seeing for Q4 is coming backto a  growth scenario, 4.3%, which will be making for a full year at 2.7%. Talking about the different companies, we will  be seeing Aer Lingus growin 11% in Q4, Vueling coming back to growth, 9.4%, Iberia 4.9% and British Airways  staying at 0.9% increased capacity level.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, as a whole, the guidance for year 2017 full year at current fuel prices and the exchange rates, we are  expecting an operating profit for the full year to be around €3 billion before exceptional items. So, thank  you.Willie?

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri

So, we've been offsetting practically 100% of the negative fuel  cost. And passengers have been taken into account 75% of these offsetting exercise, which is a high figure in  absolute terms but also in relative terms against what has been our story in previous years.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Finally, our non-fuel cost performance has been positive, adding another €30 million to the performance of the  quarter and allow us to reach this €1.46 billion operating profit results for Q3.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

And again, this minus 2.3% is possibly  affected by the compensations that we have been receiving on our agreements with engine manufacturers  through the summer.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And then let's talk a little bit more about fuel. Today, we  are at $740. So, really this has been a difficult chart to complete because fuel price in the market has been so  volatile that it was difficult to determine a specific reference to be able to produce a reliable one. Again, this is  basically on the higher end of the range of the prices that we're seeing today.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

So, it appears as the fuel bill for the quarter is now quite certain. And again, the message for  next year is, we see fuel costs and prices coming up, but at the rates that probably are not going to be dissimilar  to the ones that we're going to be seeing in this last part of the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So in these next slides, we’ll basically go through the main numbers. Headline operating profit for  the December quarter for IAG was €6 million. texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s go then to revenue trends through the quarter. The year 2010 saw a reduction in IAG  capacity, partly due and related to the strikes and volcanoes, but also due to our own active  capacity management, which aims to follow closely the demand developments in each of our  strategic markets. As you can see, this allowed us to keep load factors at similar high levels to the  same periods in last year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, moving from supply onto demand, we have put together this slide for you to give you as much  color as we can – and again, as you can imagine, visibility is low for the time being – about the  current revenue environment. It looks a bit like a weather forecast, but we hope you can find it  useful. Our main message is to say that long-haul premium cabins continue to show strong volume  growth at stable yields, so the unit revenue environment remains positive.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So let’s switch into fuel price expenses and exposure. I will try to get through a bit of what will  happen in year 2011 scenario. I’m sure the main focus for most of you today, though, is what will be  happening to fuel costs. We have these two slides on that. First of all, coming straight to the point,  shows what is our fuel bill likely to be. We show a range of scenarios. At year 2010 average prices,  our capacity growth would represent a cost increase of approximately €330 million at prevailing  year 2010 fuel prices. But of course on top of that, our final bill will depend on the average market  prices for the whole year and, again, our hedge position.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Using our current hedge cover and today’s dollar exchange rate – so approximately $1.36 – today’s  spot prices would produce a total bill of around €5.1 billion, compared with the prevailing last year  of €3.9 billion. A range of market prices between $850 per ton kerosene prices and $1,100 per ton  kerosene prices, again, would produce a cost outcome using the same assumptions of between  €4.8 billion in the lower case and up to €5.4 billion in the higher case.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, how we are hedged for the year. As you see in this chart, which shows basically the, I would  say, post-hedge fuel bill at different spot market prices of the kerosene, we are currently  approximately 53% covered for the year, about the same level of coverage as in January last year.  You can see that our cost changes by about €24 million with every $10 per ton of kerosene spot  price movement. You can also see a higher level of coverage for the first two quarters of the year  and a lower one for the remaining second half of year 2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Finally, non-fuel and non-employee unit costs will be moving down. See, the message is very much  the same as for employee costs – a negative impact from disruption in H1 last year, and maybe  again in December, but the bounce-back from one-off last year will mean that we’ll be expecting       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We are achieving this by sweating our asset base harder, increasing our utilization, increasing our  asset utilization without adding to our capacity base. Our core markets, premium and long haul,  continue to perform well, and the natural bounce-back from the volcanic and other disturbance of  last year should help us to achieve profit growth and further reduction in ex-fuel unit costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Of course, the worrying side of the story, in common with all other airlines, is related to fuel price.  Even if what we are seeing is just a spike, we still need to be prepared – and we are – for it to last  maybe several months. We will react as we have done historically, aiming to recover a significant  part of this cost impact through fuel surcharges, and because of our leadership position in our main  strategic markets, we are confident we will able to achieve.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Due to capacity discipline we see across markets, we don’t currently see any deviation from the  historical effectiveness of fuel surcharges. However, if the elasticity of demand were to change –  and remember, we are now a little bit on uncharted territories – if this elasticity of demand were to  change at these high absolute levels of the old price, we are of course prepared to produce the  required capacity reductions as we have done efficiently in the past.

And the rest have been compensated through a profitable type of same price, same  fuel cost growth exercise in relation of the disrupted fourth quarter of year 2010.

texts.speaker: William M. Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: If you turn to Iberia, quite a different picture, very limited revenue growth, 1.4%. Costs continuing to escalate,  again, largely on the back of fuel cost increases. And quite a change in the Iberia network there, which is demonstrated in the  significant increase in the stage length, 14% increase in stage length. So you will have seen us report at an IAG  level, I think we've reported domestic capacity, domestic ASKs down about 13%. In Iberia, it was down about 21%.  So we actually had some domestic growth in the BA network.

texts.speaker: William M. Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So you can see Iberia is changing its network and that's reflected in the increased stage length there. A significant  reduction in short and medium haul capacity. And I'll touch on the reasons behind that in a moment. And  therefore, that stage length increase clearly having an impact on the unit's revenue, but still a unit revenue  challenge within the business. A good non-fuel unit cost performance, down 4.5%.

texts.speaker: William M. Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: We'll get significant reductions in overheads and efficiency and some improvement in asset turn. But this is a  really positive development. It will allow Iberia to create an efficient short and medium haul fleeter airline into the  long haul at Madrid. It's not the only challenge that Iberia faces. We do continue to have a unit revenue challenge  in the face of rapidly increasing oil prices. But this is part of the structural change that we're embarking on within  Iberia.

texts.speaker: William M. Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Clearly, the ongoing developments in the Eurozone are a major factor, not just in the demand within the  Eurozone, but it clearly impacts on demand in the U.K. as well. But it's having a particularly significant impact on  our Spanish network. And Enrique is taking you through the situation with regard to fuel. We faced a big  challenge in 2011 and equally big challenge in 2012, but geared more in the first half as you've seen about 25%  increase in first half, 16% increase in the second half, but fuel will a feature of the industry in 2012. It will help to  drive further discipline. We're already seeing that certainly in the cargo side of the business.

texts.speaker: William M. Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: As Enrique said, cargo suffering from overcapacity, but we've seen a number of major cargo operators announce  big capacity reductions in their freighter capacity. So I think the current high price of oil will be a factor in  imposing ongoing discipline on the industry in 2012.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.text: And what's behind this big swing? So of course, lots of things. texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And then you have on the ex -fuel, the manageable cost base, ex-fuel unit cost coming down significantly to 2.7 %. texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Second one, of course, is fuel and non-fuel costs. Fuel costs have been, this quarter, a tailwind. So, accounting for  nearly €30 million out of €177 million. It's about the price element after hedge and also the currency element has  been helpful.

texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: The advantage that we have is we do not have any freighters. So we had a wet-lease freighter operation within IAG  Cargo which we have terminated. It will terminate in the end of April. So it's  going to be bringing something in the range of 5% reduction on a unit basis, another lever, another source of  improvement.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director

But the important message is,  as Enrique has just given you, we will continue to drive down our ex-fuel unit cost through 2015. We have a clear  path that will enable us to achieve that reduction in ex-fuel unit cost.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So the improvement in performance in 2015 is not down to the oil price; it's down to all parts of the business  continuing to do what they have achieved in 2014. So it's not going to be a revenue story. As Enrique said,  probably on a constant currency basis our unit revenue may decline slightly in 2015, where our ex-fuel unit costs  on a constant currency basis will continue to show a very healthy improvement in performance, added to the  improvement in the unit fuel cost performance.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, again, the message today is that what we are seeing is a underlying non-fuel unit cost that we want to keep  coming lower on a year-to-year basis and that we have done so. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Just a very quick back-of-the-envelope calculation; so there's going to be, on these terms, a fuel bill increase in  the range of €400 million, €450 million per year, out of which more than half is having to do with capacity  increase. The impact for  the year is comparable to 0.7% in terms of unit cost.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Now, our strong platform also is built on a clear focus on cost efficiency and since we created IAG in 2011, you  can see the chart here the reference base is 2010 in constant currency terms. texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And in non-fuel unit costs, again, a significant improvement. Of course, we don't need to refer again to employee  unit cost reductions, which is, at the end of the day, the result of all these significant plans and measures that we  have been completing and agreeing earlier in the year. It has to do with project Athens. It has to do with Plan de  Futuro II. It has to do with pension fund agreements, et cetera, et cetera. And basically improvements in  productivity you will see in our figures when you read them in the sale, significant improvements in terms of  productivity which will be lasting at least for the first quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So, finally, talking about plan on fuel costs, you see a positive one. So this positive is fully related to non-ASK  supplier cost. So basically the supplies, the contracts, the services that we need to fulfill this business related to  [indiscernible] (00:27:48) third-party and will show as positive. If we strip that one out, this would be a negative  figure. And by the way, when we do the right approach, instead of 0.5%, we get to a minus 3.8%, which is easy to  check with the figure. Because, remember, the only thing that we're doing there is a very simplistic correction  where we say let's take away as a negative cost the increase in other revenues that we have achieved. Those  numbers, you can make it. Then you get to the minus 3.8%.

texts.speaker: Enrique Dupuy de Lôme Chávarri
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So this is fuel; fuel for next year. And again, we are facing a period of quarters and a row of quarters where we  are going to be seeing increased unit fuel cost for the group. We have made this exercise at $620 per metric ton  of kerosene and $1.14 per euro. Of course, these figures are changing every day. So one day, we find this is a  $650. The other day, we find this as a $630. I think it's basically a consistent figure with how the market is  evolving, although there is a high level of volatility. This pattern of assumptions is consistent with a growth in  terms of fuel unit cost for next year in the range of 10%, 11-ish percent, which is slightly lower than the one that  we have seen this year and the one that we have been able to manage efficiently.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: To remind you of the guidance for the year. We're saying that, at current fuel prices and exchange rates, we  expect our 2019 operating profit before exceptional items on a like-for-like, so excluding the impacts of IFRS 16  that Enrique has talked about, to be in line with the €3.23 billion that we reported in 2018. Passenger unit revenue  is expected to improve at constant currency, and non-fuel unit costs expected to be flat at constant currency.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: Our cost performance, there's more that we can do and more that we will do. We continue to have this longer  term target to achieve a 1% reduction in our non-fuel unit costs on an annual basis. We've achieved 11.1% so far  to 2018. That's been through structured programs in each of the airlines. There are structured programs in each  of the airlines that will continue through 2019 and beyond.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And so, we remain confident that this is an appropriate target of 1% reduction in non-fuel unit costs. It's not going  to be 1% every year, and we said that on a number of occasions, but we do see opportunities to further improve  on our cost performance. And we will be pursuing those initiatives with vigor as we progress through the year. So  a lot more to come.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: I've told about ATC disruption, and it is a feature of the business now. But I do expect – while 2019 won't show an  improvement on 2018, I don't expect it to deteriorate. But I do expect that this can be addressed going forward  because some of the issues relating to this disruption are within the control of the air traffic control providers. And  it's principally related to a mismatch between their capacity as they believed was required based on the  assumptions that some of these ATC units had for growth, which they got wrong. So they need additional  manpower. That takes time. Those recruitment processes have been put in place, and we will see some of these  structural issues addressed in 2020 and beyond.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: So I think what you can see from that is that Vueling fundamentally is a very well-run company, a very strong  operational performance in its own right, but has been impacted very significantly by the ATC environment both at  Barcelona and at Europe. So we have no concerns about the Vueling performance, as they can control it, but  clearly we are concerned about the ATC environment which is impacting on their performance.

texts.speaker: William Matthew Walsh
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, International Consolidated Airlines Group SA
texts.text: And I don't need to remind you, but just to say is we are a Spanish company. We have long-established AOCs in  France, Ireland, Spain and the UK; substantive business in these countries. We employ, in total, over 71,000  people. It's 65,000 full-time equivalent, but it's 71,000 people employed across the group. So as I say, we remain  confident that there will be a comprehensive air transport agreement as stated in the political declaration and that  our operating companies will comply with the rules.

file: IBE - Business Update Call 8June2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Jun-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Pedro Azagra Blázquez
texts.profession: Chief Development Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This becomes the leading Brazilian utility both in terms of numbers of customers of points of supply but also  distributed energy. This number of points of supply reached present almost 13.5 million and more than 54,000  gigawatt hours of distributed energy in 2016.

texts.speaker: Pedro Azagra Blázquez
texts.profession: Chief Development Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Just as a reference is the top company in Brazil by number of points of supply and also is the second company in  Brazil in terms of distributed energy. We think it's nice to give a feeling of this 13.4 million points of supply. It's  serving a population of around 43 million people. This is, as you can see, comparable with Spain that we are  covering 18 million.

texts.speaker: Pedro Azagra Blázquez
texts.profession: Chief Development Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The concession area in the square kilometers is 836,000, as comparing to Spain with 190,000. And as you can  see, the distribution networks from a kilometers point of view is almost 600,000; and in Spain, we have no more  than 268,000. This is in addition to an existing capacity of 3,500 megawatts of both wind and hydro and slightly  above 500 megawatts of combined cycle.

texts.speaker: Pedro Azagra Blázquez
texts.profession: Chief Development Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the next page, Neoenergia, the new company, we have combined businesses mix of approximately 76% of  networks, 19% of contracted generation, and 5% of renewable. On the regulated side, the EBITDA for 2016  Coelba is the biggest distribution company with 42%. Then, Elektro is with almost 30%, and Cosern and Celpe  both we have between 12% and 16% contribution in this type of business.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And the company is focused on precisely the areas in which the group is putting more emphasis now in the  regulated and renewables activity and in a growth market that will allow us to continue showing growth in our  numbers.

texts.speaker: Company Representative

texts.text: In these first 3 months of the year, IBERDROLA has obtained a gross operating profit of €2,178  million with a growth of 11.6% and a net profit of €922 million. And  this since our business portfolio and geography enables us to stay on the path of sustainable  growth and focus on the various areas, depending on the circumstances.

texts.text: And now I would like to briefly cover the regulatory situation for the renewable energy sector in  Spain. That is seven times more than the objective set for 2010.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: This situation is a result of the existing remuneration for each technology. Wind power in Spain has  a tariff of around €77 per megawatt hour, which is much lower than that in the rest of European  countries, whose average remuneration is around €102 per megawatt. However, in the case of  photovoltaic energy, our country which has high load factors, much higher than in Germany, for  example, has a tariff of €466 per megawatt hour for around 3,500 megawatts, according to Decree  661, much higher than countries in our area. As a result, there’s a major difference between the  contribution of energy and the contribution to production costs of the various technologies.

texts.text: In 2009, wind power produced 14% of the total energy generated in Spain, representing 16% of the  total production cost, while solar energies contributed only 2% of the energy and also cost 16% of  the cost of supply. If we do not want to substantially increase the  price of electricity, it is necessary to defer the growth of thermosolar and photovoltaic energy, which  contribute little energy and represent a very high cost.

texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: Now I would like to give you some details regarding the evolution of EBITDA in each of the Group’s  businesses but starting off with the deregulated business in Spain that includes generation,  commercial and non-regulated gas. And there’s been 10% reduction in net operating expenses which tries  to soften the drop in gross margin.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: The EBITDA of the Group grew 7.8% and now stands at €1,536 million, which is somewhat below  the growth we’ve registered at the level of EBITDA after a 22% increase in the chapter on  amortizations and provisions, with a total of 642 million. Amortizations are 604 million after growing  90 million due to the increase in renewables with higher installed power, and in Scottish Power with  the appreciation of the pound and more assets under exploitation in the networks area. But  environmental investments in Spain have increased this item in the Spanish liberalized or the  regulated business. Provisions have been increased 25 million and now stand at 38 in a quarter  that was unfavorable compared to 2009, in which there was some reversals.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán, Chairman  Thank you very much, Pepe. I think that results we are presenting show the capacity of the  IBERDROLA business portfolio to obtain growth in any macroeconomic and business scenario. The  investments made in recent years have enabled us to increase our presence in markets such as  the U.S. or British market, maintaining our stakes in Mexico and Brazil and reducing the weight of  the traditional business in Spain, which currently represents only one-third of the Group’s gross  operating profits. The contribution to the results of the regulated and renewable businesses stays  around 60%, therefore, providing a high predictability to the accounts.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: This solid position has enabled us to obtain in this first quarter of 2010 an increase in results of  11.6% on an operating level and 16% on a level of net profits. In the first 3 months of the year, the  Group also increased its production by 15.4%, thanks to the contribution of technologies with a  reduced variable cost and emission-free, such as hydraulic and wind power technologies.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: All the countries in which IBERDROLA is present have contributed to this increase with the  exception of the UK, which has been affected by a more timid development in demand and the  shutdown of the coal power station at Longannet, which is again operational. The increase of 28%  in production in Spain is linked to the good status of the wind power business in the U.S. country  where generated energy has increased by 23%, and activities in Latin America where energy  production has increased by 7%. In other countries, renewables has increased its production by  over 40%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning. We’re going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The
texts.text: In liberalized businesses, we continue to expect a positive development in Spain, thanks on the one  hand to the recovery in demand and the historic level of hydraulic reserves, 9,000 gigawatt hours,  45% more than last year. In the UK, the situation will be more complex, particularly because of the  pressures on generation margins and retail prices. As I said, we will maintain our focus on  operating efficiency in all businesses, and especially in the United States where the measures  launched from the beginning of the year are already being fruitful. The financial position of the  Group will continue to improve, thanks to the securitization of the tariff deficit and investment  controls, which will be in line with the cash flow we generate.

file: IBE - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 5May2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: A decisive contribution has been made by our increased capacity to generate clean energy, where  Iberdrola has been a pioneer. And remember, few years ago, one of our colleagues said that the  wind never blew when you needed it, so it wasn’t worthwhile investing in this sector. But we have  carried out first of all hydroelectric developments and then wind power, a technology where we are  world leaders.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The application of this business model has made Iberdrola a great Group, whose value is much  greater than the sum of its parts. It’s a global Group, with sufficient critical mass to undertake new  projects for profitable growth, such as the recent acquisition of Elektro in Brazil or the development  of ocean wind energy that we are starting in the U.K., access to favorable conditions in our  acquisitions from suppliers, the diversification of operating and regulatory risks, the possibility of  maximizing efficiency and exchanging best practices, which is reflected in the operating expenses  of the Group, as we saw earlier.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, this growth, together with the growth of Renovables, whose gross margin has grown 5%,  because there’s been 11% growth in wind power, that has been partially counteracted by the  contribution made by the Gas business in the United States, have made it possible to compensate  the slump in the Liberalized business. And this has also managed to cover the reduction of margins  in the U.K. And last year, in Spain, we had a record year, in terms of wind power and electricity.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The savings, we also have savings in staff. We have had a 5% improvement as well as in the  external services that have dropped by more than 18% and we now have a single corporation and  we have an organization that is based on credible business areas. The Grid business has also  benefited from the efficiency improvements obtained in the United States where operating  expenses have dropped another 40% and there has been also a cost reduction in Spain.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have to recall that the results of the first quarter of 2010 still included the costs corresponding to  the Connecticut gas companies. As regards the Liberalized business, the net operating expenses  are, have reduced 2% thanks to the reductions obtained in the U.K. and Mexico and thanks to the  flat behavior of Spain.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And finally, Iberdrola Renovables has improved its operating cost ratio per installed megawatt for  another quarter. The improvement of the gross margin together with costs savings have made it  possible to achieve a 4.4% increase in EBITDA that now stands at €2.273 billion. And the grid  activity is working very well thanks to improvements in the gross margins and thanks to  improvements in efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA of the Regulated business in Spain grew by 35.4% to almost €400 million, thanks to  the increase in the gross margin of 15.8%, and the major improvement in net operating expenses.  The growth in gross margin is a result of the recognized income for the Regulated business. And  we have to remember that during the first month of 2010 a provisional remuneration was included  in the books which was lower than was finally approved in the electricity access tariffs based on the  reference grid model.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The U.S. Regulated business provides an EBITDA of €225 million under the IFRS regulations,  which represents an increase of 11.1%. This positive performance has been achieved in spite of  the sale of the Connecticut business, which represented €43 million less in EBITDA. The  improvement in business operations, especially in relation to costs, the increase in tariffs because  of the new rate case and the new main line, have offset this effect during this quarter, as well as the  exclusion of the operating expenses from the gas companies that were sold.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA, which dropped 54% because of lower margins and sales in spite of the fact that the  area improved expenses by 2.3%. Starting with the Liberalized business in Spain there was a  reduction in the ordinary regime production basically because of a drop of – the reduction in  hydraulic production. However, 82% of the Group reduction in Spain, or the ordinary regime in  Spain continues to be emission free.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 The net operating expenses only grew 1.6%, much lower than the growth in the basic margin. An  increase in expenses linked to higher activities is offset by the efficiency measures. The 64 TWh  production estimated for 2011 have been sold at a price of more than €56 per MWh. And 26 TWh  have already been sold for 2012 over €60 per MWh.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And the Spanish forward is still 9% lower than the European average, in line with recent years. And  the hydraulic reserves continue at maximum points close to 80%, 8,700 GWh.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And in fact in the last two years the levies in this business have practically doubled from €77 million  to €135 million. And as the Chairman said, this is due to several factors, the nuclear levy which has  had a major increase, the new levies related to the financing for energy saving and efficiency plans,  and the new generator levy, the social bonus and the eco-tax in [indiscernible], which we have  appealed again.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA in the Liberalized business in the U.K. dropped by 54.2% to €148 million. This  negative performance is basically due to a reduction of 39% in basic margin in an environment of  less production, an 11% drop globally, 4% in electricity and 12% in gas and higher procurement  costs that have not been offset by an equivalent increase in the electricity sales price.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The net operating expenses improved by 6.8%, thanks to the reduction in external services and  maintenance costs. We estimate that during 2011 there will be a progressive recovery in the  margins, both for electricity and gas. We also have to highlight that the forward curves are pointing  to possible tariff increases during 2011 to compensate the increase in the price of fuel.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We must also say that this is an especially unfavorable quarter from the comparative point of view  since the first quarter of 2010 showed especially positive results in the area of retail gas because of  the cold temperature recording during that winter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Excluding both effects the underlying operations for the business improved by 9%, thanks to the  improvement in the heat rate margin and power station availability. The drop of 1.4% in EBITDA  improved the gross margin from minus 2.2%, thanks to a 5.7% reduction in net operating expenses  because of greater efficiencies in the selling of Guatemala.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: [Foreign Language] The EBITDA of the pure renewable business grew 9.3% and now stands at  €428.3 million. Installed capacity grew 13.6% and operating capacity 6.6% and now stands at  12,584 megawatts and production 12.1%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The load factor dropped from 29.4% to 28.3%, fundamentally because of Spain because the first  quarter of 2010 was exceptional in the United States; it went up 27% to 31% and in the U.K, 21% to  23%. And wind power in this country is still abnormally low for the second year running. And the  prices have reached €71.6 per MWh, which is slightly below those of the same period of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In addition, control efforts have been carried out for costs and OpEx per operating megawatt have  improved by 1.5%. And this good evolution of the Renewables business compares with the weak  contribution of the Gas business with only €24 billion. It has been affected by the weakness of gas  prices in the United States, which have placed the total EBITDA of the company at €453 billion with  a growth of 2.6%.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA of other businesses from engineering and non-energy businesses have grown 38.6%  and now stand at €55.6 million. The improvement in engineering margins in this quarter covers the  weakness of the rest of the businesses that encompass real estate and other industrial shares, and  also because there has been a big cost contention effort.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Iberdrola is a company over 100 years old that has been transformed very significantly in the last  10 years while respecting is origins. And today it’s a great group focused on the basic business, a  world leader in the clean energy and concentrated on operating and financial efficiency. A company  that creates values for its shareholders; they have benefited from a total return of 158% in the last  10 years, and also for all those stakeholders with which we interact.

file: IBE - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 10May2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the Regulated Business, there has been a drop of 15%, and I'm talking about Spain because of the impact of  these regulatory measures approved by the Spanish Government on March 30. In Renewables, EBITDA is Spain  has dropped 10% as a consequence fundamentally of a drop of 9.4% in output due to the lower wind from January  to March. However, thanks to the increase of 54% in wind production since the beginning of April, this trend has  been turned around and the accumulated growth is currently 7.1%. In other words, in one month we have offset  the drop in output in the previous quarter; and in fact we have increased the output. The Liberalised Business has  a flat performance with a drop in production of 21.2%, mainly hydro, offset by the positive effect of a Supreme  Court ruling, which exempts generating companies from financing certain items and declares Iberdrola's right to  the reimbursement of the amounts paid out so far for this concept.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And now I will briefly focus on the regulatory situation of the sector in Spain where I think the greatest concern in  the markets currently exist. Firstly, I would like to highlight, as I said at the last meeting – or as José Luis San  Pedro also mentioned, the traditional energy mix in Spain is very competitive. Thanks to this, the prices of  electricity in the pool in recent years have been 10% lower than the European average, and I want to repeat this  and reiterate it. Also – and it was also said then, the distribution activity in Spain receives a remuneration, which  before bringing in the recently announced regulatory measures was also 10% lower than the average in the main  European countries.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In spite of this the average tariff that the residential consumer paid in Spain is higher than that European average,  as indicated in the National Reform Programme for 2012 recently approved by the government two weeks ago.  This is a result: "Fundamentally to the decisions on energy policies approved through the last decade, which have  contributed to the fact that close to 50% of the final tariff corresponds to costs that are unrelated to the power  supply, and in particular are associated to the development of very costly energy – Renewable Energy, mainly  solar technologies. And this means that in Spain the cost per megawatt-hour is the highest in Europe according to  the European energy regulators." This is what has created the tariff deficit problem in Spain, an inherited problem  and the current government has already taken major steps to correct it. In 2012, €3.3 billion was securitized in the  tariff deficit. €7 billion are still pending for which there is a transfer commitment and we are requesting the  ministry to speed up the securitization. In February, the government approved Royal Decree 1/2012 to  provisionally suspend the procedures for the previous signing of the remuneration and the economic incentives  for the new renewable and cogeneration facilities. Additionally, in March the government approved an average  increase in access tariffs of 6.3%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: However, we believe that some of the measures are not going in the right direction. In Royal Decree 13/2012,  unrelated to the generation deficit, that is the distribution activity, and there's no economic model to justify it.  And the methodology to calculate the remuneration for the distribution activity was guaranteed under Royal  Decree 222/2008, which established a general framework for the period 2009, 2012. This certain measure  modifies remuneration conditions that had already been established until December 31, 2012. And this has caused  alarm on the financial markets, and this does not help the value of the companies in the sector, neither do they  help the rating of the Kingdom of Spain. However, I am convinced that this measure, which was taken urgently,  will be completed with others that will help tackle the current structural deficit problem and restore confidence in  our energy model. Measures such as stopping the construction of the most – costly renewable facilities including  the pre-assigned facilities whose remuneration has grown exponentially in recent years; increasing the cost of the  system; remunerating with non-discriminatory criteria for all the Regulated activities to reduce the current  disparity; and take measures to provide incentives to energy efficiency and which have disappeared, the so-called  progressive tariffs to further liberalize the market; reducing the use of regulated, integrated tariffs; eliminating  items from the tariff that should not be paid for only by the consumer; sharing Renewable cost with Other sectors,  as they have already done in Italy; and while the problem persists to fund future deficits between all the power  agents. In our opinion, the start-up of these measures will bring about predictable and reasonable tariffs.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Regulated Business in the U.K. has reached an EBITDA of €213 million with an increase of 4.8%. That has –  is linked to high investments. Throughout the fiscal year the gross margin will grow quicker until it reaches  something like 4% to 5% in agreement with the higher remuneration base after the investment is made. In  addition, control measures for costs have reduced net operating expenses by 13.2%. The Regulated Business of the  United States has provided an EBITDA of €213 million according to the IFRS regulation, which represents a drop  of 5.1% However, the underlying evolution of the business has been positive as regards the gross margin with a  growth of 5.3%, in spite of the adjustments related to the IFRS regulations that are related to the cost of fuel that  have penalized the greater revenues after applying the new rates and the positive effect with the rate of exchange,  but there are also some time effects and climatological effects that have reduced the revenues reported from first  quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses have grown by 29% as a consequence of the rate of exchange, because of the more intense  maintenance work carried out after the storms we had in the last quarter of 2011. And we've also carried out some  more maintenance work with the good weather in the United States. EBITDA in Brazil has grown 105% and now  has reached €288.9 million, with Elektro included in the perimeter of which represents another €120 million  more. The 4% growth in electrical demand and positive resettlements and the adjustments of rates payable since  April 2011 that we reported in the quarter and the greater unitary margin are the rest of the factors that have  proved – that have produced this growth. The impact of the rate of exchange is negative.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As regards to the Liberalised Business in Spain, firstly, the introduction of the Ordinary Regime has been reduced  by 31% because of the drop of 63% in hydraulic production that had been partially compensated by a 14% increase  in nuclear production because we've had the driest winter of the last decade. Electrical demand dropped a little  bit, 0.9%, in the quarter. All of this has been partially covered with better prices in – well, something like €63, and  for 2012 we have 65 terawatt hours sold at a price about €60 per megawatt hour. The basic margin has dropped  11.9%, although the strong reduction of the item connected to levies as a consequence of the ruling of the High  Court, which is €118 million, compensates this drop in the basic margin. There's also a negative effect of €50  million related to settlements that were included in books in 2011 without equivalents in 2012, which partially  compensates this effect of the reduction in levies.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally EBITDA stands at €541 million, showing that there's a stable evolution. And the basic margin of the  Liberalised Business in the U.K. reaches €388.7 million, because the margins of the business have recovered from  the minimum figures of 2011 because of the improvement in procurement cost, because the contracts – the core  contracts signed in 2008 at very high prices has come to an end and also because there have been better sales  prices. And this improvement fully compensates the decline in gas sales, 80% – 8% and electricity 3% in this  quarter. Net operating expenses now stand at €148.6 million because of non-recurrent effect, that effect leading to  annual comparison. In addition, the expenses of 2012 also include some staff expenses that are non-recurrent. In  this matter, the EBITDA of the business has partially recovered and now stands at €212 million. However, this  EBITDA figure is still far below the levels prior to 2011 with margins over sales that are lower than the levels that  have been taken onboard by Ofcom.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The EBITDA has grown up to €292 million and the evolution of the business is positive as regards to gross margin  with a greater heat rate with more availability and with increases of capability of the plants in spite of some  shutdowns. And the expenses related to these shutdowns in France and two maintenance costs have penalized net  operating expenses and have slowed down the evolution of the business as far as EBITDA is concerned. And the  EBITDA in our Renewables business has grown 2.8% and now stands at €441 million because the good quarter of  international business served to compensate the poor quarter in Spain, and as the President pointed out,  production dropped 7% because of the adverse weather conditions in the country, which is also in line with what  we saw as regards to the Liberalised business.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the whole production has grown 13%, thanks to the production figures of the United States, which has 27%;  the U.K. 58%; and the rest of the world with 20%, because the best wind conditions and the greater installed  capability have made the load factor stand at a figure of 29.6%. The greater weight in the United States means that  the average prices have dropped 3.6% to €69 per megawatt hour because those wind farms that are used in France  that do not have PTCs are being commissioned. Those – because they are lower merchant prices in the United  States, and as you know, we have part of the production there. Operating capacity has grown 6.5% and now stands  at 13,398 megawatts and installed capacity is something like 14,000 megawatts. Expenses have grown 6.2%, in  line with an increase in our operating capacity.

file: IBE - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 24April2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The first quarter of the year has been marked by operational performance of our businesses as the gross margin  evolution shows with a 5.5% increase, driven by renewables and generation and supply. Additionally, the  efficiency measures we are implementing have allowed us to reduce our net operating expenses to gross margin  ratio by 4.6%. Net debt has been reduced by €2 billion, helping us to improve our financial ratios and the strength  of our balance sheet.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As I just said, gross margin has rise 5.5% to almost €3.6 billion, thanks to the good operational performance of our  businesses, in particular renewables and generation and supply. We compensate the decline in networks in Brazil.  All in all, gross margin coming from the regulated business increased by 1.6%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The strong performance of renewables with 20.1% rise in the period is due to 70% increase in output, particularly  wind production in Spain. It has been grown by more than 52%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the generation and supply businesses, gross margin has increased 11.1%, thanks to our large customer base in  UK and the growth in hydro production. On the other hand, gross margin in networks has decreased by 5.8%,  negatively impacted by two main aspects in Brazil – the tariff review in Elektro, which effect is being recorded  from August 2012 onwards and the temporary extra charges on electricity as a consequence of the growth in the  country that I will explain as well later on.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Some of these factors will be recovered or compensated along the following months. This is the case of temporary  revision of costs on electricity that our distribution companies are reviewing in Brazil, with a negative impact of  €68 million to be recovered through the annual tariff review.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Also, as a result of a more ambitious objectives including the Energy Efficiency Program introduced in United  Kingdom, ECO, expenses recorded in the first three months of 2013 are €42 million higher than those accounted  in the same period of previous year under the CERT/CESP programs, whose impact was mainly booked on the  second half of 2012.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Generation and Supply, largest hydro production reserves as well as increasing customer base in UK, have  contributed to partially compensate new fiscal measures introduced in Spain with €96 million impact on EBITDA  that should be added to the effect of the already mentioned efficiency program in United Kingdom. Additionally,  two other factors distort the comparison with previous year: the cancellation of CO2 allowances in 2013 with an  impact of €41 million and the effect of several judicial decisions, which despite being positive in 2013 to €52  million are lower than those in previous year of €100 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, in renewables, EBITDA has grown 20.8%, driven by very good wind results and efficiency improvement.  Wind production has increased by 17 % to 9.8 terawatt hours in spite of divestment of asset in non-core countries,  while the net operating expenses to average operating capacity ratio has been reduced by 5.9%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: It's worth to mention the renewable result has been obtained despite the new fiscal measure introduced in Spain  by Law 15/2012 which has had a negative impact of €26 million in the challenge on the Spain special  remuneration approved by Royal Decree-Law 2/2013.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I would like to stress, the levies has increased in the period 62% once eliminated the effect of the judicial decision  in 2013 and 2012, offsetting the operational improvement of the company. In fact, in this first quarter of the year,  the amount paid in levies is, for the first time, similar to the total group net operating expenses. This means that  costs associated to personnel required to manage and operate 46,000 megawatts, more than 1 million kilometers  of distribution lines, plus additional 36,000 kilometers of transmission line, 4,000 primary substation and 6,000  power transformer, and 1.3 million secondary substation and around 350 wind farms are lower than those by far  the amount the company has to pay in fiscal charges excluding corporate income tax. This is particularly relevant  in Spain and United Kingdom where levies are more than 30% above the net personnel expenses.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses increased only 0.8%, including €21 million of a positive FX impact. Efficiency measures  and charges taken in 2012 explain the 3.8% reduction in net personnel expenses.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Effects that have been partially compensated by a €19 million positive impact of indemnities received by the US  networks linked to the commissioning of nuclear plants.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies more than doubled to €410 million that the group has paid in this quarter. The €224 million increase  comes from Spain with €180 million, of which €122 million, €96 million in the ordinary regime and €26 million  in renewables, are due to the 7% generation tax, the hydrocarbon and the nuclear tax.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: UK at €42 million due to higher levies linked to the new energy efficiency programs for 2013 versus 2012. The  levies this year are linearly accounted, while in 2012, impacts were mainly during the second half of the year. As a  consequence, UK levies comparison will strongly improve in the second half of the year. Additionally, there are  several taxes and levies that Iberdrola has appealed to the courts and there are still pending decisions that  hopefully will impact positively our P&L in this or next years.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As a consequence, reported EBITDA decreased 3.7%, including a €38 million of negative FX impact. The 20%  growth in renewables is compensated by a 6.1% fall in networks due to the Brazil performance and a 9.5%  decrease in generation and supply due to the rising taxes. Renewables and regulated business contribute 72% of  the total EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: New levies and now CO2 allowances with a total negative impact of €135 million have offset, as mentioned, the  operating improvements.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the gross margin in Spain, the output has been 6.6% lower, mainly due to a 72% lower thermal and a  14% lower nuclear production, compensated by higher margins related to extraordinary hydro conditions, an  increase of 90% that lowers our cost base.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, the lower output basically linked to the Cockenzie closure and lower production of CCGTs has been also  compensated by higher sales due to the 7.3% increase in customers, cold weather and the tariff increase driven by  the rise on non-energy costs. As I mentioned before, 2013 is the first year with no free CO2 allocations that in Q1  amount – of 2012 amounted €40.6 million; in Spain, €12 million; and in the UK, €29 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding levies, as I mentioned before, in Spain, new taxes and levies on generation have impacted €96 million  on the negative side. And there is also an unfavorable €48 million comparable with 2012. And in the UK, there is a  €42 million higher levies linked to the 2013 energy efficiencies programs versus 2012.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewable EBITDA rose by 21%, up to €533 million, as record operating performance is able, this time, to  compensate the increasing levies and the regulatory measures, fixing our regulated price 5.3% below last year, and  the reduction of the price update to zero. By geography, Spain represents 54% of EBITDA; United States, 20%;  UK, 13%; and the rest of the world, 12%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Operating capacity increases 4.6% to 14,000 megawatts and a 3.9 percentile points higher average load factor to  33.5%, results in a 17% higher output. In Spain, record wind resources compensates lower levels in the UK and the  US. This is added to an increase of a 4.5% in the average price to €71 per megawatt hour due to a lower  contribution of the US and despite this 5.3% reduction in prices in Spain due to the new fixed tariff.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The 0.4% decrease in provisions includes an €8 million write-off linked to renewable canceled projects,  compensated by the absence of non-recurrent provisions in Brazil related to bad debts in 2012 that were €40  million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding divestments, French wind farms, €222 million, and Medgaz divestment, €146 million, funds are  expected to be collected during this quarter. Funds from Polish wind farms, €256 million, are expected to be  collected in Q3 2013.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you, Pepe. To conclude, I would like to recall that in this first quarter, year 2013, has been affected by  several typical factors. We have impacted the company result distorting the comparison with the previous years.  Although our operational performance has been positive boosted by renewables and generation and supply  businesses, the 5.5% increase in gross margin and improvement on efficiency have been absorbed by those  impacts leading to a 3.3% drop in EBITDA and 4.9% decrease in recurring net profit.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So these impacts are expected to be recovered along this in the following months. This is the case of temporary  revision in energy charges incurred in Brazil, the new efficiency program, ECO, and the corporation tax rate in  United Kingdom. Discounting these aspects, EBITDA will have been similar to that obtained in first quarter 2012  and net profit will have grown by almost 2%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The results obtained during these three months allow us to face the rest of the year with confidence. And despite  the significant challenges for our businesses, we are on track to achieve the 2012 to 2014 outlook. We have the  tools to obtain our objectives. Our large customer base, particularly United Kingdom, is improving our revenues.  The company production means is benefiting for the optimal wind and hydro condition this year, with a direct  impact on procurement costs.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Efficiency measures already implemented will keep paying off. The €2 billion divestment plan is progressing as  planned. Investments have been progressing to the generational cash flows in all businesses. And the tariff deficit  securitization process will be finally completed when the €4.1 billion of 2012 excess deficit are securitized  according to Royal Decree Law 29/2012 in 2013 tariff order.

file: IBE - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 30April2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The first quarter of the year has been marked by the good operational performance in all our businesses with the  gross margin up 1% to €3.4 billion despite the negative impact of regulatory measures in Spain. Moreover, the  efficiency has been improved by 1% due to re-pricing of all net operating expenses. We have also advanced in the  fulfillment of investment plan with the disposal amounting to more than €300 million of our stake in EDP and  Itapebí, the hydroelectric plant in Brazil which is now owned through our subsidiary Neoenergia.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As I just mentioned, gross margins has risen 1% to almost €3.4 billion. Thanks to the good result obtained by the  gas businesses, the increasing production in a more efficient generation mix. They have offset lower prices and  significant remuneration cost to distribution activity and to renewables in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the other hand, Generation and Supply had a very positive evolution, with EBITDA up 24.3%, due to better  result of the gas businesses, higher production and a more efficient generation mix, offsetting lower prices in  Spain, as I mentioned before.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, the Renewable businesses had heavily impacted by regulatory measures in Spain, where in spite of  achieving a record production, EBITDA has fallen 63% versus 2013 due to remuneration cuts and very low pool  prices. However, our geographical diversification has allowed us to mitigate this effect, with international EBITDA  growing 18% and reducing the total renewable business decrease to only 27.1%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: First quarter results include €260 million of negative impact due to the Spanish regulatory measures announced  in July 2013 that were not included in Q1 of 2013. 71% corresponds to renewables with €185 million, €20 million  to lower capacity payments, $19 million to the social bonus accounted at the EBITDA level, €8 million to co- generation, and €28 million to distribution that will be adjusted during the year, will converge during the year  with 2013 distribution results.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The full-year incremental regulatory impact at gross margin is estimated at €380 million. Adding the €276 million  already accounted for in 2013, the estimated full 2014 impact will be around €650 million mainly due to  renewables. Nevertheless, as mentioned in the Investor Day, a standard year should be affected by around €500  million, and I will try to explain why in the next slide.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The higher wind and hydro in the first quarter have led to very low spot prices during the period and affected very  negatively the renewable business especially compared with Q1 2013. However, this scenario should not be  extrapolated going forward. I would like to highlight that in Q1, Iberdrola has accounted for the premiums of  those wind farms that are entitled to receive it, calculating a 7.5% return to be collected in 2017.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: When we knew about the draft, it was too late. And half of our renewable production have to take spot prices,  which have been very low in the quarter due to the mentioned hydro and wind conditions. As the spot prices  recover and Iberdrola hedges this production, the impact will be mitigated through the year. But still, we expect a  negative impact of €121 million for the full year. So our estimate for the whole 2014 is minus €384 million in  renewables. While for a standard year should be €230 million, as it assumes that the wind farms will sell their  energy at the price of €42 megawatt hour, as forecasted by the Ministry.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies grew by 10% to €445 million. In Spain, taxes amounted to €286 million, €50 million more than last year,  including €19 million due to the social bonus. Spain represents 64% of total taxes. Levies paid in the UK were  lower by €11 million. The EBITDA remains almost flat at €2,126 million, including €40 million negative FX  impact. The impact derived from the regulatory measures like the reduction of renewable and Networks EBITDA  both have been compensated for by the liberalized business growth.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Brazil, EBITDA grows 45%, as a consequence of a 14.4% increase in gross margin, as a result of the 8.9%  increase in demand, 9% higher tariffs, and a higher compensation from the government, €161 million more than  in Q1 2013 covering the drought impact. This coverage was not in place in Q1 2013, although it was later  established. The exchange rate fall to 22% reduces EBITDA by €10.4 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation and supply EBITDA grew 24% to €950 million, thanks to higher output and better generation mix in  Spain, and higher contribution of the gas business both in Spain and in the U.S. which benefited from the weather  conditions and prices in North America, together with the 3% improvement in net operating expenses have offset  lower demand in Spain and in the UK and the 12% increase in levies.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA grew 23% with a 17% increase in gross margin due to the 31% higher output after an 87%  increase in hydro and a 3% increase in nuclear, more than compensated the 63% lower thermal. As a consequence,  margins have increased due to the lower cost associated to a better production mix despite lower prices and  average.
