The gas business includes a €43 million positive one-off in addition to the 17.4% gross margin growth.  Net operating expenses improved 3.9% more than compensating the 22% increase in levies.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA grew 7.8%. The exchange rate at €4.8 million. Gross margin growth 1.4% with a 15.8%  improvement in wholesale and generation with better volumes and plant availability and despite the impact of the  carbon tax. This is partially offset by a 1.5% drop in retail gross margin with lower volumes in a milder weather.  Net operating expenses grew 1.3% and levies decreased 15%, thanks to the ECO program extension to Mach 2017.  In the U.S., gas business EBITDA is €62 million higher benefiting from the weather conditions. Renewable  EBITDA fell 27% to €371 million due to a 63% decrease in the Spanish EBITDA affected by the remuneration cost  of the Spanish regulatory measures and the low spot prices as explained, despite the strong load factors.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thanks to the geographical diversification of the business, the positive contribution of the UK, the U.S. and Latin  America partially compensated the fall in Spain. Gross margin falls 22%. Net operating expenses improved 1.9%  and there is a 24% decrease in levies due to lower prices in Spain. It is worth mentioning that the renewables net  profit in Spain, as the Chairman mentioned, falls to €13 million or a 91% decrease in the quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The operating capacity decreased 1.1% to 13,321 megawatts, following the disposal of the Polish wind farms. The  average load factor improved 1.3 percentage points to 35%, meaning an increase in production of 3.5%. The  weighted-average price drops 27% to €51/megawatt hour after a 55% decrease in Spain. Regarding efficiency,  there is a 1.7% improvement in cost per megawatt in operation, thanks to the reduction of the net operating  expenses.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, as mentioned, EBITDA dropped 63% following a 53% decrease in gross margin as explained previously.  In the UK, EBITDA grew 32% with a 29% in gross margin, with a 39% increase in output, more than  compensating the lower average price due to energy and ROC prices reduction. Net operating expenses increases  21% due to offshore investments.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA grew 28%, with an 18% increase in gross margin, thanks to the 5.6% higher average price and  trading profits taking advantage of weather conditions. As you know, 25% of our production in the U.S. is  merchant. Net operating expenses and levies remained stable.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Latin America, EBITDA grew 52%, due to the increase in the installed capacity in Mexico. And in the Rest of  the World, EBITDA decreased 40% due to the sale of the Polish wind farms.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you, Pepe. The result we are presenting today allow us to confirm our 2014 outlook as well as the  perspective presented for the three-year period ended in 2016. For an operational point of view, all businesses had  a very good performance along the quarter, compensating the impact of lower energy prices and the regulatory  measures introduced in Spain. Additionally, the company has maintained its strong commitment to efficiency,  keeping net operating expenses flat. It's worth mentioning that even though renewables in Spain have registered  proportionate remuneration cut, we are already making our best effort to minimize the impact along the year.

file: IBE - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 29April2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The renewable businesses has also recorded a very good performance with EBITDA increasing almost 25% due to  the extraordinary low prices in the Spain last year and to a higher output in United Kingdom, Mexico and Brazil.  Let me highlight the strong performance of West of Duddon Sands offshore wind farm, which has registered an  average load factor of more than 55% versus an average of 30% in our onshore fleet.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, in generation and supply, EBITDA has decreased 11.4% compared to the extraordinary good result  recorded in 2014. Due to the positive one-off obtained last year in the gas businesses and especially generation  mix, we had in the Spain, thanks to the high hydro production 18 terawatt hours, it was well above the annual  average of the last 10 year's 13 terawatt hours.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the New York, another one the New York Reforming the Energy Vision, a new program of the regulatory  commission for the distribution activity, product technological development, smart grid, information system,  automation et cetera. And finally, the merger between UIL and the Iberdrola USA, which we expect to be closed in  the fourth quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In renewables, 450 megawatt of onshore wind farms are currently underway in the United Kingdom. Of those 350  megawatts are already under construction and additional, 100 megawatts are expected to start during this year,  consolidating our position as leading wind producer in the country.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In offshore wind, after having successful completed West of Duddon Sands, we have been awarded the British  government auction for a new offshore wind farm, East Anglia One located in North Sea. This 740 megawatt wind  farm with construction starting at the end of 2016 and scheduled to be commissioned in 2019 will require  investment worth approximately €2.8 billion. Furthermore, we have started a construction of Wikinger offshore  wind farm located in the German waters of the Baltic Sea. It will be in operation in 2017 with a total investment of  €1.4 billion.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In United States, we have put in operation Baffin wind farm of 200 megawatts. Additionally, we have 900  megawatts of new project qualify under the PTCs extension approved by the end of the year and to be built up to  2016. Of those, we have already started construction of Deerfield wind farm in Vermont and we are expecting to  announce all the new project along the year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Mexico, two new wind farms totaling 136 megawatts will be in operation this year. We also have a pipeline of  more than 1,500 megawatt of wind and solar project to deliver through future growth.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Brazil, we have been awarded two auctions to build 174 megawatt wind capacity. We will commission in 2017.  Moreover we have a pipeline of 1,000 megawatt of wind power to present it to future auctions.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, concerning contracted generation in Mexico, we're already taking advantage of the new opportunities  provided by the energy reform which is attracting private investment to the energy sector. Thus we have 700  megawatts under construction to be commissioned in 2016. The feed unit of Monterrey CCG plant, a new CGT  facility in Baja California and two cogeneration plant. And we are negotiating several new project for existing new  customers for some new thousands of megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The results we are presenting today allow us to confirm the guidance for the year 2015 that we already provided in  February. We expect that the February performance along the year of networks and renewables together, with the  behavior of the generation and supply business is affected by the lower hydro-production compared to last year,  will contribute to increased EBITDA and recurring net profits above 2014. Additionally, we will keep improving  our already sound financial position, result in a better financial ratio by the year end.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Generation and supply business fell 11.4% to €781 million due to the unfavorable comparison with Q1, 2014 which  had a strong hydro output in Spain and included up to €80 million of non-recurring positive impacts from gas in  Spain and in the U.S.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA reached €432 million with a 15.6% decrease in gross margin due to the 17% lower output  after a 47% decrease in hydro. An increase in procurement cost due to the increased thermal waste in the  production mix.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As already mentioned Q1, 2014 included €43 million positive of non-recurring gas impact. This has been partially  compensated by a €37 million positive legal resolution impact accounted in Q1, 2015 loss producing Levies.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the UK EBITDA was £173 million. Wholesale and generation business gross margin decreased due to higher  costs with the Carbon Tax doubling its price. Retail business gross margin improved due to higher volumes in gas  with a 7.8% increase in demand compensating a 6% lower gross margin in retail power due to the increase in non- energy related cost across transmission and distribution charges.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA increased 24.7% to €428 million driven by the recovery in the Spanish business in addition  to the positive evolution in the UK and Latin America offsetting the weaker performance in the U.S., Spain and  now also the UK with new offshore capacity in operation have been the largest EBITDA contributors in  renewables, each having around a 35% share.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA reached €149 million with a 15% lower output more than compensated by the recovery of  prices. In the UK EBITDA grew 45% to £111 million with a 14.7% higher output and the contribution of West of  Duddon Sands offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the U.S. EBITDA fell 40% to $88 million due to the 13% decrease in output and the 5% decrease in prices, due  to the extraordinary weather conditions in Q1 of last year. In Latin America, the EBITDA rose 31% to €24 million,  thanks to a 26% increase in output due to the stronger load factor in Mexico and the substantial capacity in  Greece, in Brazil.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: EBIT increased 5.3% to €1,344 million lower than the 8.8% increase in EBITDA due to the 17% increase in  amortizations. Half of it is due to the FX impact, with the remainder linked to the increasing operating capacity in  renewables, mainly in the UK, a higher investment in systems, in networks both – and in corporate developments  in the U.S. and in the UK.

file: IBE - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 27April2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The €2 billion of EBITDA can be attributed particularly to the good performance of Renewable businesses and a  strong contribution from our activities in United States where EBITDA increased by 21% although it was  negatively influenced by the exchange rate and the accounting rules of IFRS compared to the U.S. GAAP.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Networks, EBITDA fell 3.7 % mainly because of a high temperature in United State this winter, which led to  lower gas demand affecting mainly two of our gas distribution in Connecticut and Massachusetts. In the months   ahead, the operating performance of Networks is going to improve as non-recurring impact from the first quarter  will be reversed or diluted during the rest of the year as will be explained later by the CFO.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Renewable businesses has recorded a good performance. We had 3.1% growth, thanks to the higher onshore  output, which increased 11% in Spain and 40% United States, while the United Kingdom wind production was  27 % lower after last year record production.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Generation and Supply, EBITDA has been affected by typical factors like compensation of our customers in the  UK for the already resolved service issues in countries last year during the introduction of our new IT system, or  the comparison with a positive effect to the one-off CNMC and Eco-tax reduction in Spain during 2015. In  addition, we have experienced a decrease in our wholesale gas operation.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The energy produced by our company was 2.4% higher than in 2015, mainly due to the 41% increase in  hydroelectric production. We expect to improve further through the year as our reserves are at almost record level  of 9.2 terawatt hours which will be compensate the negative impact of this quarter.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will now briefly review the main project underway to show our progress in the execution of our 2016-2020 plan.  In Networks, the United State Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has approved the New Y ork Transco  agreement. Defining cost and remuneration for the first three projects under negotiation.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In May, we've been awarded with a new project. The extension of Cooper's Mills Station in order to ensure the  reliability of electric system in the Greater Boston area. In United Kingdom, the construction of our transmission  and distribution project in RIIO T1 and RIIO ED1 is in line with regulatory objectives. We have achieved higher  incentive for service improvement initially targeted.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Renewables, we have achieved significant milestone offshore. We are laying the first foundation of 250  megawatt wind farm Wikinger in the Baltic Sea of Germany. And we have signed the order to Siemens to supply  the turbines for our British East Anglia I project with 714 megawatts. In relation to our offshore wind farm, we  have completed the commissioning Black Law Extension reaching a total of over 1,600 megawatts of installed  wind capacity in United Kingdom.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In total, we have 1,350 megawatts of onshore wind under construction in United Kingdom, United States and  Brazil. Finally, concerning contracted generation in Mexico, we completed a commission in our co -generation  plant, Ramos Arizpe in a state of Coahuila and we have been granted another combined cycle Topolobampo II in  the State of Sinaloa. With that, a 190 megawatts to the state – to almost 2,500 of additional capacity under  construction. When completed in 2018, our total installed power in Mexico will reach almost 8,000 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the 14 of April, we completed the second green bond issue. The demand for this bond with a 10 -year maturity  and coupon of 1.12% was 4 times oversubscribed. The funds rise will be allocated to refinance, wind farm  investment in Spain, United Kingdom and Portugal.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: In the Liberalised business, Spain and Mexico have had a combined negative impact of €133 million as a  consequence of positive court rulings in Spain in the first quarter of 2015, lower gas trading activity and weak  quarter in Mexico, driven by lower margins in the private client business.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: In the regulated business, we have been affected by a very mild weather conditions and other impacts in the U.S.  that you see in the IFRS accounts, but not in the U.S. GAAP, and positive settlements that we had in Spain in the  first quarter of 2015.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: Those impacts are offset by a €25 million positive impact in the first quarter due to the fact that the attendance  premium that last year we accounted in the first quarter, this year will be accounted in the second quarter, and  €21 million one-off positive impacts at the Renewable business.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: In the UK, the EBITDA fell 3.6% to £223 million with a £10 million decrease in gross margin affected by the new  profiling of the RIIO-ED1 applicable from April 1, 2015. In the U.S., EBITDA was 5.8% up to $226 million,  including $170 million from the UIL consolidation, partially offset by $38 million lower IFRS EBITDA linked to  the under-collection that we have had this quarter due to the very mild weather conditions and other effects that  will be recovered through the year as most of our U.S. business is decoupled from demand evolution.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: Finally, Elektro EBITDA fell 5% to €221 million with a 7 % lower energy circulated, reducing gross margin by 1%,  and inflation rate increasing net operating expenses by 6%. Generation and Supply EBITDA fell 18% to €640  million affected by positive rulings last year, and also, due to a positive contribution from our gas and other  trading activities in Q1 2015, which affects very negatively the comparison of the Spanish business. As already  mentioned, UK 2016 results include €23 million of customer compensations ruled by Ofgem, and Mexico had a  bad quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: So, in Spain, EBITDA fell 31% to €296 million with a 10% decrease in gross margin, with lower ga s trading and  other trading activity [ph] accounts (18:10) €65 million less. This was a very strong trading results in the first  quarter of 2015, which was not repeated in the following quarters. This very strong trading results in the first  quarter of 2015 offset the 5.2% higher output as a consequence of better hydro conditions. Hydro reserves today  are at maximum levels with more than 9 terawatt, which makes us confident of the improvement of the business  during 2016. Net operating expenses increased 15% due to the €20 million reversal of the CNMC fine, accounted  for in the Q1 of 2015. Levies increased another 14%, also affected by unfavorable comparison with the first quarter  of 2015. That accounted for €37 million of a positive court ruling on eco -taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: Wholesale & Generation business gross margin increased 51% due to higher gas output and lower procurement  costs. But the Retail business gross margin decreased 3% because the higher unitary margins in gas did not  compensate [ph] to start (19:39) 19% lower gross margin in retail power due to the increasing non-energy-related  costs and lower volumes with milder weather conditions than last year's.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: In Mexico, EBITDA fell 15% to $113 million, affected by lower margins in contrast with private customers as a  result of the fall of the CFE tariff in 2015. In April, CFE tariff increased by 12%. Thus, EBITDA will recover in the  next quarters. In the U.S., EBITDA reached $80 million due to a better performance of the gas business.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA increased 3.1% to €441 million with Spain and the U.S. business growth offsetting a weaker  performance in the UK. Spain has been the largest EBITDA contributor with 39%, followed by the UK and the U.S.  which are around 25% each. Gross margin fell 0.7% but net operating expenses improved 13.9% with 21 million of  positive one-offs.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA increased 30% to $115 million as a result of a 14% higher output and lower operating  expenses including an $11 million one-off, more than offsetting lower merchant prices due to mild weather  conditions. In Latin America, EBITDA remained flat at €24.5 million, negatively affected by the Brazilian  devaluation. In local currency, Mexico EBITDA improved 7.1% as a consequence of additional capacity, while  Brazil is down 24% despite growing 5% in local currency due to the 39% Brazil devaluation. In the Rest of the  World, EBITDA reached €29 million, 4.1% up.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Finance and Resources Director
texts.text: EBIT fell 7 % to €1,250 million. Amortizations decreased €46.9 million driven by the closure of Longannet, €32  million, and the extension of the useful life of wind farms in line with industry standards in the U.S. and our  proven track record. As a matter of fact, we are confirming that we have wind farms of over 23 years old which are  performing very well.

file: IBE - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 26April2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I also like to highlight that effective from April 3, Gamesa-Siemens Wind merger has been completed. This merger  has led to the creation of a global leader in the wind generation industry with €11 billion of revenues, €1.1 billion  of operating profit, 26,000 employees and with the headquarters in Spain. The new group, in which Iberdrola  holds 8.1% stake, is listed in Madrid Stock Exchange. It has today a market capitalization of over €13 billion.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And Renewable businesses has remained relatively stable with an EBITDA debt, excluding the extraordinary  items, in line with the first quarter 2016. This has been possible thanks to the contribution of additional capacity  that's almost offset the low wind output in Spain versus an extraordinary high output in first quarter 2016.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our regulated generation activity in Mexico is up by 29.5%, thanks to the contribution of the additional 740  megawatts of capacity and the two-digit CFE tariff increase compared to the first quarter of 2016.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation and Supply EBITDA has been affected mainly by the UK with low retail prices and an increase in  regulated obligation cost and the comparatively lower generation output due to the closure of Longannet plant in  March 2016. We expect that the performance of the business will improve during the year as a result of the 10%  and 5% tariff increases in electricity and gas implemented from April 1, efficiency measures underway and the  dilution during the year of the contribution of Longannet about the first quarter of 2016.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As for Spain, the lowered hydro output versus exceptionally high levels in the first quarter of 2016, I remind you  what a record run, result in a negative comparison which will also be dilutive in the following months.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our net investment continue increasing to over €1 billion, a 30% uplift with 93% allocated to Networks,  Renewables and Contracted Generation. As a result of the investment in these last two businesses, we expect at  over 2 gigawatts during 2017, including 490 megawatts already commissioned during the first quarter.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In total, we have also [ph] sales cost in (5:12) 400 megawatts in construction of committee, additional to the 1,300  megawatts already put in operation in the last 12 months, all of which will be commissioned during the next three  years. 45% of these capacities will be Renewables and the remaining Contracted Generation.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: During the first quarter, a number of relevant milestone has been achieved in the execution of our investment  plan. In Networks, the Western Link high-voltage cable to bring the renewables [indiscernible] (5:45) from  Scotland to England and Wales has been manufactured and tested for this expected commission at the year-end.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the United States, the [ph] electric government enforcement (5:54) of the urban area Rochester has been  completed with the commissioning of five new substations.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, we have continued implementing the Smart Grids Project and 490,000 additional smart meters were  installed.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Renewables, all jackets and 12 turbines were installed during the first quarter in our Wikinger offshore wind  farm in Germany, with full export expect in the fourth quarter. In offshore, of a total of 167 – an onshore of 167  megawatts were commissioned in the UK and Brazil.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In United States, we had secured this long-term Power Purchase Agreement with Apple for our new 201- megawatt Montague green power project in Oregon, set to come online by the end of 2018 and signing additional  PPAs for 80 megawatts on the existing 160 megawatts Barton wind farm in Iowa.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Contracted Generation in Mexico, the commissioning of 314-megawatt Baja California combined cycle took  place in January. We were also awarded the constructions in new combined cycle for Celpe Topolobampo III, with  766 megawatts of capacity, which is expected to be commissioned in the 1st January 2020. By then, total  installed capacity in Mexico will reach around 10,200 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And in Brazil, we were just awarded last Monday with the four new transmission projects for close to BRL 1 billion,  to be put in operation or commissioned in the next few years.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies were up 10.5% due to, first, the higher generation taxes in the liberalized business in Spain, €29 million  more, linked to the very high energy prices that we had especially in January and the nuclear output increase.  Higher taxes in the U.S. Networks business, €43 million more, affected additionally by the seasonality of its  recognition, will be more aligned with 2016 throughout the year.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA fell 5.6% to £210 million with a 2% decrease in gross margin affected by lower volumes and  past year settlements. Net operating expenses grew 16% with higher external services associated to  maintenance and weather.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, Elektro's EBITDA improved 6.7% to BRL 236 million with 1.8% higher energy distributed and the positive  impact from the increase in the past August review.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation and Supply EBITDA fell 32% to €436 million, driven by, first, the adverse operating situation in the UK  with lower output after the Longannet closure, and very thin margins as a consequence of higher non-energy cost,  strong competition, increase in input cost, and the weaker British pound, and the lower contribution of the Spanish  business affected by adverse weather conditions and higher taxes, not compensated enough by the good  performance in Mexico. Nevertheless, the situation will improve during the year both in Spain and in the UK.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Getting into the details, in Spain, the EBITDA fell 19.6% to €238 million, mainly driven by a 6.1% lower output with  a 41% decrease in hydro production after an exceptional Q1 2016 and lower gas results due to higher  procurement costs. Levies were up 21% affected by the increase in generation taxes due to the very high spot  prices that we've had, especially in January and a higher nuclear output. On the positive side, stronger retail  activity was able to absorb part of the margin conversion.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I would like to stress that the production mix comparison will improve during the year as hydro production  decreased from the third quarter of 2016 onwards, partially [ph] calibrating (16:25) the exceptional conditions of  the first semesters. And today, energy prices are more moderate reducing the cost of levies.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, EBITDA improved 25.4% to €142 million, thanks to the additional capacity operation that as mentioned  the Chairman, both with CFE and private customers, and with higher CFE tariff as oil prices have recovered from  Q1 2016 lows.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: due to strong competition further compressed by the rise in non-energy-related costs, government obligations and  transmission costs. Retail Gas gross margin was 24% down, affected by a 5% lower sales and lower  [indiscernible] (18:00) margins. Recent March tariff increased 10.8% for electricity and 4.7% for gas that will start  on the 1st of April, will improve margins, and there are also efficiency measures underway that will deliver results  by the end of the year.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA was down 5% to €434 million, mainly driven by lower wind resource in Spain. Gross margin  grew 1.2% and net operating expenses increased 28% due to higher activity and non-recurring impacts in the UK  and the U.S. Spain contributes 34% to EBITDA, the U.S. 29%, and the UK 24%.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA increased by 2.8% to $135 million, driven by a 3.9% higher output, in line with additional  capacity installed, mainly the Amazon wind farm, 208 megawatts, and gains in the mark-to-market of hedges for  our merchant position. Gross margin was up 9%, but OpEx was up 35%, or $16 million, of which $12 million are  non-recurring.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Renewables, we will progressively incorporate almost 1,400 additional megawatts during the next three  quarters. And the wind condition should normalize as we are comparing inception in a high wind output in the first  quarter 2016 versus a very low one in this last quarter.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Contracted Generation, we will add 129 megawatts during the year and benefit for the increase in the CFE  tariff. We will expect to continue two-digit level compared to the exceptional low tariff in 2016 derived from the fall  in commodity prices.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: All this positive impact lead to an outlook of mid single-digit growth for the year with a growth expected in  Networks, Renewables and Contracted Generation, the businesses where we are focusing our investment.

file: IBE - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 24April2018 1145 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Networks EBITDA is up 17.5%, thanks to the consolidation of Neoenergia and the positive impact of our  investment in all geographies, especially in United States driven by the rate plans in Connecticut and New York.  Excluding foreign exchange impact, EBITDA growth in Networks will be almost 10 points higher, reaching 27.3%.  The Renewables EBITDA increased by 14%, thanks to the higher output resulting from the normalization of wind  resource in the first quarter 2018.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This was particularly remarkable in Spain where our production grew by 24%, and in the UK, which registered  32% increase in output. In offshore wind, the commissioning of our 350-megawatt Wikinger wind farm in Germany  had driven 16% growth in total output from this technology in the first quarter. This has even improved in the last  month, resulting in a 90% increase in output year-to-date.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And regards hydro production increased by 6% up to March in Spain. Let me highlight that as the result of the  heavy rainfall in the past weeks, output is already 22% higher than last year up to today. And hydro reserves has  above 20 years average levels.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net investment have reached €1,185 million in the first quarter, 40% more than last year. Networks business  represent 40% of the total investment, with 37% coming from Renewables and the remaining 23% from  Generation and Supply. In 2018, we expect to put in service 1,905 megawatt, new megawatts, which added to the  capacity already committed, totaled 7,790 megawatts to be commissioned by 2020. These figures include our 714  megawatt East Anglia 1 offshore wind farm in North Sea in Britain, about 1,500 megawatt of onshore wind, and  over 3,500 megawatt of contracted generation in Mexico.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: We have also 1,600 megawatt committed or in construction for 2021 and 2022, which correspond mainly to our  hydropump and storage project in Tâmega in Portugal. In the last three months, the company has achieved  relevant milestone in the execution of our investment plan. In Networks, Avangrid New England Clean Energy  Connect transmission project was finally selected by the Massachusetts Department of Energy. This $950 million  project include 1,200 megawatts of high voltage direct current transmission line linking the grids in Québec and  New England, and is expected to come online by 2022.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Connecticut, the new Southern Connecticut Gas rate plan approved in December, and then we have started  revision for United Illuminating, went into effect on January 1. In Spain, we have completed successfully our smart  grid project almost one year ahead of our regulatory obligation, having reached 10,540 million meters installed.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As regard to Renewables, the German offshore Wikinger wind farm was fully commissioned, and its 70 turbines  are currently in operation. Our [ph] next (00:06:59) offshore wind farm East Anglia 1 in the UK is progressing  according to our expectation. Onshore civil works for both cable installation and substation construction had  commenced as well as the installation of foundation. And in Brazil, 61 new megawatt of hydro capacity has been  added.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Generation and Supply, Scottish Power has already completed 20% official smart meter installation program  ahead of our plans. And in Mexico, the cogeneration plant of San Juan has been commissioned and the  repowering of Monterrey combined cycle has been finalized. And there is an additional 3,500 megawatts in  construction.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Avangrid increased adjusted net profit by 7% in the period to $243 million, mainly thanks to the implementation of  best practices, the impact of rate plans in Networks and the additional 590 megawatt of renewable capacity put in  operation during 2017. The company continues executing on its strategic plan with investment worth $290 million  up to March.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The divestment of non-core gas business and the new projects, as mentioned before, New England Clean Energy  Connect or the Vineyard offshore wind farm has been allowed to the company to present a bid for 190 megawatt  in Connecticut, in addition to the two bids for 400 and 800 megawatt presented last December in Massachusetts.  Given the first quarter result and its expectation for the rest of 2018, Avangrid has reaffirmed its adjusted EPS  outlook in the range of $2.22 and $2.25 per share.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the Renewables, the company secured nine additional wind farm for the total capacity of 300 megawatts with  commission date in 2022 and PPAs for 20 years. The company integration process is well on track with synergies  identified above those initially expected.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the commission of experts created to advice on the climactic change in the Energy Transition Law,  published its final report on April 2nd. This commission with members proposed by the government or  parliamentary groups and social agents has reached a remarkable degree of consensus on the most appropriate  ways to achieve Spain long-term de-carbonization objectives. In this respect, the report which covered two  scenarios 2030 and 2050 indicate that nuclear generation should be maintained to reach emission reduction  targets for a period always under a framework that make this technology economically viable.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Virtually, all coal capacity will be closed before 2030. Capacity market are necessary. A fiscal reform is essential  to distribute environmental costs based on the polluter pays principle, not charging costs only to the electricity  sector, also, to eliminate non-energy costs from the tariffs, clean up the tariff from all those costs.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And finally, the report highlights the need to encourage investment in networks infrastructure in light with the  recent report published by Deloitte. These recommendation are fully aligned with the European policies and  directives, and set a clear basis for the definition of the future climactic change in Energy Transition Law, and  have the consensus of all the political parties, trade union, and industrial organization.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you, Chairman. Good afternoon to everybody. Before getting into the details, let me explain the 2018  results include [ph] tower (00:14:06) reclassifications moving forward. 2017 results had been restated accordingly  for comparison basis. First, results from hydroelectric generation are not included in Renewable business instead  of in the liberalized business. Second, the engineering results are now included only at the equity line with no  EBITDA contribution.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies improved by 10.3%, €79 million less to €684 million, thanks to €43 million positive FX impacts, €23 million  lower U.S. taxes following our recalculation through the year of the real estate taxes, and €14 million lower  Spanish taxes on generation, as there was a big spike in prices last January as you remember. And we have had  less nuclear production in Q1 2018 compared to Q1 2017.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA grew 14% to €603 million driven by the growth in Spain, the UK, and the rest of the world,  with a better load factor and a 5% larger installed capacity that reaches now 29,275 megawatts that drove  production up 15% to 15,000 gigawatt hours. Gross margin grew 10.2%, and net operating expenses increased  by 9%.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As I mentioned before, hydroelectric generation is reported now in this area and restated in 2017 results. As a  result, Spain now is the main contributor to the Renewables EBITDA with a 40% stake, followed by the UK 24%,  the U.S. 19%, rest of the world 9%, Brazil 6%, and Mexico. In Spain, EBITDA reached €242 million, 4.9% higher  than last year, driven by a 24% higher output in wind and a 6% higher output in hydro, partially compensated by  lower prices versus Q1 2017 that as I mentioned before, had a big spike in January of last year and affect more  our hydro results.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA grew 4.3% to $140 million due to a 14% higher output with a 9% larger installed capacity and  better wind conditions, but affected by lower prices and the positive impact of $25 million power hedges  accounted for in the first quarter of 2017.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA grew 30% to £128 million, as a consequence of a 23% higher output, with 242 megawatts  increase in average operating capacity and higher load factor that boosted gross margin by 24%.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA grew 46% to €225 million, thanks to higher margins following the fall in procurement costs.  The already mentioned falling generation taxes and higher retail activity more than compensating the 6.7% output  decrease in our thermal mix due to less nuclear and coal, not compensated by higher production of our combined  cycles.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you, Pepe. To conclude, I would like to highlight our investment plan, the normalization of the output and  the efficiency measures as the main drivers of growth during 2018. Our investment plan has already started to  deliver growth in results, thanks to the 4,000 megawatt of capacity added between 2017 and 2018 mostly in  renewables and combined cycles.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In addition, the impact of normalization of hydro and wind output, our hydro reserve already had above 20 years  average. Prices are higher than last year. And in Networks, the effect of our New York and Connecticut rate plans  in the U.S as well as the rate increases in Brazil will lead to positive evolution of result.

file: IBE - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Renewables EBITDA was 13.3% due to the recovery in prices compared to March 2018, a 50% rise in  offshore wind generation, thanks to the full contribution of our German offshore wind farm, the new capacity  added in Mexico, and the better onshore wind resource in UK. All these compensate the lower contribution from  Spain and U.S.A.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Operating result in Generation and Supply increased by 19%, mainly driven by higher output in retail sales in  Spain and the contribution of 1 gigawatt of new capacity installed in Mexico over the last 12 months. These two  factors allow us to offset the lower production in the UK after the sale of thermal generation capacity at the end of  last year as well as the negative impact of the tariff cap implemented in UK since January 1, 2019.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moving to the progress in implementation of of the plan 2022 until March, the group invested €1.2 billion.  Approximately one-third of this total was dedicated to Network and the other two-thirds were mainly invested in  Renewables. The progress made up to March reaffirm our plan to put in service 4.1 gigawatt in 2019 as expected.  The coming three quarters will be more somewhat intensive in capital expenditure.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The new capacity added will imply increasing group production by almost 20 terawatt hours on an annual basis.  That means 30% rise in annual terms. And beyond 2019, we have a detailed program by technologies and  geographies. They will allow us to reach almost 30,000 megawatt of new capacity by 2022. Out of that, 9.7  gigawatts are already in advanced state of construction.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Solar photovoltaic contribute to 40% to this amount, 14 gigawatts, mainly in Spain and United State (sic) [States].  We have 11 gigawatt of onshore wind project spread over all our geographies. Our total offshore wind pipeline  amounts of 12.4 gigawatts in countries such as UK, United State (sic) [States], Germany and France.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: It is worth mentioning then the high EBITDA generation of the offshore wind technology around 5 times more per  megawatt than solar photovoltaic. If we were to compare Iberdrola pipeline in terms of potential EBITDA  contribution per megawatt portfolio base only compared with a portfolio-only base in solar photovoltaic, I will equal  around 90 gigawatt of solar projects.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the Distribution business, a Royal Decree-Law has been approved that provide power to the CNMC  energy regulator to set up tariff for those asset from 2020 in line with European directives. As you are probably  aware of, an agreement has been reached and sign for the orderly phase-out of the Spanish nuclear fleet  between 2027 and 2035, which is in line with the horizon considered in the draft of Natural Integrated Plan (sic)  [Integrated National Energy and Climate Plan] or [Foreign Language] (00:07:07) submitted to European  Commission.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the United State (sic) [States], the Avangrid result had been positively affected by new three-year rate plans for  gas network in Connecticut and Massachusetts applicable in January this year. In addition, the New England  Clean Energy Connect transmission project will link Canada and Massachusetts received the Certificate of Public  Convenience and Necessity from the Maine Public Utilities Commission. This approval was a key milestone to  maintain the expected date of commercial operation in 2022.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Renewables, the major wind offshore project in Massachusetts is progressing as scheduled, with  commissioning estimate in 2021. Almost 70% of the project supply chain is already secured, including wind  turbines from investors and foundations. Additionally, the power purchase agreement signed with the state  distribution companies has had received the approval from the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And finally in Germany, Vestas' 9.5-megawatt offshore turbines has already been selected for our 476-megawatt  Baltic Eagle offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies fell by 6.2% to €642 million, positively affected by a €67 million decrease on Spanish taxes on generation  due to lower hydro production in Spain and the suspension of the 7% generation tax in the first quarter, which is  now in place again since April. This has been partially compensated by €17 million of higher U.S. network levies  and the negative FX impact.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA rose 13.3% to €684 million as the UK, Latam, and offshore business contribution more than  compensated lower production in Spain and in the U.S. Global installed capacity reached 29,502 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA was €219 million, 9.6% below last year as a consequence of 23% lower output driven by 24%  lower hydro and 23% lower wind, partially compensated by lower taxes linked to the already mentioned lower  production and this was in hydro and the suspension of the 7% generation tax.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA was up 30% to £166 million, with 3.7% higher onshore output and better prices more than  compensating the sale of a hydro capacity in the last quarter of last year.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA fell 15% to $119 million due to an 11.5% lower output, driven by low wind resource, extreme  weather conditions, and also by lower prices.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Brazil, EBITDA was up 13.8% to BRL 160 million, with a 14.3% higher output mainly as a consequence of the  245 megawatts operating new hydro capacity.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, EBITDA increased 76% to $29 million as a consequence of the 43% higher output linked to the 270  megawatts additional solar new capacity installed.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA decreased 66% to £44 million, affected by lower revenues as a consequence of the thermal  assets sales during last quarter and the new tariff cap impact as well as lower sales especially in gas due to a  milder winter.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBIT grew 17.7% to €1.6 billion, thanks to the 11.9% EBITDA growth combined with a 3.3% growth in  depreciation and provisions caused by higher activity, €29 million, and the IFRS 16 impact already mentioned,  €60 million, partially compensated by lower nuclear depreciation, €27 million, and the sale of the UK thermal  generation assets.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Renewables, the Generation and Supply will install more than one – the 4.1 gigawatt mostly in renewables in  the U.S., the UK, Spain and Mexico. This new capacity will allow us to increase our production up to 20 terawatt  hours on annual basis, 13% above our normal production.

file: IBE - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 21July2010 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: As a result, IBERDROLA is capable of maintaining a sustainable growth based on one or another  area depending on the circumstances. And secondly, the operating optimization carved out for  each business in the Group. Thanks to this, during the first semester of 2010, the three main  activities of the Group recorded a major growth in results, both regulated and liberalized and  renewable activities.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: The production of the group has increased 14%, driven by the emission-free technologies and this  shows, once again, our firm support for these emission-free technologies and we have invested  €1.5 billion only in the last semester. As a result of that greater production and good performance of  the regulated businesses, gross profits have increased by 8.9%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: 2 Regarding regulation in Spain, I would like to clarify the remuneration framework for wind energy  under conditions that will enable us to continue to develop our activity in our investment plans in a  satisfactory manner as explained yesterday at the presentation of IBERDROLA RENOVABLES.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Therefore, the total liquidity is increased to €9.4 billion, a sufficient amount to cover the needs of  the group until mid-2012. Output for the group in the first six months of 2010 reached 80,000  gigawatt hours, a growth of 14.2% compared to the same period last year. And this has been  possible thanks to the increase in the generation of 100% emission-free output, the contribution of  which has increased 10 points to over 50% of the total.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: The combined gas cycle and thermal technology has also obtained more than 90% of the total  production of the group and we have to consider that no technology provides more than 20% of the  total, excluding combined cycles in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: I would also like to highlight the increase of 21% of production in Spain. And to this, the increase in  demand has made a strong contribution in our country, over 4% in the semester, as well as the  increase in hydro and wind production. And the hydro reserves are at a historic level of 77% of the  maximum capacity. This represents an increase of 51% over the figures for June last year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And there has been a good performance of IBERDROLA U.S.A., where the operating expenses  dropped more than 20%. We must also highlight developments in the energy business in Spain,  whose expenses have increased slightly over 1% in homogenous terms.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: We have to highlight the positive performance of IBERDROLA Renewables with a growth of 21%  with regulated businesses which increased 13%, driven by good results in Spain, United States,  Brazil and the U.K. And I would also like to highlight the good example set by the regulatory status,  which started to be applied from April 1. And the stability and predictability of the legal and  regulatory framework is without a doubt, one of the reasons why IBERDROLA has put its stakes in  the U.K. since 2007. The new government has defended the need to have a sufficiently attractive  regulatory framework to carry out large investments in energy infrastructures.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Regarding the regulatory situation in Spain, I would like to dedicate a few moments to make a  realistic diagnosis of the current problems and the causes of the same. In this sense and contrary  to what is often thought, the cause of the electricity price increases in Spain in recent years have  not been due to the so-called traditional generation. In fact, if we look at the price of the pool, we  will see that since January 2008 until December 2009, it has experienced a major drop of more  than 50%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And as you can see in this chart, that is based on information from the Ministry of Industry between  ‘97 and 2009, traditional generation costs included in the tariffs have been reduced by 25%,  whereas other costs have been increased very significantly, in particular, the premiums for  renewables, which have grown 120%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: However, I think that’s fundamental to stress the differences between some renewable  technologies and others, because their energy contribution and their economic impact vary  considerably and they cannot be compared.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: 4 So, taking data from 2009 wind technology has a practically total balance in an energy that  provides 14% and its contribution to costs is 16%. Solar technologies only provided 2% of the  energy, but they accounted for 16% of the system’s costs.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: But if they were to revise the energy planning process and its execution, we can see that although  the differences are not very significant in terms of wind or gas technologies, the installation of solar  power has been seven times higher than what we had planned, which means that we’ll have more  than 6,500 megawatts installed by the end of 2011. And this means that premiums will grow by  more than €3.6 billion a year, that’s where we have the deficit.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: So, solar technology has a long way to go along the learning curve and nowadays, represents a  cost for the system in excess of €400 per megawatt hour, which means that generation – that we  have generated many tariff deficits. So in order to solve this problem between the costs and the  tariffs, constant changes have been carried out in recent years, so that is regulatory changes. That  in the last 20 years have been based on more than 20 modifications in the laws, 100 [inaudible]  decrees and ministerial orders and 200 resolutions and the final targets have not been achieved.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: So, once again in the month of July, the government published a document of the elements on an  agreement for the energy policy with a total of 25 proposals under six major headings to try to do  something about this problem.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: But if we were to stick to the contents of this document and beyond the rumors and speculations,  we can see that it includes the main elements that are required to overcome the current problems.  Firstly, the establishment of an energy mix for 2020 that allows us to fulfill commitments in terms of  environmental issues of the EU. So it’s not going to be necessary to have a coherent plan, but also  to monitor its execution efficiently. I’m much more concerned about this, so that we can avoid the  deviations we had in the past, as we’ve seen in recent years.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Secondly, the document underscores how important it is to improve the current grid infrastructures  and that new investments have to be made in terms of interconnections and Smart Grids. And once  again, we have to achieve a full deregulation of the market, according to the Spanish and European  regulations, and it is recognized that to implement this, it will be necessary to solve the problem of  the deficit, according to the law, not any later than 2013, and it has been said that what we have to  do is pay the amounts that have to do through their securitization.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And another issue has to do with the regulated costs and the document, in principle, wants to adapt  the remuneration mechanisms of renewables to the evolution that has been experimented by their  technology. So this principle can be seen in the modifications that have been approved for the case  of wind power.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And likewise, the rest of the regulated costs will also be revised and I think we have to mention the  progress made in the updating of the remuneration and the distribution with the approval of the  National Commission for Energy, and the reference network that provides the necessary support.  And finally, the document recognizes that we have to hold a discussion on the future of nuclear  power, a technology that will be necessary to guarantee supplies in Spain and proposes a number  of measures to increase savings and efficiency.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Unfortunately, and this is something that has been happening whilst I’ve been in this sector, every  now and again, news appears in relation to possible changes in the regulatory framework that  would have a negative impact for the electrical utilities. Well, in the 10 years that I’ve been in this  business, together with some months, I can say that after this news is released, we always attempt  towards applying a rational approach and we also apply our common sense after this noise and  after these many rumors and we have the reform of the renewables sector. But what they have  done is respected the basic principle of non-retroactivity and we have a reasonable level of  remuneration.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And in addition, IBERDROLA has benefit from very favorable evolution of exchange rates that  account for €79 million as regards the gross margin and the basic margin. That covers the net  effect of the emission rights. And the P&L account has grown 8.1% and now stands at €6 billion,  because the price is lower and because there is less CO2 consumption.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And the net staff expenses have grown 3.9% and now stand at €894 million and net external  services have been reduced by 5.2% and now stand at €867 million. As regards taxes, well, there  has been an increase of 16.8%, and we have a figure €450 million. And this means that there been  an increase in the payment of the nuclear rate and it’s now €91 million in the semester. We have  the social bonus and other rates in the United States that serve to offset the elimination of the  detraction of CO2 rights, which represented a figure of €96 million in 2009. And the consolidated  EBITDA of the group has reached €3,836 million, which represents a growth rate of 11.7%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Additionally, our nuclear production has grown 10% and thermal technologies have dropped cycles  by 39% and coal plus fuel, 69%. An average total sales price of around €56 per megawatt hour  have been obtained with an output of much higher than planned. 70 terawatts hours have been  sold in 2010 at a price of more than €50 a megawatt hour. This represents more than 98% of the  output budgeted for the year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: The European market forwards and Spanish market forward point to a price increase in 2011. The  Spanish forward maintains the same trend as the German and French. However, there is a  negative spread of around 8 to €10. And this reaffirms what was already mentioned by the  Chairman regarding the lower cost of the energy under the ordinary regime in Spain compared to  the rest of Europe.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Taxes went up 21% to €192 million. Since the increase in the nuclear tax, more than €50 million in  this semester is also related to the increase in the eco-tax in Extremadura, which we have included  in the accounts although we have appealed and this represents another €10 million. And higher  IBERDROLA taxes related with the TUR and the commercial business, €19 million, and this has a  much greater impact to the elimination of taxes related to CO2, which in 2009 represented €96  million.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Regarding the reduction of 7.5% in the gross margin, this is a consequence of the provisional drop  in the business remuneration after the adoption of the new ministerial order last December 31.  These are provisional remunerations that are waiting for the definitive remuneration based on the  reference network model and the investments made in 2009, as stated by the Spanish Energy  Commission in its report.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Gross margin grew to 20.5% to €998 million, so thanks to a major increase in output, 21.5%. And  because of the greater operating capacity that grew 16.5% to 11,215 installed megawatts and also  because of the improvement of the wind resources in Spain and rest of the world that offsets the  drop fundamentally in the U.K.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Prices have reached €71.2 per megawatt hour. There is also a non-recurrent contribution of €36  million from the monetization of the state line wind power contract in the second trimester, offset by  the drop in the contribution of the gas business during the second quarter, because of 33 million in  negative mark to market. A growth of 16.17% in operating costs below the growth showed in the  gross margin means that EBITDA grew 21.5% to €706.6 million.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: In euros, EBITDA reduced its 47% to €771 million, after having a positive impact of 20 million,  because of the exchange rate. Wholesale and retail contributes €393 million with a drop of 16%,  mainly because of lower volumes and lower unit margins because of reduction in prices in 2009  and the high average cost of fuel. Networks provided €364 million, showing a growth of 8.1%,  derived from a growth of 10.2% in growth margin with the favorable impact of the new business  remuneration. Since the second quarter, the DPCR5, which is applied since 1st April 2010. There  also greater earnings related to the new investments made both in transmission and distribution to  connect wind generation.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: EBIT in the group grew 6.9% to €2,498 million, something lower than the growth recorded in the  EBITDA level after the increase of 22% in amortization and provisions amounting to 1,337 million.  Amortizations are €1,234 million, 15.8% more because of the increase in renewables, because of  the greater average installed power and at ScottishPower, with the effect from the appreciation of  the pound and more assets in operation in the networks area.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Additionally, environmental investments increase in the liberalized business and we also have the  liberalized business and we also have the reclassification in the distribution business. Provisions  increased by €71 million to 103 million, in an unfavorable period compared to 2009, where there  were some turnarounds.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: Production has increased by 14.2%. And all of those countries in which IBERDROLA is present  have made it possible to achieve this increase. The 21% increase of Spain is linked to the  wonderful situation of the wind business in the United States, where there has been an increase to  22% and in Latin America, this energy has grown by 9% and in the U.K., it’s been 6%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: And finally, the renewable assets in other countries have increased their production by nearly 30%.  But one of the [inaudible] of the group in recent years has to do with continuous efficiency  improvement and these results that we are presenting clearly show the effects that have been  produced by the savings actions in the different businesses. The contention of net operating  expenses that have dropped by 0.8% together with an increase in the business activities has made  it possible to improve efficiency 0.9%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are going to start the presentation of the Result for the First
texts.text: In the U.K., ScottishPower has managed to maintain flat recurrent expenses in pounds. In the  United States, expenses have been reduced by more than 8%. And renewables cost per installed  megawatt have dropped by 3%, which showed that this company is capable of carrying out an  expansion process efficiently.

file: IBE - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 21July2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moving onto comment on the main aspects for the results of the period, I would like to highlight that during the  six months of 2011, the group has continued to show very strong position from the operating point of view. During  the period, there has been a significant increase in gross margin in spite of the economic situation, an increase of  3% to €6.114 billion. The positive performance of the regulated business that reflects out of the improvements  achieved in the remuneration of the various businesses in the group and the incremental contribution of Elektro  in Brazil together with the growth in Iberdrola Renewables, whose gross margin grew by 11%, driven by the good  performance of wind power activities, the production of which has increased for the first time and has exceeded  both hydroelectric and nuclear production. That's the first time wind production has surpassed traditional  hydroelectricity and nuclear production.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The operating costs in Brazil increased mainly because of the contribution of electro. But this has been practically  offset by the lower cost in the divestment of the Connecticut gas companies carried out last year. Regarding the  liberalized business, net operating expenses increased 4% because of the increase of the costs related to the  increase in commercial activity in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, Iberdrola renewables has improved the operating cost ratio per megawatt by another 8%. The  improvement in gross margin together with cost savings has made it possible to obtain an increase of 4.4% in  EBITDA, amounting to €4 billion, and by businesses, we should highlight on the one hand, the good operations in  the regulated activity driven by the increase in gross margin and the efficiency improvements, and the worst  performance in the liberalized business affected not only by the complex operating environment in the United  Kingdom, but also by the increase in levies in Spain as a result of nuclear taxes and local levels, which in the  semester, amounted to €265 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As a consequence of all these financial management measures, the rating agencies of Moody's and Fitch have  reaffirmed the level A rating in recent months. And in the case of Moody's there has also been an improvement in  the prospects to stable. This performance in debt and in company equity make the increase in the solidity of our  balance sheet obvious. Also, the increase in operating cash flow together with the investment controls and the  collection of amounts owed because of the tariff deficit in Spain has made it possible to reduce the debt by €1.5  billion in spite of the payment for the Renewables operation.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So what we have to point in this semester, we've had variations in the consolidation perimeter. We've had the  incorporation of Elektro since May 1, which currently compensates the effects arising from the sale of the gas  companies in the United States and the electrical business in Guatemala. The net affected by type or rate of  exchange has been negative this semester as regards the EBITDA, and we have deducted €12 million due to the  devaluation of the dollar by 4.2%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The consolidation of Elektro that has provided €113 million allows us to partially compensate the €193 million of  the assets sold in the United States and Guatemala. Although we have improved the balance of the businesses  thanks to Elektro, we're losing more because of the sales of the businesses in the United States and Guatemala.  The basic margin has gone up 3% in line with gross margin, because the worth of the allocated emission rights is  the same as we had in 2010.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But talking about the liberalized business in Spain, the production levels have been reduced 12.3% basically  because the 26% slump in hydraulic production.
