However, 80% of the production is still free of emissions.  And  the average price is €60 per megawatt hour, which has given us greater margins, although we have growing  provisioning costs. And in this context, the EBITDA has grown 2.1% and now stands at €931 million because of an  improvement in the basic margin.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: 7.6%, it now has reached €1.5 billion. And although there's been nearly a 40% increase in what applies to levies  and there's a positive effect, a non-recurrent positive effect totaling €100 million related to the provisions of  previous year. And the operating expenses have grown less than the basic margin of 5.2%. And the increase of  expenses linked to high levels of activities has been compensated by the efficiency actions that have been  implemented. 98% of the production that has been estimated for 2011 is being sold above €58 per megawatt hour  and we already have sold 33 terawatt hour for 2012, above €60 megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Look, as I said, the EBITDA growth in the liberalized business has been affected by an increase of 38% in levies,  €265 million, and it represents almost 30% of this EBITDA. And effective the last two years, levies in this business  have increased by over €100 million from €158 million in the first semester of 2009 to 265. Most – up to €172  million is a result of the new nuclear taxes that together, nuclear taxes amount to €97 million. And the new taxes  seems as if they need to add more taxes, but we've already had a lot of levies added in the last two years. The rest  of the levies represent another €93 million, include the Extremadura eco levy, although we have appealed between  the Extremadura government and the Supreme Court of Justice.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBITDA in the liberalized business in the UK presents a drop of 53.7% to €182 million. This negative performance  is a result of lower margins, lower sales, and also, our non-favorable comparison with the first semester of 2010.  And sales in the retail gas area were especially good because of the favorable climate.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The basic margin had a drop of 30% in an environment of a drop in sales, as we can see on the slide. Electricity  sales dropped 4% and gas 17%, and very low spreads, with high supply costs that have not been compensated by  an equivalent increase in the sales price for electricity. There's also a low availability of the plants, which has  meant a reduction in output. However, the business is close to its turning point. We estimate that during the  second semester of the year, there will be a progressive recovery of the margins both in electricity and gas, with an  increase in the unit margin as a result of the increase in tariffs that will be applied from August 1. And this will be  especially significant, this impact, in the last quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As the Chairman said, more than the hydraulic and the nuclear output for the group, prices were €64.5 per  megawatt hour, somewhat below the €67.9 for the same period last year because of the greater weight of the  business in the U.S. Additionally, efforts have continued to control expenses and the OpEx per operating  megawatt has improved by 8%. The total EBITDA for the business grew 11.1% to €785 million. The EBITDA for  the Renewable business increased 10% to €755 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This good performance in the Renewable business contrasts with the weak contribution of the Gas business,  affected by the weakness of prices in the U.S. Although there is a positive effect in mark to market of €32 million  versus a negative impact last year of €33 million. And this makes the total EBITDA for the company €785 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Well, thanks a lot, Pepe. But to conclude, I would like to say that these results for the first semester showed, as I've  said many times before, that the industrial project of Iberdrola is capable of providing sustainable growth in the  long term for its shareholders, even though the conditions are unfavorable. It is a project that is based on the  Energy business, which provides 90% of the operating profits. And within it, in the Grids and the Renewables that  represent the EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So in both instances, we're talking about activities that are expanding very strongly, responding to the social  demands of security of supply and environmental sustainability. And I would like to underscore the important  growth perspectives in the Grid business in the States and the UK, and the investments we're going to be making  in the Transport business and the latter in the next 10 years will multiply by three our asset base. And another,  both our regulated activities are therefore of a predictable nature, especially after the regulatory improvement  achieved throughout the most recent years in all the areas in which we were present.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And based on the situation which the traditional energy business in Spain provided practically all the operating  results, 99%, the Iberdrola project in recent years has also represented the fact that we've put our stakes on the  internationalization and diversification of the business. And here, we've made our clean energy generation  capacity grow. We are a pioneer, first with the hydroelectric development and then with wind power, a technology  in which we are leaders in the world. And of course, this industrial model cannot be understood without our  approach in terms of operating efficiency, an aspect that I would even dare say, has become one of the signs of  identity to the group.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the first six months of the 2011 fiscal year, we can clearly see the effects of this industrial project. It appeared  that it has been characterized by a complex financial and operating environment. The group has carried on  improving its results. The gross margin has grown, thanks to the fact that the regulated and renewable businesses  have worked very well. And this has compensated the evolution of the liberalized business, affected by the  situation of the British market.

file: IBE - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 25July2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the first semester of 2012, all business have grown except for the liberalised and regulated business in  Spain. The liberalised business in Spain has been affected by a 24% drop in output under the Ordinary Regime, as  a result mainly of the low hydro output this year. The lower results of the regulated business is mainly a result of  the impact of the regulatory measures approved by the government on March 30. And with all this, the group  EBITDA in spite of this grew 2% to €4.087 million. What's more important is that the operating cash flow  increased 5.8%. And last year, we grew by a similar amount to €3.3 billion, contributing to the strengthening of  the liquidity position of the group, which amounts to almost €10 billion, with which we can cover our financial  needs for the coming 24 months.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As I said earlier, the diversified business model has enabled IBERDROLA to increase its EBITDA as of June 30 to  €4 billion, with a growing contribution of the regulated and renewable businesses, which is almost 75% if we  include the regulated generation in Mexico. The regulated EBITDA is 5% mostly, thanks to the integration of  Elektro since May 2011, which more than offsets the impact of the Royal Decree 13/2012 which represented €117  million less in earnings in the first semester. In renewables, there is a 12% growth in EBITDA as a result of greater  compared to the same semester last year. Finally, the liberalised business represents a drop of 4% in spite of the  improvement in the United Kingdom as a result of the worst results obtained in Spain, where the higher market  prices have not offset the drop in production.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The contribution to EBITDA from the International businesses has been a decisive factor with an increase of  13.4% during the period and with all businesses growing. And I would like to highlight that if we even discount the  contribution of Elektro, the EBITDA for the International business increased by 6.6%. On the other hand,  developments in Spain have been negative. EBITDA dropped 8.3% during this period. The regulated business had  a drop of 13% because of the regulatory measures. The liberalised business dropped its EBITDA by 10%. On the  other hand, the EBITDA for renewables in Spain grew 23%, driven by the 11% increase in wind power production,  which was favored by the positive developments in wind power resources during the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The net profits increased by 15% to €553 million. This €553 million are mainly from the International business,  and we can also highlight the change in the fiscal clause in the United States as a result of a favorable ruling from  the tax authorities and the recognition in Brazil of the possibility of deducting the goodwill in the purchasing of  Elektro. And additionally, these results include non-recurring expenses of €171 million of – because of the write- down of the investment in Gamesa and the provisions associated to wind power projects which were finally  cancelled. So the growth in net profits for the group, as I said, is fundamentally due to the contribution of the  International business, €1.363 billion, offsetting the 44% drop in the Spanish results which were up by €438  million, a fourth of the total.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding this latter aspect, in 2012 in June, the Supreme Court has passed three relevant rulings regarding the  claims made by solar producer associations. The last of these in June confirms the possibility of modifying the  remuneration framework under the special regime in order to maintain reasonable profitability criteria according  clauses that have effected in the past should not be deployed that will have an effect on future results. And again,  the ruling also said, if the new economic circumstances imply adjustments in many other production sectors with  obvious difficulties for their activity, it is not unreasonable that those also extend to the renewable energy sector  and that wished to continue to receive the regulated tariffs instead of resorting to the market mechanisms, and  more so before situations of a generalized economic crisis. And in the case of power, in view of the growth of the  tariff deficit, it rises from the impact of the calculation of the access tolls which has an effect on the cost of the  power system.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And finally, the text also says that it's logical that faced with any technological modification or before significant  changes in the economic situation, the initial determining parameters need to be reviewed in order to calculate the  regulated tariff. And the aspect of legal certainty cannot oppose this principle. Therefore, the Supreme Court  rejects the possibility of maintaining an unmodifiable economic regime and refers to the economic circumstances  and the technological maturity in the same way that this occurs in the United States remuneration regime to avoid  unreasonable returns, although the Americans do not talk about retroactivity, but about a remuneration  adjustment. And it's well known that the President of the government is a prudent, honest and a man with  common sense, and he's having to make brave decisions at this difficult time. Therefore, I trust that he's going to  do everything that is necessary to put an end to this scourge of the tariff deficit and, as he said, through a model  that will be economically and environmentally sustainable. So it doesn't seem reasonable to have a cheap power  station shutdown. While power stations are in production, the energy of which costs us seven or eight times more,  such as the case of some solar plants. So as I said, the deficit problem will only be solved by acting on the factors  that caused it and not on those that are outside the area.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the United Kingdom, on the other hand, important steps have been taken in defining a predictable and stable  regulatory framework for some of the sector activities. In the grid business, we have regulatory stability, both  transmission and distribution, with tariff frameworks that will be enforced up to 2015 and 2021 respectively, thus  ensuring a sufficient and predictable remuneration for the planned investments which in our case amount to –  close to €6 billion over the coming years. However, it is necessary to still complete the definition of the regulatory  framework for the generation activity in order to offer an adequate remuneration that will provide incentives for  the major investment required to replace the obsolete current generation facilities. And in this sense, we need to  continue with the reform of the electric power market to establish a sufficient remuneration framework, both for  our nuclear and combined gas plants, and renewable plants as of 2014. In the case of renewable plants, they have  a transient period between 2013 and 2017, and the remuneration framework called Renewables Obligation  Banding Review has been made public today with a sufficient remuneration adapted to the degree of technological  maturity, as we have defended over the last few months.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you very much, Chairman. Good morning. As we can see and as the Chairman said, in spite of the difficult  economic conditions that we are going through in Europe, the group continues to grow in its operating lines and  cash flow. Elektro contributed to the results in the first half of 2012. Last year, it contributed since the month of  May and the exchange rate is also favorable since 53% of the EBITDA in these first six months is outside the  Eurozone, which is an important characteristic in this group. Therefore, we've been favored by the revaluation of  the dollar and the pound although we are partially affected by the devaluation of the real. And as the Chairman  said, there are non-recurrent items that have an impact on net profit and the details of which I'll give later on.  Sales increased 9.3% to €16.992 billion and purchasing 14% to €10.595 billion. The gross margin grew 3.2% to  €6.309 billion, including a positive impact of €112 million due to the exchange rate. Excluding this effect, the  businesses contributed a further €83 million. The main items responsible for this growth are Renewable and  regulated businesses and especially the International business. Our growth is 9.1% in the UK, 9.7% in the United  States and 41% in Brazil, with the greater contribution of Elektro. Renewables grew 9.1% in gross margin. This  offsets the weak performance of the business in Spain, showing reductions in the gross margin, both in the  liberalised business, 11.8%, and the regulated business, 8.3%, because of the lower output and regulatory impact.  The 2.3% increase because of the increase in emission rights assigned has fallen by 46% because of the lower  price. The net operating cost grew 5.7%. The consolidation of Elektro continues to have an unfavorable impact  since it's being consolidated since May 2011. The exchange rate has increased the net operating cost by €32  million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And starting off now with the liberalised business in Spain, demand in Spain has fallen 0.3% although it's 1.5%  when adjusted. The ordinary regime production figures have been reduced by 24.4% as a consequence of a drop of  57.1% in high-quality production and more than 67% in combined cycle production that has been partially offset  by an increase in nuclear power and coal, although we have very little in Spain. Prices have gone up a little bit also  because of the generation mix and they now stand about €60.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBITDA in Mexico has grown 8.4% and now stands at €131 million. The rate of exchange has added another €13  million to the EBITDA and the gross margin grows 10.6%. And the evolution of the business after excluding the  exchange rate effect is also positive because of the heat breaks and because of the increases in plant capacity,  although there have been some shutdowns. There are also some non-recurrent maintenance costs, which have  penalized the net operating expenses in such amounts that the EBITDA has grown somewhat less than the growth  we've had in the – the growth in the gross margin. EBITDA in our renewables business has grown 12.2%. And this  is thanks to a very good second quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the whole, production grows 12.6% with an average load factor of 28.7%, which improved 27.4% of the same  periods of previous fiscal year, which means that the EBITDA of the wind business has grown 19.7%. The average  price also has gone up, up to €69.1 per megawatt hour because of the change, because of the modifications of the  rate of exchange. Operating capacity now stands at 13,560 megawatts and installed capacity has reached 14,171  megawatts.  Operating expenses have improved with a drop of 0.9%, because we've had less non-recurrent expenses. And  efficiency improvements also show that the GON megawatt ratio has improved to 4%. The EBIT of the group has  dropped 3.3%, which has a worse evolution than EBITDA because of an increase of 142% in provisions,  fundamentally linked to the integration of Elektro and some non-recurrent provisions basically in Brazil, and  other measures that have to do with promotion of the pipeline as the President pointed out, which affects the  United States and which reached €44 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So on the whole, non-recurrent provisions are for Brazil as well as of the pipeline, represents something like €100  million. And an increase of 4.6% in amortizations is due to the integration of Elektro and also because there are  larger amortizations brought about by investments in the grid. And this has been in part compensated by the  extended life cycle of the wind farms. And we can also see that there has been a negative impact produced by the  rate of exchange in terms of provisions and amortizations. The net financial results have grown 17%. And this17%  increase is due to two factors; firstly, because there's a lower market value of the hedging factors for rate to  exchange, because last year the dollar and the pound were devalued vis-à-vis the euro, whereas this year it has  been just the opposite, and this lower market value is something you can see in the financial costs; and secondly,  because there's been – there have been more financial expenses because of the greater average of debt relative to  the first semester of the previous fiscal year.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Secondly, because there's been a greater cost of the debt after integrating Elektro, so we can say that the cost of the  debt has hardly changed relative to the previous year. And the reported net profits have grown 15.2% and now  stand at €1.8 billion because of the impact of positive non-recurrence at a fiscal level, partially compensated by  measures taken in terms of provisions and in terms of consolidation by the equity method. So now, we're talking  about €1.4 billion. We've also taken measures in relation to assets totaling €171 million related to the cost of  developing renewables. And secondly, we've also taken actions in relation to the Gamesa portfolio that has to do  with the equity method. We have included another €127 billion in the book, and we consider that the prospects  arising from the analysis are positive as regards the business in the future.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So with this, what we want to do is reduce our level of indebtedness and we want to go on improving – as the  Financial Director said, we want to improve the financial ratios and the liquidity position of the company in order  to be able to maintain our remuneration policy to the shareholder, as we've done in recent years. So, these are  going to be the basic elements of our upcoming strategic approach that we will present on the Investors Day and  we will send out the call once we've – once the reform of the electricity sector has been presented in Spain. And  you can be sure that all of us people working for this company will do whatever is required to carry on improving  our results in the future.

file: IBE - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 24July2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Group performance throughout the first half of the year has led us to offset the impact of the sharp increase in  levies during the period, mainly fiscal measures for energy sustainability in Spain and energy efficiency programs  in the United Kingdom, thus the recurring net profit rose 2.8% to €1.4 billion. It is worth mentioning the good  operational performance of our businesses as shown in the gross margin with a 5.8% increase to almost €6.7  billion.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But Iberdrola has also made further progress toward its net reduction commitment with a decrease of more than  €3 billion compared to June 2012, despite having to continue financing almost €2.2 billion in tariff deficit. Firstly,  debt reduction has been possible. Thanks to the receipt of payment of divestments agreed in previous quarters, as  has been the case with our stake in Medgaz pipeline and wind farms in France. And we have, secondly, the closure  of additional sales of non-core assets, such as the Chilean hydro plant in Lican. Thus far, we have completed  transactions with €1.2 billion of ongoing divestment plan, with €800 million having already been received.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As I said, the gross margin rose 5.8% in the first half of the year to almost €6.7 billion. Despite the fall in demand,  a 2.5% rise in Group production has contributed to this result. I would like to stress the fact that the 71,000  gigawatt hour produced 57% are completely emission free. And in Spain, this percentage is up to 92%. This has  allowed a 50% reduction of emissions, which at the end of the first half represent 227 grams per kilowatt hour,  which is more than 30% below our European peers' average.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Nevertheless, all this has been offset by the sharp increase in levies which as of June 30, 2013, amounted to €863  million, which is 79% higher than the same period of the previous year. This is mainly due to the introduction of  local taxes in Spain that impact both traditional and renewable technologies and the energy efficiency programs in  the United Kingdom.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As a result, the EBITDA remained similar to that obtained in the previous year and amounts to more than €4  billion. The regulated business provided 76% of the total, which is an increase of 2.4% versus 7.2% fall in non- regulated businesses. Thus, renewables EBITDA has grown by 10.5%, thanks to a 10.1% increase in production,  particularly in Spain and the United Kingdom, exceeding the average increase in installed capacity.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBITDA in grids fell slightly by 0.8%, mainly due to both the impact of tariff review for our distribution  companies in Brazil, and the extra charges for electricity supply as a consequence of the drought in the country. In  the generation and supply business, EBITDA has decreased by 6.1% despite a 12.4% increase in gross margin. This  is due to the increase in levies, which for this particular business, are 145% higher than those in the first half of  2012.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: To the Group's operational performance in the period, we have to add solid financial management, thanks to  which recurring net profit has increased 2.8% to €1.4 billion. Finally, net profit amounts to €1.7 billion, registering  a 2% decline compared to the same period of the previous year. This result includes a provision on the value of our  investments in gas and renewable activities in the United States and Canada, resulting from narrowing margins in  gas storage as a consequence of the rapid development of shale gas in the country, which also has an impact on the  renewables market. In that sense, we have concentrated our assets in the United States on those with better  prospects for growth. On the other hand, various Spanish companies with the Group have decided to carry out  asset-value adjustments according to Law 16/2012 of December 27 with a positive after-tax effect, as the CFO will  later explain.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And these measures include an extension of the State's guarantee by €4 billion to cover the extra 2012 deficit to be  securitized in the next few weeks. However, the scope of this package of measures has some limitations for failing  to take into account basic elements of energy policy such as economic and environmental target, demand  forecasts, the planning of network infrastructures, or definition of the target energy mix.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moreover, and in order to remove the tariff deficit, the solution proposed requires unequal efforts that burden the  parties who are neither responsible for generating the problem nor for planning it. Because the real problem of the  Spanish electricity sector is, on the one hand, the exponential increase of incentives to immature and inefficient  technologies, such as solar power plants, which contribute only 4% of the total energy mix, while resulting in a  30% increase of the total energy cost for the system; and on the other hand, the inclusion of items that have  nothing to do with the supply in the electricity bill.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Secretary of State for Energy recently gave a speech in which he stated and I quote, "Electricity in Spain is  expensive due to a series of energy policy decisions taken in the past decade, which have burdened the system with  costs it should not assume in relation to the development of solar technologies, when these were still not mature  enough." The Secretary of State also stated that in Spain, and I'm quoting him again, "We have invested at a time  we shouldn't have and in a way we shouldn't have. The country has paid the learning curve for the rest of the  world." In his opinion, the measures adapted in the past in order to boost these technologies, and this is another  quote, "have meant the transfer of revenues from consumers towards specific technologies or policies."

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Likewise, the Minister for Industry, Energy and Tourism recently stated, I quote, "That in Spain, the average price  to produce 1 megawatt hour is €50. If energy is produced through solar technology, the average price is €450. We  all pay the difference through the electricity bill." And that was a quote. Therefore, the solution to the problem is  to be found within the factors which are creating it, avoiding transfer in revenues from the more efficient to the  more inefficient sectors. In that sense, in accordance to the statements, it doesn't seem to be reasonable to  proceed with the closing or decommissioning of facilities that operate at €50 at the expense of those which  operate at €450. On the other hand, this should not increase the obligations we have.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the other hand, the new package of measures establishes returns, regulated activities which are insufficient or  lower than the cost of capital. Thus, investment is discouraged in the sector such as distribution and employment  intensive sector of a highly qualified workforce with public service obligations. This is not the case in other  countries, where the development of these infrastructures is encouraged, thus, promoting investments both in  upgrades and in the extension of the grid, which results in higher energy efficiency levels, a better service and, in  the long run, lower costs of supply. But in any case, the government will have to make an effort to establish a  dialogue with all the stakeholders and during the approval process of the bill in order to correct some of the  shortcomings I've just described.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As regards generation, the electricity market reform process continues with the aim of establishing the sufficient  remuneration scheme for new capacity to be built. Although a system of options has been established for capacity  payments that will start in 2014, it would be necessary to stop imposing non-supply cost applications onto agents  which, in the long term, will increase the electricity bill.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As regards renewable technologies, in the UK, there is a regulatory stability with remuneration defined until  March 2017 and a new 15-year framework based on Contracts for Difference with the strike prices already set by  the administration and which will be adjusted for inflation. Although first impressions are that this is just a  regime of adjusted prices, especially for offshore wind, we hope that the consultation process will allow for  sufficient profitability to ensure the development of these technologies.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Good morning, everyone. The proposal to change the system that regulates the Spanish electricity sector is being  implemented in a Royal Decree Law that has already been passed, a draft electricity sector bill and proposals for a  further seven royal decrees, a ministerial order regarding transmission and distribution charges, and three  ministerial orders. I'm going to try to be brief at discussing this package, but I doubt I'll be successful.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: There are two basic reasons for the existence of a structural deficit in the electricity tariff first since 2005. On the  one hand, cost derived from social policies defined by the government and entirely unrelated to the cost of supply  will transfer to the sector's costs. Some examples of this were the support provided to insular electricity systems,  government policy backing Spanish coal, bonuses for disadvantaged consumers, et cetera.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the other hand, the government applied inefficient regulatory measures such as those that followed the  application of excessive incentives to non-mature renewable technologies and poor management in developing  energy policies, in the light of the high penetration achieved by renewable energies.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As for the second least positive aspect of the reform, I believe that the regulation system is the fundamental tool  that enables the regulatory institutions to vouch for the effective application of a particular energy policy. And in  the midst of all the regulatory changes that are referred, I find it striking that the energy policy to be implemented  in the country from now on has not been defined. In fact, I believe that many of the measures, which I will now  comment on in greater detail, are actually at odds with the energy targets already being set in the majority of  European countries and which the European community will very soon be defining for the 2030 horizon.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: If we analyze the entire period since the tariff deficit took on structural status in 2005 until this year, we will find  that the various governments have gradually reduced the companies' income figures in more or less orthodox  ways but always with the goal of reducing costs that would allow them to remove the deficit, although this was not  in fact achieved. Measures such as allocating operators the second part of the nuclear fuel cycle, reducing income  through the allocation of CO2 emission rates free of charge, et cetera. And these have required that the companies  provide in excess of €19 billion. The vast majority of these costs have been borne by the traditional activities in the  sector such as generation under the ordinary regime or distribution, with almost €17 billion in total. Iberdrola's  cumulative contribution to-date towards reducing the tariff deficit amounts to €5.3 billion.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Remuneration scheme for renewables. The Royal Decree regulating remuneration for renewable energies,  cogeneration and waste management maintains many of the aspects already regulated by the old Royal Decree 661  such as the classification of facilities, priority and access to the market, the need for a registration with control  centers, et cetera.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: However, it has done away with the incentive for reactive power but maintains the penalties for non-compliance.  And it has also done away with the incentive for efficiency at cogeneration plants. And all this may mean a drop in  remuneration of some €3 per megawatt hour. It also provides for the creation of a new register in addition to the  administrative register that is already in operation to contain the information needed to decide on the  remuneration for each facility. The remuneration scheme is described in the Royal Decree which is 92 pages long.  It is extremely complicated, and at the moment, as I will go on to explain, it is not possible for us to make even an  approximate assessment of the remuneration that may be expected for each of the technologies.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: First of all, it provides that the facilities that used to receive some form of incentive in the past will be able to hold  on to a grant if necessary to guarantee a rate of return on assets of 7.5% before taxes for the remainder of the  lifetime of the project. It is hard to interpret how the excess or shortfall in the rate of return obtained by facilities  already in operation will be calculated. We would do well to remember that the economic report that accompanied  Royal Decree 661 of 2007, which has now been cancelled by this Royal Decree and the renewable energy action  plan for 2005, 2010 that preceded it, both refer to the principle of a reasonable rate of return. And the government  itself estimates that the reasonable rate of return should be between 7% and 8% after tax in relation to the net  asset value.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: To calculate the rate of return for each facility, standard cost will be defined. I presume these will be linked to  investment costs, operating and maintenance costs, and market prices. It is my understanding that income  received is not liable to standardization because it depends on the availability of the renewable source, which is  something entirely unrelated to how the company is managed.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: We continue with the remuneration for renewables. The parameters that are needed in order to redo all these  calculations will be defined in a Ministerial order classified according to type of technology, capacity, years in  operation, electricity system, et cetera. And some of these parameters may be reviewed every three years with  incentives being changed after every six years.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Once the standard costs have been defined, which is not yet the case, the rate of return for each facility will then be  calculated on the basis of the remaining lifetime, depending on the estimated costs of the market price. In my  opinion, to base the remuneration payable to a facility on the basic detail of the price of energy for the remaining  lifetime of that facility, 10, 15, 20 or 25 years is an absolutely arbitrary decision.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I'm going to move on to comment on the remuneration for the distribution activity. The Royal Decree Law  provides a provisional methodology for 2013 and 2014 with a regulated asset value based on the implicit RAB  recently calculated by the Spanish National Energy Commission.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Three negative comments regarding the approach to remuneration to distribution in the Royal Decree; first of all,  the Royal Decree considers that the technological and operational risk associated to the activity of distribution is  lower than for renewable activities. And to be more specific, it claims that this is much lower than in the case of  renewable energies, and that is the reason why the remuneration for this asset is being reduced by 100 basis  points, which entails a drop in remuneration of over 13%.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I don't personally understand how the risks have been measured, but it strikes me that there must be some  mistake. The distribution activity in itself is facing major changes in terms of technology and management with  the investments planned in smart grids, management of distributed energy, compact substations, all of these  represent a considerable technological risk, which is going to be required aside from the significant economic  resources that this process of change will require, and it's tough. And there are also significant operational risks in  terms of logistics, storms, flooding, et cetera. I don't exactly know which risks have been taken into account in the  evaluation of the risk related to renewable activities. I hope that this measure will be corrected in the short-term.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And it is almost immediately apparent that the WACC in Spain should be between 9% and 10% before tax.  Therefore, the proposed rate of return destroys 300 basis points of value. The Royal Decree seems to have  forgotten all of these, putting across the message that we should get into as much debt as possible and that we  shouldn't invest. It's also overlooking another obligation that is guaranteeing the economic financial sustainability  of the business. And I don't think that this remuneration will guarantee this sustainability. This, again, is a very  serious regulatory failure. And the impact for Iberdrola in 2013 is estimated to amount to some €115 million, a  similar figure expected for 2014. And I'll finish with this distribution activity.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Distribution constitutes an irreplaceable link in the electricity supply chain, and it is inconceivable for regulations  not to guarantee economically sustainable development of this activity. To hold the activity of distribution for so  long will have severely detrimental consequences for the country, which will take a long time to offset.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moreover, the distribution activity all over the world is facing a very significant and highly costly technological  overhaul in order to enable distributed generation, self-consumption, provide incentives for improving efficiency,  investing in smart grids, et cetera. This paralyzation will also have a negative impact on the Spanish  manufacturers of equipment and services, some of which are world leaders in technology. And this will probably  unnecessarily lead to higher unemployment levels.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I'm now going to move on to capacity payments. The capacity payment was initially set up to remunerate the fixed  capacity that each facility made available to the system operator. And this was assessed at just over €40,000 per  megawatt year. This figure was then reduced to €26,000 per megawatt, a 35% drop. And now, it is being reduced  yet again by a further 60%, down to €10,000 per megawatt, only applied to the case of combined-cycle power  plants.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: These reductions were made coinciding with the time that the system needed more fixed capacity guarantees. This  paradox is one of the consequences of changing the regulations without having an overarching energy plan for  guidance purposes. The Royal Decree proposal regulating this incentive on investments for future power plants,  which will come into line in 2017, will be based on the results of wholesale market auctions launched by the  system operator depending on prospective 10-year analysis and possible non-compliance with the coverage rate  below a particular threshold for the new capacity over the following four years.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The environmental targets to which all the member states of the European Union have committed with a view to  reducing CO2 emissions and increasing output with renewable energies, and the targets that EU is likely to  impose for the 2030 horizon means that a significant increase in output from renewable energies in Europe may  be predicted.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This reality is being acknowledged in the energy policies of most member states and even the European itself,  which was reluctant to considering capacity payments as an unjustified intervention on the market. And it is now  reconsidering its position. Countries like the UK, Germany, France and Italy are defining capacity payment  systems, and they are likely to be set up in the rest of the European countries as well. Since combined cycle power  plants are going to be guaranteeing power capacity and they're going to be in operation for a very short number of  hours, these capacity payments will tend to ensure that a significant proportion of these facilities' fixed overheads  are covered.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: To reduce capacity payments in Spain, as proposed in this Royal Decree, would be at cross purposes. If Spanish  energy policy is to be based on a significant contribution from renewable energies, it is going to need even more  than – in other European countries, a firm capacity contributed by the combined cycle power plants. And this  measure is at odds with the decisions being made by all of the countries in Europe in this regard. The impact for  Iberdrola in 2013 of this measure will be around €40 million that will rise to €50 million in 2014.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As well as the incentives of future investments, the Royal Decree also regulates the possibility of temporary  closure of facilities, referred to as hibernation. The total amount of power for hibernation, some 6,000 megawatts  according to the ministry, will be defined by the system operator. And this amount will be allocated to the various  operators by means of an auction procedure for which only the combined cycle power plants can sign up.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Well, this new Royal Decree, once again, raises the issue of the social bonus being funded by companies. Providing  that this will be allocated to vertically integrated business groups, that is, once again, the UNESA member  companies, and the distribution will be dependent on points of supply and a number of retail consumers. I believe  that the system for funding the social bonus is, once again, being based on insufficiently justified and  discriminatory measures.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Economic impact. Despite the limited time that we have had to analyze all the proposed changes, all these pages  weigh 5 kilos, and the lack of information available in some cases, it is possible to reach some initial conclusions  regarding the possible economic impact of the package of measures as a whole. The adjustment of risk range in  Iberdrola for all of the efforts required is around €170 million in 2013 according to the company's current forecast  for 2013. And without including the adjustments to Iberdrola's renewable energies, this figure will be increased by  a further €90 million in 2014.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moreover, the economic sustainability measures that are expected to be introduced guarantee that if the  temporary or cyclical deficits exceed 2.5% of the total regulated income or if the cumulative deficit exceeds 10% of  this income, the excess tariffs will be automatically adjusted. And I think that this will guarantee the problem –  guarantee that the problem of the deficit will no longer persist.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This means that we have missed a wonderful opportunity to achieve a form of sectorial regulation in keeping with  the goals of our country's energy policy. This would have allowed us to tackle the huge technological challenges  facing this sector in the coming years with greater guarantees. For example, distributed energy, self-consumption,  penetration of renewables, smart grids, change in functionality of combined-cycle power plants and energy  efficiency measures. And that's all. Thank you very much.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you, José Luis, I'm going to move on quickly to the results, the most outstanding point is the increase in  2.8% in recurring net profit. However, we have to point out that regarding the EBIT, there has been a drop of  65.3% due to the inclusion of €1.657 billion gross because of the write-off basically of gas and renewable assets as  I'll detail later on. €1.538 billion are also included from the positive tax impact in the revaluation of the balance  sheet, which the Iberdrola Group has undertaken as I shall also explain.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Which in terms of comparison, the net profit for 2012 re-expressed under these conditions is €1.763 billion versus  €1.8 billion that Iberdrola declared or reported at the end of 2012. The sales figure fell 0.9% to $16.836 billion  (sic) [€16.836 billion] and procurement 4.9% to €10.160 billion due to the lower cost of the production mix  because of the higher hydraulic and wind power production in the year.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Consequently, the gross margin grew 5.8% to €6.676 billion with a negative impact because of the exchange rate  of €113 million and another €60 million because of the loss of the free CO2 allowances with all businesses in  countries providing growth except Brazil.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The net operating expense improved 2.2%, thanks to the efficiency plans that the group is carrying out and  including €35 million positive impact because of the exchange rate. The efficiency measures represent a reduction  of 0.8% in personnel expenses and a drop in net external services of 3.5%. The levies paid by the company grew  80% to €864 million. The business in Spain carries €291 million in levies, of which €252 million correspond to  the tax measures for energy sustainability that the government approved in 2012. Regarding the gross margin,  there are also more than €5 million in taxes because of the green tax.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Additionally, there are €48 million in the unfavorable comparison with 2012 since this included €100 million  from the reimbursement of the social bonus. And this is not offset this year by the €52 million in positive impact  from the reversion of the green tax in Castilla-La Mancha. The business in the UK had €95 million more in levies  because of the energy efficiency program in 2013 versus 2012, where 75% was charged to the second half of the  year. Consequently, the comparison will improve in the second semester.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And because of the drought effects with an added thermal cost with an impact of €47 million, of which €43 million  will be recovered in the annual tariff review. The GON improves 3% due to energy efficiency improvements and  positive impacts in the United States, which offset a negative adjustment in the United Kingdom of €30 million  and a limited GON growth in Brazil because of the greater demand and inflation.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The operating improvements as results of hydrology in Spain and a greater customer base in the UK have offset  the effects of demand weakness in Spain, a drop of 3.8%, which, if adjusted, is 2.6% and the absence of free CO2  allowances, and this takes us to an increase in gross margin of 12%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, in particular, the gross margin grew by 13.9%, thanks to the fact that production has been 5.1% higher  because of the increase of 110% in hydraulic production, which offsets the lower thermal production, 67% less;  and UK production, 6.9% less. Additionally, the margins have increased due to lower costs associated to a  production mix in hydraulic-production context.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, gross margin grew 12.7% because of a greater customer base, representing 8%, a more favorable  climate for the business, and the increase in tariffs to recover the greater non-energy costs suffered by the UK such  as the efficiency programs, the disappearance of CO, the price for additional costs for transmission and  distribution.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The EBITDA for the Renewable business grew 10.5% to €937 million as a result of greater production, 10% more,  which increases the gross margin, 12.5%, and cost control with a reduction of 4% in net operating costs. This good  development has made it possible to offset levy increases, which, in Spain, multiplied by four. We went from €17  million to €70 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The operating capacity increased 3.5% to 14,028 megawatts, and the average load factor increased – improved 1.9  percentage points to 30.6%. This means an increase in output of 7%. And the average price increased 1.7% to  €69.9 per megawatt hour in spite of a reduction of 3.5% in the final price in Spain basically because of the change  in the regulator tariff according to Royal Decree 2/2013, which is offset by an increase in prices in the rest of the  geographic areas.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The group EBIT, as I said, fell 64% due to the inclusion of €1.657 billion more as non-recurrent provisions, mainly  related to write-offs for gas assets in the United States and Canada and renewables particularly in the United  States. In the case of gas assets, it is accepted that the business will not continue to grow for the time being. And  therefore, the whole pipeline is being provisioned, as well as the goodwill funds paid out in a day when the  business was more valuable before the appearance of shale gas. In the case of renewables, that has just been  adjusted to the pipeline regarding more modest growth that was expected because of the low energy prices in the  United States.

file: IBE - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 23July2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation & Supply has had a very good performance through the semester with an increase of 27% in EBITDA  reaching €1,452 million. Higher production with a more efficient generation mix together with the positive  contribution of the businesses has made it possible. Discounting the one-off of the ruling in a Spanish court of the  CO2 emission rights, another non-operational aspect underlying EBITDA increases over 23% in the period.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, as you all know, the Renewable business has been heavily impacted by regulatory modification in Spain,  where despite a solid load factor, EBITDA has fall 46% versus first half of 2013. The other impact of changes  introducing the global renewable business is a 25.4% fall in EBITDA, but thanks to the international renewable  businesses, we have a strong contribution with 80% increase in Latin America, 8% in the United States and 11%  United Kingdom, with the offshore business providing half of that increase. The EBITDA for Renewable drops  20.3%. The result of Renewable businesses are likely to improve by the year-end, given that no significant changes  to regulation are expected in the second part of the year and market prices will normalize after very low level  during the first semester in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Next, I will briefly go over the main regulatory highlights which show increase in visibility in the geographic areas  where we operate. In Spain, uncertainty on regulation has been cleared as the reform of renewable has been  concluded.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, as you know, we feel confident about the business opportunities with large private consumers the  Energy Reform is going to offer. The secondary legislation of the Electricity Bill has been already passed by the  Senate and the final Congressional approval is expected in August. According to the Bill, a liberalized market will  be progressively created for qualified customers with the level of consumption about 1 megawatts, managed by the  new independent operator. We also positively value of the fact that the private agents will be allowed to invest in  several transmission and distribution activities under certain conditions.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And finally, Brazil, the regulator is already implementing timely and effectively the necessary measures to  compensate the drought impact on distribution companies, both through injection of funds from the treasury and  tariff increases which have reached 35% interim basis.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The result we have presented today together with the trends expected for second semester allow us to feel  confident about our previous guidance for the end of the year. In Networks, we do not expect any additional  changes to regulation. Additionally, the impact of drought in Brazil on result is expected to be progressively  recovered through tariff increases and additional injection of the funds by the treasury.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now, this general regulatory impact is expected in Renewables, and under standard condition results in second  semester should be in line with previous years.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The full year incremental regulatory impact versus 2013 at gross margin is estimated at €367 million. So the  estimated full 2014 impact will be around €643 million, 56% due to Renewables. I would like to stress that the  impact in the second half of the year should be similar to the one accounted for in the 2013 second half, as  regulatory cuts started to be accounted in July 2013.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation business in total has an impact of €609 million. Taxes and green cent derived from the Law 15/2012.  Capacity payments and cogeneration derived from the Royal Decree 9/2013. Distribution business has an impact  of €345 million, including €112 million from Royal Decree 2013 and €233 million coming from the Royal Decree  2012, Renewables business, €363 million and the social bonus minus €70 million (sic) [€78 million] at the  holding level. So as I mentioned, €1.4 billion is the total impact for the Group of the regulatory cuts in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The comparison versus 2013 first half results is positively affected at the EBIT level by asset impairments carried  in the second quarter of last year mainly related to U.S. gas and renewables, €1.6 billion negative. And positively,  the tax level due to the first half 2013 balance sheet revaluation that had a positive impact of €1.5 billion.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies fell by 13.7% to €737 million due to the reduction in the UK as a consequence of the ECO program  extension and a favorable High Court ruling in Spain accounted for in the second quarter of 2014 for €111 million  linked to legal actions initiated by Iberdrola when the previous government penalized the emission-free  technologies forcing to pay CO2 costs.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Brazil, EBITDA fell 52% as a consequence of 33% decrease in gross margin due to lower compensation on a  higher drought impact that will be recovered from August onwards with the new tariff review. Net operating  expenses fell 10% and levies 3%. The 18% exchange rate fall has reduced also the EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA grew almost 40% with a 42% increase in gross margin due to the 13% higher output after a 37%  increase in hydro, a 3.9% increase in nuclear production, more than compensating the 23% lower thermal  production. As a consequence, margins have improved despite €5 lower prices on average. The gas business at  €132 million due to the excellent trading activity and a positive one-off. In addition, the gross margin growth, net  operating expenses improved 0.6% and levies decreased 20% due to the already mentioned €111 million positive  court ruling.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, EBITDA fell 26% due to a negative one-off impact associated to the renegotiation of private contracts  adapting them to new and more favorable conditions. In the U.S., EBITDA is €46 million higher taking advantage  of the extreme weather conditions during the first quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA fell by 20% to €712 million due to 46% decrease in the Spanish EBITDA, affected by the  remuneration cuts of the Spanish regulatory measures and the lower spot prices. As to the geographical  diversification of the business, the positive contribution of the rest of the geographies partially compensate the  mentioned fall in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Spain EBITDA declined 46% as explained previously. The UK EBITDA grew 11% with a 13% increase in gross  margin, with a 7% increase in ARPU, more than compensated the lower average price due to energy and watt price  reduction. Offshore wind farms started contributing to the second quarter EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The U.S. EBITDA grew 8% or 12.4% excluding the FX impact, with a 5.7% increase in gross margin thanks to the  higher average price and trading profits taking advantage of weather conditions.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Latin America, EBITDA rose 80%, thanks to a 34% increase in output due to the increasing installed capacity in  Mexico, 11% and in Brazil, 97%. Rest of the World EBITDA decreased 41% due to the sale of Polish wind farms in  2013.

file: IBE - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 22July2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As I previously mentioned EBITDA has grown by 5.7% boosted by the solid performance of regulated activities  despite €111 million positive one-off recorded in 2014 due to a Spanish High Court ruling on CO2 allowances.  Excluding this impact, EBITDA is up by 9.1%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Renewables businesses also show a very good performance with EBITDA having increased by almost 19%;  thanks to a good output in Mexico, Brazil and United Kingdom, where our offshore wind farm at West of Duddon  Sands is included for the first time in the year on comparisons.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, Generation & Supply EBITDA has decreased 11.7% due to the extraordinary good result recorded in 2014  as a consequence of the referred positive one-off for CO2 allowances. No recurring impact recorded in gas  businesses and extraordinary hydro production for last year in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thus, investments have increased 0.7% to €1.3 billion, of which more than half had been allocated to ongoing  growth projects including more than 2,500 megawatt of offshore and onshore wind farms spread across most of  the main markets; 7 60 megawatt of combined cycle and cogeneration plant with long-term contract in Mexico,  almost 1,200 megawatt of hydroelectric pumping-storage plant in Portugal and Spain; a numerous distribution  and transmission project in UK, Spain and United States. Additionally, we have continued investing through our  Brazilian subsidiary in networks, new hydroelectric plants: Baixo Iguaçu, Teles Pires and Belo Monte and several  wind farms. Altogether, we estimate to maintain investment levels of around €4 billion per year mostly in growth.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We will now give a brief overview of the regulatory situation in our main geographic areas. Starting with United  Kingdom, the competition in market authority has recorded – recently published its preliminary finding and  recommendation on the fusioning of the energy sector. Regarding the generation and wholesale market, the CMA  does not identify in general terms major competition concern. As for the retail market, the regulator proposed  strong measures encouraging a more active participation by consumers in line with our [ph] convention (6:05)  that a well designed market is the most effective and efficient model for the retail activity. We will support any  proposal that may improve customer engagement and competition in the energy supply. In the following months,  we will continue collaborating with CMA in order to complete this process.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With respect to renewable businesses, the UK government has announced the early closure of Renewable  Obligation Certificate for new capacity for April 2016. Giving the 12 months grace period granted, this measure  has very limited impact in our almost 500 megawatt onshore wind farm in construction, and it has no effect in our  offshore wind farm of East Anglia One.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also in UK government had recently announced the removal of the Levy Exemption Certificates for renewables  from August 1, 2015. However, the impact of this measure will be offset by the also announced reduction of the   corporation tax rate from their current 20% to 19% in 2017 and 18% in 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Spain, the proposed unitary costs for remuneration of the distribution activity were published last week,  consolidating current remuneration eliminating uncertainty over this matter. In addition, there is a draft under  consultation that provides a general regulatory framework for sales generation of electricity.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With regards to Europe, Parliament has recently approved the implementation of the Market Stability Reserve  scheduled to begin in January 2019. This will reinforce the role of the carbon market as the most efficient way to  support the necessary change toward a low carbon economy. Also, the European Commission has proposed a  review of the Emission Trading System directive in order to secure the contribution of all sectors to the carbon  emission reduction goals by 2030. Additionally, last week, the European Commission publishes a proposal to  deliver a new deal for energy consumers.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Every sign of electricity market intensifying the cooperation between members state for an integrated and more  competitive system, and defining the security of supply at the European level. Following a public consultation up  to October, the Commission will prepare legislative proposal in the sec ond half of 2016. The second  communication refers to the retail market. It highlights that the role of the consumer and the importance of  demand management in the smart grids. Additionally, it states the charges must be designed to allocate system  cost fairly and equitably, and that the implementation of efficient renewables support has to be done in a  transparent way.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the United States, the application for the new rate case in the state of New Y ork was filed in May. We expect it's  coming to effect from April 26, 2016 from both Rochester Gas & Electric and New Y ork State Electric and Gas  Corporation. Also in New Y ork, the regulatory commission has published a roadmap for the implementation of the  New Y ork State Energy Plan, which includes a program to adapt the distribution activity to new technological  development, and to promote renewables energies with a goal to reducing CO2 emission to 40% in 2030, versus  1990 levels.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Mexico, the government has progressed with a required regulatory deployment of e nergy reform, which  provides significant opportunities for investment in the sector. In this sense, we are progressing to reach an  agreement with the Comisión Federal de Electricidad Energia, CFE, for the joint development of electricity and  gas project.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Furthermore, the Secretary of Energy recently presented a program of development of the National Electricity  System, a master plan for the next 15 years, which aimed to improve the quality of service, reduce the generation  cost, and promote renewable energy projects. According to this document, investment of around $60 billion are  required to satisfy demand over the period 2015-2029, increasing the generation capacity by nearly 70%, 60,000  new megawatts, and improving the reliability of electricity grid through development of a smart grid and  interconnection with North America and Central America.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Brazil, the regulator, ANEEL, has already approved a methodology for the fourth cycle of the periodic tariff  review, increasing the WACC from the previous 7.5% to 8.09%, equivalent to a pre-tax nominal rate of around  19%. We expect the tariff review for Elektro to be approved in the third quarter of this year, when we set the  remuneration framework for the next four years. Also, measures has been announced to re duce the hydroelectric  generators' exposure to drought down to 5%, effective since January 2014.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In relation to the merger between UIL Holdings and Iberdrola USA, we have already received all the federal  approvals from the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission, the Federal Communication  Commission, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and the Committee on Foreign Investment. We are  presenting this month a new filing to the merger, to the public regulatory authorities in Connecticut an d  Massachusetts. Also, on the 17 July, we filed Form S-4 to Securities and Exchange Commission and we expect to  close the whole transaction before the year end.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have continued contributing to the fight against climatic change. Today, almost two-third of our total capacity  are free of carbon emission. And in face of this year Paris Climatic Change Summit, we have set a new objective of  reducing by 50% the intensity of our carbon emission by 2030, which, as you know, today is 30% lower than  European electricity sector average; and become carbon neutral by 2050.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, our social action plans include several initiatives which range from electricity for all program which  promote access to electricity in countries like Brazil, to the Románico Atlántico Plan for the preservation of  cultural heritage in Spain and Portugal.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Adjusted for the €111 million positive impact of CO2 allowances recognized in Q2 2014, first -half EBITDA grew  9.1%. This growth is slightly better than the 8.8% first quarter growth. Excluding such CO2 ruling adjustment,  reported EBITDA grew 5.7% to €3.7 94 billion.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Levies grew 14% – 13.9% to over €1 billion versus the 3.2% increase at March mainly due to the €111 million CO2  positive court ruling previously commented. FX evolution increased levies by €7 6 million. In the first -half, we had  also €65 million of lower environmental taxes due to ruling in Spain – positive ruling in Spain and lower ECO  costs in the UK.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Generation & Supply EBITDA fell 11.7% to €1.662 billion due to the unfavorable comparison with the first half of  2014 which had a strong hydro output in Spain, and included up to €7 5 million of non-recurring positive impacts  from gas in Spain and in the U.S., and had a positive impact also of the CO2 ruling partially compensated with  lower environmental taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €775 million with a 12.3% decrease in gross margin due to the 16% lower output  affected by the 39% decrease in hydro and increasing procurement costs due to the increased thermal weight in   the production mix. Also, first half of 2014 included €43 million positive non-recurring gas impact and levies were  up €55 million due to the reasons previously commented.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA was £203 million, 1.4% up. Wholesale and generation business gross margin decreased 26%  due to higher costs with carbon tax increasing to £18 per megawatt hour from April 1 – sorry, £20 of CO2 ton  from April 1 onwards. Retail business, gross margin improved 7.3% due to higher volumes in gas with a 9.7 %  increase in demand compensating the 11% lower gross margin in retail power due to the increasing non-energy  related costs.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA increased 19% to €825 million, driven by the positive evolution in the UK and the recovery  in Spain, offsetting weaker performance in the U.S. Spain and now also the UK, with new offshore capacity in  operation, have been the largest EBITDA contributors in renewables with 32% and 29% share followed by the U.S.  with a 28% share. Gross margin increased 17% and net operating expenses 13.5%, 4 percentage points below. The  operating capacity was up 3.3% to almost 14,000 megawatts. The load factor decreased 2.6 percentage points to  28% and output fell 5.6% due to extraordinary wind conditions during 2014 in Spain and the U.S. compensated by  a 25% increase in the average price due to the very low spot prices in Spain last year, new offshore capacity in  operation and the positive FX impact.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain EBITDA reached €260 million, 11.9% up, with a 9.2% lower output due to especially weak second  quarter. This has been compensated by the recovery in prices. In the UK, EBITDA reached £177 million with a  27 % higher output and the contribution of West of Duddon Sands offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the U.S. EBITDA was $259 million with a 12% decrease in output due to climate conditions in the west and  lower prices due to the good conditions in the first half of 2014 due to the low temperatures.
