file: IBE - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 20July2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The renewables business' EBITDA has been affected by 26.2% lower output in UK after extraordinary year in  2015, both for onshore and offshore. Nevertheless, Spain and United States increased output by 7% and 10%,  respectively. In total, overall renewable output grew 5% year-on-year. For our regulated generation activity in  Mexico, CFE has reduced reference tariff of which some of our contracts are [indiscernible] (04:10). Nevertheless,  this tariff has already been increased in dollars by 9.2% since July.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In generation and supply, EBITDA is recovering, decreasing only 1.9% versus 19.6% in the first quarter as  atypical impact has been offset. In Spain, hydro output is up 68.4%, reaching 30% of total output, which in the UK,  higher CCGT output partially compensated closure of Longannet. The overall energy produced globally by our  company grows 5% higher than in 2015. Proof of the strong operating performance of our businesses, the 3.9%  increase in EBIT during the period, which, excluding foreign exchange impact, grew 5.7%. And thanks to the  financial management of our company, including foreign exchange hedging, recurring net profits have grown by  14%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Consistent with our strategic investment plan to 2020, net investments had already increased by 43% to almost  €1.9 billion of which 68% are allocated to growth projects and over 80% to regulated activities. The operational  cash flow has increased 6.5% to €3.2 billion, exceeding investment by almost €1.4 billion. At the business level,  operating cash flow exceeds investment across all businesses, except for renewables, due to the investment  undertaken in our offshore projects.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will now briefly review the main capital expenditure projects and the way we saw our progress in the execution of  our 2016-2020 Plan. In other words, in United States, the New York Rate Cases has been approved, including  higher tariff for the three years, starting in May. Also, the filing of the Connecticut electric rate case has been  made. Furthermore, several transmission projects are in progress. Among these, let me highlight. Metro-North  Railroad, aimed at increasing the capacity and reliability of the transmission line along the Metro-North corridor in  Connecticut with an investment of $175 million over the next few years; the Rochester Area Reliability Project in  New York, which includes extension of 25 miles of lines in a substation with an investment of $100 million for the  next few years as well; and a new project in Maine for the reconstruction of 50 miles of transmission lines with an  investment of $80 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In renewables, significant milestone has been achieved in offshore. We have already laid 50% of the foundation  of our 350 megawatt Wikinger wind farm in the German Baltic Sea, and the [indiscernible] (08:01) substations are  ready to be installed. For our British East Anglia I project with 714 megawatts capacity, the turbine order was  signed with Siemens. And in relation to our offshore wind farm, we continue the construction of 1,336 megawatts  in United Kingdom, United States, and Brazil.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, with our contracted generation in Mexico, we have over 2,500 megawatts of additional capacity under  construction, of which almost 700 megawatts, mostly from Baja California III and Monterrey V will be  commissioned during second half of 2016. The remaining 1,800 megawatts will be delivered between 2016 and  2018, totaling 1,000 megawatt of installed power in the country by this date.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, the execution of our investment plan is on track with good progress in the development of our transmission  and distribution networks in all countries and almost 5,000 megawatts of new wind farm and regulated  generations, which will increase our future results.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As we have already put forward in many occasions, our currency diversification helps mitigate potential foreign  exchange impact. Our net profit 2016 is 100% hedged against exchange rates fluctuation eliminating any risk for  the present year. And almost 76% of our UK EBITDA is in regulated networks and contracted renewable  businesses, which have remuneration scheme indexes to inflation. As currency devaluation could lead potentially  to higher inflation, this scheme mitigate any foreign exchange impact.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As for our capital expenditure plan in the UK until 2020, 75% of our expected investment has no currency risk.  And 21% mainly includes a part of East Anglia I offshore wind farm investment in networks with both as I  mentioned before, include price revision formulas linked to inflation.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lastly, I would like to mention the integration between Gamesa and Siemens Wind, which has led to the creation  of a global leader in wind generation industry. Both companies are highly complementary in terms of global  footprint, existing product portfolios and technologies. And synergies are expected in areas such as design,  production, et cetera. The main goal of the agreement signed by Iberdrola and Siemens Wind is the protection of  the interests of minority shareholders [indiscernible] (12:37) the best corporate governance practices are put in  place.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Just to conclude, the result we are presenting today allow us to improve the outlook of our net profit for the full  year. With the strong performance across networks, a good evolution in generation and supply businesses and  the stability in renewable businesses. This positive evolution reaffirms the achievement of our 5% expected  growth in result at EBITDA level for 2016 despite foreign exchange fluctuation and a typical impact. Our net profit,  as I mentioned, growth rate is expected to be significantly higher than that expected for EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Finally, Elektro EBITDA fell 12% to BRL 387 million, with 3.5% lower energy circulated and lower tariff due to the  August 2015 full year review, reducing gross margin by 7.7%, while net operating expenses remained flat.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Generation and supply EBITDA decreased 3% improving the first quarter 18% fall, reaching €1,226 million, with  improvements in operating results partially offsetting lower gas results in Spain and €23 million of customer  compensations in the UK.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA fell 2.5% reaching €756 million, thus improving the 31% fall in the first quarter. Gross margin  was up 1.4% as higher output driven by a 22% (sic) [68.4%] (19:35) increase in hydro production and a 3.8%  increase in nuclear together with our better retail results, compensated the lower gas results. Net operating  expenses were up 15%, still affected by €42 million of non-recurring results.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA grew 1% to £206 million, which had 1.2% increase of gross margin and a 2.9% increase in net  operating expenses, offset by a 23% decrease in levies. Wholesale and generation business gross margin  increased 7.9% following Longannet closure, and higher gas output and lower procurement cost, and positively  affected by a negative €20 million [ph] derivative (20:41) impairment in Longannet in 2015, partially compensated  by higher carbon tax for [ph] £70 million (20:48).

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Retail business gross margin fell 2.7%. Higher unitary margins in gas did not compensate 15% lower gross  margin in retail power, due to the increase in non-energy related costs, lower volumes driven by milder weather  conditions than last year and the already mentioned customer compensation.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Renewable EBITDA fell 3% versus the first quarter 3.1% increase, reaching €836 million due to the weaker  performance in the UK in the second quarter of 2016, partially offset by better performance in Spain and the U.S.  Gross margin fell 3.9%, but net operating expenses improved 6.8% with €21 million of positive one-offs accounted  for in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: EBIT increased 3.9%, improving versus the first quarter 7% fall to €2,254 million. Amortizations fell by €56 million  driven by the closure of Longannet and the extension of the useful life of wind farms, more than compensating the  UIL consolidation. Provisions grew €23 million, up €123 million, affected by the UIL consolidation and an €8  million of one non-recurring positive impact in the first half of 2015.

file: IBE - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 20July2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Brazil, the higher demand and the annual tariff adjustment to inflation have also contributed positively to the  results. The renewable businesses has remained relatively stable with an EBITDA that is excluding foreign  exchange impact is in line with the last years. The main driver has been the higher output in UK, thanks to a 31%  increase in wind production, with the addition of 260 megawatts of new average capacity in operation compared  to the first half of 2016, almost offsetting the 41% lower wind output in Spain which compared to exceptionally  high level last year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the other hand, the lower generation output due to the closure of Longannet in March 2016 is starting to dilute  slightly. And we still expect an improvement in the business performance in the second half, as a result of higher  demand and savings from the efficiency actions.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As for Spain, the hydro output continues to be at exceptionally low levels, 7 terawatt hours below the remarkably  high levels of the first half of 2016. In fact, the second quarter of this year has been the driest recorded. This has  been partially offset by the positive adjustment in gas, which had the opposite effect last year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our net investment continue increasing to over €2.5 billion, a 35% growth, with 91% located to networks,  renewables and contracted generation. In total, we have 90% of the investment of our plan completed or in  construction, with almost 1.5 gigawatt added since 2016 and an additional 6.3 gigawatts in construction due by  2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Western Link high voltage cable project to bring renewable synergy from Scotland to England and Wales is  well advanced. The installation of the first of the two subsea cables has been completed and successfully tested,  and the second one is underway. Overall, more than 90% of the total cable length of 840 kilometers has already  been installed. The commissioning is expected by the last quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the Smart Grid project has reached 92% of the smart meter installation. Having added almost 1 million  in the first half of the year, reaching a total of more than 10 million smart meters fitted. In Brazil, the fourth  regulatory cycle of Celpe, the energy distribution company in the state of Pernambuco come into force in April and  is expected to increase over 50% the result of this company.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In renewables, at our Wikinger offshore wind farm in Germany, 33 turbines with a capacity of 165 megawatt out of  the total 350 megawatt were installed during the first half. 27 of these turbines have been pre-commissioned and  one of the two export cables have been installed.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: [indiscernible] (6:59) for the wind farm is expected in September and full export by the yearend. As for our next  offshore wind project, East Anglia ONE in Britain, 80% of the construction contracts has been signed. In onshore,  327 megawatt commissioned in the first half, 200 megawatt in the UK, 84 megawatt in Brazil and the remaining  capacity in the United States.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Where AVANGRID has also executed 400 megawatt of PPAs for new wind farms, 100 megawatt of PPAs for  repowering and 590 MW of fixed price contract for existing capacity, reducing merchant risk. In total, there are 2.8  gigawatts of wind and solar photovoltaics capacity in construction in the UK, U.S., Mexico, Brazil and Spain, and  1.2 gigawatts are to be commissioned in the second half of the year and the remaining 1.6 gigawatts are  expected before the end of 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, 336 MW of contracted generation capacity has been commissioned and 100 megawatt is due before  the yearend. In total, there is currently 3,500 megawatts in construction. So, by 2020, total installed capacity in the  country will reach over 10,000 megawatts and output will exceed our current production in Spain. Altogether, the  6.3 gigawatts in construction in all the market will increase our total installed capacity by 13% between the second  half of 2017 and 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And in New York, we expect approval in 2018 of the advanced metering infrastructure project for the deployment  of 1.8 million smart meters by 2022. And we expect [ph] to have this execute (09:13) investment of the DSI plan  related to Automation and Advanced Controls System of the distribution networks.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In renewables, we have achieved the permit for the construction of the offshore wind farm Saint-Brieuc in France  with commissioning expected by 2022. Also in offshore, we have an important set of opportunities, which are in  process of being awarded. In UK, we are expecting by August the permits to the development of East Anglia  THREE with a capacity around 1,200 megawatts. The auction is due in 2018. At the same time in Germany, we  are working on the extension of Wikinger with up to 750 megawatts of additional capacity. The auction is  expected in first quarter 2018 as well.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And in the United States, AVANGRID secured two leases at the first half of the year. Vineyard Wind Farm off the  Coast of Massachusetts could potentially support around 2,000 megawatt of capacity. In June, the Department of  Energy issued a request for proposal for procurement up to 800 megawatts. And the other lease area is off the  coast of Kitty Hawk in North Carolina, with a potential capacity of around 1,500 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, regarding storage, we are building three hydro pumping plants in Portugal in the Tamega River with 1,150  megawatts of capacity. The commission of the first phase is expected in 2021.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our American company, AVANGRID, where we hold 81.5% stake, increased net profit by 14% in the period,  reaching $359 million, with a net profit growth of 10% in networks and 19% in renewables.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In addition, the company has around 2,500 megawatts of wind and solar photovoltaic projects in advanced stage  of development, many of which should come into operation by 2020. Meanwhile, the company also continues to  the implementation of efficiency measures of our 2020 Plan.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The transaction involves no cash component and no capital increase. Once completed, Iberdrola will hold a  majority stake in a company focuses in regulated and renewable activities, with potential for additional value  creation. Through implementation of group best practices to achieve further operational efficient synergies,  improving EBITDA and cash flow generation profile and increasing group RAB enhancing our regulated profile.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The newly created company will be present in 12 states and will have over 3,500 megawatt of contracted capacity  in operation and construction mainly in renewables. And we are working on the necessary step for the future  listing of the company in the stock exchange.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Levies were up by 13% to €1,157 million due to in Spain €80 million of positive court rulings accounted for in Q2  2016 and €12 million higher in generation taxes in the liberalized business linked to energy prices. In the U.S.,  there was €21 million higher taxes in the network business that will be reducing its impact in the second half due  to the seasonality of its recognition in the IFRS method versus the GAAP method. Other effects were mainly  higher taxes in the UK liberalized accounted for in Q2 associated to the Warm House Discount (sic) [Warm Home  Discount] that added €16 million to the taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As you can see in the slide, Spain contributed 39%, the U.S. 32%, and the UK 23%. In Spain, EBITDA decreased  €13 million to €771 million, with lower investment recognized in the first half of 2017 versus last year and high net  operating expenses due to the storm costs.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S. EBITDA was up 24% to $682 million, as a consequence of the implementation of the new rate cases,  in UIL and New York, positive IFRS impacts compared to last year that will flood them throughout the year,  partially compensated by the already mentioned $76 million storm costs with no impact on the U.S. GAAP, but  impacted in the IFRS accounting and 6.7% higher taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA fell 4.1% to £388 million, with a 2.7% decrease in gross margin, affected by lower volumes  due to mild weather, around £10 million that will be recovered in the following years and settlements of around  another £12 million due to lower investments during 2016 that has to be adjusted during 2017.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, Elektro EBITDA improved 12.8% to BRL 436 million with 4.6% higher energy distributed and a positive  impact of 9% increase in the past August review.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As you can see in the slide, the UK has only 6% of the generation and supply EBITDA, while Spain accounts for  67% and Mexico reaches 27%. Getting into the details, in Spain the EBITDA fell 12.4% to €662 million with the  stronger retail activity and higher gas results due to a one-off positive review of prices of the portfolio during the  second quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: [ph] Absorbed in part (20:37) of the margin compression driven by the extremely adverse operating environment  with a 20% lower output, including a lower 7 terawatt hours production in the hydro after a record hydro year  production in the first half of 2016 that has been followed by the driest second quarter recorded as the Chairman  already has pointed out. Levies were up 33% due to an unfavorable comparison with 2016 and including this €71  million of positive court rulings and higher generation retail taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In wholesale and generation, EBITDA decreased £49 million. And as a matter of fact, the group has registered  EBITDA losses of £15.7 million in wholesale and generation with higher cost of gas and lower output after the  Longannet closure at the end of the first quarter of 2016.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the retail business, the EBITDA decreased £170 million (sic) [£107.5 million] to £64.5 million, in the retail  electricity business due to higher government obligation and lower margins and in the retail gas business, due to  lower margins and volumes linked to milder weather.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA was 2% down to €819 million, recovering the first quarter 5% fall, with the UK improving  substantially its evolution in this second quarter and the U.S. maintaining its growth levels, almost compensating  the lower results in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €257 million, 19.4% lower than last year as a result of 14% lower output compared to  an exceptional first half of 2016 that normalized thereafter. In addition, there's a positive adjustment of the  investment incentive, more than compensated by lower regulatory asset due to high energy prices.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This has allowed us to also start seizing opportunities with commissioning date beyond 2020. We continue  working towards further growth focuses in low carbon sources, storage capacity, and digitalized grids in our  markets.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S.A., we will continue growing in renewables through development of further onshore wind farm for  clients and executing offshore wind projects, exporting our know-how in this technology.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In networks, we will continue growing through our rate cases, participating in the development of the smart cities  like the Energy Smart Community project of Ithaca and developing transmission projects for the integration of  renewable energies into the system. In the UK, we will continue focusing renewables and networks.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In offshore, we have the development of the East Anglia THREE offshore wind farm for which we are expecting  the permits in August. And they will carry on investing on transition and distribution, including the development of  smart meters expecting to reach 100% by 2021.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As for Mexico, as well as our investment in contracted generation, we have an important portfolio potential wind  and solar photovoltaic projects.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And in Brazil, new networks and renewables opportunities arise as a result of our merger to Neoenergia and  Elektro. All these opportunities offer further visibility after our current plan and allow us to reaffirm our expectation  of continued growing result beyond 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: For our 2017 outlook, I would like to briefly go through the main business drivers that will support a mid-single- digit net profit growth, thanks to the U.S. and Brazil rate cases in networks, the new installed capacity in  renewables and the expected normalization of wind condition during the year, the new contracted generation in  Mexico, the improvement in the leverage generation and supply business in UK due to the dilution of the  comparatively higher output last year and as a result of efficiency measures and tariff increases implemented in  April and finally we have the record [indiscernible] (29:43) in Spain. All this will allow us to maintain our  commitment of growing shareholder remuneration in line with our good results.

file: IBE - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 25July2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you, Ignacio. Good morning, everyone, and thank you very much for your participation today in this  conference call. In the first half of the year, operating net profit grew 27% to €1,386 million, reflecting the  investment made by the company during the past five years, about €20 billion, including the €2,478 million  invested in the first half of this year. These, together with the normalization of the operating and weather condition  in Spain and the UK, and the further improvement in efficiency globally, allow us to reach an EBITDA of €4,436  million, 17%. Excluding foreign exchange impact with total €260 million during the first half, EBITDA increased by  24%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Last year, net profit included over €400 million of extraordinary positive impact driven from the capital gains in  Siemens-Gamesa and a gas price adjustment. And in spite of this, our report to net profit reached €1,410 million,  only 7% less.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The performance of our Renewables business also improved significantly reflected in a 25.5% growth. In Spain,  output rose 29% higher than year earlier due to the normalized hydro condition and the higher wind resource.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S., the additional onshore wind capacity commission during 2017 contributed to a 12% increase in wind  output. In the UK, improved result were driven by the better wind condition and the new capacity added. And  finally, in Germany, our 850 megawatts Wikinger offshore wind farm [indiscernible] (00:03:35) service and is now  fully operational.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation and Supply EBITDA also increased in comparison to the last year, thanks to the normalization of  market condition in the UK and also to the higher retail activity in Spain. Excluding a positive one-off gas price  revision in 2017, as I mentioned before, the EBITDA of these businesses will have increased 33%. Net  investment had reached €2,478 million in the first half of 2018, broadly in line with 2017, minus 3%, and we have  €7.8 billion of capital in progress.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Networks business represent 42% of the total investment with 36% coming from Renewables and the  remaining 22% coming from Generation and Supply. 423 megawatt of capacity had been installed during the first  half of the year. And for the rest of the year, we expect to complete the installation with an additional 2,326  megawatts mostly in Mexico, including the 1,800 megawatts combined cycles of Escobedo and Topolobampo and  the onshore wind farms in Pier and Santiago with total 326 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: During the first half of the year, significant progress has also been made. In Networks, our new subsidiary,  AVANGRID, has continued to progress development of the New England Clean Energy Connect transmission  project for which it was selected earlier this year. In June, the company secured a contract with Massachusetts  electric distribution companies in Hydro-Québec. The project is expected to come online by 2022.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Renewables, the construction of our UK 714 megawatt East Anglia One offshore wind farm is well on track with  the first jacket already installed and the offshore substation completed and ready to ship into the North Sea. And  the onshore work is on track as well after some delays as a consequence of the discovery of [indiscernible]  (00:06:07) archaeological ruins close to the site.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Also, in offshore wind, a number of projects has been awarded or confirmed. In the German Baltic Sea, we were  awarded with the 486-megawatt Baltic Eagle with commissioning expected by 2023. In the United States,  AVANGRID was awarded with 800-megawatt Vineyard wind farm off the coast of Massachusetts with 400  megawatts expected to be commissioned in 2021 and the remaining 400 megawatts just one year later. And  finally, in France, Saint-Brieuc, a 496-megawatt offshore wind project has been recently confirmed to be in  operation in 2023 as well. Total investment for this offshore project exceeds €6 billion.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In offshore wind, Neoenergía will add 471 megawatt of new capacity to the Paraiba onshore wind farm complex  by 2022, reaching 565 megawatt and becoming the group's largest wind farm in South America. Also, in Brazil,  122 megawatts of hydro capacity has been commissioned in Belo Monte. And in Portugal, works for the Tâmega  hydroelectric complex are well on track for commissioning on the first dam, Gouvães of 800 megawatt in 2021  and the remaining capacity in 2023. Earlier this week, we signed a loan with the European Investment Bank for  the financing of up to €650 million of this project under very competitive condition.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In solar photovoltaic, a total of 226 megawatt in Mexico are ready for commissioning during the third quarter of the  year and the construction of two new plants with around 400 megawatt of total capacity will be announced shortly  to be in operation by 2020. And we have announced the construction of 391 megawatts solar photovoltaic plant in  Extremadura in Spain with a commissioning also in 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, in Generation and Supply, ScottishPower has already installed 1 million smart meters. And in Mexico,  CFE tariff increased by 10.7% in July as a consequence of gradual implementation of additive tariffs. We also  complete the repowering of Monterrey combined cycle.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: All in all, we can affirm that the delivery of our investment plan is well on track. Project awarded recently had  raised the percentage of CapEx secured for new-generation capacity network project to 86% of the 2022 plan.  Beyond the current plan, we already had €1 billion committed post 2022 to penalize the renewable project of  Saint-Brieuc, Baltic Eagle, and Tâmega as well for the smart meters and networks investment already committed  in distribution in the UK.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our efficiency, measured by the net operating expenses to grow margin ratio, has improved by 100 basis points  year-on-year excluding the positive non-operating adjustment in gas price already mentioned. Efficiency will  continue to improve in the second half as Neoenergia in Brazil and in the rest of the group companies continue to  benefit from synergies and implementation of debt practices.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The result were negatively affected by the impact of minor storm and the delay in commissioning of El Cabo and  Tule onshore wind farms. Excluding these adjustment net profit would have increased by 10%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The company continued delivering on its strategic plan, having executed contract for 378 megawatt of the new  wind project in the year, including 220 megawatt in Texas announced yesterday by AVANGRID. Also, in  Renewables, the company has under construction almost 500 megawatt of onshore wind and solar photovoltaic  capacity, all which will be in operation by 2019.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Networks, AVANGRID has filed new multi-year rate cases for Connecticut Gas Natural (sic) [Natural Gas] and  Berkshire Gas in Massachusetts with new tariff effective from 2019. In addition, as already mentioned, the  company was awarded two remarkable projects: Vineyard, the first large offshore wind farm in the United States  at a moment in which this technology prospect is gaining momentum in the country. In Networks, the New  England Clean Energy Connect project, which include a 1,200 megawatt) high-voltage direct-current transmission  line linking the electrical grids in Québec and New England to bring clean electricity to Massachusetts during the  next 20 years.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: New renewable capacity will be in operation in the second half in Belo Monte and additional wind capacity will  start construction to operate from 2022 onwards.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regards to financing, we have continued to improve our debt profile. During this semester, the group has issued  €4,450 million in bonds including hybrids, 58% of which were green, and €5.3 billion plus $2.5 billion [ph] will arise  (00:13:07) in credit lines. As of today, 23% of our total debt portfolio is green and 75% of our credit lines are  linked to environmental factors.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA was 3.6% up, to $706 million. Due to the growth in rate plans, positive IFRS impacts, partially  compensated by storm costs, which were $40 million higher than last year, reaching close to $129 million, which  is an extremely high amount that should not be repeated in following years. According to IFRS rules, we have not  yet accounted for future reduction in EBITDA following the tax reform that will happen once regulators officially  adjust their tariffs now under discussion.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA grew by 25.5% to €1.2 billion, with positive evolution in the most relevant geographies and  output increasing by 20% to 35,000 gigawatt hours with a 4 percentage points higher load factor, mainly thanks to  our strong hydro growth in Spain and the UK onshore business. As a result, Spain is now the main contributor to  the Renewables EBITDA with a 41% stake, followed by the U.S. 23%, the UK 20%, rest of the world, 9%, Brazil  5%, and Mexico 1%.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €491 million, 32% higher than last year, mainly driven by a 48% higher hydro output,  partially compensated by lower prices than the first – compared to the first half of 2017. And you remember there  was a big spike on prices in January on higher levies linked to the higher volumes. The EBITDA growth is also  due to a 12% higher output in wind and better prices for wind.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA grew 27% to £205 million as a consequence of a 12% higher output with 195 megawatts  increase in average operating capacity, higher load factor, and better prices that boosted gross margin by 19%.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA fell 27% to €397 million, impacted by the already mentioned positive one-off accounted in  the gas business. In addition, output fell 10.7% due to the higher renewable production and 12% lower nuclear.  Retail activity was strong and prices are improving for the year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Renewables, they expect acceleration in results, thanks to the increase in output provided by the new capacity  of the onshore wind farm in Mexico as well as the additional power of Belo Monte in Brazil. The 350 megawatt  offshore German, Wikinger, which is now working at full load and additionally, we have already higher hydro  reserves than the normal average.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Generation and Supply, we expect the CFE tariff in Mexico to continue improving and forward prices in Europe  are showing a positive trend for remaining of the year. In Spain, nuclear output will normalize now. The outage of  two plants had concluded.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Generation, Mexico, the contribution – the new cogenerations are one and repowering of Monterrey will  complement it by the new combined cycle capacity in the last quarter of the year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: The first nine months of this year had a gross operating profit of €5,563 million. This is 12.4% more  than in the same period last year. It must also be highlighted that all businesses have shown a  positive performance during the period. And this shows that the investments carried out during the  period have provided the group with a portfolio of activities in geographic areas capable of  providing a path of sustainable growth, even at times like these. So our renewable and liberalized  businesses have been driven by an increase of 10.2% in output, thanks to the greater contribution  of emission-free technologies and which in recent years – or last year, we invested €2.3 billion.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: Moving onto more specific items, group output in the first nine-months of 2010 raised 115,000  gigawatt hours with a growth of 10.2% with respect to the same period last year. And investments  made in recent years have improved our portfolio by increasing the output of emission-free output.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: The wind, hydro and nuclear technologies have increased their joint contribution by close to 10  points in the last 12 months, amounting to 50% of total production. This has also increased the  diversification of our generation facilities. So in September 2010, no technology contributes more  than 20% of the total, excluding combined cycle in Mexico which as you know, has a practically  independent economic regime in operating hours and fuel costs.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: I would like to highlight that the 14% increase in production in Spain, thanks to the increase in  hydro and wind generation, as well as the performance in demand, which in spite of having slowed  down in recent months, continues to grow at a rate of around 3% this year. Regarding hydro  reserves in Spain, they are currently more than 6,800 gigawatt hours. This represents an increase  of 45% over the figures recorded in June 2009. The increase in output and the good performance  of the regulated businesses mean that the gross margin for the group is €8.7 billion, driven by the  growth in all our businesses.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: By businesses, there is a positive performance in IBERDROLA Renewables, a growth of 19% and  in the regulated businesses, EBITDA has grown by 16% and again, we must highlight  developments in the U.S. driven by these efficiency improvements. We must also mention the  growth in the Latin American business, whose gross operating profit has increased by 14%, thanks  to the major growth in demand of our Brazilian distributors, amounting to close to 10%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: Regarding new development areas in IBERDROLA USA, the beginning of the works for the main  transport line now to Canada is, without a doubt, a major landmark for the company. This new  infrastructure will have a length of 800 kilometers and its construction will last until 2014. And will  represent a total investment of $1.4 billion that will be obtained from our divestment in the  Connecticut and Massachusetts gas companies.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: The sales figure grew 16.1% to 22,978 million. With larger volumes in Spain that offset the lower  price of our liberalized business and the lower remuneration and distribution, with major growth in  Renewables in Latin America. Regarding suppliers for the group, they grew 21.9% to 14,032 million  especially in the national energy business and Latin America.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: The gross margin increased 9.2% to €8,674 million. And there has been growth in all business  areas. Additionally, IBERDROLA has benefited from the good developments in the exchange rate  set, representing €207 million. The basic margin, that reflects the net effect of the issue rights on  the operating accounts, increased by 8.4%, somewhat less than the gross margin because of the  lower pricing consumption of CO2 in 2010.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: Net staff expenses have grown 1.8% and now stand at €1.295 billion, meaning that there has been  a 3.9 improvement relative to June. And the net external services have been reduced by 6% and  now stand at €1.283 billion. And they’ve improved by means of a reduction of 5.2% relative to June,  but it has to be pointed out that we have the issue of the reclassification of the nuclear rate, which I  will be talking about later on, because of the facilities that have been provided according to IFRIC  18.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And as regards taxation, there has been a 22.8% increase, reaching €695 million. This represents  the increase in reclassification of the nuclear rate or tax, 62 million more than in 2009 and which in  the first months represents €141 million that the group is paying in terms of nuclear tax. And then  we have the social bonus and another taxes in the United States, U.K. and Spain.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And if you add-up all these effects, they compensate the elimination of the detraction of CO2 rights  that represented €98 million. That is a clawback in 2009. And the consolidated EBITDA of the  group stands at €5.563 billion, which is a 12.4% increase.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: I would now like to move on to the operating profit by businesses and starting off with the liberalized  business in Spain. That includes generation, commercial and non-regulated gas. It has to be  underscored that IBERDROLA has increased its production by 13% in the ordinary regime.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And there is also been a much better progression of the system, which has shown a slump in the  ordinary regime of nearly 2%. And this positive evolution can be explained by the growth in the  demand of the system, 3.4% or 3% when adjusted, and the significant increase in hydraulic  production, as the President pointed out, which represents 134% more.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And in addition, our nuclear production has grown 12.8% and thermal technologies have declined  40% in the case of cycles and coal, 48%. An average sale price, total sale price, stands at €57 per  megawatt hour with a production level that is higher than we expected it to be. And all the  production for 2010 and something like 50 terawatt hour of those estimated for 2011 have been  sold at prices above €50 per megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: The increase of expenses linked to more commercial activities is – has been compensated by the  efficiency actions implemented and by the impact produced by the nuclear tax that is under the tax  heading. And tax has gone up 46% and now stands at a figure of €299 million, because of the  incorporation of the nuclear, the tax, €141 million, the social bonus and the increase of the eco-tax  in Extremadura, which is another 15 million and the taxes paid by IBERDROLA in relation to TUR  and commercial. And these four effects have a much greater impact than the €98 million of less  CO2 in the year 2010.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: So that means that here, we have the results that have been placed under the heading of the  facilities that have been surrendered to the subscribers, and in the case of IBERDROLA, we’re  talking about €15 million, which have been included under other income. And in September 2009,  there were also maintenance expenses because of the storms, whereas in 2010, we did not have  these effects.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: As regards the 3.6% reduction of the gross margin, this is the consequence of the reduction – the  temporary reduction in the remuneration of the business. So, it brought about temporary  remunerations, but we have to wait for the definitive remuneration that is based on the reference  model and on the investments made in 2009, as mentioned by the National Energy Council in the  report of June of this year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: This decline in remuneration has been partially compensated by resettlements that have taken  place in this third quarter of the year, and the gross margin of renewables grew 18.6% and now  stands at €1.412 billion, thanks to a strong increase in production, 20.2%, and because there is  more operating capacity. That has grown 16.1%, and now stands at 11,434 megawatts and also  because there have been improvements in Spain and the U.S.A.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: Prices now have reached €68.4 per megawatt hour, similar to 2009. And this means that the  EBITDA of the renewable business has grown nearly 25%. And this has furthered the total growth  of the consolidated EBITDA of IBERDROLA RENOVABLES, which now stands at €972 million,  which has grown 19.4% in spite of the smaller contribution of the gas business. And the growth in  14.2% of the operating costs has slowed down in the third quarter relative to the second one, and is  now four points below the growth we have in the gross margins, because of the efficiency efforts of  the business that has managed to improve the expense per operating megawatt by 3.8%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And fundamentally, the worst behavior can be found in the electrical business, because the gas  business improved its results in 2010. And it has to be said that 2009 was an especially strong year  in the electric retail business of ScottishPower and that 2010 is more of an average year, like 2008.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: So the gross margin has gone up 10.8% and now stands at €1.173 billion and most of this growth  has been produced by the IFRS adjustments, because the best margins have been compensated  by lower sales because of the weather.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And by business – by businesses, Brazil has made a contribution of €419 billion for the EBITDA  with an 18% growth, because there has been an increase of 9.6% in demand and because there  has been a greater adjustment of prices to inflation and because the rate of exchange has a part of  influence and despite of sales of assets in Chile that has been compensated by the exploitation of  new hydraulic power stations. And Mexico has a contribution of €319 million to the EBITDA,  meaning that this is a 10% growth rate. And the effect of the rate of exchange has a positive effect,  3%. And the EBITDA of Non Energy & Engineering businesses had a 4.0% slump and now stands  at €197 million.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: 7 And the EBIT of the group grew by 9.1%, which is somewhat lower than the growth we had in terms  of the EBITDA after an 18.6% increase in amortizations and provisions, which now stands at  €1.994 billion, of which amortizations represent 1.9 billion and which is 17.1% more, have to do  with increases in renewables with more installed power.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: In ScottishPower, with an effect that has to do with the appreciation of the power and more assets  under exploitation in the networks area and also because there have been more environmental  investments that have been made in Spain. And the reclassification of the deferred income and  facilities that have been surrendered to subscribers in the distribution area in the case of gone,  there has been a negative impact for the group of €54 million in terms of net operating expenses,  and the provisions have been increased by 35 million and now stand at €94 million, which is  somewhat lower than the 103 million we had in June.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: We also have had the good business developments and the positive effects derived from the scrip  dividend, the divestment of the Connecticut gas distributors and other divestments that will be  announced soon. And all this will enable us to more than comply with the financial objectives,  financial solvency objectives for 2010.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer  Well, I think that after this magnificent presentation by the CFO, there’s little I can add. In the first nine months, we have obtained an increase of 12.4% in operating  results and 6% in recurrent net profits. texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine

The good situation of the wind power business in the U.S., where output increased by  22%, production in the U.K. that grew by 8%. And finally energy generated in Latin America, which  grew 2% and the renewable assets in the various countries in Europe and Latin America have also  increased their output by 22%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine

Renewables has improved its cost per installed megawatt and is still a growing business by  almost 4%.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine

And the U.K. is going to be investing a lot in energy infrastructures, which the  Ministry of Energy could soon have said that they will be investing more than £200 million until the  end of 2020.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And we hope that ScottishPower will carry on developing its distribution of grids within the revision  that has been issued and that they will increase the investments in transport, so that they can  reinforce the current grids and increase the interconnection between Scotland and England and  also provide connections for the many onshore wind projects and offshore wind projects.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And with the scenario – the certain scenario defined by the strategic group of energy and networks  which has been jointly presided over by the Ministry of Energy and the Ofgem regulator means that  total investments in the transport business are going to be in excess of £20 billion in 2011 and –  between 2011 and 2018. As you know, ScottishPower is the second most important transport in the  U.K. after National Grid.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: As regards the liberalized business, the U.K. now is facing the challenge of renovating a significant  part of its current generation park. And as you know, the group has an extensive portfolio of  projects in the nuclear, gas and clean coal technologies. And IBERDROLA RENOVABLES is a  leader in the onshore wind business in the U.K. and has a large portfolio of projects in marine wind  technology and that will be constructed as from 2012 with the West of Duddon Sands park or wind  farm.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: 11 And as regards Brazil, the group can grow in the distribution business in which demand is growing  a lot, as I’ve said before, as well as in the field of hydroelectric generation. And before the end of  this fiscal year, we’ll be commissioning three new hydroelectric power stations that will be  incorporated to the other six built over the last few years.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: And likewise, we have an extensive portfolio of hydroelectric projects. And the most important one  has to do with the involvement of Bello Montaigne in – you know that it’s a macro project and it’s  going to have an installed power of 11,000 hydraulic megawatts.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We’re going to begin the presentation of the Results for the First Nine
texts.text: On the other hand, next year, we will initiate the construction of 250 megawatts in wind power in  addition to those that we already have, thanks to the tender we just won in August. And in Mexico,  we are putting our stakes on any new opportunities cropping up in the generation business and  we’ll grow to in the wind business, where apart from the 80 megawatts we have in operation, we  have another additional under construction.

file: IBE - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 27October2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And the regulated business has played a very important role that nearly accounts for 50% of the group's gross  margins. The 6% growth obtained in this item reflects the improvement in the remuneration businesses in the  grids in Spain, the United States and the U.K., and the incremental contribution made by Elektro in Brazil, that  compensates the divestitures of the gas companies in Connecticut. So the gross margin has grown 7.5%. That has  been boosted by the very good behavior of the wind power activity, whose production has grown 15%, although  there has been less growth in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And then the operating expenses of Brazil have increased, because of the contribution made by Elektro, which at a  global level, is practically compensated by lower costs because of the divestiture in the Connecticut gas companies  that was carried out last year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Just to mention those that I've not referred to yet, in the regulated business, the growth of EBITDA has been  affected by positive settlements in the third quarter of 2010, which has increased the comparison base. And then  because there were extraordinary expenses in the United States that are connected to the Irene hurricane, which  we hope will be recovered over the next fiscal years according to the British regulations, but which have an effect  on the balance sheet.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And as regards the renewable business, the third – in the third quarter, we've had very low levels of wind, which  we hope will improve, and we're seeing how the wind is blowing very strongly, especially over the next few  months.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And on the liberalized business, I would like to underscore the lower levels of production in Spain produced by  some of the programmed shutdowns of our nuclear power stations, and because there is less hydroelectricity. And  the situation of the U.K. where there have been very significant slumps in demand, especially of gas throughout  the third quarter, which are now being mitigated. All of this has been partially compensated by the improvement  in prices after recent increases.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But now, I would like to move on to the regulatory aspects of the period. And I would like to start by underscoring  that the sector has focused on the stage that is characterized by enormous investment need and this is not only so  because of the degree of obsolescence of the generation assets and the current grids, and also because there are  requirements imposed by the energy policy objectives and in particular, in terms of safety of supply and reduction  of emissions in all countries.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And we also have to add the investments that have to be made in the group business and commercialization to  achieve energy efficiency and the fulfillment of these objectives requires a very careful planning process, a process  in which you have to choose the generation technologies that are sufficiently mature and capable of achieving a  reduction in emissions that is effective and has a reasonable cost.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The fiscal year, we have to – in this fiscal year, we have to understand the effect that the base technologies we'll  have, like nuclear power, and scarcely predictable technologies like wind power. And we need to know to what  extent we will have to maintain a number of thermal plants up and running. And planning, that also has to predict  the impact that all these changes will have on the electricity transport grids. So we have to establish a program for  their extension and reinforcement, according to our needs.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So this is why the Spanish system is one in which support for Renewables represents a cost per megawatt hour  which is the highest figure in Europe. And in fact, in 2009, this cost already exceeded €22 per megawatt hour, vis- à-vis less than €15 in countries like Germany.  So as a result of this, each Spanish consumer will have to pay something like €250 as regards some premiums  attached to the special regime. But the reason for the Spanish system to have created a bubble, which is the term  that has been used by the European Regulator Council, has to do with the massive implementation of a non- mature technology, which is the solar technology.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And right now, wind technology has achieved a sufficient level of development to provide an energy solution. And  in this regard, its contribution to the system in terms of energy is very similar to the weight it has in relation to the  total cost of the system.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But solar technologies and PV and wind power only provide 3% of the power, although they represent 13% of the  total cost of the system, that is solar power and PV. But I am sure that this figure will increase as the new [ph]  Mercado (14:39) power stations are commissioned, and we have to do something about this over the next few  years.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So this is the main cause behind the deficit. We shouldn't forget that in 2010, the total amount of money that was  spent on solar plants was 45% the money received by the wind power plants, although it produced an amount of  power that was six times lower.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So this situation could become much more severe in the next few years, if we allow the errors made with the PV  plants to be made again with thermosolar generation. So we have rushed into the massive implementation of PV  stations, which means that the nearly 4,000 megawatts already installed are going to obtain premiums of  €200,000 per every €1 million invested over the next decades. And should we have waited for the technology to  achieve its current level of development, these premiums would be much lower and they would represent between  €70,000 and €90,000, in other words, less than one-third. Well, if we focus on the date of the pre-register, the  mistake could be made all over again with the thermosolar plants, which, according to the current regulations, are  as costly as the PV plants were a few years ago.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And in this regard, the 2,500 megawatts that have been pre-registered for this technology could provoke an  additional cost of €2 billion in premiums. And thus, if you calculate what has to be spent by each customer, it  could be €100 per – every year for the next 40 to 50 years. And from the environmental perspective, the  thermosolar technology is considered to be less efficient than wind power and PV, because the need to use gas in  the production process means that we have emissions of nearly 200 grams of CO2 per every kilowatt hour. So it's  not a clean source. So that means that, practically half of what is emitted by a combined cycle plant.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The additional needs for water-steam cooling, together with the additional process of mirror cleaning, means that  these plants consume close to 10,000 liters of water for each megawatt hour produced, figures which are closer to  those of a coal plant, of course, and much greater than photovoltaic plants, which practically require nothing, and  much more than wind power production, that requires zero.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So therefore, the massive deployment of thermosolar plants has no justification, neither from the energy,  economic or environmental point of view. And we will have to wait for a massive deployment when the technology  improves, as occurred with photovoltaic production when production costs were reduced.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Another key issue in understanding the actual situation of the electricity sector in Spain and the sustainability of  the prices makes it necessary to understand that the prices paid by the end customers include many more costs  than those of generating and distributing electricity.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: According to the preliminary calculations for 2011, the energy and the grid costs represent less than 50% of the  recently saying, there are sufficient measures available to us to avoid greater increases in prices than are strictly  necessary to design a sustainable framework for the future.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And this means reducing methods that are economically unsustainable. Therefore, the first thing that needs to be  completed is a reduction in the extra costs or the additional costs that were incurred. We also have had to consider  additional measures, such as separating [ph] over costs (18:36) the national coal from the electricity tariffs, or the  possibility of using earnings from CO2 emission rights as of 2013 to reduce the tariff deficit.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: These measures that could be carried out to put an end to the symmetries in the electricity system in Spain, and  they are certainly more effective and go less against the legal and economic rationale than the imposition of the  additional levies, which have already been paid and which in these nine months, represented €400 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And we only need to look at the UNESA reports published each year to find that the profitability of the generation  activity in Spain is already so tight that any additional levy would bring values close to zero or even take them to  negative levels.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the British system, according to the Ofgem regulator, the necessary investments in the next 10 years  could amount to £200 billion. And I would like to highlight two differential characteristic in the U.K versus Spain.  First, is that the replacement process for the generation facilities and in particular, the construction of new low  emission technologies is less advanced. And therefore, the various agents in the sector have the opportunity of  learning from the mistakes made by others.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And secondly, most of the reforms are being carried out through procedures that are considerably transparent.  And [ph] at this sense (20:14), starting with energy transmission, we are establishing the remuneration for the  period 2013-2021, a period in which ScottishPower is going to triple its assets base through the investments it's  going to carry out.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the renewable energies, the key issues are the non-retroactivity in any modification in the tax regime  according to the existing capacity, which has been clearly accepted by the authorities. This, therefore, is not under  discussion.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Within the traditional generation, as well as the regimes applicable to the new nuclear power plants, the  implementation of capacity [ph] payments (21:53) for thermal generation are also being discussed, an aspect  which we consider to be a key for the security of supply in the U.K. in the future and a fair sharing of transmission  charges.  Finally, the British commercial market is subject to controversy in recent weeks. We have to say that at  ScottishPower, we are also trying to improve transparency in relations with our customers. We have published a  number of measures to control in the best possible way our sales channels. And this way, as you will have been  able to see, we have decided to create the figure of the energy consultant, separate from those in charge of selling  products, and who will channel the relation with new potential customers.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: There have been growth in the regulated renewable and liberalized business in the U.K. that offset the  developments in the British liberalized business, which fell €157 billion. Without this impact, the growth margin  would have grown 3.3%. The consolidation of Elektro provides €277 million and compensates the loss of the  assets sold in U.S., €257 million. Basic margin represents 1.9 million, more than €9 billion, since the value of the  issue rights assigned in September 2011 is somewhat higher than those assigned in September 2010.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The net external services, including the impact of the hurricanes, show an increase of 2% up to 1.308 billion.  There is a strict control over these expenses. GON improves €41.5 million, levies increased 19.1% to €821 million

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Brazil EBITDA increases 51.1% to €633.9 million after incorporating Elektro to the perimeter, which has  contributed €196 million since May 1. Additionally, the revaluation of the real has contributed €13 million, an  increase of 3.3%. And the new hydroelectric plants have also added to this increase.  The gross margin for the business increased 56.6%. €277 million are a result of incorporation of Elektro. The GON  rises 73.3% and there is also an effect of €81 million, as a result of the exchange rate and increases in inflation and  higher output in Brazil.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In fact, in the last two years, our levies in this business have practically doubled, from €205 million in September  2009 to €398 million. According to our estimates, these levels represent, for our nuclear output, €13 per  megawatt hours produced. Most of them are made up of the nuclear levy, which represent €146 million and the  new levies associated to funding savings plans and the energy efficiency, which represent €112 million. And the  rest of the levies represent €141 million, that include the Extremadura eco levy and which is being taken to court.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The basic margin in the liberalized business in the U.K. presents a drop of 18.5%, in an environment in which  there has been a slump in sales, 3% in electricity and 15% in gas compared to 2010. And there have been very low  spreads, with procurement costs that have not been compensated by an equivalent increase in the electricity sale  price. And there has been an 18% reduction in output, because of the low market spreads.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses have shown a stable evolution. There has been a reclassification of the CERT and CESP  levies, that are expenses imposed by the regulator for energy efficiency programs, based on GON, totaling €42  million. So that's why there has been a strong increase.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And the main – as regards the main operating variables for the Renewables business, operating capacity has  grown 12% and now stands at 12,800 megawatts, and installed capacity has also increased and now stands at  13,450 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The average load factor stands at 24.9%, nearly 25% relative to the previous year, although as the Chairman  pointed out, there has been a slump of 3.3%, because of the low levels of wind. And output has grown 14.5% and  now stands at 20.7 terawatt hour. Prices, €68.5 per megawatt hour, which is below the €72.3 megawatt hour over  the same period of 2010, because of the greater weight of the business in the U.S.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So, the greater installed power has been partially compensated by lower price and by the negative impact of the  rate of exchange. That has subtracted €40 million and has produced a growth of the gross margin of 7.5%, which  means €1.5 billion, which in the Renewable business, is 5%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Total EBITDA has grown 6.6% and now stands at €1,035 million and EBITDA of the Renewables business has  gone up 6% and now stands at €1,029 million. And the Gas business only has made a contribution of €7 million in  terms of the EBITDA, although it has improved the position we had relative to last year.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The greater installed power of Renewables and investments in the regulated businesses in Spain and U.K. have  also produced this growth.
