The financial results have improved 19.7%, thanks, among other things, to the impact  that has been brought about by the hedging actions and this nearly accounts for €90 million in relation to 2010,  because as you know, Iberdrola does this to reduce the volatility of net profits by using financial derivatives. The  Iberdrola impact has to do with reversal of provisions, that accounts for €85 million, and which is compensated by  a similar impact in minority actions, although we know that they total €92 million this year, vis-à-vis €34 million  of last year.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: [ph] It has to be said on this call (41:11) that in spite of the difficult market conditions, we've maintained the FADE  emissions in particular. On September the 26, we had the fifth issue totaling €1.5 billion of the €6 billion, we'll  take those ones we have an opportunity window in the market. And the government made it possible for us to  move onto private operations, which gives us much more flexibility as regards issuing bonds.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Thank you very much. Well, to conclude, I would like to underline that once again, the results of Iberdrola show
texts.text: how suitable our industrial project is. It's a project that is based on the energy business and it's a project that is  always related to our operating efficiency approach. It's a project that has allowed us to optimize the risk of  exposure to a specific area or activity through the geographic diversification of business.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Thank you very much. Well, to conclude, I would like to underline that once again, the results of Iberdrola show
texts.text: Diversification, it's a project that is focused on sustained cash flow and on maintaining an optimum financial  structure. And in a period that has been characterized by a complex operating and financial environment,  especially in Q3, this value creation process has allowed us to carry an improving result. And the gross margin has  grown, thanks to the healthy situation of the regulated Renewable businesses. That account for two-thirds of the  total that has compensated the trends in the liberalized business that is still affected by the situation of the British  market.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Thank you very much. Well, to conclude, I would like to underline that once again, the results of Iberdrola show
texts.text: And the Renewables business, well, we expect there to be an improvement in results in all geographic areas in Q4,  because of the increase in installed power and because there is going to be more wind, especially in Spain, where  the production of Q4 last year was very low, which is what has happened this year in Q3.

file: IBE - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 24October2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The first business that Mr. San Pedro will [ph] develop (1:01) is going to be the networks. And afterwards a coffee  break, with no more 20 minutes, will be offered after this chapter. The second block includes generation and  supply and renewables, plus an intervention of our CFO, Pepe Sáinz, related to the financial management. After  Pepe Sáinz's speech, the lunch will be served outside this room.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: EBITDA of the group amounts nearly €5.8 billion with an increase of 3.4%, mainly driven by renewables and  international network businesses. We have grown more than 15% of the total EBITDA.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As I have just said, the EBITDA of the group is up 3.4%. The breakdown of business shows a significant growth in  renewables and an increased contribution from the most stable businesses: regulated and renewable which  amount, as I mentioned before, 75%, including the Mexico – the Mexico regulated generation.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Renewables growth 16.4% at EBITDA level, thanks to an increase in output of 12.5% due to 7.5% increase in  operating capacity and 4.8% improvement in load factor. Finally, the wind blows. We've already had years we will  not – to have no much wind. This year is becoming normal. [indiscernible] (05:36) gains have also contributed to  the increase in EBITDA.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Finally, the generation businesses showed some EBITDA decrease of 1.7% as a result of lower output and the  negative impact of certain non-recurring charges and provision in the United Kingdom. Again, the contribution of  networks and renewable business; we grew 15% and 13% respectively. Part of this increase is explained by the  integration of Elektro incorporating the second quarter 2011. Nevertheless, excluding its contribution,  international EBITDA will grow 10% despite the negative impact of non-recurring provision in CERT/CESP in the  United Kingdom as I mentioned before.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Renewables in Spain grows 19.3% at EBITDA level as a consequence of an output increase of [ph] 12.4% (06:53)  and significant efficiency improvement with net operating expenses down 5.7%, despite increase in operating  capacity.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Finally, the generation businesses shows a flat evolution in the period as 19.1% output reduction mainly due to the  low hydro resource in combined cycle production has been offset by better prices and the positive impact of the  Supreme Court ruling on social bonus. Despite this negative evolution, the solid performance of our international  businesses has reinforced the group capacity to generate operating cash flow which amount to more than €4.7  billion with an increase of 6.5% more than doubling the 2011 growth.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: There is also a €225 million positive FX impact. The basic margin rose a little bit less, 4.2% to €9.4 billion as  revenues from CO2 allowances allocated fell 47% due to lower prices and lower CO2 consumption.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As already explained by the Chairman, the 3.4% growth in EBITDA is driven by Iberdrola's international business.  Both networks and renewables have seen their EBITDA rising 2.5% and 16.4%, respectively, while generation and  supply EBITDA fell 1.7%. Renewables and the regulated business, including the Mexican generation, contributed  76% to our total EBITDA. EBITDA for the international activities is 55% of the total as of September 2012.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Despite the dollar's strength, as you can see, there is an improvement in net operating expenses of €22 million due  to the storm cost recorded in the nine months of 2011, and a non-recurring effect related to better conditions of  our healthcare contract.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: About the generation and supply business in Spain, the output in the ordinary regime has been down 19.2%,  driven by a fall of 48% in hydro production and a 70% lower production in combined cycles, partially  compensated by a 5% increase in our nuclear production.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The basic margin in the UK generation and supply business has reached €112 (sic) [€812] (19:11) million, a 22%  increase driven mainly by the business supply. The supply – sorry, the supply business with margins recoverings  in minimum levels seen in 2011, thanks to the improvement of our procurement costs and the increase in tariffs in  August 2011. It also reflects a positive FX impact of €54 million. All these effects more than compensate the 23%  lower output due to plant stoppages and lower gas spreads affecting the wholesale and generation business.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBITDA at the renewable business is up 16.4% to €1,182 million. The main drivers are a 12.5% higher output with  growth in all geographical areas. 1.2 percentage points improvement of the load factor to 26.1% due mainly to  weather and wind conditions in Spain and in the UK and higher average prices, €71 per megawatt hour versus  €68.5 in the first nine months of 2011, due to the exchange rate evolution and a higher contribution of the areas  with higher selling price. All of these factors have driven a 22% growth in the EBITDA from pure renewable  activities. The operating capacity is up 7.5% to 13,760 megawatts and the installed capacity is up 6.5% to 14,319  megawatts. Net operating expenses are slightly up, 1.3% but well below the increasing capacity. So the business  shows an improvement of the net operating expenses per megawatt ratio of 4.6%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The EBIT of the Group drops 2.4%, showing a worse evolution than the EBITDA due to the 216 increase in  provisions due to the Elektro integration, some non-recurring provisions in Brazil related to insolvencies and  write-offs linked to development costs in renewables, cancelled projects for over €50 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The 4.5% increase in amortizations is due to the integration of Elektro and the investments in networks and  renewables, partially compensated by the increase in the usual life of wind farms from 20 to 25 years.  Amortizations and provisions have also been negatively affected by the appreciation of the dollar and the sterling.

file: IBE - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 23October2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The rise in production and the reduction of unitary costs both in traditional and renewable generation have been  the major contributor to this result. The increase in gross margin has been coupled with a reduction in net  operating expenses in all businesses. Networks has improved by 1.5%, Renewables by 3.4%, and Generation &  Supply by 6.4%. As a whole, the group's net operating expenses fell by 2.9%. In this regard, IBERDROLA remains  fully committed to operating efficiency, which, as I have already mentioned, improved by 4.6% throughout the  period. Nevertheless, operational improvements are wiped out by the increase in levies, which, as of September  30, amounted to €1.2 billion, 45% higher than the previous year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The introduction of taxes to generation in Spain impacting both traditional and renewable energy is especially  significant given to the fact that our country's levies have increased beyond 100% up to €800 million,  consolidating itself as the major cost item in our country, higher than labor cost and external services.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The remuneration for the distribution activity has been trimmed by €79 million whilst in generation the so-called  green cent under the incentive to investment cut returns by €43 million. Moreover, the increase in taxes to  traditional and renewable generation leads to an increase of €381 million in expenditure.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The recent and mandatory efficiency and environmental government measures in the United Kingdom such as the  higher price of renewable certificates, the ROCs and the increase in electricity and gas access charges and removal  of free allocation of emission allowances, et cetera, coupled with low margins had led to economic losses in the  country's Generation & Supply business with a negative EBITDA of €27 million, forcing the company to adjust  prices in this country very shortly.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain taxes amounted to €792 million. They've doubled compared to 2012 with an impact of €381 million,  thanks to the fiscal measures for energy sustainability approved by the government in 2012 to reduce the tariff  deficit, a tax of 7% on invoicing, a rate on hydraulic production, a tax on nuclear waste and the green tax.  Regarding the gross margin there, another €27 million because of the green taxes I mentioned.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The United Kingdom paid €264 million in the first nine months mainly because of the eco-energy efficiency  program. As a result of all this, the EBITDA for the group fell 4.1% to €5.542 billion, including a negative impact  of €150 million because of the exchange rate. Excluding which the EBITDA reduction is 1.5%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The increase in taxes mentioned earlier, the reduction in the remuneration for the regulated business in Spain in  the first quarter and adjusted for the nine months of the year, the loss of emission rates, and the increase in  regulatory costs in the UK together with tariff impacts in Brazil are other factors that are relevant in the fall of the  EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, UK and Mexico, EBITDA fell 8.9% to €1.531 billion affected by an increase of €326 million in taxes  amounted to €811 million for the period. And this is related to the loss in free CO2 emission rights. And this  means an increase of 6.1% to the gross margin and efficiency improvements that reduced net operating expenses  by 6.4%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the gross margin the operating improvements resulting from the favorable hydro conditions in Spain  and a greater customer base in the UK has offset the effects of the weakness in prices and demand in Spain, as well  as the absence of free allocations for CO2 and the compression of margins in the UK.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain the gross margin grew 11%, thanks to the fact that output was 2.4% higher with an increase of 91% in  hydro production, which more than offsets the lower thermal output, which lost 52% and nuclear output, which  falls 8.4%. Additionally margins have increased due to the lower costs associated to a production mix in a high  hydro context and due also to the green taxes and payments for capacity.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK the gross margin fell 0.6% although excluding the exchange rate, it increases by 4.1% with the retail  growth because of a greater customer base and higher sales price. But this is partially offset in negative terms by  the drop in generation and wholesale, and affected in particular by the great cost of the carbon tax, ROC increases,  increases in distribution and transmission costs, and also the lower weight of coal in the mix affected by the  closing of Cockenzie and shutdowns in Longannet.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The output increased 0.7% and this increases the gross margin by 6.4% and has reduced the net operating  expenses. This has made it possible to offset the increase in taxes which increased 120%, amounting to €139  million after tripling renewable Spain because of the inclusion of €61 million associated to the sustainability  measures under Law 15/2012 and the negative effect of the exchange rate of €18 million, without which the  EBITDA would grow 4%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The operating capacity increases 0.7% to 13,850 megawatts with the new installed capacity offsetting the sale of  assets. The average load factor improved to 27% in spite of a poor quarter for wind power because of good  developments in the first few months of the year. And this means an increase in production of 6.4%. The average  price dropped 1.2% to €69.8 per megawatt hour because of the drop of 3.5% in the final price in Spain because of  the regulated tariff change according to Royal Decree 2/2013, which is not sufficiently offset through higher prices  in other geographic areas.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net profits fell 3% to €2.274 billion and recurring net profit 4.6% to €1.71 billion. As in the first six months of the  year, in the EBIT, there is a negative impact of €1.665 billion because of the write-off of the renewable business in  the United States. This negative impact is offset by revaluation of assets in Spain with a net impact of €1.537  billion. Additionally, regarding corporate tax for the quarter, there is a positive impact of €71 million because of  the reduction of corporate tax in the UK. In September 2013, there's a reduction in the tax rate at 3% compared to  a 2% reduction in 2012.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the rest of the items under that figure, €1.121 million are deficit pending recovery from the total  generated in 2013. Another €137 million are related to financial taxes at IBERDROLA because of the new  sustainability measures, and we haven't yet recovered at the closing of the quarter. And Spanish Parliament has  finally approved the extraordinary credit of €2.3 billion.

file: IBE - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 22October2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Before presenting the result, I would like to make a brief reference to the European Council meeting that will be  held over the next two days, given its relevance for the energy sector. In this sense, as I regarded the new climate  and energy policy framework, we are confident that heads of the state and government will approve the binding  target proposed by European Commission to reduce 40% the level of emission into 30% compared with 1990  levels. Following our environmentally-friendly strategy as of last years, Iberdrola fully agrees with this proposal.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As a pioneer in the development of clean energies and world leader in wind farms, Iberdrola is firmly committed  to the fight against climate change. In fact, we already have a level of CO2 emission 30% below the average for  European electricity sector, and we are committed to reduce 20% our emission by 2020 as compared with those of  2007.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moreover, together with our colleagues from major European utilities, we have already defended the foremost  political leaders of European Union the necessity that Europe's energy and climate policy be focused on the  European carbon market. We believe the European Trading Scheme, ETS, should be the core instrument to  reduce emission and promote investment in low carbon technologies. It's essential that this m echanism be  accompanied by the implementation of the market stability reserve by the new commission as soon as possible,  certain by – latest 2017 in order to limit the volume of allowances and strengthen the price signal of the ETS  reducing carbon price volatility. All these will certainly be a good starting point ahead of the global climate  summit to be held next year in Paris.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Networks, the impact of the drought in Brazil will be significantly reduced, mainly thanks to 38% tariff increase  for Elektro, approved by the regulator last August, which this past quarter has been applied only for one month.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Additionally, there is an open sectorial negotiation in Brazil about the accounting of regulatory asset and liabilities  aimed to reduce the volatility of distribution companies' accounts. Due to [indisc ernible] (5:37) delay the impact  in drought, we expect the negotiation to be finished before year-end.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Going back to this third quarter result, EBITDA as I mentioned reached €5.2 billion in the period. By businesses,  Generation & Supply has a very good performance with an increase of 26% in EBITDA, almost reaching €1.9  billion. The higher production with a more efficient generation means and the exceptional contribution of the gas  businesses has been the main drivers of our growth.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Networks, EBITDA remains flat as a good operational performance in United Kingdom and Spain offset the  impact of the drought in Brazil. We will be probably [indiscernible] (7:07) recover mostly through the already  mentioned tariff increase approved by Elektro, and these are countermeasures which I also already mentioned  before as well.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, the renewable businesses has been heavily impacted by regulatory measures in Spain, where EBITDA has  fall 44% versus previous year. Thanks to the contribution of Latin A merica, United Kingdom and United States,  the drop in EBITDA for the global renewable business has been reduced to only 20%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Reported net external services grew 4.4% v ersus the 6% growth at June, mainly due to the UK business, linked to  the increasing capacity in renewables and specific projects cost associated to the commercial IT system, marketing  campaigns, and consultancy services related with the ED1.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Levies fell by 9.5% to €1,135 million due to a €52 million reduction in the UK due to lower government levies that  will be reversed in the Q4, and a favorable high court ruling in Spain accounted for, in Q2, for €111 million linked  to legal actions that we initiated with the previous government, penalized the emission-free technologies by  forcing them to pay CO2 costs.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA grew 27 % with an 8.4% increase in gross margin due to the 8.4% higher output after a 28%  decrease in hydro and a 1% increase in nuclear production. Higher output and lower costs have compensated  lower wholesale prices.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA fell 20% to €927  million, driven by a 44% decrease in the Spanish EBITDA, affected by the  remuneration costs from the Spanish regulatory measures, the low spot prices, and a low load factor in Q3.  Thanks to the geographical diversification of the business, the positive contribution of the rest of the geographies  partially compensated following Spain. Gross margin falls 14% and net operating expenses increased 6.2%,  especially due to the new offshore operating capacity that has just been added and a positive one-off accounted in  Q3 of 2013.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The 3.5% increase in operating capacity to 13,773 megawatts in operation compensate the slight decrease in  average load factor to 26.8%. The weighted average price dropped 14% to €60 per megawatt hour, driven by a  34% decrease in Spain. In Spain, the EBITDA declined 44% as explained previously.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the UK, the EBITDA grows 11%, with 5.7% increase in onshore output and FX positive impact that compensates  the lower average price and to mention that the offshore wind farm is starting to contribute in Q3.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the U.S., the EBITDA grew 2%, mainly thanks to the 0.8% output increase and the trading profits, taking  advantage of weather conditions that we had in the first quarter. Higher prices on local currency were offset by the  adverse FX movement. Excluding FX-negative impact, EBITDA grows 5.5%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Latin America, EBITDA rose 100%, thanks to the 49% increase in output due to a higher installed capacity in  Mexico and Brazil. In the rest of the world, EBITDA decreased 39% due to the sale of the Polish wind farms in  2013.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: EBIT reached €3,074 million, €1.7 billion more than in September 2013, which included, as you remember, €1.7  billion of gross asset impairments, and mainly related to U.S. gas and renewables. Depreciation and amortization  grows 3.5%, mainly driven by our UK business, with addition of operating capacity in Renewables, Networks and  the increase in IT investments.

file: IBE - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 21October2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Renewable businesses continued to show a very good performance with EBITDA having increased by almost  23%. Thanks to a strong output, especially in United Kingdom, which our West of Duddon Sands offshore wind  farm exceeding availability and resource expectation. However, in United States, green output was lower than  usual due to the impact of the [ph] Maine (04:01). On the other hand, our Regulated Generation in Mexico is  growing strongly with a 38.5% greater in EBITDA due to our increased activity within private customers. Finally,  the liberalized activities in Spain and UK reflect a negative evolution, with a decrease in EBITDA of 14.3%. The  reason behind Spain reduction is a lower production and higher cost and taxes compared to the last year's  extraordinary results.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Meanwhile, the situation in UK is affected by three main factors; the increase in government obligation, the rise of  carbon tax, and the operation implementation to all our new financial integration system, which has require  extraordinary cost to successfully maintain our client base and even increase it despite the problem detected  during this phase.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, we are progressing on the development of St. Brieuc in France, which are planned investment of €2.6  billion, and an expected commission date by 2022. These three projects together with the West of Duddon Sands  already in operation, will add up to circa 1,800-megawatt of offshore installed capacity in our group.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Onshore will also follows a positive trend, with two new projects to be started in UK, which add to the four already  under construction. United States, we are currently building four wind farms, which have 100% of future  production covered under PPAs. This added to our Brazil and Mexico wind farm under construction, result in  overall additional onshore capacity of more than 1,200 megawatts to be commissioning between 2016 and 2017.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Spain, after the recent memorandum, the Royal Decree published last week established new auction for the  wind power that we are analyzing. In Mexico, during this last quarter, we have awarded two new projects with  regulated or long-term contracts. One combined cycle and one cogeneration plant to be added to the four plants  already under construction.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Altogether, they will add up to 1,600 megawatt to the operation before the end of 2018. Altogether, our installed  power in this country will reach more than 7,000 megawatt at that date. The increasing generation through  intermittent renewable sources to require a storage capacity to stock energy surplus, and supply it to the system  when it's needed.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Iberdrola approach to this need is to invest in a storage technology, in which pumping is a much more efficient  and larger-scale solution than other more fashionable and highly advertised technologies. We have just finished  the construction of Cortes-La Muela in Spain, the largest of this kind in Europe with 1,800-megawatt of storage  capacity.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And now, in Portugal, we are starting the construction of a new pumping storage plant on the Tâmega River with  1,200 megawatt capacity expected to be commissioned in 2023. Altogether, will amount to close 6,000 megawatts  of pumping capacity between Spain, UK and Portugal, providing efficient energy supply at peak hours for several  million of households. In Networks, as a result of our agreement with Ofgem in the United Kingdom, RIIO-T1  transmission and RIIO-ED1 in distribution are in progress with a combined Totex of nearly €9 billion for the next  six years to eight years.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In United States, we are negotiating several growth opportunities in transmission network in Maine and New  York. This project will address reliability and congestion issues and will provide additional transmission capacity  for Renewables.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Spain, also, we have launched the set of new product to cover the potential demand of self-consumption and  benefit from our smart grids. For instance, Smart Solar is a full service for self-consumption solar installation for  households and companies or plan a tu medida, tailor-made plans. These and other products have resulted in an  increase of our customer base.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Revenues grew 6.7% to €23.7 billion, while procurements rose 6.3% to €14.2 billion, due to higher costs in a worse  production mix and price of CO2 rising, especially in the UK. Gross margin increased 7.3% to €9.5 billion as  revenues grew more than procurements.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Finally, Elektro grew 163% to BRL 614 million as the first nine months in 2015 have not recorded any negative  drop impact – drought impacts, while in the first months of 2014, we included BRL 298 million of negative  impact. This difference will be reversed in Q4 as last year; we had a [ph] BRL 441 million (18:51) positive impact  recognized in one go past drought impacts. EBITDA growth in Elektro is also helped by the tariff reviews that we  had in August 2014 and 2015.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €1,180 million with a 6.8% decrease in gross margin, due to the 10% lower output and  increased procurement costs, due to the increased thermal waste of the production mix. Also, Gas business had a  non-recurrent negative comparison versus 2014. Levies are up net €64 million, basically due to the already  mentioned CO2 allowances accounted for in 2014, compensated by the positive court ruling in 2015.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA reached £182 million. Wholesale and Generation business gross margin decreased by 22% due  to higher costs, with the carbon tax growing from £9 to £18 from April 1 onwards. Retail business gross margin  decreased by 2%. Higher volumes in gas with a 10% increase in demand do not compensate the 17% lower gross  margin in retail power due first to the increase in non-related energy costs, like the ROCs and the transmission  and distribution charges. And in addition to that, the difficulties in the deployment of the new retail IT system that  increased net operating expenses by £32 million. Despite this, we have been able to maintain a relatively stable  number of customers.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA reached €353 million, 13.9% more, with a 5.5% lower output compensated by the recovery  in prices. In the UK, EBITDA reached £219 million, up 60%, with 30% higher output due to better wind  conditions and West of Duddon Sands offshore wind farm positive contribution.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA was $396 million, 16% down, with a 7% decrease in output due to climate conditions in the  West. Baffin wind farm 200 megawatts in Texas in operations since Q2 will help us to improve our performance in  the next months.

file: IBE - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 26October2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Networks, EBITDA increased 8.6% due to the improved business performance in Spain and the United States,  more than offsetting the negative foreign exchange impact. In Renewables, the Spain and U.S. increased output  by 6% and 7% respectively, offsetting 18.3% lower output than UK. But in total, the Renewable output grew by  4.4% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Generation and Supply, EBITDA grew 1.7%. In Spain, hydro output is up 56.2%; while in the UK, higher spot  market activity compensate for the closure of Longannet. The overall energy produced globally by our company  was 2.1% higher than 2015 with almost two-third emission free.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Operating cash flow has increased by 9.5% to €4.7 billion exceeding investment by almost €1.7 billion. At the  business level, operating cash flow continues to exceed investment across all our businesses, except for  renewables due as you can see, of the accelerated execution of our offshore projects.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: We are also leading green financing in bond markets. An example of this is the €700 million euro Green Bond we  issued last September, with an eight-year maturity and all-in cost under 0.5%. As a result of this our cost of debt  has gone down from 4.10% to 3.46%. I will now briefly reveal the main project underway. We show our progress  in the execution of 2016, 2020 plan. In networks in UK, we have a stable long-term return under the current  distribution and transmission regulatory framework.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So, an example of our networks construction are the Western Link project, South W est Scotland, Beauly Denny  Lines all in schedule. In United States, as announced last quarter, the New York rate cases were approved  including higher tariff for three years starting in May this year. And the final decision of the Connecticut electric  rate case for the next three years also effective on January 2017 is expected in December 2016. Other  transmission project are in progress in New York, Connecticut and Maine.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, we have continued with the deployment of smart grid having digitalized 50,000 secondary substation in  almost 160,000 kilometers of line, which represent over 65% of our medium and low voltage line. A distribution  regulated asset base of €8,690 million and a new remuneration scheme have also been approved. With the first  regulatory period going from January 2016 to December 2019, increasing 2016 remuneration by 2.5%. In Brazil,  the Elektro distribution tariff has increased by 9.11% effective for August. Overall in Networks, 85% of the growth  investment included in the plan are already underway.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: With regard to our 16 million retail customers, 9 million of which already have smart meters installed, we offer a  variety of product and services, being the only utility to offer tailored tariff based on kind of use. Other services we  are offering include remote control heating, distributed generation and storage, electrical vehicle charges or the  newest ScottishPower application called PowerUp which enable customers to buy their own energy in daily units  from their mobile phones.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As you can see in slide 13, in Renewable Offshore, we have over 1,000 megawatts under construction. In  Germany, Wikinger, 350 megawatts initial production is expected in 2017. In the UK, 70% of the equipment and  services for East Anglia 1 have been contracted, and the first output of these 714 megawatts capacity is expected  in 2019. Finally, in France, we are doing preliminary work in St. Brieuc where initial production of this 500  megawatt capacity is expected in 2022.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In relation to our Onshore wind farms, we have over 1,900 megawatts under construction in the United States,  United Kingdom, Mexico, Brazil and Spain, over 80% of which are to be commissioned between 2016 and 2018.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: We also have 336 megawatts of solar photovoltaic plant in construction in Mexico and United States to be  commissioned between 2017 and 2019.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As for our relevant bet in Offshore Wind, in which – in addition to the current project, we have just described, we  have 3,100 megawatts of future project in our two main hubs in the British North Sea and the German Baltic Sea.  Altogether, they are up to almost 5,000 megawatt of offshore capacity.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Just to give you an idea, in slide 16 shows that the height of wind turbine generators in East Anglia 1 will be  similar to the Eiffel Tower, and the diameter of the rotor will be larger than that of the London Eye. At the same  time, important progress is being made in the generation capacity of the turbines. What we have gone from 3.6  megawatt in our first offshore wind farm in West of Duddon Sands to 5 megawatt in Wikinger, up to 7 megawatts  in East Anglia 1, and probably more than 8 megawatt in St. Brieuc in France.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, you can see in slide 17 in Mexico, we have been present for over 30 years. We have almost 4,000  megawatts of additional capacity in construction, in renewables, combined-cycle and cogeneration. So, by 2020,  our total installed power in the country will reach almost 10,000 megawatts. And by 2019, our output in Mexico  probably will exceed our current production in Spain. Therefore, the execution of our investment plan is well on  track with current capacity under construction adding 4,057 megawatts by 2018 and by 2020, almost 7,000  megawatts of regulated and contracted generations. And probably capacity will be added mainly from Mexico and  United States.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On slide 20, you can see that Avangrid investment plan is progressing with the construction of 744 megawatts in  offshore wind farms and 66 megawatts of solar photovoltaic. As a PTC extension up to 2020 has recently been  approved, we have taken the necessary step to be eligible ordering 2,000 megawatt of wind turbines and  repowering 350 megawatts to have the opportunity to be before the 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As for Networks, we have in construction several transmission and distribution project such as Lewiston Loop in  Maine, Metro-North Corridor in Connecticut and Ginna Retirement in New York. And we have another potential  opportunities such as deployment of 1.8 million smart meters in the New York under Reforming Energy Vision  strategy.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Over the last months, much has been said about global warming as a consequence of climate change and the  urgent need to limit temperature increase. Actually, very few global issues have accomplished such as a  consensus on the imperative need to take an action.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, next 4 of November, the Paris Agreement, under which most countries has committed to reduce the CO2  emission, will enter into force sponsored by and lead by United Nations. This is going to accelerate any transition  into the carbonization where the electricity sector has the key role to play with more renewable energies, more in  smarter networks to integrate more distributed generation and delivery services, to increase energy efficiency and  more storage capacity. Therefore, utilities have to transform their businesses model into the so-called utility of the  future.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Iberdrola, we have already been implemented in transformation from the past decades, and we are, today,  number one renewable producers among European utilities, leading lower emission companies in the sector, the  cleanest United States integrated utility, with almost zero emission and the second wind producer.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Leading digitalization with over 160,000 kilometers of digitalized smart grids and more than 9 million smart meters  with full connectivity and with a storage capacity over 4,000 megawatts, enough for more than 1 million homes.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As a consequence, we have been recognized by the Dow Jones Sustainability Index as the World's top utility in  2016. Also we are the only European utility included in the 17 editions of this ranking. During the first nine months  of the year, we have employed 1,917 new persons.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA was up 1.6%, reaching €1.2 billion, thus improving the 2.5% fall in the first half. Gross margin  was up 3.1% as higher output driven by a 56% in hydro production and a 4.6% in nuclear together with a higher  retail activity more than offset the lower gas results minus €50 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA grew by £4.8 million to £187 million with a 5.9% decrease in gross margin compensated by a  4.2% decrease in net operating expenses and a 30% decrease in levies. In the Wholesale and Generation  business, gross margin decreased by 5% due to a lower output and higher carbon tax, but it is more than  compensated by the improvement in non-operating expenses following the Longannet closure. As a result,  EBITDA increased by £22 million to £34.8 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Retail business gross margin fell 6.1%. Higher unitary margins in gas did not compensate 16% lower gross  margin in retail power due to the increase in non-energy-related costs and lower volumes driven by milder  weather conditions than last year. Expenses included an OFGEM customer compensation negative ruling of €26  million offset by lower levies due to the ECO extension. As a result, EBITDA decreased by £70 million to £152  million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, in the Rest of the World, EBITDA reached €70 million or €3 million lower due to the 10% lower output  partially offset by lower net operating expenses. EBIT increased 7.6% to €3,257 million. Amortizations fell by €8  million driven by the closure of Longannet and extension of the useful life of wind farms, more than compensating  UIL consolidation and the increase in depreciation due to the larger investments. Provisions grew by €10 million  to €169 million, affected by the UIL consolidation and the increase in bad debt provisioning.

file: IBE - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 7November2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The resilience and international diversification of the group has allowed us to compensate for the extraordinary  low result in generation [ph] modeling Spain due to the strained (01:50) hydro conditions. Net investment had  reached €4 billion in line with our planned focus on guaranteeing sustainable growth in the long term. This  represents a 31.5% increase versus September 2016, driven by the acceleration of onshore and offshore wind  investment.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The new investment has been able to partially offset the extraordinary low hydro condition in Spain, which have  had an impact of around €400 million at EBITDA level and the weak result in the Liberalised business in United  Kingdom, mainly due to lower demand and lower margins. Excluding these extraordinary factors, growth will be in  line with the expected mid-single-digit growth.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, hydro output has been 58% lower than the same period of 2016 when it was typically high. This means  8.8 terawatt hours less production even compared to the historical average, hydro output was 39% lower. The first  nine months has been one of the driest ever registered [ph] gear (03:07) as you can see in the slide number 7.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA remained stable, growing 1.8% in constant currency terms. This performance is driven by  the positive output of the United Kingdom, thanks to the higher wind factor and the new capacity added, resulting  a 35% increase in EBITDA [indiscernible] (04:03). On the other hand, low wind factor has led to 11% lower  EBITDA in Spain after a very good 2016 performance. Finally, as previously mentioned, Liberalised EBITDA fell  40.6%, driven by Spain and UK.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net investment continued increasing to almost €4 billion, as I mentioned before, with 91% allocated to Networks,  Renewables, and Contracted Generation. Out of these investments, 77% has been allocated to growth, €1.1  billion more than the first nine months of 2016. These investments are – we are securing the group long-term  growth. We have 7,361 megawatt of renewables and contracted generation capacity in construction, of which 2.7  gigawatt will be commissioned in the remainder of 2017 and 2018. That includes our 350 megawatt of German  offshore wind farm which all the 70 turbines are already installed, over 500 megawatt of onshore wind in different  countries, 336 megawatt of solar photovoltaic in United States and Mexico, 428 of hydro capacity in Brazil, and  over 1 gigawatt of contracted gas-fired power in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Networks, which accounted for over 30% of our total investment result, result will continue improving, thanks to  the investment approved as part of the new regulatory arrangement signed in the last years. In United States, in  addition to the New York and Connecticut three-year rate cases effective until 2019, we are expecting new  Southern Connecticut Gas rate case to be effective from January 1, 2018.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Concerning renewables, the government has confirmed the budget for the upcoming competitive auction and we  believe this is the right path to follow. As for backup capacity, given the low [ph] resale (07:29) margin, it's  especially urgent to continue taking measures to improve the design of capacity mechanism to ensure that it  encourage the new build of efficiency plan.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the United States, Avangrid continues to deliver robust earnings with adjusted net profit up to 14% in the period  reaching $494 million, driven by the good performance of its core business. The execution of the Plan 2020 also  continue on track. Investments are up 39% to $1.6 billion. 487 megawatt of new wind PPAs has been executed in  the period, including 86 megawatts in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, we have been present for over 20 years. EBITDA grew 23% in the period to $480 million thanks to the  6,157 megawatt of capacity in operation. And our commitment to the country is reflected in our additional 4,167  megawatt of thermal and renewable capacity in construction. So, by 2020, we'll have more than 10,300 megawatt  in operation. Today, we are the largest private producer in the country, and we will continue to be so in the future.

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Complying with the merger [ph] TransGrid (10:56) with our partners, we've also been working on the necessary  steps for the future listing of the company in the stock exchange, which is expected before the year-end. The new  company is focused on securing long-term growth opportunities. [ph] Our grid (11:11) investment in networks of  over BRL 3 billion per annum will lead to a substantial increase in our regulatory asset base. In addition, the  company has over 1,000 megawatt of renewable capacity in construction to add to the 3,000 megawatt already in  operation.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Analyzing the different businesses and starting by networks, its EBITDA grew 5.4%, reaching almost €3.1 billion,  driven by Avangrid and Neo; that adds €56 million more to the EBITDA contribution at the network level. Gross  margin grew 6.2% and net operating expenses, 9.5%, due to the already mentioned €73 million impact of storm  costs and Neo consolidation. And taxes were up 3.5%, mainly due to the €20 million increase in the U.S.  business.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA was almost flat to €1,184 million, with €13 million of lower incentives and investments  recognized in the first nine months of 2017 versus last year. In the U.S., EBITDA was up 15.8% to $1,127 million.  As a consequence of the implementation of the new rate cases in Connecticut and New York, positive IFRS  impacts compared to last year that are flattening throughout the year, partially compensated by the already  mentioned storm costs with no impact on the U.S. GAAP, and 5.7% higher taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, EBITDA fell 2.4% to £567 million, with a 1.2% decrease in gross margin, affected by lower volumes  due to weather that will be recovered in following years and £10 million of negative settlements due to lower  investments.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, Brazil EBITDA grew 55.2% to almost BRL 900 million, driven by the corporate reorganization that  increased the EBITDA by BRL 199 million, 1.8% higher energy distributed, and the net effect of Elektro annual  tariff revisions increasing 9.1% in August 2016 and reducing 4% in August 2017 due to lower inflation.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Going country by country. In Spain, the EBITDA fell 34% to €792 million, driven by the abovementioned adverse  operating environment with 22% lower output and almost 9 terawatt hours decrease in hydro production versus  nine months of 2016.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The positive evolution of retail gas absorbed part of the margin compression with stronger retail activity and  higher gas results due to the positive review of prices of the portfolio during the second quarter that nevertheless  has been adjusted in minus €60 million in the third quarter. Levies were up 30% due to an unfavorable  comparison to 2016, that include €130 million of positive court rulings. In Mexico, EBITDA improved 27% to $445  million, thanks to the additional capacity in operation both with CFE and with private customers, and better prices  due to the higher CFE tariff.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Wholesale & Generation, EBITDA fell £48 million to minus £13 million with higher cost of gas and 28% lower  output after Longannet closure at the end of the first quarter of last year. In the Retail business, EBITDA  decreased £93 million to £59 million in the electricity business due to higher government obligation and lower  margins, government obligations are up £70 million, and in the gas business due to lower margins and volumes  linked to milder weather. Brazil adds €50 million to EBITDA that include regulated generation, and it will be fully  visible next year.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €366 million, 11% lower than last year as a result of an 11.9% lower output. In  addition, there is a positive adjustment of the investment incentive compensated by lower regulatory asset  recognition due to higher energy prices.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moving to financing, the last, compared to December 2016, net debt closed €4.5 billion above to €33.7 billion,  mostly due to the already explained Neoenergia integration that that's €3 billion debt, but also due to our net  investments that grew 31% to €4 billion while our cash flow generation has been impacted by very negative hydro  conditions in Spain and reduced our FFO by €300 million. Dividends and treasury stock repurchased amounting  €1.7 billion. Other effects that increased debt are mainly explained by capitalized costs, €0.7 billion; and working  capital variation, €0.6 billion; and other minor effects. FX impact reduced debt by €1.3 billion.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The last 12 months pro forma FFO increased by 5.4% to €6,652 million, adding €482 million from Neoenergia and  €160 million from the rest of the business, that is €300 million below our expectations due to the abovementioned  hydro conditions. Excluding the temporary effect of hydro conditions, group FFO would have reached almost €7  billion or 10% over 2016 FFO. Our FFO over net debt closed September at 19.7% versus 21.5% at the end of  2016.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So, thank you, Pepe. As you have seen, in spite of operational challenging first nine months of 2017, the group  has demonstrated once again the structural resilience. As of today, hydro output is 9.7 terawatt hours lower than  the same period of 2016. October has been the driest month since recorded, which will be [indiscernible] (27:04)  impossible to recover in the remaining seven weeks of the year, this 9.7 terawatt hours. But the positive non- recurring result will allow us to compensate this impact, even applying this result partially to strengthen the future  business profile in the group. With this, we will continue growing and delivering our 2020 Plan.

file: IBE - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 24October2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Growth in Renewables improved significantly, accelerating from 25% in the first half to 30% as of September. In  Spain, output was 24% higher due to normalization of production. In United States and UK, offshore wind output  registered double-digit increases, thanks to the additional onshore wind capacity and relatively good results. And  in onshore, our 350 megawatts Wikinger windfarm in Germany fully operational since April led to increase 140%  in offshore wind output compared to the year earlier. Generation and Supply did increase 70%, thanks to the  normalization of market condition the UK. The CFE tariffs in Mexico resulting from the government application of  the full levy tariff model and the consolidation of Brazilian Neoenergia. In total, the solid performance our  businesses led to an EBITDA increase of 22.5% despite the negative reported exchange impact to €312 million  due mostly to the dollar and Brazilian real.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net investment has reached €3.6 billion in the first nine months 2018. 43% of investments were allocated to  Networks, 34% to Renewables, and 20% to Generation and Supply businesses. The group will complete 2.2  gigawatt of new capacity in the fourth quarter of this year out of the 2.7 gigawatt added in the year. Up to 2022,  the group will increase its top power by 12 gigawatts, more than 20% of the current capacity, 10 gigawatt of which  correspond to project progressing, in most cases in construction. These figures include 3.5 gigawatt of combined  cycle we launched in PPAs in Mexico and 5.3 gigawatts of onshore wind, hydro, and solar photovoltaic. In  offshore wind, from the 2.5 gigawatts in progress, over 1.5 gigawatts are expected to be in operation by 2022.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our current four offshore target with PPA signed are expected to be operational by 2023. The first one is  [indiscernible] (00:05:17) in the North Sea. In Britain, we'll have 740 megawatt of capacity. It will be in operation in  2020. Saint-Brieuc in France will have a capacity of 500 megawatts, will commission in 2023. We have recently  agreed new condition with the French government adjust tariff but maintaining profitability of the project. In  Germany, last quarter, we have awarded the Baltic Eagle project in the Baltic Sea next to our Wikinger windfarm.  The technical works have already begun and the two sides are in negotiation for this project. We will add 486  megawatts of capacity by 2023 as well. On the other side of the Atlantic, in Massachusetts, AVANGRID is making  progress in the first large scale American offshore windfarm project.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This windfarm will be built in partnership with the team has worked with us in our UK offshore project West of  Duddon Sands. Half of the 100 megawatt of capacity is expected to be operational in 2021 and other half in 2022.  All-in-all, our total offshore wind capacity in Europe and United States will reach 3 gigawatt by 2023, with a total  investment of close to €9 billion. And we have an additional pipeline of 3.1 gigawatt in Europe and in the North  Baltic Sea, so UK and Germany. And in the United States, we're [ph] in the session (00:06:41) process in  approving the high market valuation of this technology. Our Vineyard project has potential for up to 2.2 gigawatt  already for future auction expected to be – to expect in the following months in Massachusetts, Connecticut, New  York and Rhode Island. Also in North Carolina, we have applied for a grid connection for our 2.4 gigawatt project  in the area where high demand is expected.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our operational efficiency measured by the net operating expenses to gross margin ratio also continues  accelerating improved by 180 basis points year-on-year up to the 80 basis points in the first quarter and the 100  basis points improvement in June. In fact, net operating expenses excluding Neoenergia and exchange rate rate,  impact remain flat. Efficiency will improve in the following months as Neoenergia continues with the  implementation [ph] and measures and defines (00:08:21) during the integration process and the rest of the group  continues to benefit from synergies and implementation of best practices. The company is also delivering on its  asset rotation plan, allowing us to focus on more profitable business based on low carbon technologies.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: During the past months, we have divested around €1 billion including the sale in the UK of our traditional  generation will make us [ph] country's power (00:08:47) the first power utility in the country that's 100% renewable  on the divesture of 50-megawatt solar thermal plant in Puertollano, Spain for €180 million as of the end of last  week.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I would now like to go through the most relevant regulatory fact that had taken place in the last quarter. In Spain,  the Royal Decree-Law for carbon measure for the energy transition was approved last week including the  suspension of 7% tax of power generation and the removal of so-called Green Cent in gas tax that are low and  applies only to coal in this moment. The measures are having a direct impact on coal prices reducing any import  as well as prices for consumers.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But the current allowed margin are too low to guarantee the sustainability of a complex business like Energy  Retail. As you know, in recent months, we have seen several new suppliers' failures. In any case, always, we are  confident that the biggest regulator will apply the model according to the parameters based in real data.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In United States, the Connecticut Natural Gas three-year rate case settlement is in progress settlement proposed  in 2019. In Mexico, as I mentioned, the implementation of the new CFE Tariff model progress as scheduled. And  in Brazil as probably I mentioned as well, Elektro tariff will increase in September.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The company has [ph] set a (11:19) new rate case for Central Maine Power and is moving forward with the  settlement of the rates for Connecticut Natural Gas and Berkshire Gas in Massachusetts for a new tariff effective  from 2019. Avangrid has also continued to make progress on development of the New England Clean Energy  Connect transmission project. The 1,200 megawatt high voltage, direct current transmission line [indiscernible]  (11:42) for clean competitive hydro generation from Quebec to New England.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The project is being managed by the same team that successfully executed the Maine Power reliability project  completed in 2015. And all parameters are expected during 2019 for the commission in 2022. In Renewables, the  company has 970 megawatt of additional onshore wind capacity in construction, all of which will be in operation  during 2019.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, the Vineyard Wind project is on track and has recently signed until 20 years contract with Massachusetts  Public Utilities Commission. In Brazil, [indiscernible] (12:24) register net profit of BRL 1,170 million, increasing  357% in the nine months.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: It has been possible thanks to the growth registered in businesses activities, the improvement in efficiency, the  positive tariff reviews already mentioned in Networks, and the decrease in the financial cost. Neoenergia has 800  megawatt of hydro generation capacity in construction due operational between 2019 and 2020, and 472  megawatts of wind capacity with commissioning expected in 2022.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But excluding these two effects, net operating expenses remained flat. Levies increased by 4.4% to €1.5 billion,  mainly affected by a €93 million increase in Spanish taxes on generation due to higher prices on higher output. I  would like to point out that taxes are paid based on the high-pool prices that internalizes CO2 cost. While  Iberdrola's revenues and generation are mainly based on forward references which have been lower than the  abovementioned pool prices in 2017 and 2018.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Tax authorities benefit from this high-pool prices through VAT and other taxes. In addition to that, they also collect  CO2 proceeds, which in the end is an additional tax. This impact has been partially compensated the impact of  the €93 million of the Spanish taxes and generation, has been compensated by positive FX and lower U.S. taxes.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA rose 38% to €1.8 billion, accelerating the 25% first half rise with growing results in all  markets. Output increased by 22% to 46,874 gigawatts hours with 4.3 percentage points higher load factor.  Installed capacity reached close to 30,000 megawatts. Spain is now the main contributor to Renewables EBITDA  with a 40% stake, followed by the U.S. and the UK.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €702 million, 46.8% higher than last year, mainly driven by higher output, both in hydro  with a 34% increase and in wind with a 4% increase. In the U.S., EBITDA grew 15.8% to $529 million, growing  versus the 4.4% increase in the first half, thanks to the 12.7% higher output linked to the 9% rise in average  capacity as summarized in our results in Q3.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA fell 1.6% to €669 million, recovering from the 27% losses at June, but it is still the only  business with lower results than 2017 first nine months affected by the one-off accounted for gas last year. And  as I previously mentioned, the big increase in taxes due to the high pool prices, while revenues are based on  bilateral contracts. Outputs recover and was almost flat versus a 10.7% fall in June with more associated  production compensating lower nuclear goal. Retail activity was strong.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thanks to regulatory tariff increases in Networks in United States and Brazil. The new solar photovoltaic and  onshore wind capacity in operation in Mexico, Brazil, and in the UK, and United States, plus the full year  contribution of our Wikinger offshore windfarm in Germany, and increasing input for our Mexico driven by two new  CCGT plants in operation and the evolution of the CFE tariff.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The delivery of our investment plan continues as programmed, almost 90% of the plan is in construction, 10  gigawatt in generation and renewables, and €14 billion in Networks project. As a result of our restored generation  capacity, we'll increase over 20% in our regulated asset value [ph] by 13% by 2022 (26:51).

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And we are maintaining our financial strength. Improving financial ratios, actively managing our debt with 70% on  long-term fixed rate and leading the green financial market.

file: IBE - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 24February2010 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: In 2009, IBERDROLA performance proved that the focus of growth in clean energy’s international  diversification followed along the last years has the right to follow. In one of the most difficult years  experienced in last decades, the company has continued to achieve improved results with EBITDA  up 6.3% and recurring profit 7.2%. IBERDROLA bet on wind energy has strengthened further our  production mix, driving 1.1 rise in output despite the weak demand evolution. Thanks of the, to the  investment made the last year, the Renovables international businesses have continued to drive  the group increasing results.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: In this sense, both businesses have obtained a combined 11% growth in EBITDA that offset the flat  evolution of the Spanish traditional energy business, affected by low prices in the wholesale market  and low demand.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: In 2009, the company output exceed 140,000 gigawatt hours production, increased by 1.1%  outperforming demand evolution. It was possible, as I mentioned before, thanks to the contribution  of renovable energy, which increased by 26% and offset the combined 2% decrease registered in  other technologies.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: Let me highlight the strong performance of wind energy in the fourth quarter of the year, in which its  contribution to the total production reached 17%, becoming the second technology by output. By  the way, yesterday was the record in Spain of production of wind. We bet on the records yesterday.  Close to the whole production of yesterday, the share out of IBERDROLA yesterday in the whole  Spanish market was 42% of the total electricity produced, which only in the case of wind was over  74 gigawatt hours in the day, so which is the record – absolute record. We will talk later now on  that.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: The main driver is increased weather output at the group wind farms in the United States with a  63% versus the fourth quarter of 2008 in Spain with 28% increase. As a result of this, overall world  production reversed the trend shown in the first nine months and show an increase in the first time  in 2009.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: I will also like to mention the level of hydro reserves in Spain, with as of December amounting  6,000 gigawatt hours plus a 33% increase over the 2008 end-year and highly continued to increase  in the first two months 2010, driving a 120% increase in hydro production in the first months of the  year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: The group as well has already in this increasing production continues as well. Yesterday as well we  produced close to 100 gigawatt hours of hydro in Spain yesterday. And the reserve of the total  group has already increased by more than 2,000 gigawatt hours toward the previous year. So  altogether, it’s close to 4,000 gigawatt hours more than the previous year, accounting those one  which has been producing, not counting the one in production. It’s in the dumps in this moment.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: In this respect, I would like to highlight the evolution of three businesses: Energy business in Spain,  which achieved 2% improvement mainly by led by cost saving in networks; RENOVABLES, which  is combining its ambitious capacity expansion plan with a clear focus on efficiency are shown by  the 16% fall in the expenses per megawatt installed; and finally, ScottishPower has reduced its cost  by 8% in sterling.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: Gross margin advanced 7.9% to €10.8 billion, driven by the growth in renewables and the regulated  business, especially the consolidation of IBERDROLA USA. The basic margin that reflects the net  effect of emission rights recorded in the income statement as an expense rose 6.3% to €11.1  billion.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: IBERDROLA’s out-performance in the ordinary regime production is due to the 5.4% growth in  hydro that partially offsets the decrease in nuclear and in the combined cycle production that fell  around 8% each.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: IBERDROLA average unitary fuel cost decreased 26% to €21 per megawatt hour due to the lower  price reviews in the gas contracts. This average fuel cost cannot be match by our competitors due  to our lower cost mix. This competitive advantage will be much more evident in 2010 as the hydro  conditions are much better this year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: EBITDA in the Spanish liberalized business fell 12.4% to €1.3 billion due to the lower generation  income affected by the energy prices and the mentioned 4.5% fall in demand. This was partially  offset by the €297 million lower CO2 levies and the greater supply activity. As a consequence of  this greater activity, operating expenses rose 10% to €775 million.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: EBITDA in renewables increased 11.8% to €1.3 billion. This is a 26% rise in the output that offsets  9.3% falling prices. The falling prices will not happen in 2010, as it was driven by the Spanish  operations that have its price hedged since July 2009 for 2010 and the first half of 2011. As a  consequence of this already in 2009 second half, prices rose 8% compared to the first half. In  addition, in the U.S. 90% of the megawatts in construction have already Pips signed at better prices  than the average of the previous years.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: The output growth is in line with increasing operating capacity that rose 2,184 megawatts to end ‘09  with 10,284 megawatts in operation. Expenses grew only 8.2% as OpEx per megawatt – operating  megawatt – fell 16.4%. It has been critical for IBERDROLA renewables the support of the U.S.  administration and after investing $1.6 billion in the U.S. market in 2009 it has been able to get  $577 million of grants which will allow the Group to continue growing fast in this country.
