texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: Networks contributed €663 million. In local currency EBITDA fell only 1% due to lower energy  distributed around 4%. IBERDROLA USA has contributed €450 million close to the group EBITDA  under IFRS accounting. Being 2009, the first full year of consolidation, in 2008 only fourth quarter  was incorporated into the accounts.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: In local currency, EBITDA grew 1.8% thanks to the 4% rise in the month at the distribution  companies. The efficiency measures and the lower expenses, which offset the negative impact  caused by the lower tariff review of the different distribution companies for 2008 and 2012 and the  disposal of some hydro assets have been some of the other negative impacts.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: EBITDA from non-energy business fell 7.7% to €336 million due to the lower activity in the real- estate division in the whole year, but recovering slightly in the fourth quarter after disposals of two  buildings. The engineering business contributed most of the group gross margin with 48% of the  total but it’s also responsible of the increase in operating expenses.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: Regular renewables will maintained its growth trend with a rising EBITDA of around 20% driven by  the built up of 1,550 megawatts and the expected evolution of price stability, especially in United  States where PPAs has already been signed, over 90% of the megawatts under construction.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for being here today. We are going to start right now with the
texts.text: As regard to liberalized businesses, we have staked a neutral evolution, resulting from the  combination of the performance of activity into the main market. In Spain, the signals of demand  recovery, especially in the month of February, together with the evolution of hydro production in the  first two month – as I mentioned before increased by 120% – and the level of hydro reserves, we  have increased by 30%, reached close to eight terawatt hours, make us feel optimistic about the  evolution in this country.

file: IBE - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 24February2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The renewable and liberalized businesses have been driven by an 8% increase in production  thanks to the greater contribution of the emission free technologies, which now represent 50% of  the total production for the Group; and in the case of Spain, this is 80%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2010, characterized by a complex macroeconomic and energy environment, has been a key year  for the optimization of the Group at all levels. During the period, we have carried out a number of  initiatives that will enable us to face the coming years from a more advantageous position. First of  all, we have continued to improve our current business portfolio and have strongly invested in  growth activities in areas and divesting in non-basic businesses.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 We have made compatible strong growth in our basic business with a stricter cash control, and for  this we have carried out divestments amounting to over €2,000 million in businesses in geographic  areas that are not basic for the Group. In this sense, we can highlight the sale of the gas  subsidiaries at Iberdrola USA in Connecticut and Massachusetts, of which $1,300 million was  obtained; the divestment of the Group business in Guatemala; and our reduction of our  shareholding in EDP where we still have 6.8%. At the same time, we have continued to invest in  our basic business where we have provided a total of €4,600 million in net terms.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Therefore, in 2010, we have focused on the most attractive organic growth opportunities, including  the wind power business in the U.S., driven by the federal government grant program and the  transportation line that will make it possible to interconnect New England with Canada. This project  has started during the second half of the year, and we have invested €100 million during this  period.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have also set up a single corporation that provides services to all businesses in an efficient and  flexible manner, avoiding duplications. I would like to underline that in 2010 alone, we have saved  over €100 million, thanks to the rationalization of coal productivities.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Spain, we have the new remuneration framework for distribution. It is more stable and more  predictable. And not only that, but the royal decree, 14/2010, recently approved has introduced a  number of measures that will solve the future tariff deficit among which we can underscore a  number of points. That is the management of development and remuneration of renewables. And  then, we have the maximum limits of the ex-anti-tariff deficit for 2010 to 2012 to put an end to this  tariff insufficiency in 2013. But also have to maintain the social bonus and actions required for  improving energy efficiency. And finally, something that has not been mentioned very much, but  which is very important, which is that we’ve eliminated the maximum ceiling of 40 years for the  nuclear power stations, and their continuity has been established based on technical and safety  criteria. And this has nothing to do with political criteria.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As regards to the UK, in April, the new remuneration regime was approved for distribution that  provides greater visibility and stability until 2015. And as you know, 2011 will be very important for  this country, for the U.K., from the regulatory point of view because specific actions will have to be  implemented as regards reforming the energy market that are currently being debated, as well as a  new framework for the transportation of electricity. And we hope that the outcomes of both  processes will be in line with the messages that are incentivating investments that have been  released by the British government, as well as by Ofgem, the regulatory body.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the United States, both the main activities of the Group have significantly improved from the  regulatory perspective. As regards to the grid business, the improvement of the gas and electricity  rates in New York were implemented in October, and will be bettered until 2014. And now, all the  subsidiaries of Iberdrola USA will have regulatory stability until 2014, which will allow us to carry on  addressing the optimization and efficiency actions that have already produced a significant  improvement of results in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As far as wind power is concerned, we have approved the extension of the opening debt for the  construction of new farms in order to alter the grant system until the end of 2011, which gives more  stability and visibility to the projects that will be commissioned throughout 2011 and 2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Moving on now to details. The production figures of the Group in 2010 reached a new record  exceeding 154,000 gigawatt hours with a growth of 8% relative to the previous year. And the  investments that we’ve made in recent years have improved our generation portfolio by increasing  a production that is free of emissions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And that means that wind power production has increased 18%, which when linked to the greater  contribution made by hydraulic and nuclear technologies, means that the weight of clean  technologies has increased 10 points and now represents nearly 50% of our total production. And  as I said before, this emission free production in the case of Spain exceeds or is close to 80%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So, this has also increased the diversification of our generation pool. So, no technology is offering  more than 20% of the total, with the exclusion of the combined cycles in Mexico, which as you  know, they have a practically independent economic regime as regards hours of operation and cost  of fuel. But as regards the hydroelectric reserves, in December in Spain they reached 7,500       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 4 gigawatts per hour in the reservoir, which represents an increase of 26% relative to the figures  reported in December 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And this figure has increased in the first months of 2011, and right now they exceed 8,000  gigawatts per hour, which is 10% higher compared to the previous year. And higher production  levels, as well as an improvement of the mix together with the evolution of the regulated business  mean that the gross margin stands in excess of €11,600 million, which means an 8% increase.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: By businesses, we have to talk about the positive behavior of the regulated businesses whose  EBITDA has grown 25%, boosted by very good progression in all markets, as mentioned  previously. As regards Iberdrola Renovables, the wind power business has increased its EBITDA  by 19%, although the total increase of this item is down to 10%, as a result of the negative  evolution of the storage business for gas in the United States.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Starting with the various items on the accounts, the sales figure grew 17.5% to €30,431 million,  especially because of the growth in the national energy business with bigger volumes in the  liberalized business and improvements in the remuneration of the regulated business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Latin America and the USA also contributed, and the exchange rate has also helped in this  performance. Regarding Group supply, this grew 25.3%, up to €18,394 million, also because of the  national energy business, Latin America and the exchange rate.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The basic margin, which shows the net effect of the issue rights goes up 7.3%, somewhat less than  the gross margin because of the lower price and consumption of CO2 in 2010. The net operating  expenses continue with a positive evolution, improving 3.7% to €3,457 million, an improvement of  2.2%, compared to September and in spite of increases of €95 million because of the exchange  rate. With this positive evolution, as the Chairman said, we can highlight the personnel expenses  control measures and efficiencies applied, especially in the U.S. and United Kingdom.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The net external services show a reduction of 7.2% to €1,752 million, a 6% reduction with respect  to September. However, there is a reclassification in the nuclear tax that I’ll mention later on, as  well as the inclusion of other earnings according to the IFRIC 18 agreement.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In global terms, there is an increase of €108 million in nuclear taxes amounting to a total of almost  €200 million in nuclear taxes paid by Iberdrola in Spain. And it also includes the social bonus and  other taxes in the United States, United Kingdom and Spain. And all these effects added together  more than offset the elimination of the removal of CO2 clawback, which represented €82 million in  2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 6 as the regulated and renewables business, which shows the solidity and sustainability in cash  generation for the Group.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The business context for 2010, our regulated activity has showed the biggest growth, 25%;  renewables grew 10% in EBITDA, although the pure renewables business grew 19% in line with  the installed power.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And moving on to businesses by countries, I’m going to analyze the operating profits in Spain,  starting with the liberalized business, which includes generation, commercial and non-regulated  gas. Iberdrola has increased the ordinary regime production by 10.5%. Again improving the overall  performance for the system, we showed drop of 0.9%. This positive evolution explained by the  growth in demand in Spain, which has grown 3.3%, although adjusted to temperature and other  elements, it represents 2.9%. And a major increase in hydraulic production at Iberdrola, which  doubled compared to last year. Our nuclear production has grown 14% and thermal technologies  have dropped cycles by 39% and coal plus fuel 42%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As we said, this is due to the sum of several factors: the already mentioned nuclear tax, which  amounts to €108 million; the social bonus; the increase in the Extremadura environmental tax,  which have been appealed before the Extremadura Court, and this represents €27 million plus €44  million; and the greater Iberdrola taxes related to TIU and commercial taxes. And the total was €82  million, and therefore this means that taxes grew by 84%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Additionally in 2009, there were additional maintenance expenses, after the storms that did not take  place in 2010. Regarding the increase of 9.5% in the gross margin, this is basically the result of the  increase of 8.8% in the recognized earnings for the business. We have to remember that the year       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 2009 closed with remuneration according to the Ministerial Order of 31st of December, which was  provisional and which was lower than that finally approved in the ministerial order for electric  excess prices based on the reference network model. Therefore, there is an additional positive  impact derived from the increase related to 2009, which represents €87 million more and which  cannot be repeated in future years.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA for the renewable business grew 19.4% to €1,449 million over and above the increase  in installed capacity of 16%. This positive evolution has been achieved, thanks to a major increase  in production, 18%, because of the greater operating capacity and because of the improvement in  wind power resources. Prices reached €73 per megawatt hour, similar to 2009, meanwhile the cost  control efforts have continued and the OpEx per megawatt has improved by 3.8%. This good  performance in the basic business contrasts with the weak contribution of the gas business, which  also contributes €6 million to EBITDA affected by the weak gas prices in USA, which places the  total EBITDA for the year at €1,4525 million showing an increase of 9.8%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In euros, EBITDA reduced its drop to 7% to €1,349 million after having a positive impact because of  the exchange rate of €50.4 million. Networks contributed €799 million with a growth of 20.4%,  derived from the growth of 15.8% in the gross margin, with the favorable impacts from the major  investments made since the second semester in the new agreement for business remuneration  called DPCR5, Distribution Price Control Review Five, in application since April 1st, 2010 and  distributed energy. This has been stable compared to 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Wholesale and retail provides €545 million to the EBITDA with a drop of 25.5%, mainly due to the  retail business where on the one hand there are smaller volumes, 1%, and lower unit margins  basically in the electricity business a result of a drop of 4% in the sales price, which was not offset  by lower supply costs. And 2009 was also a year that was especially strong in the ScottishPower  electricity retail business, and this also affects the comparison.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA of non-energy businesses and engineering has dropped 40%, and now stand at €201  billion. The lower activity of the real estate business and of the slump in engineering activities are  the main causes. Now, engineering provides 37% in terms of the gross margin. And other services  like the area of telecommunications and measurements provide the rest of the revenues. But then,  net operating expenses have been reduced by 5.6% because of the adjustments.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The EBITDA of the Group grew 7.1% and now stands at €4.829 million, and after the – an increase  of 17% in amortizations and provisions, which now reach €2.7 billion. Amortizations now total €2.5  billion, which is 14.5% more because of the higher installed capacity in renewables and because  more investments have been made in the ScottishPower networks, and also because there have  been environmental investments in Spain in the liberalized business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have grown 10.5% in EBITDA. We have increased the recurrent net profit by 5.6%, and this  response to the application of the profitable growth model that has been our sign of identity during  the last 10 years. This model is based, first of all, in our determination using green technologies.  And this has enabled the Group production to increase 8% in an environment where there is  moderate demand for electricity.

file: IBE - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 23February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Moving on to the main aspects for the period, we can highlight that Iberdrola has increased the gross margin by  3.3% to €12,026 million, increasing by up to two-thirds the contribution of the regulated and renewable  businesses that depend less on evolutions in demand.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding renewables, in a very low market scenario in the U.S. and with the negative impact in the dollar and  pound exchange rates, the gross margin grew 5% driven by the increase in wind power output thanks to which  production has increased by 13%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: By businesses, we can highlight first of all the good situation of the regulated activities driven by the increase in  earnings and efficiency improvements. Secondly, the limited growth in the renewable business because of lower  prices, especially as a result of the negative performance of exchange rates in the U.S. and UK. Excluding the effect  of the sale of some assets made in 2010, the wind power EBITDA would have grown 4.3%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And finally, the negative performance in the liberalized business, as I mentioned earlier, which is affected by the  complex operating environment in the United Kingdom and the increase of more than 50% of the levies, which  considerably raised to €621 million. This increase is especially significant in Spain, where this item has doubled in  the last two years. And at the end of 2011, it amounts to €518 million. This is practically one-third of the EBITDA  generated by the business in Spain. The main item in this levy is the nuclear production levy, which since 2006 is  of the turnover for this technology in Spain. And finally, we have to highlight the impact of the divestments in the  Guatemala businesses and the effect that this has on the results of the liberalized business in Mexico.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As a result of all this, the Iberdrola financial ratios are still comfortably within the A rating ranges. The credit  rating agencies, Moody's, Fitch and Standard & Poor's have reaffirmed the A rating level for Iberdrola and have  improved their prospects to stable. And all of this in spite of having taken on organic investments amounting to  €4 billion, 85% of which have been aimed at regulated and renewable businesses with the balance shared out in  the various countries; to these investments we have to add the integration of Elektro and the merger with  Iberdrola Renovables.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the Network business, I would like to highlight the efforts made by the regulator to guarantee a stability  and an acceptable return for these activities. In this sense, last January 23, Ofgem officially announced that they  have accepted the proposal from ScottishPower for the approval of tariffs for the energy transport business for the  period 2013-2021. Investments are planned over £2.6 billion in the next eight years with acceptable certainty and  profitability. And according to the regulator, this will provide good value to customers. With this new regulation  for transport, the earnings of our Network business is defined in the UK since the distribution activity will  continue to be enforced till 2015, within the current DPCR5 framework. And this is enabling us to carry out the  investments of £2 billion in the period.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The UK generation activity, however, requires greater definition to establish a clear framework that can be  assessed to provide incentives for the necessary investments since for environmental or obsolescence reasons the  country must replace close to 40% of its generating facilities in the coming years. We, therefore, expect that the  Electricity Market Reform will design this framework by the end of the first semester, both for traditional  generation and for new renewable capacity as of 2017.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, progress is being made to establish a cost allocation system for energy transport that will now penalize the  generators further away from the consumer centers. This reform is key for the United Kingdom to be able to meet

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And moving on to the main regulatory landmarks in Spain that José Luis San Pedro will comment on later, the  sector is characterized by a drop in electricity demand. At the end of 2011, the demand in Spain was similar to  those of 2006. However, installed power was much higher than that year especially renewable power which has  more than doubled in that period.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Also the firm stakes put on renewable technologies in Spain, that has gone much further than the objective laid  down by the European Union of 20% for 2020, has made it possible for us to meet with that commitment for  2020. We have a very competitive traditional energy mix thanks to which, energy crisis on the Spanish market the  so-called pool are 10% lower than the European average. Also the distribution networks in our country have a  remuneration, which even after the recent increases is also around 10% lower than the average for the main  European countries. However, the remuneration for renewables in Spain according to a study made by the  European Council for Energy Regulators is higher than the European average, the repercussion per megawatt  hour.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Not only that but the Spanish system is the European system with the highest cost. And this will be even more  significant in the future in view of the development of the expensive and immature technologies that are taking  place, especially solar energy. Additionally, the electric bill in Spain includes a number of costs such as a social  bonus or incentives for national coal, which are superior to those in other countries in the European Union. These  lead to a final supply price in Spain, which is slightly higher than the average.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the so-called tariff deficit has been generated, which is the result of the difference between what  companies are authorized to charge and what we are obliged to pay. This has been the direct consequence of the  exponential growth experienced by premiums, especially the special regime in recent years, which has multiplied  by three between 2007 and 2010 and is still growing significantly with an increase in the cost of the system and  the premiums for solar and hybrid gas-solar systems or thermo solar systems. The growing volume in the deficit  generated and the urgency in providing a sustainable solution have led the Spanish government to take measures  to tackle the problem.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And we can highlight the recently approved Royal Decree 1/2012 to temporarily suspend the pre-allocation of  procedures for the remuneration of economic incentives for new renewable and cogeneration facilities. Without a  doubt, this is a positive measure with the proper objective that lays down the proper path and this is being  developed by the Ministry for Industry, Energy and Tourism. This is an important measure but has a small impact  in the short term and doesn't solve the problem since it doesn't prevent the errors already made with photovoltaic  plants being repeated in the hybrid gas solar plants. On the other hand, we continue to move forward in the  securitization of the tariff deficit, thanks to private issues, close to €13 billion have been securitized and around 7  billion are currently pending.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thank you very much, Mr. President. First, I would like to underline the most important aspects of the accounts  and operating trends and I will finish with an analysis of the financial situation, the gross margin has grown 3.3%  and now stands at €12 billion, although the exchange rate has subtracted nearly €144 million with growth in the  compensate the weak behavior of the liberalized business in the UK. And without the impact of the rate of  exchange, the gross margin would have grown 4.5%. The consolidation of Elektro that provides €436 million  compensates the loss of the assets sold in the United States, Guatemala and other assets that have also been sold  that subtract nearly €300 million. The basic margin has gone up 3.2% in line with the gross margin and now  stands at €12,275 million and the value of the emission rights allocated in 2011 is only €1 million higher than  those allocated in 2010. Net operating expenses have grown 1.7% below the growth of the gross margin. And the  lower expenses arising from the sale of the difference businesses, €103 million, have made it possible to  compensate the greater costs of those associated to Elektro, €123 million and there has been increase in expenses  in renewables as a consequence of the increase in capacity. And this fiscal year includes €443 million of non- recurrent impacts because of the hurricanes.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The impact related to the rate of exchange change has been negative. So that means that the EBITDA would have  improved 5.4%. The regulated business in the United States provides an EBITDA of €548 million under the IFRS  regulations, which means that it's a 23% slump. As regards to the negative effect of the sale of the gas business in  Connecticut, which means €94 million less in EBITDA, there's been a nonrecurring impact of €43 million because  of hurricanes and storms, which has to do with one of adjustments which linked to the negative effect of the rate  of exchange, €27 million represents most of the slump.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses reduced 2.7% whereas the levies have undergone a very strong increase 50.7% that really  penalizes the EBITDA of the business. And starting off with the liberalized business in Spain it has to be  mentioned that there has been a reduction in the production of the ordinary regime of 13% because of the slump  of 22% in hydraulic (sic) hydroelectric production and 7% in nuclear power, this is one of the driest winters we've  had in the last 50 years. Even so the hydraulic (sic) hydroelectric reserves were 51% till December the 31st which is  slightly above the historic figure and the average sale price is €61 per megawatt hour which has given us a greater  margin although the procurement cost environment has been growing and the basic margin has grown 6.4%,  which linked to the limitation of operating expenses which have dropped 4.6% because of cost limitations and  some other specific effects of 2010, this has allowed us to counteract the strong increase in the levies paid, 30.5%  more, which now represents 33% of the business's EBITDA. And the growth of this item is 5.9% and now has  reached €1.5 billion. There's also a positive effect of €102 million related to resettlements. And for 2012, there are  56 terawatts hour of production already sold at a price in excess of €60 megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Until 2006, practically no nuclear levies were paid and now they account for nearly €200 million. According to  our calculations, the total of levies in terms of nuclear production represent an average of €13 per megawatt hour,  million, apart from those that are specifically nuclear, there are €150 million more that are linked to energy  efficiency programs and to the social bonus and the rest of the local and regional levies total €179 million. We  have the eco levy of Extremadura although we have filed an appeal before the Court of Justice and the High Court  of Justice in Spain.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The basic margin of the liberalized business in the UK presents a slump of 11% in which there's been a decline in  sales, 5% in electricity, 19% in gas, and very low spreads with higher procurement costs that have not been  compensated by an equivalent increase in the price of sale of electricity and a 22% reduction because of the lower  spreads in the market.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses have grown 4.1% due to non-recurrent effects that affected the annual comparative.  There's been a reclassification of the CERT and CESP levies that are imposed by the regulator for energy efficiency  programs based on the net operating expenses and therefore there's been a very significant increase but this has  been compensated because in the net operating expenses there was a positive item of €50 million in terms of  insurance indemnities in 2010. So that means that the EBITDA presents a slump of 41% and now stands at €322  million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And as regards the EBITDA of the Renewables business, we're talking about €1.5 billion because of greater costs  because of an increase in capability and because of the contracts and the maintenance contracts that have come to  an end and because of the merger costs and because of lower prices that is €66.3 million below the figure reported  for 2010 because of the greater weight of the business in the United States versus Spain. Where in the case of  Hydraulic business, the load factor in the fourth quarter was bad and the evolution of the rate of exchange has had  a negative impact of €26 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The pure wind power EBITDA has grown 4.3%. Operating capacity has grown 10% and now stands at €13.2  million (sic) [13.2 MW] and the installed capacity has increased 9.2%. The average load factor now stands at  25.7%, which is slightly below 25.8% reported one year ago. Although in Q4, it was 0.4 points lower and as I  mentioned this was affected by the low level of wind power produced in Spain and EBITDA has dropped 6.7%  because of the increase in provisions that have grown 187% and now stand at €528 million. And this increase has  no impact on the cash flow especially because of the €332 million produced by impairment of assets that are as  follows.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Firstly, €286 million in thermal assets in the UK due to the cancellation of the CCS project and the carbon flow  that was announced by the British Energy Authorities that reduces the expectations in terms of spreads and the  life of these assets. And secondly, €46 million related to promotional costs of the wind parks in the United States  where considered on the current situation, they're not going to be developed. And then we've also extended the life  of wind farms from 20 to 25 years which reduces the payback by €66 million. Although, amortizations have grown  4.1% because of the increase in investments made in the Regulated business as well as in the Renewables business.  And the financial results have improved 17.5% thanks, among other things, to the impact produced by the hedging  for rates of exchange for these subsidiaries, which represent €87 million. And another important impact comes  from changed provisions related to the deficit totaling €85 million. Financial expenses associated to the debt has  grown 5% because of the increase of 40 points in the cost of the interest paid and now stands at 4.6% including the  new debt in reals that Elektro has provided and the fact that it is partially compensated by a 3% reduction of the  average figure of the debt. On the other hand the greater levels of remuneration of the deficit has a positive effect  of €31 million because this is a remuneration system that's linked to the Euribor of three months of the previous  year which in 2010 was 0.7 and in 2011 it was 1.05 and to finish with the analysis of the results I have to point that  the net recurrent profits have grown 1.2% and now stand at €2.6 billion. However, the reported net profits have  dropped 2.3% as the President pointed out.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Firstly – the difference between both items is due to the following, firstly because of the impairment of assets  totaling €402 million gross because in the case of the €286 million related to thermal assets in the UK and €46  million for renewables, we have to add another €70 million as regards the participation of Gamesa, which can be  seen here in the consolidation by the equity method where we postponed the dates of achievement of these  objectives because of the weakness of the wind power market.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This problem, which initially had a dimension that could be taken on, has grown exponentially as of 2008, with  the coming into operation of what we call the photovoltaic bubble. At this point, the deficit pending securitization,  I think Pepe Sainz mentioned it, for the sector is around €7 billion. Including in the €7 billion, the ex-anti and ex- post deficit for 2011 and the ex-anti deficit for 2012.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The history of the deficit has changed over the years. When it started in the year 2000 I think it was because of  volatility in electricity output in Spain, which was very much affected by the price of fuels and the hydroelectric  resources led to volatility in generation costs. And the generator wanted to flattened those costs by saying I'll drop  them when the actual cost is low and I'll increase them in the opposite situation so I won't pass on this volatility to  the consumer. This initially was a good idea but as of 2005, as we can see on the chart, it became a structural  issue. And instead of flattening the volatility in generation costs, it hid the actual environmental cost that the  sector was incurring and it has become a structural deficit that amounts to around €5 billion.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And let's see what we can analyze to solve the problem. This chart shows what all electric energy consumers have  paid in 2010, €37 billion and where this money has gone. Well, 20% of that money has gone to the inland revenue,  to do with supply and that have been made by the regulator over the years. That's 30% of the cost for the sector  and in 2010 amounts to €11 billion. And on the left, we have the conventional costs. In other words, the  production costs at market price and it includes all the output of renewable energy at market price. And the  second blue square, the costs of the transport and distribution in Spain, which amount to €6.9 billion.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And two very clear messages here, if I take away the left side of the chart, the sector continues to provide energy  with the same guarantee of supply and at a price that is half the price the consumer is currently paying. Secondly,  the associated costs decided by the regulator amount to the same as the total production costs and they are almost  double the transport and conventional distribution costs. And I think that this chart gives us various clues on  where the solution to the problem may lie.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: There's an added cost because of the extra peninsular compensation and by law, this ought to be included in the  national budget. There's an energy savings and efficiency plan that I don't know why has to be funded by the  Spanish generators. And there's an interruptibility service or a cut-off service that is paid at a price that is 10 times  higher than the price paid by conventional generators. And there's an added cost for domestic coal to guarantee  the purchasing of around 29 million tons per year. All these decisions that have nothing to do with the cost of  supply represent €3.299 billion.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And now we're going to slowly analyze whether the problem lies in generation earnings or somewhere else. This  curve on the right shows the evolution since 2003 of the average monthly prices of the Spanish spot market and  the average monthly prices of the European spot prices. And we can see that both lines practically run in parallel  and this is logical because the power stations that establish the marginal cost are the same and they have the same  price.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But even though the curves are very close together, I would like to highlight that in these eight years the average  price in Spain of the spot market has been €4 lower than the average European price and when I say €4, and I  multiply it by the output which is close to 300 terawatts per year. This means that the Spanish consumer has paid  for energy €1.2 billion less than the European consumer just on the energy side.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Another important point and this is a defensive slide, it's often said that the hydroelectric power plants and the  nuclear power plants are over amortized and that all the money we receive goes to our operating results. Well,  hydroelectric plants have €6.828 billion to be amortized and they have an average amortization period of 25  years. The hydroelectric plants are amortized over 60 years. Of the 15,000 installed megawatts in Spain in  hydroelectric plants, only 600 are over 60 years. Therefore, all the rest have part of their assets pending  amortization and the same goes for nuclear power plants. There are €7 billion to be amortized over an accounting  life of 40 years and there is still 13 years ago. And this leads to an amortization rate close to €500 million and this  is approximately equal to the recurring investments we have to make in these power plants. And this means that  last five years. So it's unlikely that we're going to be able to reduce the net fixed asset amortization for these  facilities.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And the outcome of what I was going to call low revenues, yes and I have to use that term is that the relationship  between the operating profit before interest and after taxes divided by the net fixed assets related to generation,  transportation and distribution in Spain. And these are all of the UNESA companies, we're talking about a figure  ranging between 4% to 5%. When the work that has been allocated by the market to the sector totals 6.7% or in  other words in the last six years, the Spanish Electricity business has destroyed value, destroyed worth. And these  are objective data and they have been analyzed by the auditors. And once we've looked into, what I call,  conventional activities that had to do with the transportation, generation and distribution, let's see if the problem  is related to the non-conventional activities, which are the renewables.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This is a chart that was made by the European Commission of Regulators. The first column shows the objective  that has been allocated to each country by the EU as regards the presence of renewables. In other words, France  has a commitment and what they have stated is that 23% of the primary power they consume have to come from  renewables, and then Spain is 20% and so on and so forth. So this chart delivers two messages. If we materially  focus more on France and Italy, the general power objective as regard to penetration in terms of primary power,  primary energy, is very similar, well, perhaps somewhat greater, it's fairly similar to the allocation that the  government has given to the electrical business in terms of the penetration of renewables, in other words relative  to this figure of 23% in primary power.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And as regards the Electricity business, this objective has been transformed into 27%. So in other words,  renewables are going to be implemented in other areas and in particular they're talking about transportation and  they're talking about heating and cooling. And in the case of Italy, exactly the same thing applies. It does not  transfer all of its objectives to the Electricity business.  And as you can see, in Italy, the Electricity business has achieved its goals. But in countries like Spain and  Germany, what they have done is this objective, this penetration target for renewables relative to primary power  has been transferred practically 100% to the Electricity business. So that means that the penetration of renewables  in Spain is much greater than what they have in France and Italy. We're talking about something that ranges  between 38% and 40%. And in the case of Germany, it's somewhat similar.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And that is what the second column says. And this clearly establishes energy policies in European countries that  are very different. And then the third column says what was achieved in 2010. And in 2010 in Spain in the  Electricity business, the goals have been achieved. And the only thing we have to do to maintain this is introduce  more renewables as demand grows but as demand is decreasing this goal without doing anything in particular is  being fulfilled. It's being achieved. And we are the first in achieving this goal compared to another country where  they've made an enormous effort as regards the implementation of renewables like Germany where they are only  at a level of 17% of penetration and they have to climb up to 39% in places like the UK where they have 7% and  they have to reach 31% penetration but we are definitely the leaders in this race without a doubt.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So what is the consequence of all this? And this is a chart that I'm sure that you've already seen and it also comes  from the Renewables Council. The size of these circles shows the cost of volume that is being taken onboard by the  Electricity business as a consequence of the arrival of renewables. We are also in the lead in Spain, well this shows  the year 2010, where you can see that the additional cost related to renewables total €5.7 billion. What does that  mean? Well it means essentially that each consumer has to pay €22 to maintain this renewables policy, €22 vis-à- vis a total sales price of something like €110.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So we're talking about surcharge, tariff surcharge that reaches 20%. And the next country behind us is Germany.  And they've made a very similar effort, very similar to Spain, and they are applying only €10 per megawatt hour in  the form of a surcharge. In other words, half compared to Spain. And if we compare ourselves with other places  like France and Italy where they've implemented a completely different energy policy, France is applying a €0.01  surcharge and Italy is applying a €0.07 surcharge. So in other words, we are placing our industrial consumers in a  completely anticompetitive position.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: But if we now focus on the vertical segment, in other words, those that are being underneath Spain, those that  already have a degree of penetration in terms of renewables similar to Spain something like 30-odd percent. And  here I'm referring to Portugal and Denmark where they have made a very significant effort. We can see that with  the same level of penetration, they have a cost or they are applying a cost to the user and in the case of Denmark,  it's one-third of the cost we are applying in Spain. So there have to be some problems somewhere along the line in  terms of planning and execution in the case of our renewables plan.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So looking at this from a more demagogic angle, these are the data we have from the year 2010. And in 2010  energy in Spain, the nuclear and hydroelectric power stations produced 85 terawatts whereas the PV power  stations and thermosolar hybrid stations, and I'll tell you why we call them that, produced one-ninth of that figure.  But if we talk about revenues recognized and related to these activities, you can say that both activities had the  same costs associated to them. And if we were to extrapolate this to the year 2013, I can guarantee that the yellow  column you can see on the right would practically be multiplied by two and the blue column you can see on the left  would remain constant. So in other words, what we are doing is, we're not being very rational about this by the  way, but what we are doing is increasing our future supply costs.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: This is a slide where you can see many sources of information because I know that this is going to be very  criticized by people. But now let's see at this point in time the thermosolar stations that are commissioned in 2012  and 2013 especially if they have storage facilities and I think that practically all of them have facilities of this kind.  40 years they are guaranteed an internal rate of return after tax, 15.6% and this is a regulated activity because 90%  of the revenues are defined by the regulator and the same applies to distribution and transportation.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And now I would like to make a number of remarks that have to do with the energy policy although relative to the  future, which I think that any planner has to do this kind of work, but firstly let's see, and the first question one  would have to put to our citizens considering the current situation we have in terms of penetration of renewables  is what would they prefer that renewables be produced although we increase conventional production and  conventional production is €61 megawatts per hour whereas in the case of renewables, we're talking about  something from €70 to €300 megawatts per hour. And that's the first question we should ask ourselves.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And the second question is, if we want to produce renewables, what renewables should we produce? Those that  cost €70 megawatt hour or those that cost €300 megawatt hour because at the end of the day, it is the citizens that  are going to be footing the bill at the end of the process. And the third question that I think is the most important  of them all is what should we spend €300 megawatt hour per year on? Should we use it to guarantee a demand of  one megawatt hour per year which is costing us €300 or should we use this money to improve industrial processes  or domestic processes so that we can upgrade efficiency and reduce the demand we have in terms of megawatts  hour and the outcome is the same, from the point of view of CO2 emissions it would be much better to reduce  demand.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And in the case of these festivities I think that the annual cost in 2013 will be something like €2 billion. And if we  were to spend €2 billion every year for every single year in order to improve the efficiency of our industrial  processes, that's well without really working out the figures, I think that it would be far more profitable but  whoever is going to draw out the plans or the energy plans will certainly have to do this.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And another question, of the three main sources of renewable energy, new ones, wind power, photovoltaic and  thermosolar hybrid and I'll say more about this, they've all been regulated and therefore, as regulated resources,  they all ought to have the same reasonable profitability rate because I think this is an obligation of the regulator.  But wind power has a premium of €20 per megawatt hour guaranteed for 20 years and wind power is a renewable  energy that emits no CO2 that consumes no water.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: If we go to photovoltaic energy, the premium I think is €70, the new one, €70 per megawatt hour. It doesn't emit  any CO2 either and it needs small amounts of water for flushing and thermosolar hybrid energy has a premium of  around €280 per megawatt hour I think guaranteed for 25 years growing at a rate of the Consumer Price Index  minus 0.5.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And as of 2026 until the end of the installation, it has a guarantee of 80% of the premium which according to my  estimates will be around €700 per megawatt hour. And it's also a renewable energy that emits CO2. Bearing in  half that of a combined cycle. Therefore, it's not so renewable. And since it's a thermal power plant, it consumes  around 10 cubic meters per megawatt hour like any other thermal power plant.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And I'll end with some final comments. This is not objective data. What's some of the problem we've had in Spain?  I have no doubt that the people responsible for defining the Energy Policy is the government and in the  government, the Ministry of Industry probably and the Ministry for the Environment. And they have the  responsibility of managing the implementation of that energy policy. Well, when that energy policy is  fundamentally based on state aid, the second obligation that the planner has is to first see how am I going to pay  for that state aid, and secondly, what is the total amount of that state aid and how am I going to calculate it?

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In other words, of that state aid that is a complement to the Energy Policy as I define it, I first have to decide who's  going to pay for it. In the U.S., it was very clear, all citizens paid. And therefore, it was turned into tax incentives  for the developers of that kind of facility. In other cases, I think it's the case in Germany but I'm not too sure, when  we're putting all the responsibility into the hands of the electricity sector and therefore the electricity sector covers  all the cost, it doesn't make sense for the electricity consumers to have to take on this burden because it goes  against the provisions of the International Energy Agency. And their first objective is to electrify consumption and  to electrify consumption, we have to make electricity consumption competitive compared to other forms of energy  consumption. If all the environmental costs are passed on to electricity and is paid for by the electricity  consumers, then we're doing exactly the opposite of what the International Energy Agency is saying. But the  regulator can decide to have the electricity consumers pay for it.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: What has happened in Spain? Well, first of all, it hasn't been said who's going to pay for this indirect state aid. It  seems that it has to be paid for by the electricity consumers. It seems that way because it's included in the tariff or  they include it when they calculate the tariff but it disappears in the final price for the tariff.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So far, this environmental cost hasn't been paid for by anyone, it's been funded by three companies and nobody  has paid for it for the time being. Secondly, how much? The government has every right to establish the state aid it  considers suitable but it has to say until when? What is the limit? Does it make any sense when we are first in class  in the penetration of renewables? We continue to invest in renewable facilities and in the most expensive  renewable facilities. I think that the first decision made by the Minister in Royal Decree passed in 2012 of giving a  moratorium to the plans defined by the government, I think, is a measure of common sense.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Well, I think that José Luis has given us a magnificent presentation on what's been happening in this country and  what we have to do to use common sense, rationality and equality. And I'm going to say it in different words. So  the first message is that there's a solution to the deficit problem. It has a solution and this solution means  adopting measures, measures beyond those already approved by the government and as I said, they're going in the  right direction but they're insufficient.  First of all, I think that we have to stop right away the construction of the most costly renewable energy whether  assigned or pre-assigned, the country cannot afford it.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And secondly, the hybrid solar technologies, as José Luis said, those technologies that use gas and sun that had  generated an unsustainable bubble has already occurred with photovoltaic energy some years ago. And secondly,  that all the regulated activities, all of them and he said so too, should receive the same regulated remuneration.  The WACC is the same WACC for all and therefore they should all follow non-discriminatory criteria, a reasonable  criteria regarding profitability. Those are the existing ones and the future one. I say existing and future ones  because when we talk about retroactivity, I think this is a mistake. Retroactive is getting back what has been taken  away but not modifying what was done wrong in the past. We're paying for nuclear levies we weren't paying in  2006 and we're paying them now. That doesn't mean they are retroactive.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: We can discuss what the WACC should be. We've been discussing the transport line in the UK where there should  be five, six, seven, 6.5 but in the end everyone should be at the same level. On the other hand, we ought to  reconsider all those costs included in the electric tariff eliminating those that have nothing to do with supply and  that should not be borne by the consumers since they are items related to social, territorial or environmental  policies. We already pay taxes for that. We're paying €2 billion in taxes every year. So those taxes should be used  for those purposes and we shouldn't have to pay them twice.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Issues such as energy efficiency, et cetera, I don't want to dwell on it. And also all the costs caused by the  development of renewable technologies should be shared by all the energy sectors. José Luis San Pedro also  mentioned it, the difference is in the case of Spain all the burden is put on a single sector, the electricity sector, to  achieve the renewable objectives. While in other countries, they are shared by other sectors. I think that the  environment is the responsibility of everyone and therefore all of it should contribute and not just a part of the  consumers.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And also the earnings generated through future auctions of CO2, which will be held as of 2013, should be signed to  fund these technologies, and this is what the European directives say. And following with these European  directives for the single market where the pseudo environmental regional levy should be harmonized. In other  words, those that are the tax activities in the electricity sector but which have nothing to do with the environment  related criteria but where you get nothing in exchange here. And as I said, we have to follow the European Union  criteria, single environmental criteria and not different ideas on how to tax something.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The electricity sector bears a lot of these state, regional, local levies and as we've seen, they are going up  significantly. But there's already a tax in the bill, an electricity tax that is for this purpose to fund the autonomous  regions. We don't need to invent new tax models. There's already a tax we'll pay on our bill that has this purpose  and it should be adjusted in a uniform manner and also shared in an equitable way. And also access tariffs,  especially in those quarters where there are lower energy prices. This government has done it also with common  sense in the first quarter of the year. These tolls can be reviewed without seriously affecting the consumer and it  would also be good to go back to some measures that existed in 2009 to provide incentives for energy efficiency  and which were made to disappear. We don't know quite why because they did help energy efficiency.  On the other hand, we'll also move forward more in that market liberalization. Theoretically, we say that the  market has liberalized but there are still 20 million consumers attached to the official tariff and this seems a  contradiction.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So there's a growing contribution made by the regulated renewable business that counteract the evolution of the  liberalized business that has been affected by the situation of the British market and has been strongly penalized  by the increase in levies, especially in Spain where as we mentioned previously, these levies have been multiplied  by two in the last two years and they now account for 33% of the EBITDA we generate in that business.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So we are facing economic conditions that are adverse and this means that recovery seems to be taking longer  than we expected it to. In the last three years, the conditions in our environment have worsened significantly. In  our sector, there's been a reduction both in demand and in the prices; in some of our main markets, the wind  margins have been reduced. And in some countries, there's been a change in the regulatory environment and that  means that we've had to adapt our investments plan and we've had to stop the expansion plan we already have up  and running.

file: IBE - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables has significantly contributed to the positive evolution of their gross margin, thanks to 10.7% increase  supply has already a positive contribution to growth in gross margin thanks to higher prices and increased  customer base and in spite of the lower production.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables, on the contrary, rose by 13.8% thanks to the increase in group margin, 10.5% and the efficiency gains  that have allowed the company to keep net operating expenses flat along the period. Generation and supply shows  an EBITDA increase of 3.7% with a good performance in all areas, especially in United Kingdom where we have  considerably increased the number of customers with a significant reduction of cost per unit.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: All in all, as I mentioned before, 75% of EBITDA comes from the regulated renewable businesses, they're more  stable in predictable activities in those times. This predictability of cash flows is one of Iberdrola's differential  features over the competitors. But in the year 2006, when Iberdrola began its international expansion, our  businesses mix was similar to that of our European peers today with a much longer contribution of the liberalized  business to EBITDA. Three years later, three quarters of our EBITDA come from regulated and record businesses  while the European peer remain in 47%.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Following one of our main 2014 guidelines in 2012, all our business integrated cash flows exceeding net  investment. Total operating cash flows amount €6.2 billion, growing 2.5%. After deducting investment, this figure  almost reaches €3 billion. Also, according to the provision of the 2012-2014 outlook, Iberdrola has suggested  investment to €3.3 billion to the end of 2012. 61% we are signed the networks and 23% to renewables.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: By geographic areas, almost 50% of our total investment were addressed to United Kingdom and United States, in  line with the contribution to the net profits. For our divestment plan in 2012, Iberdrola has signed agreements to  sell non-core assets and assets in non-core countries for €850 million, completing 40% of our prerogative. Among  others, we agreed the sale of our wind farms in Germany and France and our stake in Gas Natural Mexico and  Medgaz.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: I should give you a brief description, first of all, of the most important regulatory measures, which you're already  familiar with, and which have come out through – out 2012. Okay, the first of them is Royal Decree Law published  in January 2012. It was a very quick measurement taken by the Ministry of Industry creating a moratorium for the  new renewable energies and heat and power generation of cogeneration, i.e., all technologies which had incentives  and which were not registered.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now the second measure taken was an unexpected cutback, an unexplainable cutback, of remuneration of  regulated transport and distribution networks. And the third was the fiscal measures published on the 26th of  December, fiscal measures for energy sustainability, which account for seven – or five different tributes for  different generation activities.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now the first issue, the moratorium, seems to me was a reasonable measure since there was a growth in  incentives. They were growing – were exponentially and sufficient at the same time because what should've been  included were all of those plants – already registered plants but whose inflation had begun. Not having done so,  meant that this year, the more than 1,500 megawatts of renewable energy came on the line.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The second decree, which affects the cutbacks in transport and distribution, was a very strong cutback, completely  unexpected, and unjustified too. It doesn't answer any new model of remuneration for distribution, and my own  personal opinion is that it should've been proposed by the National Energy Commission and published whereby a  carry forward, not as a royal decree.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The third measure, the fiscal measures, which came out in due of the final publication was in December this year  – sorry last year, is a five tribute, so taxes, all of them, are aimed to very clearly regulate and they're aimed at  reducing the tariff deficit. There's a general tariff, a 7% tax which applies to all generation. We also had two other  taxes, or tributes, nuclear and hydropower. We have another tax which is applied to fuels. The aim here is to  reduce emissions. The coal – this is coal and gas consumption tax.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now, turning to how we're going to look at the increase in taxes, €680 million – €690 million. This will depend a  great deal on the rest of the sector, mainly how those units which are secondary or non-core, which might transfer  to the price of these taxes. For example, for coal, all of these levies accounts for an increase of price between €9  and €10 per megawatt hour. In gas, something like €7. Now these are units which are marginal and which are  going to pay for the price of energy.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now insofar as these costs are passed on, because of tax to the price of energy, an important part of these taxes, of  the €3.6 billion, don't know how much will be passed on to the customer via the final price for energy.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now, so it has been a realistic royal decree on one hand, and on the other hand, it's not been too good – not too  bad for our sector. Let's look at the last two measures now. The Royal Decree Law 12 of 2013 defined as urgent  measures for electric and financial sectors.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As regarding the electric sector, first of all, the first measure is that in the rate of – I'm sorry, the uptake rate which  has been used now to uptake the value of incentives of premiums and in general, all regulated costs, was the IPC  minus 5.5 points of the retail price index, the RPI, sorry. So the numbers of the RPI are desegregated from the  energy costs and other levies.  Now, the effect of this change has a negative effect which is one-off, because in the long-term as a trend, these two  rates would need to be similar. And then the change of the index has a logical reason for it, the regulated costs are  not – did not have a great deal to do with the increase in taxes and don't have rate include energy costs. So the  measure as a measure has its logic behind it but it does have a negative effect on remuneration of the sector for  2013.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: And the third consequence, which seems to me important is that they don't even call it a premium, they're called  tariffs. A tariff is something which is there to define in the criteria for remuneration and the value of this  remuneration in the National Commission of Energy and the Ministry of Industry. In other words, currently again  in my opinion, all renewables as well as transport and distribution are activities which are regulated, whose  remuneration and whose procedures of calculation for that remuneration belong to the regulator, which are the  National Energy Commission and the Spanish Ministry of Industry.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: What are these new sources of income? First of all, the levies or taxes which are going to be got or gotten with this  layer of sustainability which came out 26 of December, which I've just mentioned. The calculation of tariffs is  regarded as €2.9 billion. Now in our calculations, some €3.5 billion can be found. But initially, the law says that  either the general budget of the state only take onboard €2.9 billion, although we believe this figure will be higher.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The second effect is that 90% of the revenues from the auctions of CO2 emissions will reduce the tariff deficit. This  has been calculated €450 million. It seems to me, these government figures, that this is optimistic. Bear in mind,  the quotations we have for CO2, the third which was the most surprising of all is that a credit, an extraordinary  credit from the government to the Ministry of Industry for the €2.2 billion to tackle not only sector costs of this  credit, but the ministry, or the regulator, will be using – gradually using as first initial settlements as we get  negative results. In other terms, initially, this credit will replace financing which has been given to companies to  date.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now these are – this is new revenue if you add them all up, the final figure I believe is – I've written it down  somewhere – €7.3 billion, something like that. Again, another positive aspect is that we have a whole series of  costs which are recognized for 2013 and which have already been recognized in previous years but have not been  paid to us. I'm talking more specifically about the fact that we have €732 million for costs of transport and  distribution and to compensate or offset the incentives which we had assigned to us for improvement in the  quality of the service or a result of leakages of energy loss.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Now, so here, we have the calculation for the forecast for our tariff deficit 2013, which is done by the Spanish  ministry by the way. The regulated costs, without an increase in tariffs and with an increase in demand of minus  0.2%, is simple, I think. The other income I've already mentioned – CO2 auctions, fiscal measures and  government or extraordinary credit access costs or feeding costs.

texts.speaker: José Luis San Pedro Guerenabarrena
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Fixed data, you know this already, special regime as we go and add new facilities with the same as we've had to  date or calculated in line with the price of electrical tariff. Transport intuition against a fixed figure deficit or  interest so I'd say that of this calculation, we have three uncertainties. One, if the demand is going to grow, so  minus zero two or minus – zero minus one.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net sales are up 8.1% to €3.4 billion and procurements froze 11.2% to €21.5 billion, maintaining the growth trend  during the year. Gross margins increased 4.6% to almost €12.6 billion, thanks to the higher international activity  and the positive foreign exchange impact. The basic margin is up 3.5% to €12.7 billion, slightly below the growth  of the gross margin as revenues from CO2 allowances fell 51% due to CO2 lower prices and consumption.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The Q4 one-off can be explained in the U.S. by the impact of the Sandy hurricane that has had a negative impact of  €48 million for our operations in the U.S. and that will be recovered in the next first case. In Brazil due to the  drought, distribution companies have to buy thermal capacity despite at higher prices that will be passed through  to the consumers in the next yearly review period. So we are right now buying at higher prices but that will be  passed to the consumers in the next review period.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Nevertheless, the outlook for 2013 in Brazil still is challenging. In addition to the drought that continues and we  are seeing these negative impacts in the months of January and February, there is also a lack of access to  generation PPAs as auctions were canceled and producers are selling their electricity in the sport market. This is  forcing Elektro to buy around 8% of its needs again in the market at higher prices with the same negative  accounting impact as the drought. So, this will be also be recovered in the next tariff review.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Iberdrola output in the ordinary regime has been down 15%, driven by a 39% lower hydro production and a 64%  lower combined cycle production, partially compensated by a 7.1% increase in nuclear production. The basic  margin is slightly down. Net operating expenses increased by 10%, due to nonrecurring effects and other expenses  related to supply business.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: It also reflects a positive FX impact of €75 million. All of these effects more than compensate the 20% lower  output due to plant stoppages and lower gas spreads that have affected the business. Tariff increases compensate  the higher non-energy cost that suppliers are suffering in the UK. Net operating expenses have risen 8.2%,  affected by efficiency measures and the appreciation of the pound.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses have increased €24 million, €9 million of them out of the FX impact and the rest from  non-recurring items as lower compensation from suppliers that we had for damages in 2011. Renewables  improves its performance as the 4% higher operating capacity to 13,735 megawatts and a 2.5% higher load factor  to 26.3% resulted in a 10.7% higher output to 31,784 gigawatt hours with growth in all geographic areas that has  higher average prices, €71 per megawatt hour versus €69 per megawatt hour in 2011, due to the exchange rate  evolution and the higher contribution of the areas with a higher selling price.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
