texts.text: Net operating expenses are flat due to non-recurrent expenses, but there is a 4.6% improvement of net operating  expenses per megawatt. All these factors have driven a 15.8% growth in EBITDA from the pure renewable  activities. The installed capacity is up 14,034 megawatts or 2.5% up after the sale of the wind farms in France and  Germany. So we have already taken away the wind farms in France and Germany from this figure.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBIT drops 2.8% showing a worse evolution on EBITDA mainly due to a 7.6% increase in amortizations due to  plant closures, the integration of Elektro and the investments in networks and renewables partially compensated  by the increase in the useful life of wind farms. The 1.1% increase in provisions included in 2012 write-offs linked  to renewables canceled projects, some nonrecurring provisions in Brazil related to bad debt, another write-offs  that we have accounted in gas assets in the U.S. 2011 including almost €300 million of provision related to  thermal assets, mainly Longannet, which have been replaced by the previously mentioned write-offs.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So, as of today, there are an additional €866 million of debt reduction, including the divestments already done but  not collected. So the divestments done in 2012 at the end of 2012 have not been collected, this is meth gas and  renewables in France and Germany. And the deficits securitizations of 2013 already mentioned, not including in  the 2012 year ended.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Thanks to this model focused on the diversification of businesses, EBITDA in total growth, 1% to €7.7 billion with  75% of regulated renewable business and for us has been always treated as regulated as now is recognized by the  Spanish government. Our net profit amounts to more than €2.8 billion with an increase of 1.3%, boosted for the

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, the measures recently adopted have an impact in our businesses but give more rationality to renewables  activities and networks, constituting in a step forward to eliminate tariff deficit, it has been ensured system  sustainability.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Concerning the UK, the further definition of the energy market reform to be concluded in 2013 in order to provide  clarity needed to promote required investments, beside the written market review, should help implement a real  true and free energy market.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: From the different business perspective, growth will be focused on regulated activities in UK and United States.  Additionally, and in spite of increasing environment obligation in non-energy cost, I would like to underline the  positive prospect of our retail business in UK, which has grown its customer base reflecting the improvement of  our service.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, let me underline the positive evolution of the operating figures recorded along these first months of the  year. In particular, a good performance of wind and hydro output will help us to mitigate a bit the negative impact

file: IBE - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 19February2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Reviewing briefly the key items on the P&L account, I was – and I had just remarked, in spite of regulatory  measures, gross margin remained flat versus 2012, amounting to €1,577 million (sic) [€12,577 million] (3:42). The  rise in production, particularly in renewables and hydro and operational improvement, have offset the regulatory  impact and the exchange rate movements. It is worth mentioning that nearly 90% of the energy generated in  Spain was free of CO2 emissions.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net operating expenses remain flat, improving by 3.5% in generation and supply and 2.8% in renewables.  Concerning networks, a regulatory activity, as you know, the lower capitalization cost in United Kingdom resulted  in 3.3% increase in net operating expenses.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Nevertheless, operational performance has been undermined by the increase in levies which amounted €1,57 7   million, as I mentioned before, 33% higher than the previous year. The introduction of taxes to gener ation in  Spain, impacting both traditional and renewable production, is especially relevant. Levies have increased by  100%, up €1,044 million consolidating, and that is very important, as a major cost item in Spain, higher labor cost  and higher external services, which I think is something which is absolutely incredible.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Total 2013 EBITDA reduction under IFRS 11 methodology is €448 million or 6.2% and net debt is down €1.2  billion or 4.3% while net profit remains unchanged. The Neoenergia deconsolidation reduces EBITDA by €339  million and net debt by €885 million. Liberalized, Renewables and Non-Energy business have a lower impact,  being the largest one related to less than 50% stakes in wind farms.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: As the Chairman mentioned, levies for the group grew by 33% to €1.6 billion and in Spain amounted to €1,044  million almost doubling 2012 levies, with an impact of €484 million due to the fiscal measures approved by the  government in 2012. There are another additional €35 million of green taxes accounted at the gross margin level.  The UK paid €251 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The EBITDA of the group fell 6.8% to €7 .2 billion, including a negative impact of €210 million due to the  exchange rate, excluding which, the EBITDA reduction is 4%. The increase in taxes mentioned earlier, the  additional reduction in the remuneration of the regulated business and renewables in Spain, the loss of emission  rights, together with tariff impacts in Brazil, are the main relevant factors in the fall of the EBITDA.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation and supply EBITDA fell 14% to €2 billion, affected by an increase of €366 million in taxes that reached  €1 billion and the loss of free CO2 emission rights for €121 million, taking away the growth of the business that  grew 2.1% levels of gross margin and had 3.5% lower expenses.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Regarding the gross margin, favorable hydro conditions in Spain and the higher customer base in the UK offset  the effects of the lower output and prices in Spain, as well as the absence of CO2 free allocations. In Spain, gross  margin grew 7 .8%, with a 1.3% lower output after a 64% increase in hydro partially compensated 44% lower  thermal and 12% lower nuclear output. Additionally, margins have increased due to a lower  costs associated to a  better production mix in a high hydro context.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the UK, the gross margin fell 3.5%. Excluding the exchange rate, it grew on a slight 1%, with a 2% retail growth  offset by a 21% drop in the wholesale and generation with higher costs, as wholesale and generation has to pay a  higher carbon tax, the ROC increases and increases in T&D plus the loss of CO2 allocations and lower weight of  coal in the mix affected by the closure of Cockenzie, replaced by gas generation plants with lower ma rgins. The net  operating expenses improved 3.5%, mainly as a result of the cost reduction and efficiency measures accounted in  2012.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA fell 2.9% to €1,573 million. As in the fourth quarter, we have included almost the six -month  impact of the regulatory measures in Spain, which account for – that we have accounted for €122 million that are  allocated fully in the fourth quarter. In addition, there is a 94% increase in taxes due to the inclusion of €7 3  million associated to the 7% tax generation. There is also a negative exchange rate impact of €30 million. All these  negatives have been partially compensated by a 2.8% improvement in net operating expenses, higher availability,  and wind resource.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The operating capacity increased by 1.2% to 13,900 megawatts with the new installed capacity offsetting the sale  of assets. It's total installed capacity at this moment is 14,247  megawatts. The average load factor improved to  27 .7 % with improvement in areas, meaning an increasing production of 6.7 %.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net profit falls 7 % to €2,572 million and recurring net profit 9% to €2.2 billion. As advanced during the year, the  EBIT – there is a negative net impact of €1.2 billion due to the asset impairments in renewables and gas. And this  negative impact is offset by revaluation of assets in Spain with a net impact of €1.5 billion. Additionally, regarding  the corporate tax, there is a positive impact of €7 2 million due to the reduction o f a 3% in the corporate tax in the  UK versus 2% in 2012.

file: IBE - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 18February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In renewables, our first offshore wind power plant, West of Duddon Sands, is already in operation. And in  Germany, the construction of our second Wikinger offshore wind farm is under way. Regard of generation  businesses in UK, all the existing facilities we offer in the capacity mechanism auction has been awarded, totaling  2,261 megawatts. And in the retail businesses, we have implemented the new IT system which is already  delivering efficiencies now.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In renewables, we finished the construction of Baffin wind farm of 200 megawatts and we have also qualified  another 600 megawatts of the new project to be built up to 2016 under the new PTCs extension approved by the  end of last year. Finally, at the corporate level, we have completed the integration project to optimize the  company's structure in United States.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Mexico, we're already taking advantage of the new opportunities provided by the energy reform. Two CCGTs  and two cogeneration plants are under construction, and we are already signing contract with private consumers.  In renewables, we have also two wind farms under construction and a pipeline of more than 900 megawatts to be  built in the next years.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Positive news also comes from Brazil, where the drought impact has been mitigated through the tariff increases.  Moreover, favorable financial conditions had been agreed for the return on regulatory asset base in falling tariff  reviews. This current regulatory framework allow us to keep investing in the distribution activity in order to  respond to the increasing demand and extend the access of electricity supply. And in renewables, we have been  awarded two auction to build six new wind farms. Furthermore, the 1.8 gigawatts Teles Pires hydropower plant  has been completed.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In networks, EBITDA grew 5.6% to €3.5 billion. The return on investment and the good operating performance in  UK, U.S. and Brazil explain this improvement. Finally, the renewable business has been heavily impacted by  regulatory measures in Spain, as I mentioned before as well, where EBITDA has fallen 37% versus previous year.  Thanks to the contribution of Latin America, 65%-plus; United Kingdom, 40%-plus; and United States, 10%-plus,  the drop in EBITDA for the global renewable business has been reduced to only 11.7% and amount €1.3 billion.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As a big part of this job creation is due to the purchases of goods and services of €5.4 billion last year to more than  18,000 suppliers. Let me underline the high quality of most of our contractors. 93% of them have A or A+ already  sustainability level. 92% has been certified under ISO quality and environmental management system or OHSAS  health and safety system.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Looking ahead to year 2015, we expect EBITDA to grow above 2014, thanks to the positive contribution of the  networks and renewable businesses. Our investment in regulated activities, especially in UK and United States,  together with efficiency measures undertaken, will have a positive impact under the assumption of an average  wind resource.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Renewables, as the Chairman commented, the EBITDA fell 11.7% to €1.3 billion driven by Spain with a 37% fall or  €247 million affected by the remuneration cost from the Spanish regulatory measures. The positive contribution  of the rest of geographies partially compensated the fall in Spain. As a consequence of this, now in the U.S., the  largest contributor to the EBITDA in renewables with 37%. Gross margin fell 7.6% and net operating expenses  increased 5.6%, especially due to the new offshore operation capacity that has just come in line.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In general, in renewables, the operating capacity was up 3.3%, the average load factor fell 0.06 points to 27.2%,  and the output decreased slightly. Average price dropped 8% due to the Spanish market. In the U.S. specifically,  the EBITDA grew 10.7% to $658 million, thanks to the 0.9% output increase and the trading profits that we took  advantage due to the weather conditions in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA was down €247 million to €421 million, with a €339 million negative impact from the new  regulation in 2014 versus an €122 million impact that we already accounted in 2013. In addition, prices and load  factor decreased compared with the extraordinary wind conditions of 2013, although, in general, the output was  solid. In the UK, the EBITDA grew 8.7% to £214 million, with higher average capacity offsetting the lower onshore  load factor. West of Duddon Sands offshore wind farm has contributed to £34 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Latin America, EBITDA rose 65% to €71 million, thanks to 28% higher average capacity in Mexico and Brazil  and a 45% increase in output. In the rest of the world, EBITDA decreased 33% to €73 million due to the sale of  184 megawatts of our Polish wind farms in 2013.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: EBIT reached €3,940 million, €1.7 billion more than in 2013, which included €1.8 billion of gross asset  impairments mainly related to the U.S. gas and renewables. Depreciation and amortization grew €149 million,  mainly driven by the UK, with the addition of operating capacities in renewable and higher investments in  systems and in networks. We have also taken advantage of the strong operating results to make over €100 million  of non-recurring provisions in renewables and network business.

file: IBE - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 22February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Afterwards and right after the lunch, two interesting speeches. One, given by the MIT related to the utility of the  future, and the second one of – about one of the most requested topics in our industry in these days, the wind  offshore business. We'd also like to remind you that this event can be followed online as well through our  webpage, www.iberdrola.com.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In renewables, wind output was stable or above 2015 levels except for the UK, which experienced a decrease in  16.8%. To this, we must add the impact of the elimination of LECs in August 2015 and the negative impact of  foreign exchange.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Our regulated generation EBITDA in Mexico has decreased due to the lower CFE tariffs during the first month of  2016 and to the small delay in the commissioning of  some of the power [ph] plant in (04:56) construction [ph]  take all of them (04:59) today are in operation.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Operating cash flow increased by 6.8% to over €6.3 billion, exceeding investment across all businesses, except  for renewables, where over 3,000 megawatt of capacity are in construction, half of which will be commissioned  this year including the offshore wind farm in Germany.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Additionally, we'll remain strongly committed to the employee safety where we have achieved a 58% incidence  rate decrease in the last five years. Our environmental commitment is reflected in the 31 emission reduction in the  last five years as well and 75% since year 2000. Dow Jones Sustainability Index has recognized us as the world  top utility.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Our €211 million investment in innovation in clean energy, efficiency and services has placed us in the fourth  position of utilities worldwide. And finally our total tax contribution in the country we operate was almost €5.8  billion including our own taxes and those collected by Iberdrola to pay to the fiscal authorities.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The increased importance for the group of our American company, AVANGRID, is shown by the increased of  53% in attributable net income. The investment of the company had grown by 64% to $1.9 billion. In other words,  three years rate agreements had been signed in New York and Connecticut. And in renewable, AVANGRID has  5,900 megawatts of renewable in operation and has 800 megawatts in construction. The efficiency measure  implemented had begun improving efficiency by 5.6% to achieve the proposed target by 2020.  Finally, the  company has confirmed its dividend commitments in annual dividend floor of $1.728 per share.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: And now let me conclude with our guidance for 2017. Our networks activities show a positive evolution, notably in  United States, with a full-year contribution of the New York rate case and the new Connecticut rate case effective  from last January. We also expect a good performance from our generation and supply businesses as we have  an additional 717-megawatt in operation over the full year but with a normalization of the Spanish hydro condition  compared to record production in 2016.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We foresee a positive performance in Renewables businesses, thanks to the contribution of the additional 467  megawatts of capacity commissioned during 2016 and the megawatts, which will be in operation in the fourth  quarter of this year. Overall, we expect a mid-single-digit growth at EBITDA and profit level as well.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Finally, Elektro's EBITDA fell 3.6% to BRL 899 million with a 1.4% lower energy distributed and lower tariffs due to  the August 2015 full-year review, which impacted – was minus 5%, that has been partially compensated by the  9% increase in the annual August review of this year. Net operating expenses improved 28% including €32 million  of positive one-off accounted for in this quarter.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Generation and supply EBITDA fell 3%, reaching €2,253 million. Growth in Spain is offset by the UK, also affected  by the FX and a weaker than expected performance in Mexico. In Spain, EBITDA grew 1.1%, reaching over €1.5  billion, 16% higher output driven by a 48% increase in hydro production and 5% in nuclear together with higher  retail activity, more than offset the lower gas results, which were minus €75 million compared to last year.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the retail business, gross margin fell 11% driven by a 16% lower gross margin in retail power due to the rise in  non-energy-related cost, basically government obligations, and a reduction in the retail gas of 8% on lower  volumes, due to milder weather conditions than last year. Expenses included an Ofgem customer compensation  ruling of €23 million. And as a result, the EBITDA fell £92 million to £204 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the Wholesale and Generation business, gross margin decreased 28% due to a lower output and higher carbon  tax, but it is more than compensated by the improvement in net operating expenses following Longannet closure.  As a result, the EBITDA increased by £26 million to only £36 million. So, the EBITDA of the whole Generation and  Wholesale business is £36 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Mexico, EBITDA fell by $23 million to $483 million, affected by the CFE lower tariff to private customers and  delays in the Monterrey V and Baja California plants now in operation. Renewables EBITDA was down 8.9% or  €147 million less to €1.5 billion driven by weaker performance in the UK that lowered this contribution by a €171  million due to the FX impact and wind conditions. Gross margin fell 7.7% and net operating expenses improved  4.1%.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached to €497 million, €24 million higher than last year as a result of higher output and  including €45 million of an account receivable due to low prices in the market versus expected price on the  regulated wind farms.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the U.S. EBITDA decreased by 2% to $624 million driven by 5% higher output offsetting lower merchant prices  but with a $31 million negative non-recurring impact on lower market value of electricity derivates. Excluding that,  recurring EBITDA was up $20 million. In Latin America, EBITDA increased 10% to €77 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: EBIT increased 18.9% to €4,554 million. Amortizations were almost flat to €3,076 million with the closure of  Longannet, the extension of the useful life of wind farms and FX compensate the UIL consolidation and the  increase in depreciations due to larger investments. Provisions fell by €360 million to €178 million driven, as you  remember, by the Longannet impairment that we accounted for in the fourth quarter of 2015, that amounted €288  million. And the reversal of some provisions made in previous years on our renewables pipeline in the U.S. as we  are accelerating the building of more renewables in the U.S.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Our net debt totaled €29.4 billion as there has been a €1 billion additional of one-off payments with no impact on  the P&L due to the anticipation of renewable investments, basically the Safe Harbor in the U.S. and some non- offshore anticipated payments for €320 million and one-off tax payments for €720 million as a consequence  mainly of the Spanish Royal Decree 2/2016 that forced companies to anticipate tax payments to reduce the  Spanish budget deficit in 2016.

file: IBE - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 20February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Networks EBITDA increased over 16% with a strong result in all geographies, notably in Brazil where distribution  tariff increased by 60% on average, and cost savings and synergies had continued to perform better than  anticipated. In USA, the positive impact of new rate cases and efficiency [indiscernible] (00:03:41) AVANGRID to  offset the negative effect of unprecedented minor storms.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA was up 39%. Due to the normalization of hydro and wind condition in Spain, will led to a  33% rise in output. In the USA and the UK, offshore wind production was 10% higher; thanks to the capacity  added in the last month and the better wind results especially in the UK. Offshore wind generation doubled;  thanks to the contribution of our offshore windfarm, Wikinger of 250 megawatt windfarm in Germany, fully  operational in April.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Net investment reached, as I mentioned before, €5.3 billion during the year. Close to 80% of total investment was  allocated to the Networks and Renewables businesses. Investment in Networks asset driven by the long-term  framework in place in all countries, increased by 16% in Brazil and 7% in United States and UK in local currency.  In Generation, the group has commissioned more than 2.7 gigawatt capacity since the beginning of 2018. We will  have a positive impact in result this year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On top of that, we also have 7.3 gigawatt under construction or committed; meaning in total we will have 10  gigawatt of new capacity by 2022 at least. The ongoing implementation of efficiency measures along the year  reaching €250 million has allowed the group to maintain flat net operating expenses, while increasing gross  margin by 15.5%. As a consequence, our efficiency ratio has continued accelerating to improve by 429 basis  points year-on-year.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Totally committed investment in transmission and distribution to 2022 is on the range of BRL 22 billion. This will  drive Neoenergia to more than double its current regulated network assets by then reaching over BRL 36 billion.  Also in Renewables, the company will install 500 megawatts of hydro capacity in 2019 [indiscernible] (00:08:16)  megawatt of hydro and onshore wind capacity under construction.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In the United States, AVANGRID adjusted net profit reached $684 million in the US GAAP. The company  continues to execute its long-term investment plan with $1.7 billion, [ph] mostly allocated to grow on (00:08:37)  initiatives. The New England Clean Energy Connect project which will link Canada and Massachusetts is on track  for commission in 2022. I do remember it's an investment of $950 million.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: The company also executed 594 megawatt of solar and onshore wind long-term contracts [indiscernible]  (00:09:01) 1.3 gigawatt of onshore capacity in construction, out of which 1 gigawatt will be in operation during  2019 and the other 260 in 2020. Additionally, the Vineyard Wind offshore project in Massachusetts is progressing  as scheduled, with the [ph] commission entry estimated (00:09:23) between 2021 and 2022. We are trying to  push to 2021 as much as we can.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: On the regulatory front, AVANGRID reached settlement for the rate case of Connecticut Natural Gas and  Berkshire Gas Company in Massachusetts. These three years plan are effective from January. The company also  filed a new rate case for Central Maine Power which is under negotiation now.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: Renewables EBITDA rose 39.3% to €2.4 billion with a strong growth in all markets. Output increased by 21.7% to  61,754 gigawatt hours with a 3.8 percentage points higher load factor, mainly thanks to Spain, Mexico and the  Rest of the World. Installed capacity reached 29,177 megawatts. Spain is now the main contributor to the  Renewables EBITDA with a 38% stake followed by the U.S. 23% and the UK 21%.

texts.speaker: José Sainz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: In Spain, EBITDA reached €918 million, 49% higher than last year mainly driven by a 33% higher hydro output. In  the U.S., EBITDA grew 13.2% to $677 million, thanks to a 9.7% higher output linked to the 7.9% rise in average  installed capacity and higher load factor. In the UK, EBITDA was up 33.4% to £458 million with higher load factor  and 6% higher average operating capacity in onshore together with better prices and payments for curtailments.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Iberdrola SA
texts.text: So to conclude, let me highlight then the set of result we are presenting today position company almost one year  ahead in the delivery of our 2018-2022 plan. This trend is expected to continue in 2019 through the acceleration  of investment in regulated networks asset in the addition of almost 6,000 megawatt of renewable or contracted  generation capacity which has been already done between 2018 and 2019.

file: IBE - Strategic Outlook Meeting Q4 2015 Earnings 24February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ignacio Cuenca
texts.profession: Director-Investor Relations
texts.text: After this block, we will have a five-minute break and then we will start with the intervention of our top  management presenting the strategy for the next years, that will be ended around noon. Immediately , another  Q&A session will be celebrated. After which, two interesting speeches. One related to our Avangrid, our new  subsidiary in the U.S. and the second about one of the most requested topics of our industry, the smart energy.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The Renewable businesses had an strong performance with EBITDA increasing by almost 19% to €1.6 billion,  driven by higher production in Mexico, Brazil and United Kingdom. I would like to underline the very good  operating performance of our West of Duddon Sands offshore wind farm which exceed availability and resource  estimate.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In United States, wind output was much lower than usual due to the impact of El Niño, and in Spain, production  was also lower compared with a very strong year, very good year in 2014. Our Regulated Generation in Mexico has  increased 30% to almost €500 million due to our increased activity with private customers.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In UK, Liberalized EBITDA was down as well 8% due to lower prices, the rise in carbon tax, the extraordinary cost  related with a closure of Longannet and the implementation of our new financial integration system aimed at  improving the services to our customers.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: They have resulted one of the leading renewables and regulated utilities in United States with $12 billion market  cap, over $30 billion asset, around 7,000 employees and present in 24 states. The group brings together seven  regulated companies operating in the State of New Y ork, Maine, Massachusetts and Connecticut with over 3  million electricity customers and a regulatory asset base of around $9 billion expected to grow up to $12 billion by  the end of 2020.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are also the second largest wind operator in United States with 5.8 gigawatts installed capacity and 780 MW  (sic) [7 50 MW] (7 :18) under construction and a pipeline of [ph] more than (7 :21) 6 gigawatts. As a consequence,  Avangrid is probably one of the cleanest integrated utilities in North America with almost zero emissions.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: All in all, our activity has a significant impact on the economy as a whole. According to estimate by Analist as  Financieros Internacionales, Iberdrola Group contributed to the generation of 360,000 jobs around the world.  And besides acting as an engine for growth, Iberdrola is also a benchmark in sustainability and corporate  governance. We have outstanding position in Dow Jones Sustainability indexes, in the FTSE4Good indices and  the Climate Disclosure Leadership indices.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And despite our installed capacity emission are today 30% lower than the average in the industry in Europe.  During the COP21 in Paris, we presented our commitment to reduce 50% – further 50% our emission by 2030  and become carbon neutral by 2050.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our Networks activity will show a strong positive evolution namely in the United States with a full year  contribution of year result. We also expect a good performance to all our Generation and Supply businesses  having 100% of our production already sold in Spain and thanks to higher hydro output and the contribution of  new power plants in Mexico.

texts.speaker: José Ignacio Sánchez Galán
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally in Renewables, businesses should also deliver a positive performance after a very good 2015 as we are  currently seeing improved wind results in Spain and United States better certainly than last year.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Finally, Elektro EBITDA decreased 5.3% to BRL 884 million affected by the positive impact registered in the 2014,  recognizing in one go past drought impacts.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Generation and Supply EBITDA grew 1.2% to €2,320 million, driven by the continued growth in Mexico and the  less negative impacts in Spain and the UK in the last part of the year. In Spain, the EBITDA fell 1% to €1.5 billion  with a 3.2% decrease in gross margin due to the lower output and weaker performance of our wholesale gas  activity.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the UK, the EBITDA reached £305 million, 17% lower than last year. Wholesale and Generation business gross  margin decreased 15% due to higher costs with a carbon gas – tax increasing from £9 to £18 from April and costs  associated – extraordinary costs associated to the closure of Longannet. So EBITDA in the Generation business  decreased 81% to £10 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The Retail business gross margin increased 0.4%. Higher unitary margins and volumes in gas with a 4% increase  in the month compensate the improvement – do not compensate a 26% lower gross margin in retail power due to  the increase in non-energy-related costs, ROCs, DuOS, TuOS. In addition, the non-recurring cost in the  deployment of the new retail IT system increased net operating expenses by £32 million. So EBITDA in this  business also decreased 5.9% to £295 million.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Renewable EBITDA increased 18.6% at €1,572 million, driven by the recovery in Spain and the po sitive  performance in the UK. The U.S. and Spain have been the largest EBITDA contributors in Renewables with 32%  and 30% share, but followed very closely by the UK that has 28% of our EBITDA share. Gross margin increased  16% and net operating expenses rose 11.9%, 4.2 percentage points below.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Spain, the EBITDA reached €473 million, 12% higher with a 10% lower output compensated by the recovery in  prices. In the UK, EBITDA was up 48% to £318 million with 19% higher output due to the better wind condition s  and West of Duddon Sands offshore wind farm positive contribution.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In the U.S., EBITDA was $554 million, 15% down, with a 4% decrease in output due to bad climate conditions in  the West. Baffin wind farm contribution that started operating in Q2 was not able to compensate the lower  capacity factor.

texts.speaker: José Sáinz Armada
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Provisions grew €202 million, increasing in the fourth quarter basically due to the accounting of the €288 million  provision linked to the Longannet closure, partially offset by €50 million less provisions in the wind business in  the U.S. due to the PTC extension and lower 2015 wind provisions in other countries.

file: ICGL - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 23November2010 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Nov-10.pdf
ICGL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 21November2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Nov-13.pdf
ICGL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 18November2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, we embarked on this journey four years ago and this is very much a transition exercise. We have ob viously  not achieved everything that we said we would. So let's just have a look at what we have done.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Starting with fund raising. The environment is very supportive. This slide shows the results of the McKinsey  Survey and what it essentially shows that all institutional investors, the population that we are targeting for our  funds, do intend to increase their share in the alternative asset space. This is also a bit off in the market that we  are targeting from 3 percentage points. Now, 3 percentage points might sound like a big increase, but when it  relates to 12% of their assets under management, it is a 25% increase. And when it relates to a market which in  size is about $70 trillion, it is a $2.1 trillion increase in allocation to the alternative space.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At the other end of the spectrum, we've seen private equity investors or institutional investors targeting private  equity funds, increasingly moving towards more debt-like products simply to balance the volatility that they can  see in their private equity funds. So in terms of the environment, we are at pretty good p lace that this market is  pretty favorable and we do intend to take a fair share, even modest, of that $2.1 trillion market.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Just a few examples of some of the transactions we've closed in the first half. The first one is a German company  that we know well. We have been invested in this company since 2006. It's a fire protection company named  Minimax Viking. It's the third largest global fire protection business. And with that business, we did support  management alongside a very well-known Nordic family office to allow management to buy their business. And in  the process, we invested £296 million, 75% into a debt product and 25% into an equity co -investment in a  company that we have known for eight years.

file: ICGL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 17November2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Guidance for the second half, no meaningful change here. We do not see any reason at this stage, and bearing in  mind, seeing the environment, we do not see any potential change in impairments for the second half.

file: ICGL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 15November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: Starting with fundraising, and first to comment on the environment. Just to say that fundamentally there has been  no change in our environment. Alternative assets continue to attract and they will continue to attract more capital  as investors look for higher yielding strategies. There has been no impact of Brexit. There will be no impact of the  U.S. election. And this is because these asset do provide superior returns with a manageable risk. Interest rates,  the level of interest rates, which we expect in Europe are going to be lower for longer only amplify the trend. They  do not create the trend.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: We're also working on a number of new ideas. Early stages yet, but we're looking at, for example, energy. We're  looking at expanding our fund – the family of funds that we have. And finally, we're looking into the distressed  base. Not all of these will succeed, of course, but it goes to show that we do have a pretty strong pipeline of  potential new products.

texts.speaker: Benoît Durteste
texts.profession: Executive Director & Head of European Investments, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: To develop these new strategies, the balance sheet is critical. It's a key competitive advantage for us. With the  balance sheet, we could seed new strategies. And in some instances, we can warehouse new investments.  Without the balance sheet, we could not have developed these strategic secondaries business. And likewise, the  balance sheet today is enabling us to pursue what could be a very interesting niche strategy in the energy sector.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to portfolio, pretty good news here, too. You're familiar with the graphs here. Our asset performance is  strong, 75% of our companies have generated profits ahead of the previous year. This is the highest level we  have seen in seven years. Now indeed, we have seen a couple of – weaknesses in a couple of our UK  companies, one has suffered since the energy crisis and the other one has been suffering from a highly  competitive food retail environment. But this is kept under control as the impairment levels remain in line whit the  long-term average. And elsewhere, you would've seen that the strength of the portfolio is evidenced by the strong  valuation, and you can see that in unrealized capital gains part of the results.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: The environment continues to be supportive of realizations, valuations are attractive and we are going to take  advantage of that, which means that we are going to continue to see realizations, although we do not expect the  second half to be as strong as the first, as I mentioned before.

texts.speaker: Christophe Armel Evain
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: And going forward, we'll continue concentrating on our key strategic objectives, which is the really to create  shareholder value by continuing to build our recognized diversified alternative asset managers, building stronger  fund management profits, also rebalancing the profits towards fund management with a continued capital  efficiency of our balance sheet. Obviously, we are pretty pleased with our achievements this half year. In spite of  the various obvious challenges, the environment is very supportive and we are very well-positioned to take  advantage of that environment. So I am actually very confident about our short- and medium-term prospects for  the business.

texts.speaker: Philip H. Keller
texts.profession: Chief Finance and Operating Officer, Intermediate Capital Group Plc
texts.text: The IC cost profile as you all know is driven by – the big change is often driven by the balance sheet carry which  are deferred awards that are given out and paid out on successful realizations of balance sheet investments  which are co-investments with the funds last year. So this year's figure is very much driven by the realizations we  saw in FY 2017, FY 2018, so we've seen an increase in deferred awards there. The other non-staff costs at the  bottom have also increased. These include the costs where we've looked into new strategies and they haven't  been necessarily successful. So this includes, if you remember, for the last years we've been investigating an oil  and gas strategy to see if we can create a fund strategy out of oil and gas assets. Having worked with the team  for 18 to 24 months, we concluded actually the pipeline wasn't sufficient for us to foresee a very long-term fund  strategy and long-term income that we could generate for the FMC. It's very important to us that we do explore  these new areas. If we're exploring enough, not all of them are going to be successes.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Royal Mail's Results Presentation. Please ensure you have all  mobile devices switched off or on silent. There are no fire alarm tests planned for today. In the event of an alarm  sounding, please leave the auditorium using the fire exits clearly displayed in the room.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: Before I get started, I want to try to preempt a few questions, and just give you as much of an update as I can on  the whole pension and pay negotiations, and the industrial relations climate. As you are aware, we are in  mediation. I think it is a great thing that that agenda for growth agreement that both, we and the CWU have  signed, have given us an opportunity to avert strike action and to get into ultimate dispute resolution mechanism.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: We have a Universal Service. We have still a lot of letters. They may be in structural decline, but you can't forget  about the letters. You can't forget about that source of revenue. It's still very important for the company. And,  again, we saw a very resilient performance in the first half despite an overall climate, a backdrop of continued  business uncertainty in the UK. We are really lapping a relatively weak Q2. That is true in the prior year, and so  our guidance is unchanged. But still, in terms of letters, we are smack in the middle, as I say, of that 4% to 6%  decline that we called out actually at the point of privatization.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: I'm pleased to say that we are on track with our cost avoidance target for the full year. Performance is likely to be  skewed to the first half, and the pace has changed. I'm hoping this doesn't happen, but it could happen depending  upon the industrial relations climate. The pace of change could slow down a little bit in the second half.

texts.speaker: Stuart Campbell Simpson
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: Just to remind you, we signaled depreciation will be up this year, around £30 million. It's actually slightly more in  the first half at £20 million. There was a £5 million one-off in that related to an IT write-down, but a good  performance on costs despite the environment we're working in.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: Well, now for the outlook. I'm pleased it's been a really good start to the year. The outlook for addressed letter  volumes is unchanged. We could be at the higher end of the range. I think, it's fair to say, if the current climate of  business uncertainty persists or in fact deepens. The UK Parcels market is still just as competitive as it always  has been. In fact, maybe even more so. Except for a peak periods like Christmas, we still are in a state of  overcapacity in the UK.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: We are dealing with the current industrial relations climate, which in fairness has soured over the past year. I  hope to get us back on track with my colleagues. If effort has anything to do with it, we will be there, but it's going  to take lots of work. And even post-dealing with the differences that are currently on the plate, to get us back into  that cooperative spirit that I think really characterize Royal Mail, is it's going to take continuous work. I can only tell  you I'm very committed to doing it.

texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: We have tested our revised cost avoidance targets against a number of scenarios and we are sure that we will  deliver this. Our investment expenditure will remain according to plan. This necessary increase will help us to sustain the universal service.

texts.speaker: Stuart Campbell Simpson
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: Turning to non-people costs, these are flat. This is primarily driven through distribution and conveyance, the  vehicles that we run. If you recall, at the end of last year, there was some very severe rough weather around  March. That meant we kept a lot of vehicles longer, more incidents with them, we've had to invest fixing those up  and keeping them longer and actually hiring a few more. So a challenging time in UK costs. We'll touch on what  we're doing going forward.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: As a result, we have maintained our number one position in the UK parcels industry. We have taken that same  strategic approach to cost reduction. As you know, about 3.5 years ago, we put in place the office of cost  reduction to give us a multiyear perspective on that. We have delivered more than we thought we could over the  three years. This year alone, we are going to deliver £235 million worth of cost reduction, that's above our target  of £190 million.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: Another area that we test very rigorously, actually every single month, is customer satisfaction. So, even though  we had a difficult time this year with the dispute and with the worst weather I've seen since I've been in the UK,  our customer satisfaction scores are up, way up. They are the best customer satisfaction scores that we have had  since privatization.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: More on letters, slide 10. This result in relation to customer satisfaction is, as I say, particularly gratifying because  this was a tough year. We were against a lot of challenge. If you get snow at Easter, I've been here for eight  years, you've been here for what much longer, some people said it was 92 years since we had snow at Easter.  Well, that is a real problem because it closes major arteries, it closes major highways, it even closes airports. It's  hard for us, even people like us, who are very resilient to deliver in the face of those kinds of transportation  disruptions.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: And sadly, that caused us to miss our quality targets. But if it had not been for the snow in Easter, we would have  actually gotten ourselves back on site. And so, that is a very big disappointment. And thankfully for us, it didn't  show up in overall customer satisfaction scores.

texts.speaker: Moya M. Greene
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Royal Mail Plc
texts.text: Stuart talked about our cost avoidance program. We're targeting to deliver about £230 million in avoided costs this  year. And this will encompass productivity improvements at the upper end of our targeted 2% to 3% range. Higher  variable costs, as Stuart mentioned, in some of our businesses, they have a different cost structure than the core  network. The – these costs will be associated though with increasing volumes of tracked and international  products. They are expected to present a little bit of additional cost pressure.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, let’s go to details by market. I’ll start with Emergency Response & Security market on page  seven, where we started the year with a record shipment to Asian customers and sales – and a  sales increase of 84% compared to the same quarter a year ago. Large shipments to customers in  China and Singapore for environmental and security applications were the highlights in this quarter.  This year we expect a large order to replace first generation HAPSITES that we have shipped eight  years ago, mainly to the U.S. Department of Defense.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: After two smaller upgrades, we launched a heavily revised new product, the HAPSITE ER last year,  and we see an ongoing good acceptance of this latest product line. This new product also uses a  new GC technology, an improved more user friendly software, and operates at lower operating  cost. At the same time, the number of applications and detectable components has been improved  by offering a wider temperature range and new accessories to be used in conjunction with  HAPSITE to analyze soil, liquid and gases. The steady stream of all those for INFICON HAPSITE  product gives us confidence that our Emergency Response & Security business is continuing to  diversify and build internationally.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now, moving to the Refrigeration & Air Conditioning or RAC market on page eight, sales growth in  all regions have increased by 26% compared to Q1 ‘09 and 5% compared to the previous quarter.  Our wide variety of patented technologies and the ability to design products to exacting  specification has establish INFICON leak detectors as the premier product for all RAC quality  testing applications, ranging from single component testing to final assembly for manufacturers of  commercial, residential and automotive air conditionings.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Also, in making new quality testing equipments has been holding back since 2009, the recent large  investments especially in Asia indicate that we have gained market share. Our state-of-the-art  products enable customers to cope with the type of specifications, changed regulations for more  environmental friendliness and lower power consumptions. We continue to explore attractive new  markets for INFICON technology. We expect to benefit from additional applications in various  industries for our leak detection products.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Before I turn over to Matthias, I’d like to close my part of the presentation with an outlook slide on  page 11. The indications from all of our target markets are positive. Increased consumer demand,  additional installed capacity, as well as new regulations and government support, are the basis for  the broad recovery around the world. Nevertheless, we remain cautious regarding the sustainability  of this strength. Since we cannot exactly determine how much of the current business level can be  executed to inventory adjustments and hold-type investments, therefore we leave our guidance  [inaudible] unchanged with sales between 200 and US$230 million, and operating income between  20 to US$26 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Emergency Response & Security markets recorded sales of $6.8 million when compared to 3.7  million in last years first quarter, an increase of 84 million – 84%. This increase was mainly due to  higher environmental protection sales, mainly in Asia, where military sales increased. But this  increase was partly offset by a decrease in military sales in North America. Sequentially, compared  to fourth quarter, first quarter sales were down due to the just mentioned decrease in military sales  in North America.

file: IFCN - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 20April2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Apr-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Now, let's go into details market by market. I will start with the smallest market, Emergency Response & Security  market on slide number 7, where we had a disappointing start into this year with a year-over-year decrease of  53% and even sequentially it was another 48% decrease. The disappointment is primarily coming from the  missing large government-sponsored projects for security and environmental applications, especially the  postponement of replacement projects for the first generation HAPSITE that are used within the US Department  of Defense had a negative impact on the performance in this market.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: We are not losing market share, but the uncertain financial situation in many countries with huge deficits makes it  more difficult to get the funding for those projects for military as well as environmental purposes. On the other  hand side, we do enjoy a quite stable base business and with increased number of installed instruments, a good  aftersales business with service and consumables. I'd like to mention the large number of ongoing projects, too.  The pipeline of interesting applications and projects around the world including regions such as the Middle East is  not getting smaller, and it's a question of time and politics to get the financial approving. Therefore, we remain  confident about the mid- and long-term prospective for this market. The world [indiscernible] (00:06:02) yet.  Unfortunately from a personal perspective, but business-wise those are good news.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Now, moving to the Refrigeration & Air Conditioning, or RAC, market on slide number 8; sales rose in all regions  except the US, and increased by 45% year-over-year and 2% sequentially compared to the previous quarter. Our  wide variety of patented technologies and ability to design exactly the products that the customers want made the  INFICON leak detector the premier product for all RAC quality testing applications from single-component testing  to [indiscernible] (00:06:48) leak detection as well as the final quality check at the end of the assembly line before  the devices get shipped. Further, once the devices are installed, we have the right product to do the aftersales  services, too. We continue to dominate this niche market, and are pleased with the performance in all business  aspects.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: I can say that almost all refrigerators and air conditioner units worldwide has been in contact with an INFICON  instrument in one way or another. Our state-of-the-art products enable customers to cope with the type of  specifications and changed regulations for more environmental friendliness, such as the new refrigerants, as well  as lower power consumption by securing a more leak-tight closed loop refrigeration system.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: The recent disaster in Japan changed the way we think about using nuclear power to produce electricity in the  future and all alternative methods became more popular again. We realized an increased demand for our  products that go into production equipments or photo-voltaic solar cells, especially for the silicon wafer-based  technology.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: We expect that in line with the general economy recovery, we will see the same strength in orders and shipments  to customers in this market. Vacuum, as an R&D and manufacturing technology, is more common used for a  widespread of applications in all kinds of industries to generate a unique, pristine, clean environment. It has  become more affordable and less sophisticated, and will contribute to the growth in this market.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: The positive order trend started about nine months ago continued into 2012. We are happy to see no immediate  change ahead of us. In fact, besides the full order book for our flagship product, the HAPSITE ER system, we  work on a large list of interesting projects for security and environmental applications in all the regions of the  world. Those projects include HAPSITE products as well as gas chromatography instruments.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: A new generation of a Micro Gas Chromatograph, which will be launched soon, should enable us to increase our  market share and find new niches as we develop a more user-friendly interface to simplify the integration of the  new product in new and existing applications. With an increase number of installed instruments, we do also enjoy  a quite stable aftersales business with training programs, maintenance services, and consumer goods.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Moving to the refrigeration and air conditioning or RAC market on slide number 8, sales rose in Europe and  Americas and increased 3% year-over-year and over 10% sequentially. texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: And in addition to the traditional RAC market [audio gap] 00:06:32 increased our sales in the automotive and  industrial leak detection market. texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Despite the challenging short-term market environment especially for flat panel displays and solar panels, the  long-term perspectives are healthy and INFICON is prepared and well-positioned to play a dominant role in this  market.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Now let's go into the details market-by-market. I'll start with the smallest market, emergency response and  security market on slide number 7 where we experienced a sharp drop both sequentially as well as on a year- over-year comparison of more than 30%. The first quarter 2012 was our all-time record quarter. Therefore, the  drop looks rather sharp and it has been caused primarily by much smaller shipments to Asian countries, expect  Japan. Revenue from the US and Europe were relatively stable. Looking forward, we see a shift in focus in China  from water pollution to air pollution. And we do not yet know if our business with the US Department of Defense  might be negatively impacted by the automatic US budget cuts.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: As already mentioned in our full year press conference in March, we just launched a new Micro GC with some  interesting new technological features at the Pittcon Tradeshow in Philadelphia. Together with the handheld  product line which we acquired about 16 months ago, we can approach a wide range of applications around the  globe. The list of promising projects ranging from security to environmental application continues to be long. But  with a customer base that is traditionally government based, it may take a little bit longer time to materialize. With  an increased number of installed instruments, we do also enjoy a quite stable after sales business with training  programs, maintenance services and consumables.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: On the positive side, we have been able to improve our market position in the automotive market. More and more,  car components need to be leak tight with tougher and higher specifications. We offer a superior gas-based  technology to allow the component manufacturer a more reliable and traceable quality control function.  Furthermore, we have the right handheld battery powered tools to provide the after sale service for RIC as well as  the automotive market.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: In the Specific Vacuum Process industries market which does include solar, display optics and semiconductor  manufacturers on slide number 9. INFICON sales decreased year-over-year by 5% but increased 17% over the  previous quarter, mainly driven by semiconductor device equipment manufacturers in the US, Taiwan and Korea.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: The increased demand came from investments in additional foundry capacity around the world, since many  semiconductor device companies such as ARM, Qualcomm or Apple that specializes on mobile communication  chips, do not have their own manufacturing fabs and therefore they rely entirely on foundries. The new market for  OLED displays, we experienced a temporary weakness since the top OLED manufacturer moved to larger display  sizes and that takes some time. The fact that more companies like to start making OLED displays is a clear  indication that this new technology is on the way to replace that today's LCD technology for flat panel displays.  OLED screens are thinner, have a more clear and natural picture and require less energy to run them. That is  also one of the reasons that the traditional market for LCD flat panel displays remains weak. There is enough  manufacturing capacity in the markets to cover today's demand. The same situation applies to the market for  photovoltaic solar panels.

texts.speaker: Matthias Tröndle
texts.profession: Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Specific Vacuum Process industries which include solar, display, optics and semi and sales in the first quarter of  $25.2 million compared with $26.7 million in the first quarter of 2012, which represents a decrease of 5.6%. As  already mentioned in our press release, we experience experienced good demand from equipment manufacturers  especially in North America. Sequentially, compared to fourth quarter first quarter sales increased by plus $3.8  million or 17.2%.

file: IFCN - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 16April2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: I'd like to highlight the reduced contribution from the Specific Vacuum Process Industries market from 35% to 30%  a year ago, mainly driven by weaker sales to semiconductor chip manufacturers in Asia. On the other hand side,  contribution from the Refrigeration, Air Conditioning and Automotive, as well as ER&S market increased 2% and  4%, respectively.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: The same is true for large OLED flat panel display market where we see uncertainties about the best way of  making large home TV OLED displays to replace the LCD technology eventually. The market for optical thin film  vacuum coating has been relatively stable. Last but not least, we can see a first small silver lining on the horizon  that solar portable-type equipment manufacturer started to make some new systems again. Also, some of them  started to make equipment for the production of sapphire which is used in LEDs, and according to some rumors,  for the new iWatch or iPhone 6 from Apple.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: The HAPSITE, which is the onsite portable battery-powered chemical identification system, continues to be the  flagship INFICON product for fast and accurate volatile organic compound detection. With an installed base of  close to 1,000 units, it's by far the most successful and most used device to protect people from unwanted  chemicals around the world. Looking forward, we see business opportunities in all regions for security,  environmental and industrial needs. In addition, our new Micro GC Fusion is now ready to be shipped to  customers for a broader field of monitoring applications. We see further businesses for our gas analysis core  competence in the field of energy production and distribution, especially in conjunction with the hydro fracking  technology for gas and oil exploration.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Moving to the Refrigeration & Air Conditioning or RAC markets on slide number 8, sales decreased 8% year-over- year and was stable compared to the last quarter of 2013. We have established a dedicated sales force to gain  market share in the automotive markets around the world and the results are promising, and we expect to  increase our revenues for leak detection products that are used to cope with the type of specification in the  manufacturing process of automotive components. Our products are used to make sure that fuel tanks, fuel  injection pump, brake pistons, airbag igniter and all sorts of pipes and fluid containers as well as complete  batteries and engine blocks are leak-tight that makes cars more efficient, safer and environmentally friendlier.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, INFICON Holding AG
texts.text: Additionally, we decided to put more marketing and sales efforts in our sales, aftersales products, so-called  handheld battery powered devices outside of the US and we will see the first results this year, too. And we  launched two new or we will launch two new leak detection products for two different new applications within the  next 18 months to guarantee further growth in new interesting niche markets. First of all, in natural gas leak finder  for the public utility market, and secondly, an inline leak detector for the food packaging market.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, let's go into the details market-by-market. I'll start with the most prominent one, Specific Vacuum Process  Industries market, which does include solar display optics and semiconductor manufacturers on slide number six,  where sales increased 3% year-over-year but dropped 25% sequentially compared to the very strong last quarter of  2014.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We currently improved internal capabilities together with our suppliers to eliminate the shipment bottlenecks, on  one hand side; and secondarily, we continue to work hard on new application opportunities, especially to be  ready, to have the right product available for the new Chinese initiative to clean up the polluted rivers.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Chinese Government just announced a new plan to curtail the water pollution. We're well positioned to work with  the respective agency very closely. On security side of the business, the U.S. Department of Defense just  announced that INFICON has been awarded with a five-year base contract worth $10 million of U.S. dollars. We  expect the first larger order based on this new program within the next couple of months. Well, we also have new  products for new applications that we just started to promote and sell. First of all, the new Irwin, a mobile natural  gas leak detector which is based on several INFICON sensor technologies to easy survey gas pipes in the gas  distribution networks.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And secondly, a gas chromatograph mass spec based instrument for mud locking analysis in the hydrofracking  market in the U.S. Both new products will generate revenue in 2015 for the first time, of course on the low level at  the beginning, but should contribute small double-digit sales figure over the next five years.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Over the last years, we have been growing that business and gaining market share year-over-year and reach now  double-digit sales figure last year for the first time outside the traditional air conditioning application in our cars  which we already served for many years. Tougher safety environment and environmental regulations drive the  increased use of leak detection instrumentation, the global automotive market.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At the same time, car makers try to reduce the complexity of their products by using fewer, but multi-purpose  components which needed to be typed and therefore require more sophisticated leak detection instruments,  preferably integrating in their fully or semi-automated manufacturing lines.

texts.speaker: Lukas Winkler
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We love to see that more and more components that are used in our cars are considered critical for tightness that  the car market overall is still growing. Regardless of the engine technology, gasoline or diesel combustion motors,  electrical or hydrogen fuel cell powered vehicles, some fundamental critical parts, need to be tight in any case.  Finally, we had a weaker first quarter 2015 in the General Vacuum Processes market, on slide number nine, with a  year-over-year decrease of 10% and 7% sequentially, mainly due to lower sales to European distributors.
