texts.speaker: Hans Kooijmans
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, IMCD NV
texts.text: As indicated by Piet, our industrial activities in Brazil have a more difficult time. Price erosion, difficult markets,  difficult economic industrial climate had a severe negative impact on our local Brazilian industrial results.

file: IMCD - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 8November2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-17.pdf
IMCD - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 7November2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-18.pdf
IMCD - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 16March2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Pieter C. J. van der Slikke
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: According to the Chemicals Trends Report published by Cefic, which is the organization of chemical producers in  Europe, the chemical output grow in the EU, which is our most important market in 2015, was a meager 0.3%.

texts.speaker: Pieter C. J. van der Slikke
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Chemical prices were down 4.7% and chemical sales were down 3%. I remember you that of course the chemical  industry has, let's say, two meanings to us. On the one hand, they are our suppliers. On the other hand, many of  them are also our customers.

texts.speaker: Pieter C. J. van der Slikke
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The biggest impact on prices apply to petrochemicals due to the drop in oil prices. Although our portfolio of  products is very diversified, we are also active in petrochemical derivatives. Other factors we had to deal with plus  the economic crisis in Brazil, where GDP contracted with more than 3%, and of course, currency swings in  emerging markets which required extreme vigilance to keep our margins intact.

file: IMCD - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8March2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-17.pdf
IMCD - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 2March2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-18.pdf
IMCD - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 1March2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-19.pdf
IMIL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 22August2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: And so, ladies and gentlemen, to the agenda this morning, Douglas will lead off with a brief overview of the results  and take you through the balance sheet and other financial matters. Roy will take you through the operating  results for Severe Service and Fluid Power. And I will follow up for Indoor Climate and the two retail dispense  businesses. I will then provide an update in respect of our strategic development before closing with a number of  comments on the outlook for the remainder of the year.

texts.speaker: Douglas Malcolm Hurt
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Let me now hand you over to Roy to take you through Severe Service and Fluid Power.

texts.speaker: Roy M. Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director & President-Severe Service, IMI Plc
texts.text: Our new product agenda is certainly building momentum, and I'm sure that you will remember that we  introduced some tremendous new products just eight months ago, including some highly engineered ball valves  for oil and gas applications and a complete new range of the pneumatic actuators and safety shutoff market in oil  and gas, both of which are shown on this slide. The good news is that new orders for at least two new product  ranges are already at about $7  million.

texts.speaker: Roy M. Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director & President-Severe Service, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning to the order intake, it has been a very pleasing first half, with organic orders up 19% overall. Oil and gas  was very strong, 66% up, driven by the major £40 million order for a high-integrity pressure protection system in  the Middle East, as well as a continuation of the high activity levels in LNG, where we won the new floating LNG  business as well as Ichthys LNG in Australia. Petrochemical orders were also up 18%, with good wins in PTA  applications in China and India.

texts.speaker: Roy M. Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director & President-Severe Service, IMI Plc
texts.text: Despite our most selective approach and the subdued westerns markets, fossil power bookings were still up 6%,  with good wins in India and South Korea. It was also good to see some improvement in the nuclear market, albeit  of a low base last year, where we won a project for strainers in the Ukraine.

texts.speaker: Roy M. Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director & President-Severe Service, IMI Plc
texts.text: On a less positive note, iron and steel investment is generally still very subdued, and this was reflected in our  bookings performance.

texts.speaker: Roy M. Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director & President-Severe Service, IMI Plc
texts.text: The energy sector was also up, followed by the oil and gas sector, where our emergency shutoff valve systems are  becoming increasingly well accepted. Overall, the sector business outside of trucks was 1.5% down in a more  difficult industrial environment than a year ago.

texts.speaker: Roy M. Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director & President-Severe Service, IMI Plc
texts.text: In energy, we have successfully launched our redundant valve manifold for critical applications, where we have a  strong pipeline of opportunities, and our new smart solenoid valve, which helps to maximize process uptime, is  now starting to witness some orders. We've also just released solenoid valve specifically optimized for Shell gas  applications, which again will drive further growth.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Well, thank you, Roy. Indoor Climate revenues was similar to the first half of last year, down 1% on an organic  basis, but 3% up on a reported basis, reflecting the stronger euro. Whilst the overall construction market in  Europe remains difficult, we have seen good growth in a number of countries including Sweden, Norway, France,  Austria and Switzerland, albeit offset by weaker performances elsewhere, notably in the Benelux region, whi ch  was down over 10%. The refurbishment market, which is driven by energy efficiency considerations, continues to  be much more resilient.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: As with Fluid Power, new products more generally have been a key feature of the first half, including a new range  of integrated control and balancing valves. We've branded TA -Fusion and a new pressure-independent  thermostatic radiator valve called the A-Exact. Both of these products have been well received by customers and  have already generated good orders.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: We expect the new construction market in Europe to remain subdued for the rest of this year. However, we do  expect to return of growth for Indoor Climate in the second half, benefiting from improving trends in both the  Americas and Asia, supported by an increasing contribution from the range of new products launched in the first  half. Operating margins are expected to show their normal second half improvement as we benefit from seasonally  higher volumes.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Ensuring that a greater proportion of our business sits in our operating sweet spot is central to our forward  strategic development from a growth, margin and long-term sustainability perspective. And you will by now be  familiar with the building blocks at our disposal to deliver that conversion from 60% today to 7 5% over the next  few years.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: To this end, we have stepped up our efforts to drive common product technologies across the group, forming joint  teams to exploit new products opportunities, most recently in the commercial vehic les and energy markets using  in particular actuation and control knowhow.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: A key contributor to our sweet spot convergence strategy is M&A. And as Roy has already mentioned, we're very  pleased to announce today a small technology acquisition in Canada, which will provide significant IP and  additional valuable technical differentiation for Fluid Power in their life sciences and energy market sectors, with  plans now well developed to rapidly commercialize this opportunity through the global Nor gren network.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: We also recently received final government approval for our joint adventure with SAIC in China, a complex and  lengthy process, which paves the way now for an acceleration of our business in the Chinese nuclear sector over  the next three to four years, just at a time when the moratorium on new build in the wake of Fukushima has been  lifted.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Our efforts to close out some bigger deals in our core target niches and close adjacencies continue undiminished,  with the pipeline continuing to build, albeit valuations I have stated on several recent occasions have become  stretched, particularly for targets in the upstream oil and gas sector with high emerging market content.

file: IMIL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 1August2014 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: As I run through the presentation, you'll notice the new branding and divisional names, which we've done just to  make your life difficult, but I think they are essential elements for the next stage of the group's future  development. And the big player, Severe Service is now Critical Engineering; Fluid Power is Precision  Engineering; and Indoor Climate is now Hydronic Engineering.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Critical Engineering; this division, as you're aware, is involved in the design and manufacture of  highly-engineered valves, actuators and controls capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and pressure  for the most demanding applications.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Oil & gas was down 33% and that, of course, reflected the impact of the £40 million HIPPS order, which was  skewed in the first half of last year. Fossil power was up 9%. Nuclear was down 37%. And the higher -margin  aftermarket was lower by 1%.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The nuclear reduction was due to a decline in the enrichment process. And given the expected outlook of that  pipeline, we decided to restructure our UK nuclear components business, and included an impairment charge of  £1 million in the first half results with further restructuring cost in the second half of this year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Half year revenue of £315 million was up £9 million on an organic basis but down £7 million on a reported basis.  Currency impacted the revenue line by £16 million, while growth in oil and gas, petrochemical and the  aftermarket more than offset lower revenues in fossil power, nuclear and iron and steel.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Hydronic Engineering, and that includes three industry-recognized names, Heimeier, TA and  Pneumatex, and is the leading provider of energy-efficient technologies to water-based heating and cooling  systems for the residential and commercial building sectors. Revenue with £139 million was 1% higher on an  organic basis and 5% lower on a reported basis. Sales in Western Europe, which represents about 75% of revenues,  were flat. Emerging markets were up over 10%, principally driven by stronger performance in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: And to ensure that we deliver those benefits, we need to enhance our systems, including a new divisional ERP  solution. The new system is already approved and will initially be installed in CCI and will then be cookie cut into  the balance of Critical Engineering businesses in a cost and resource-efficient way.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Our third largest sector is oil and gas, and we expect it to deliver stronger growth and margins when compared to  the balance of the businesses. And the final sector is life sciences where the division currently enjoys about £50  million of sales.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: This next slide provides an overview of the results of our assessments in Hydronic Engineering. There are a total  of nine sites with a high score of 54% and an average score across the division of 36%. All sites have now  completed detailed action plans and their ambition is to achieve significant improvement between now and the  end of this year. And while the overcapacity issues, which are present in Precision, are filed as pro minent in  Hydronic, there remains substantial installed capacity which can be used to grow and significantly leverage our  current market positions.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In Critical Engineering division, we operate in highly attractive markets and hold excellent competitive positions,  with the exception of oil and gas where we've got plans to extend our product range and capture more of the  addressable market.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Beyond the current portfolio, we've reviewed the criteria that would apply to adjacencies, which includes a  preference for North American revenues, strong aftermarket dynamics and critical applications which create  significant barriers to entry, and our work has also identified a preference for highly engineered oil and gas  products, not necessarily solely related to valves.

file: IMIL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 31July2015 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark W. Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Order input at £292 million was 6% lower on an organic basis with oil and gas up 8%, reflecting good LNG project  wins in both the U.S. and also in the Middle East. Fossil power was down 6%, nuclear down 79%, and the  petrochemical market was also down 32%. Importantly, the higher margin aftermarket was up 5% when  compared to the first half of 2014.

texts.speaker: Mark W. Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, we recognize that oil and gas remains a topic of considerable interest. And to help you understand the  division's current exposure, of the £473 million total order book at the end of H1, £128 million relates to new  equipment orders for oil and gas. Of this, approximately 6% relates to HIPPS, 65% relates to midstream and  downstream activities, including LNG, leaving only 30% exposed to upstream which, at this point, appears to be  the most volatile end of the oil and gas cycle.

texts.speaker: Mark W. Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: You'll also recall from our announcement that we outlined significant synergy benefits expected from the  acquisition of Bopp & Reuther. And I'm pleased to confirm we're absolutely on track. Roy's most recent decision to  close his Swiss nuclear manufacturing business and move it to Bopp & Reuther will accelerate those benefits with  £3 million expected savings in 2016.

texts.speaker: Mark W. Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So in the second half, on a constant-currency basis, organic revenues are expected to be marginally lower than the  second half of last year with profits similar to the first half of this year. Turning now to Hydronic Engineering,  which includes three industry recognized names: Heimeier, TA and Pneumatex; and it's a leading provider of  water-based heating and cooling systems for the residential and commercial building sectors.

file: IMIL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 29July2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, with that backcloth, now to the operational performances of the division. Turning first to Critical Engineering,  this division is involved in the design and manufacture of highly engineered valves, actuators and controls  capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and pressure for the most demanding applications. Order  input at £281 million was 14% down on an organic basis, with oil and gas £19 million lower, reflecting a £17  million decrease in LNG following record order bookings last year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fossil Power was down £14 million, reflecting lower levels of new construction in Asia, the Middle East and also in  North America. Now, the higher margin aftermarket was down 12% when compared to 2015, principally due to  delayed power outages in North America and the non-repeat of upgrade work which was booked in the first part  of last year. Organic revenue of £285 million came in a little better than we'd expected at 7% below the same  period in 2015. New construction revenues were 9% lower, with downstream oil accounting for the majority of that  decline.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Aftermarket at £135 million was 6% lower, with Fossil Power parts and upgrade work representing the bulk of that  decline.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to Hydronic Engineering, which as you know, includes three industry recognized names: Heimeier,  TA and Pneumatex, and it's a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for residential and  commercial building sectors. Revenue at £133 million was 4% higher on a reported basis and, after adjusting for  £5 million of favorable currency, was flat on an organic basis. Sales in the three core businesses, which represent  about 90% of the total, were 1% higher and included almost £23 million of new product sales in the first half of the  year.

file: IMIL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 28July2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: And with that, I'll now take you through the operational performances for the first half. First to Critical Engineering.  This division is involved in the design and manufacture of highly engineered valves, actuators and controls,  capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and pressure for the most demanding applications.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Order input at £350 million was 11% higher on an organic basis, with New Construction Oil & Gas £3 million  lower, reflecting a decrease in LNG bookings when compared to last year. Petrochemical orders increased £21  million year-on-year, with excellent wins in China for gas processing.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Fossil Power was down £2 million and reflected lower levels of New Construction in Asia, while Nuclear was up  £7 million, reflecting a good contract win in China. The higher margin Aftermarket bookings were up 9% when  compared to 2016, principally due to an increase of £14 million in LNG orders and £5 million of nuclear part  orders, which offset lower bookings in Fossil Power.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Organic revenue of £308 million came in a little better than expected at 3% below the same period in 2016. New  Construction revenues were 4% lower, with LNG accounting for the majority of that decline, but offset to a large  extent by growth in HIPPS and our downstream activities. Aftermarket at £147 million was 2% lower, with Oil &  Gas upgrades representing the bulk of this decline.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Moving now to Hydronic Engineering, which you'll recall includes three industry-recognized names, Heimeier, TA  and Pneumatex, and is a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for the residential and  commercial building sectors. Revenue at £150 million was 13% higher on a reported basis, and after adjusting for  £14 million of favorable currency, was 2% higher on an organic basis. Sales in the three core businesses, which  represent over 19% of the total, were also 2% higher, including almost £33 million from new product sales in the  first half of the year.

file: IMIL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 31July2018 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Dan. I'll now take you through the operational performance for each of the divisions and provide an  outlook before I summarize the group's expectations for the balance of this year. First, to Critical Engineering.  This division is involved in the design and manufacture of highly-engineered valves, actuators, and controls  capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and pressure for the most demanding applications. Order  input at £297 million was 12% lower on an organic basis due primarily to the exceptional level of gas processing  orders booked in the first half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: New construction orders at £133 million were 26% lower. Petrochemical and nuclear were the biggest differences  with large project wins on both in the first half of last year. Oil and gas was down 10% and Fossil Power was  down 14%. Aftermarket bookings at £164 million were up 3% due primarily to an increase in upgrade orders,  which offset lower LNG spares as a result of commissioning activity in the first half of last year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Our smaller verticals all achieved double-digit growth in the first half and this reflects a combination of improved  markets and the benefit of the divisions' sector-focused organization. I should remind you that Rail and Energy  orders can vary significantly period to period.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Moving now to Hydronic Engineering, which as you know, includes three industry-recognized names, Heimeier,  TA, and Pneumatex, and is a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for the residential and  commercial building sectors. Revenue at £147 million on an adjusted basis was 2% lower, and after adjusting for  £1 million in currency, 1% lower on an organic basis.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Sales of Pneumatex water quality products increased 4% due to the success of new products and our increased  investments in technical support in our key markets. Adjusted segmental operating profit of £22 million was 7%  lower, and after adjusting for £1 million of adverse exchange, organic operating profits were 3% lower than the  same period last year. Operating margin's at 15.1% compared to 15.9% in 2017 and they were impacted by  reduced revenues and increases in raw material costs, which are expected to be recovered in the second half of  this year.

file: IMIL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 7March2013 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And so, ladies and gentlemen, to the agenda this morning. Douglas will lead off with a brief overview of the results  for the year and take you through the balance sheet and other financial matters. Roy will take you through the  operating results for Severe Service and Fluid Power and I will follow for Indoor Climate and the two Retail  Dispense businesses. I will then provide a little more color in respect to our strategic developments before closing  with a number of comments on the outlook for the year.

texts.speaker: Douglas Malcolm Hurt
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Restructuring costs at £23 million were in line with the prior year and include the cost of the move of Severe  Service Fossil Power valve production from Switzerland to Brno, the setup cost of a new central Indoor Climate  head office in Switzerland, the closure of a Merchandising site in Tennessee, and the first phase of a streamlining  of the UK Beverage Dispense business.

texts.speaker: Roy Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director, President, Severe Service and President, CCI, IMI Plc
texts.text: Both of our 2012 acquisitions, Remosa and InterAtiva, have good prospects, improving our position in the Severe  Service valves market in the petrochemical sector, which is seeing a revival in the U.S. because of the low-cost  shale gas, as well as improving our access to the Brazilian market. In fact, only last week, we were awarded the  approval to supply Brazil's largest oil and gas company with our isolation valve products, which was on the back of  work led by the InterAtiva team.

texts.speaker: Roy Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director, President, Severe Service and President, CCI, IMI Plc
texts.text: Full year organic orders were broadly similar to 2011. As expected, LNG remained strong and we saw good growth  in petrochemical bookings. Fossil Power, on the other hand, is currently more subdued in the U.S. and Europe,  partly because of the surface power capacity which remains following the 2008, 2009 recession, and partly  because we are being more selective in the projects that we take on.

texts.speaker: Roy Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director, President, Severe Service and President, CCI, IMI Plc
texts.text: We have made really good progress in Brno, where productivity improvements in welding, machining and  assembly did come through in the second half although as expected, the bottom line effects of these actions were  offset in the period by a weaker sales mix. The good news is that margins in the order book are notably higher  than they were 12 months ago. This improvement has been mainly down to the three effects that we've previously  discussed.  The majority of the low margin fossil project booked in 2009 and 2010 have now been shipped. We've taken a  more selective approach to new fossil power projects in China and India. And we have shipped some of the low  margin nuclear contracts in 2012 but some do remain to be shipped in 2013. In summary, we do expect  progressively improving margins as we move through 2013.

texts.speaker: Roy Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director, President, Severe Service and President, CCI, IMI Plc
texts.text: And a complete new range of pneumatic actuators which is aimed at the safety shut-off market in oil and gas. The  actuator is shown on this slide and as you can see it is covered with IMI flow-control technology from Fluid Power,  demonstrating how our engineers are working together to build class-leading solutions. And this next slide goes  one better and shows how the actuator interfaces with one of our isolation valves used in LNG applications.

texts.speaker: Roy Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director, President, Severe Service and President, CCI, IMI Plc
texts.text: Within the bespoke engineered sector business, commercial vehicles were around 10% down in the second half as  the U.S. truck market weakened appreciably after the half-year mark. The Energy and Food & Beverage sectors  were roughly flat in the second half, while Life Sciences was 4% up. Overall, the sector business now represents  46% of the total Fluid Power business.

texts.speaker: Roy Twite
texts.profession: Executive Director, President, Severe Service and President, CCI, IMI Plc
texts.text: In terms of new business wins, the second half was an exciting time for Fluid Power, as we won future contracts in  the truck sector in Brazil, India and China. Our Euro VI control valve systems will also start to sell in volume late  this year. While our Energy sector redundant valve manifold for emergency shut-off systems, which was presented  at the Capital Markets Day last year is gaining traction with several petrochemical and oil and gas customers.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Well, thank you, Roy and so on to Indoor Climate, where revenues were flat for the full year on an organic basis.  in the German and Swiss markets. Whilst the new build commercial construction market in Europe remains  challenging, the refurbishment market which continues to be driven by energy efficiency considerations was more  resilient. Encouragingly, we did see good growth in a number of our key emerging markets, which I will touch on  in a minute.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Other major new product developments include a Blend in cup multi-flavor dispenser for a major QSR chain, a  range of variable carbonation dispensers for a specialist beverage retailer, and a multi-function water dispenser  for a large OEM targeting both commercial and domestic markets.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Progress within Severe Service was encouraging, albeit slightly held back by shipments of a significant backlog of  lower-margin, lower-technology valves for the Fossil Power sector, a legacy issue, of course, with a very much  reduced impact as we go through this year into next year.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Equally critical to both our growth and convergence agenda is our progress in the emerging markets, which are  particularly well positioned to benefit from a number of the favorable and long-term megatrends we targeted,  such as energy infrastructure and urbanization, as well of course from a much higher level of underlying economic  growth.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Asset prices, particularly in the energy space have increased significantly over the last 18 months. And we're  having to consider more aggressive post-integration strategies in preserving our long-held post-tax return-on- investment hurdles. But let me assure you, however, that those hurdles, which have a high bar indeed, shall not  under any circumstances be compromised as we maintain what is a very disciplined process here in IMI. We have  further increased internal resource and have brought into consideration a number of near adjacency opportunities  which look to have considerable potential.

texts.speaker: Martin James Lamb
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Looking at 2013, and whilst welcoming an improvement in sentiment compared to six months ago, we do expect  market conditions to remain somewhat subdued for much of the first half. We anticipate a gradually improving  trend into the second half, however, with an increasing contribution from new products, most notably in Fluid  Power, Indoor Climate and Beverage Dispense, and an improving sales mix within Severe Service as project  shipment margins returned to more normal levels.

file: IMIL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 6March2014 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Now, to the specifics. Revenue was up 3% to £1.7 4 billion, reflecting relatively good conditions in our most  important markets and with a strong performance from Severe Service. Profit before tax was up 8% to £298  million against £275 million in the prior year, with stronger performances in Severe Service and Indoor Climate  more than offsetting marginally lower results in Fluid Power.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Operating margins improved 70 basis points to 18.4% against 17.7% in the previous year. Severe Service increased  its margins to 16.3%. Indoor Climate was up marginally to just above 21%, while lower sales held back Fluid Power  at 19.4% in the full year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Despite being the lumpiest of all of our divisions, Roy and his service team fired on all cylinders in 2013 and  delivered increases in bookings, revenues, margins and profit in the year. Full-year order input at £7 42 million  was 12% up on the prior year, with a number of our end markets performing particularly well. Oil and gas was up  27 %; fossil power, up 16%; nuclear, up 19%; petrochem was up 11%; and significantly, the higher aftermarket  increased by 9%.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Full-year revenue at £7 16 million was up 4% on a reported basis and 3% above last year on an organic basis.  Growth in oil and gas, petrochemical and the aftermarket more than offset lower revenues in fossil power, nuclear,  iron and steel.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The highlight of the year was the division success at securing one of our largest ever orders, a £40 -plus million  HIPPS order for installation on the gas field in the Middle East, which is scheduled to be delivered progressively  during 2014.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: We continued to invest in new products and technologies, and launched two new product ranges in the year:  highly engineered ball valves and quarter-turn actuators for the oil and gas industry. And these new products will  enter the group's capabilities and further enhance our competitive position for the future.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning now to the Indoor Climate division, Indoor Climate includes three industry recognized names: Heimeier,  TA, and Pneumatex, and it's the leading provider of energy -efficient technologies to water-based heating and  cooling systems for the residential and commercial building sector. Revenue at £305 million was 4% higher on a  reported basis and 1% higher on an organic basis against the £293 million achieved in 2012.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: As you know, Peter Spencer took over the reins of Indoor Climate in March of 2013, and we think he's done a  stellar job. His analysis has determined that of the 29 emerging markets which Indoor Climate has targeted over  the past few years, only nine of them provide serious opportunities for growth. And as a result, we've agreed to  scale back our interest in these marginal markets which together represented a little under £4 million of annual  revenue in 2013.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In terms of Indoor Climate's outlook, we're expecting the recent stability in our European markets and the benefit  of new products to broadly offset the impact of the emerging market exits in the first half of t he year. Margins in  the first half will be impacted by product launches and one soft exit cost, but are expected to return to more  normal levels in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Douglas Malcolm Hurt
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Moving down the income statement, after net interest of £16 million, and the pension financing charge of £8  million, profit before tax and exceptionals was £298 million, up 8% on last year. Restructuring costs at £14  million were lower than the prior year and principally comprise the costs associated with the German site closure  in our Fluid Power business and strategic cost reduction exercises in our Indoor Climate and Severe Service  businesses. Restructuring costs are expected to be less than £5 million in the first half of 2014. Other acqu isition  and disposal cost of £10 million comprised £8 million of proprietary costs related to the disposal of the retail  dispense businesses and £2 million of deal costs and accruals for earn-out payments in relation to the AFP and  NPSL acquisitions made during the year in the Fluid Power business.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: For example, across Fluid Power and Indoor Climate, both of which have high volume repetitive manufacturing  operations, we have significant underutilized capacity and lengthy supply lines which impacts the effectiveness of  the group's working capital, our inventory and our customer service. I expect when our work is done, we'll need to  make some decisions on the geographies and the products we intend to grow in order to improve t hat utilization  and efficiencies to world-leading standards.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In Indoor Climate, it's our ability to produce leading-edge system-based products, backed by the support of a  multitude of installers who are trained in the application and effective use of the product. This critical  understanding of customer needs is an essential element of the current review. And while we recognize the need to  be competitive in every area of our business, a clear recognition of the core competitive advantage, whether it be  customer intimacy, operational excellence or product leadership, will be essential in determining our investment  priorities for the future.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Thank you. And with that, if I can ask Douglas and I to get ready for questions. I also have my Divisional Executive  here, Roy, who you all know. We've also got Brendan, he looks after Fluid Power; and Peter, he looks after the  Indoor Climate. So, I'll try and field as many of the questions as I can, but where I stumble, I'll push  over to these  guys. Or if you ask a hard one, I'll put over to these guys as well. So, thanks very much. Ready to take the first  question.

file: IMIL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 27February2015 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Order input at £686 million was flat on an organic basis, but impressively it increased 16% in the second half of  the year. Oil and gas was up 3%, which was an excellent result considering that 2013 included the £40 million  HIPPS order. Fossil power was up 4%, nuclear was down 27%, and the higher margin aftermarket was up 9%.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Clearly, oil and gas is a topic of considerable interest. And to help you understand the division's current exposure,  of the £474 million total order book at the start of 2015, £124 million relates to new e quipment orders for oil and  gas. Of this, approximately 10% relates to HIPPS; 7 0% relates to midstream and downstream activities including  LNG; and that leaves only 5% of the total order book exposed to upstream which, at this point, appears to be at the  volatile end of the market.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The nuclear reduction was largely due a decline in the enrichment market, and given the expected medium -term  outlook, Roy was proactive in taking the decision to close our UK nuclear components business and took an  impairment charge of £1 million in the first half and £4 million of restructuring cost in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Full-year revenue of £692 million was up £16 million on an organic basis, but down £24 million on a reported  basis. Currency impacted the revenue line by £37 million, while growth in the aftermarket and in oil and gas more  than offset lower revenues in fossil power and nuclear. Operating profit at £120 million was up 3%, and margins  increased to 17% against 16% in 2013. And despite the ongoing dependency on large project work and a £7 million  currency hit, disciplined pricing and the benefits of higher margin contracts, helped increase profits and margins  in the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to Hydronic Engineering which includes the three industry-recognized names: Heimeier, TA and  Pneumatex, and is a leading provider of energy-efficient technologies to water-based heating and cooling systems  for residential and commercial building sectors. After accounting for £19 million of adverse exchange movements,  revenue of £284 million was 1% lower on an organic basis and 7 % lower on a reported basis. Sales in Western  Europe, which represent almost 75% of previous revenues, were down 3% due to abnormally warm weather in  Europe in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The team also completed the benchmarking of our project management and new product development systems  and have now formalized Critical Engineering standards which are being rolled out across the entire division.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This slide shows the results of the second lean assessments in Precision Engineering. As with Critical Engineering,  not all companies achieved their targets but overall, the average lean score has increased substantially from 32%  to 46%. We have set targets for the next six months, and we will update you on our progress at the interims in  July.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Having now covered the review of the strategic progress on a division-by-division basis, I will now pull this  information together to give you an understanding of what it means in relation to the water group.

file: IMIL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 26February2016 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I'll now take you through our operational performance and the strategic progress on a division-by-division basis,  starting with Critical. This division is involved in the design and manufacture of highly -engineered valves,  actuators and controls capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and pressure for the most demanding  applications. Order input at £619 million was 13% lower on an organic basis with new construction, Oil & Gas  down 3%, Fossil Power down 1%, Nuclear down 76% and Petrochemical lower by 42%. Oil & Gas orders of £137  million were 3% lower than 2014, with 8% growth in the first half, offset by a 13% decline in the second  half of the  year. LNG remained strong right throughout the year, with all of the second half Oil & Gas downside related to an  £18 million order booked in Kazakhstan in 2014.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the aftermarket, full year order input of £283 million was 3% below 2014, with good progress in the first half  being offset by declines in the third quarter before returning to growth in the final quarter of the year. At the  aftermarket sector level, there are number of significant movements. LNG grew to £13 million from only £7  million in the prior year and this reflects our newly-installed kits starting to come onstream. Aftermarket power  was lower by £6 million with a few large upgrade projects not repeating in 2015 and aftermarket in Petrochemical  was also lower by £4 million due to maintenance postponements at the U.S. refineries.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: At the time of my strategic outline in August 2014, the oil price in that month had averaged $107 per barrel, and  had been within plus or minus $5 of that price for the preceding 13 months, and I don't need to tell you that  conditions have changed dramatically. And as a result, our 6% to 8% growth objective seems well beyond current  reach, and our latest update on the addressable market looks closer to £6 billion than £7 billion. I'd also ask you to  consider a bit of recent history. When in the middle of the financial crisis, the oil price undertook a significant  decrease from $134 a barrel in June of 2008 to just over $40 in December of that year and then back to about $70  per barrel by June the following year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And in light of the significantly reduced nuclear activity post-Fukushima, we have closed IMI Components and are  transferring our manufacturing operations in both Switzerland and Canada to Bopp & Reuther. These actions will  incur £8 million of once-off costs, of which £7 million was taken last year and they will deliver £5 million of cost  savings once complete. In addition, we announced our decision to consolidate TH Jansen into Z&J in Germany,  which will incur £8 million of one-off cost, delivering a two-and-a-half-year cash payback.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We were, however, fortunate to have secured Bopp & Reuther before the market dried up. And it has extended our  position into power sector, enhanced our German service footprint and provided a platform to consolidate our  nuclear operations. And while the headline numbers for Bopp & Reuther are lower than 2014, it's no w an integral  part of CCI and, as a consequence, their orders are now recognized elsewhere within the division.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Y ou will recall the significant synergies that we expected from Bopp & Reuther and I'm pleased to confirm we're  absolutely on track. And Roy's decision to close his Swiss and Canadian nuclear businesses and move them to  Bopp & Reuther will accelerate those benefits.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This slide shows the results of the four lean assessments. And as with Critical, not all companies delivered their  targets. But overall, the average lean score has improved substantially from 32% at the first benchmark to 59% at  the end of last year, with our Seattle plant leading the way, having achieved a score of 7 0%. The application of lean  made great progress right across the division, with significantly improved productivity and an inventory reduction  of 7 .5% in the year. The newly implemented global quality system helped reduced warranty cost by 50% and scrap  cost by 23% when compared to 2014.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to Hydronic Engineering which includes three industry-recognized names: Heimeier, TA and  Pneumatex; and is a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for residential and commercial  building.

file: IMIL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: I'll now take you through our operational performance and the strategic progress on a division-by-division basis,  and I'll start with Critical. You'll be aware this division's involved in the design and manufacture of highly  engineered valves, actuators, and controls, capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and the pressure  for the most demanding applications.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Order input at £614 million was 11% lower on an organic basis, with new construction Oil & Gas down 13%.  Fossil Power was down 23%. Petrochemical was up 2%. And Nuclear increased substantially from the lows we  saw in 2015. Oil & Gas orders of £135 million were 13% lower than 2015, with a 25% reduction in the first half,  importantly offset by a flat performance in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: As previously flagged, LNG was 60% lower year-over-year following the peak of our project activity in 2015.  Midstream grew substantially and reflected a £23 million order in Kazakhstan, while HIPPS benefited from a £15  million order in the last quarter of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In the Aftermarket, full-year order input of £299 million was 6% below the prior year. Importantly, with the return to  2015 levels in the second half of the year. At the Aftermarket sector level, there a number of significant  movements; LNG was 3% lower at £14 million and that reflected the delay in newly-installed kit coming on- stream. Aftermarket Power was down £19 million with lower levels of spend, particularly in North America and  Aftermarket in nuclear increased 36% to £44 million due to one South Korean order in the final quarter of the  year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In terms of revenue, after adjusting for £77 million of exchange benefit, and £6 million from prior year disposals,  the revenue line at £651 million was 7% lower on an organic basis and 3% higher on a reported basis. New  construction sales was 7% lower at £356 million, an 18% reduction in oil and gas, partially offset by a 13%  increase in Fossil Power.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Aftermarket sales of £295 million were also 7% lower. With oil and gas up 2%, reflecting solid progress in  downstream and also in LNG offsetting continued softness in the upstream activities. Power aftermarket sales of  a £132 million were 15% lower, with parts down 13%, and upgrades lower by 25%. Now, Nuclear was up 14%,  while Petrochemical was 10% lower and that was mainly due to the disposal of our Italian service business.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Now, I don't need to tell you that conditions have changed dramatically since we first presented our strategy back  in 2014. And as a result, our near-term growth objective has been paid back significantly. Also, in 2016, we  experienced lower activity in Fossil Power, and outages in North America reduced by almost 6%.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: And in light of the significantly reduced nuclear activity post-Fukushima, Roy successfully executed the closure of  IMI Components and the transfer of our manufacturing operations in both Switzerland and Canada to Bopp &  Reuther.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Hydronic Engineering, which actually now includes three industry-recognized names, Heimeier,  TA and Pneumatex and is a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for the residential and  also for the commercial building sectors. Revenue at £290 million was 1% lower on an organic basis and 10%  higher on a reported basis. And while warmer weather impacted the heating season in the division's largest  European markets, revenues in that region were marginally higher than the previous year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: And in Germany, Peter's largest manufacturing site undertook a transformational project to improve this and  casting operations. This required the entire operation to be dismantled, refurbished and rebuilt while continuing to  deliver products to our customers. And the project proved a major success. Today, we can close world-class  performance with scrap rates reducing to 6% from 16% back in 2014.

file: IMIL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 2March2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: I'll now take you through our operational performance and the strategic progress on a division by dividend basis  and as always, I'll start with Critical. As you know, this division is involved in the design and manufacture of highly  engineered valves, actuators, and controls capable of operating at the extremes of temperature and pressure for  the most demanding applications. Order input at £658 million was 2% higher on an organic basis. New  construction oil and gas orders of £128 million were 11% lower than 2016. But you will recall 2016 included £15  million of HIPPS orders, which we booked in the last quarter of that year. New Construction Power orders of £88  million were 11% lower, reflecting significant reductions and delays in new project activity, particularly in China  and in Korea.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning now to the strategic elements of Critical Engineering's performance. You'll recall from our market  assessment that this division plays in three principal sectors, power generation, oil and gas, and petrochemical,  and our plans are all about focus and growth, both organically and supplemented with value-enhancing  acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The Fossil Power market continues to experience significant project delays and cancellations. And as a  consequence, in the year ahead, we're expecting lower levels of Construction Power orders than we did in 2017.  However, our recent success at using Value Engineering has extended our Power product offerings and is  helping to increase the value of sales into those opportunities which remain available.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: There's more optimism today in oil and gas than there was a year ago, although customer CapEx is yet to  recover. Now, despite this, we're expecting an increase in LNG and downstream orders weighted to the second  half of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In petrochemical, final approval of investment decisions remain slow. However, large project opportunities are in  the works; and while I doubt that we'll repeat the £27 million of gas processing orders which we won in the first  half of 2017, we are expecting some growth but in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The third element of Critical Engineering's change program included investments in modern world-class facilities  and that commenced in 2015 with the addition of a greenfield operation in South Korea, and service centers in  China, and also in Houston. In 2016, we consolidated three of our Chinese operations into a single facility in  Shanghai. And last year, we finished the upgrade of our Z&J operations in Germany.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Now, the fourth and most significant change included a program of restructuring, with an overarching ambition to  dramatically change the geographic footprint and the cost base of Critical's global operations. The program  started in 2014 with the closure of the UK nuclear components business.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: This slide shows the results of Precision's latest Lean assessment. And, overall, the average Lean scores  improved substantially from 33% at the very first benchmark to 70% at the end of last year, and our Seattle plant  led the way with a score of 81%.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Hydronic Engineering. As you know, this includes three industry-recognized names; Heimeier, TA,  and Pneumatex, and it's a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for residential and  commercial building sectors.

file: IMIL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 1March2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Order input at £652 million was flat on an organic basis and, as we predicted, was heavily biased to the second  half of the year. New Construction orders at £302 million were 10% below 2017. Our oil and gas and power  markets continue to struggle, and despite our excellent hit rates, new capital projects remain thin on the ground.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: So, turning now to the strategic elements of Critical Engineering's performance. You recall from the market  assessment that this division has traditionally played in three principal sectors: power generation, oil and gas, and  petrochemical, with the aftermarket representing a valuable contributor across all three of these segments.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The New Construction Fossil Power market continues to experience significant project delays and structural  change. And as a consequence, in the year ahead, we're expecting lower levels of New Construction Power  orders. Now, our recent success at using our Valve Doctors to chase upgrade and field service work, when  combined with Value Engineering , is helping to increase the value of sales into those power opportunities which  remain available.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: And today, there is more optimism in the oil and gas market than there was a year ago. But customer CapEx is  still slow in coming, and despite this, we're expecting an increase in LNG and also downstream orders which will  be biased to the second half of the year. And in Petrochemical, we're well-placed for the projects which are  available, but we don't see the same level of opportunities as we saw last year, particularly from China.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The first element was the realignment of the division's footprint from lower-growth, high-cost markets, to higher- growth, lower-cost regions. The investment in modern world-class facilities commenced in 2015, with a new  machine shop and service centers in [indiscernible] (17:25) and also in China. In 2016, we added a greenfield  operation in South Korea. And in 2017, we consolidated three of our Chinese operations into a new facility in  Shanghai. And last year, we finished the upgrade of our Z&J operations in Germany. This year we'll move our  operation in Japan to a new and more efficient facility, and that'll be largely paid for by the sale of our existing old  plant which is clearly inefficient.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The second and most significant change included a program of restructuring, with an overarching ambition to  dramatically change the geographic footprint and the cost base of Critical's operations. The program started in  2014 with the closure of the UK nuclear components business. In 2015, we then announced the closure of our  Swiss and Canadian nuclear operations and the transfer of TH Jansen in Germany. And those actions delivered  savings of £7 million in 2015.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Now we continue to realign our cost base with the dynamics of the market. And this year our European power  operations will undergo a further program of rationalization, to reduce our overheads and to increase the  utilization of our plants and our engineers. Now it is really important to recognize that despite the complexity, all of  these projects have been delivered on time and on budget and without disruption to our customers.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: The third element of Roy's plans included a division-wide program of Value Engineering which in 2018 delivered  £180 million of new orders. And not only is the Value Engineering reduced the cost of our new products, it's also  enabled us to be competitive in other parts of the market, including the water sector.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Our Rail, our Life Sciences and our Energy verticals all achieved double-digit growth in the year, and that  reflected the benefits of our new product offerings and the division's sector-focused organization.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: In terms of new products, Precision can now boast a world-class product development process and an exciting  pipeline of great new products in the various stages of development. In 2017, we introduced our first new actuator  and air products in the industrial automation sector. Since then, we've launched a range of dispensing pumps in  life sciences, air preparation systems in Rail and some great new products in the energy sector. And sales  generated from new products represented 12% of revenues in 2018.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Moving now to Hydronic Engineering, which includes three industry recognized names, Heimeier, TA and  Pneumatex, and is a leading provider of water-based heating and cooling systems for the residential and  commercial building sectors. I'm really pleased with Phil and his division's success at reinforcing our market  leadership position while also increasing margins in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Mark Wayne Selway
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, IMI Plc
texts.text: Revenue at £309 million was 1% lower on an adjusted basis, and after £3 million of currency, was flat on an  organic basis. Sales of TA balancing and control increased 4% with stronger sales in North America, Switzerland  and the Nordics underpinning that growth. Sales of Heimeier thermostatic control products were 6% lower,  reflecting the phasing of distributor orders, particularly in the first half. Now following our rebate negotiations, we  did see improved sales in the second half of the year. Sales of Pneumatex water quality products increased 5%  due to the success of our new products and our increased investments in technical support in our key markets.

file: INCHL - Q2 2009 Earnings Call 29July2009 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix, Group Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning to you all, and welcome, and thanks for making the time this morning. As I was

file: INCHL - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 29July2010 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix, Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay I think we are ready to go a few minutes late but we’ll try to catch up.  Good morning and
texts.text: In Belgium the revenue growth was better than we expected, the market has been stronger and we  also benefited from good business results in parts which is very important for us in this market.   And given the strong performance of the market on the back of the strong Brussels Motor Show but  also a very important incentive that the government put in place which is basically a 15% tax rebate  for low-CO2 vehicles, we are revising our market estimate for the year and we expect that market  to be at around 576,000 units, a growth of 9% year-on-year in ‘010.  In the second half we will focus  on the launch of the Auris Hybrid which in our view has got a big potential in Belgium and we  continue to drive demand for four-by-four.  We’ve seen a very good demand in Belgium on the back  of the new Land Cruiser which is a fantastic new model.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix, Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay I think we are ready to go a few minutes late but we’ll try to catch up.  Good morning and
texts.text: Let’s now talk about Southeast Asia where as you know our main business is Singapore.  No  surprise there the market was down as expected by 33% in the first half and we know this is due to  the significant reduction of the CO2, COE quota on the back of lower deregistration over the last 18  months.  This significant quota reduction has made the market extremely price competitive and  that’s understandable because we’ve seen an increase of the COE price by more than 100% in the  first six months of 2010 compared to the COE price at the end of 2009.  As discussed a few months  ago given the highly discounted environment and given our strong scale position and our market  leadership, we’ve put a strategy in place to protect our margin.  We don’t want to lower price for  sheer market share gains because frankly as a market leader we have more to lose than to gain  and we can do that because we’ve got a very strong after-sales business, tremendous car park and  world class operation and that is helping us to offset some of the difficulties in the new car market.   And I have to say that our business has coped well with this changing environment. And as John  said a return on sales of 8.7% on the back of a revenue decline of 37% is frankly better than we  thought.  This has been achieved through careful pricing management on new vehicles, very good  after-sales performance but also cost reduction. We have realigned the marketing expenditures to  reflect the lower market and also we have reduced our head count, as you would expect.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: And as one important strategic initiative we are working more and more with sustainability and we see  sustainability as a clear business opportunity and as a company now we have signed the UN Global Compact and  we'll talk a bit about that as well. So, all-in-all a good quarter from Indutrade.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: However, we have had a bit of an issue in terms of the larger company we have, making valves for the power  generation sector. And they came back in terms of order intake quite okay but came into the year with lower order  intake which affected sales negatively, and I will elaborate a little bit more on that as well. But overall good order  intake plus 10% and organically plus 5%.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: And the fourth area which we have worked on more actively in the last year is sustainability and where we see  sustainability more as a clear business opportunity. So if we focus a little bit more on that, we – as I said earlier  we have now signed the UN Global Compact principles. It's basically built on 10 principles in four different areas,  human rights, employment conditions, the environment and anti-corruption. So I think it's a good structure system  for us to work with. And now we are on a sort of development path to implement this in our way in all different  companies. So it sort of fits our de-centralized business model in a good way. But most of our companies have  work with sustainability for quite some time and are quite successful I would say. They understand that by being  good at this, you can impact your revenues, you can definitely impact your costs is positive in terms of talent  management and a lot of different other dimensions.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We have – on a group level updated our materiality analysis and during the last couple of months there has been  active workshops and training modules for all our companies' MDs linked to this. And the way we will actively sort  of work with this is more linked to our board work going forward. So there's going to be a mandatory part in a  board meeting once a year where we will discuss sustainability in all our companies. And we have developed a  tool kit which is relevant for our companies in order to sort of use and support this in their different developments  going forward.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: So if we try to summarize this webcast and the message from us, we have a positive business climate still, we  don't see that trend change. And as I just said, our values, our business model and our strategy is on an  evolutionary development and step by step improvement. We came out sort of good in terms of organic growth  and total growth, both in order intake and sales. And we saw good operational leverage, which resulted in a high  EBITA margin in quarter one of 12.3%.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: If we potentially were to enter into a weaker business climate, I would still underline that with the diversified group  we are, we are very agile and flexible versus a large, more single oriented product line type of industrial company.  So I would say that we are well positioned to tackle a weaker business climate, however, underlining that we don't  see that right now at all.

And that means also that they don't need to have that intensive service at this  moment. So that has mainly been the reason why the recent drop in that business area. Otherwise, the other bad  companies in Flow are supplying to other industries and processing this is being doing quite okay last year.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: If we look on the group level, look at the segments, we have customer segments and if you compare that to one  year ago, there is not that much of a difference. The split is about the same. Someone might think that energy is  lower than it used to be. It was – some years it was 25%. But what has happened over the years now we actually  have expanded in many other areas at same time as energy has been expanding, but not at the same pace as all  the others we have acquired.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Also there are less business now in windmills. There are less businesses in other areas related to the energy  sector like how the innovation for pulp and paper mills. That was strong some years ago. Also to nuclear power,  we have some nice orders some years ago. So in spite of a nice growth for some areas of energy sector is only  accounts 14% now at this moment.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: If you look over the years, you can see the development of the turnover and order intake. And there you see the  blue column where it is actually a little bit higher than the red column. And I might comment a little bit about the  energy sector because we had huge orders coming in in the end of 2011, and they were invoiced during 2012.  But we have had a very nice orders coming in during the whole year and so the backlog we have end of this last  year for the energy sector is very good. And we see a continuous good order intake now coming so far this year,  and we'll expect it to continue the whole year actually. So it's a combination of strong market that we are gaining  market share. So we – I'm very trustful in this industry for the whole year of 2013, actually.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Topflight is a printing company, but is not printing on paper. It's printing on special labels used for machines. It's  very much connected to our customers. Hydnet is in hydraulics, and they are supplying to the big OEMs in  Sweden with hydraulic blocks. They're representing a very nice US company and supplying it to mainly Sweden.  Krämer, recent acquisition, is working to medical areas with kind of vacuum cleaners, dusts for tablets when they  manufacture tablets in the pharmaceutical industry.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: So what I think about 2013? Well, as everybody knows, the forecast is always very, very difficult. I know, for  instance, that the energy sector will continue to perform for the whole year. I know that everyone else out there  has an optimistic view now on the markets in Europe, United States and in China.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We've seen the bookings for the first month. It was better than expected actually, organically. So from – in the  beginning of this year, I was very questioning what is going in the market, so I must say I'm much more optimistic  today. And now I have respect for it's only one month, but the sign from our customers what they say generally is  it looks much better. Still I should say that the forest industry, we don't see any sign of change there in marine  sector, but many of the sectors it's more positive signs at this moment.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: So, that is really those markets within Switzerland and the UK has really been positive in our portfolio. Almost all  of the [ph] associate (1:22) national energy market has continued to grow very nicely and with a very nice profit  development and we expect that for the coming years also. And this is a business we have in Holland and in  South Korea selling worldwide. So, when we look at total, the acquisitions were really contributing to the growth  and sales and the [ph] EBITDA (1:46) last year.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We have some areas there also actually doing pretty well. And one company working to the [ph] windmills (7:21)  with equipment are doing very well. And it's the case in Finland as well as one company working with kind of  differential GPS system in the Finnish market. Otherwise, generally, the Engineering & Equipment has a tough  time in the Finnish market, but we have all industries related to forest, pulp and paper, and mining and all of them  are out in the best mode at this moment.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: And here, we have this Swiss business, UK business, energy business, and all of those things are outside the  Nordic. And most of them are actually in this business area. And also we did three acquisitions, and one is in a  new area for us in UK; Verplas that grows into construction industry in UK and that is now actually a growing  industry,. They are starting to build houses and other buildings in UK, and we will benefit from that in the coming  years now.

texts.speaker: Leif Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Outlook is very hard to – everyone has 2009 in memory and we have seen some bumpy roads during last years.  But we can see is, during the autumn, we see improvements in a number of areas, not all but, hopefully, if it  continues, we are in a slight upturn for the coming year. And sooner or later even forest industry, I guess, start to  invest and have to buy machines and everything. If it would happen, generally, on this year, I don't know. And if I  look at what [indiscernible] (18:44) just say today, they are, I think, generally more optimistic about 2014 than they  were in 2013. Then it has to be transferred into orders or bookings as the next stage.
