texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We see there that the hydraulic business going to – that offshore machines has been – have very good bookings  and that markets have picked up and continues to be in a good level. They also have businesses going to  infrastructure, that means the water applications where you transport fresh water in that business also doing very  well in that business area.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If you remember, we had a weak start for the energy sector, both in sales and bookings but the bookings picked up  during especially third quarter, fourth quarter and also then the sales starting. So we had an excellent end of the  year in that area and we have a booking, one let's say backlog today that is actually above the level of sales we had  last year in that special business. So, it looks very nice for the future.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, not much of clouds in the sky, even though, when I look outside, I see a lot of clouds but the business it looks  very good. So, I now open up for questions.

file: INDT - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 16February2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Thank you. Welcome everybody to this presentation, I don't know how many we've had so far, but it's the same  procedure as last year more or less. One year ago we had a nice growth in 2014 and now we had even better  growth in 2015. And as most of you know that it's been a challenging market and when I look at the market, I  think we have a general situation where the earlier markets with higher oil prices were investing a lot like Russia,  Saudi Arabia and others and of course their investments have dropped down now and then the money is  transferred to the Western world, but we don't use it for the investment, we use it for other purposes. So the  general market has been down I guess in most areas.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In spite of that, we managed to grow our business with 22% and also increase EBITA with 26% and I think it's – I  have compared our companies earlier with [indiscernible] (1:20) around Stockholm; now I can compare it with  these small gray birds that are around your table, when you are sitting and drinking your coffee outside, the small  birds goes around and pick up the small things, comes down from the big table. And that's another way of showing  how we are, we are always managed to survive and also grow the business in spite of a bad business climate in  general.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, if you look at the last quarter, order intake rose 20%, and the EBITA is 90%, and the EBITA margin 12.4%,  EBIT less than last year for different reasons. But the cash flow was strong, and also nice increase here in profit  after tax. And what we can see that in the last quarter also we had a very nice development of the energy sector.  Actually, we had that also in last year, 2014, but this year even further on. And what especially is good is that also  the bookings was very good in that sector. So, we had the dramatic increase between 2014 and 2015, depending on  orders we received in 2014. And the start of the year 2015 was a little bit slow on the order intake, but it finished  up on the level, on the same level actually as 2014. So, we have now a very good situation for the  coming year in  the energy sector.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Next area, Flow Technology are working through the process industry and the y had very nice bookings during last,  almost two years. And it's in many different areas, but in [ph] process (9:25) industry, and especially now lately  it's also in pulp and paper industry in the Swedish market, a lot of what you call refurbishment and re building of  different plants. So, there are some nice projects there. Also the nuclear power have been very good for us, and  then you can question will there be any future in that? Well, some of the equipment we have delivered will never  be used, but still we have new products coming up this year. So even in 2016, we expect a nice year for nuclear  power. And generally pretty optimistic organization within this area of outflow, the only area that's not so  optimistic here is the marine side. And of course that still is a very, very slow – slow business we have in Flow  Technology.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Industrial Components are suffering last year from the currency, and because mostly it's imp ortant in Sweden,  also that we have one business still suffering a lot on that is the oil and gas sector in Norway, they would still have  a tough time during the first quarter this year, but expect Q2 to start up much better because they are products  coming on in Norway in Q2. But Q1, oil sector will be not performing well. Most of the other business in Industrial  Components in the Swedish market looks pretty positive I must say. So Sweden as a market is okay, it's growing to  some extent.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we go to UK, the south means Ireland, Ireland is doing very well and we saw opportunities with the – from [ph]  a skeptical (13:17) industry there. We also are in construction industry in UK, also growing, some of the other  parts [ph] general industry has (13:24) been flattening out. We think is depending on the connection to oil and gas  with our customers, but also to the strong currency or the strong pound. Not really worried, but we can see it  flattening out in part of the UK market.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Our biggest business is in valves for power generation, had a fantastic 2015 and had actually very good 2016, but  the comparable figures were tough between 2016 and 2017 and that has affected the outcome of the year. And  also the marine segment, that's only a few percent of our turnover, but still, has been troublesome and they also  follow other businesses that the marine side has not developed in any areas more or less. It's really a very bad  segment and we have been suffering from that also. But if you take away these two parts, everything else has  developed very well during the year.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: If we look at the market conditions, this is one way to describe. Sweden is flat or actually slightly a bit up, as I see  it. Finland is really up, we can see, oil and gas. We have a small business in oil and gas in Norway, and they have  big troubles in 2015, but actually they made a nice profit last year. It's a small business, but we have turned it  around. So, that is okay.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Net sales, I mean, we had a drop in the marine sector and also in the power generation, but I will come back to  that when we go into the business areas later on.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: And this is how it looks for the whole year. And same story there if we exclude the power generation, we had a  much higher organic growth both in net sales as well as in EBITA.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Acquisitions. 11 acquisitions, and I must say, since I joined this group, I've been trying to increase the number of  acquisitions with own brands. And last year, we had a number of very nice companies with relatively high  technology that we acquired. So, if you look at Senmatic who is a nice Danish business working with sensors for  10% moisture and also working with equipment for greenhouses has developed very well. Beldam Crossley, our  manufacturing sealings for different applications, a very profitable business in UK, has a very nice growth. And  also, their customers start developing very well. Klokkerholm, quite different business, it is body parts for cars  aftermarket, also doing very well.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Vacuum Engineering is same little business we acquired some years ago, with leak testing, selling to  manufacturers for car industry, testing different parts, is used in car industry. Crysberg is another company, it's a  controlled system for actually controlling aggregations or for dewatering of golf courses and also of parks. Very  interesting company, very high degree of export. Alphr Technology, is another testing company with high  technology in UK. And finally, Scanmaskin is doing all machines for grinding concrete, with a very good market in  United States. So, I must say it's an unusual amount of campus with own brands, also very high margins we  acquired last year and they're doing very well.

texts.speaker: Johnny Alvarsson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We started this year as we normally do [indiscernible] (11:22) with acquisitions. And so far, we have done three  acquisitions. The first is a small one in Holland, but that is connected to Pentronic, which is one of our really high- performing companies since many years in temperature sensors. And this is a small business in Holland that will  be a subsidiary to Pentronic's, and I hope it will develop very well, also very profitable business.

file: INDT - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 13February2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: In terms of geographies, we have a beneficial climate in the Nordic countries, also in the Benelux and Germany;  perhaps a bit slower in certain [ph] senses (00:05:15) in the UK and in Switzerland, and I will also talk about that a  bit more. We are becoming more and more international as a company and I think during 2018, we will prep for  the first year show, higher invoicing outside the Nordics than within the Nordics. So, step-by-step we are building  an international business in a successful way.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We have had, on a relative basis, lower performance in one of our companies, one of our larger companies within  power generation. And that has quite substantial impact on our earnings and EBITA margin. This specific  company had, I would say, good benefit from mega projects during 2015 and 2016. And those type of very  substantial large projects are not present in the marketplace anymore. And this is, I would say, to a large extent,  linked to higher or lower oil prices and lower investments in that sector. But there are still investments and we see  that the order intake are improving or is improving for this company in a good way.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We have a good situation, I would say, in Sweden and Finland. Part of Denmark is more towards the stable side,  and Norway, we point out, being stable here. But I would say that oil and gas is definitely showing some  improvements linked to the somewhat higher oil price, so I think you have also seen that companies like Statoil  and others are showing very good results for quarter four. And we also see that – and this is benefiting some of  our companies in that sector.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: But I want to reinforce here that we came in at 11%. I'm not fully satisfied with that, even if we then, in that  number, exclude the restructuring. But most of this could be explained by – in a relative sense, lower result for  this power generation-related company. Again, this is a successful company but in relative perspective, they have  the considerably lower result in quarter four.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Again, I am optimistic and positive and not worried about this going forward. We are seeing better order intake for  this power generation company and the relative situation will be easier to manage in that perspective. And I think  we will see well-performing companies in this portfolio going forward here. So, even if I'm absolutely not satisfied  with quarter four, I am optimistic that this will improve going forward.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: And the third dimension, in terms of our overall objectives, is sustainability. We are working with this, both long- term and short-term and on a day-to-day basis. And I would say Indutrade's business model is very much about  sustainability. First of all, we are sustainable in the sense that we are stable in our performance. And we don't  want growth which is not sustainable. We want stable growth over time. And the best, I would say, receipt on that  is when you look at the Indutrade performance in 2009 when a lot of businesses had very difficult times. Indutrade  went from approximately a margin level of 10% – 12% [ph] now (00:47:19) down to 9%. So, a very stable  performance in a difficult market environment. But we are also working on sustainability in a broader perspective  and that's also, I would say, close to our heart and part of our culture in a natural way within Indutrade.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: for us. I don't think so. We have very little exposure, I would say, to house buildings in larger cities in the Nordic  area. We are more linked to infrastructure and to give you an example, a strong, I would say, base in the water  and wastewater segment where basically all major cities have a lot of need for maintenance repairs and a great  business opportunity for us, which is actually partly why one of our business area had a good development in  quarter four which I will come back to.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: We finalized two acquisitions in the quarter. The Dutch company by the name Thermo Electric, very good at  temperature sensing and another UK-based company called NRG. NRG making, I would say, control systems for  door automations.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: But I would say the overall outlook for the company is still positive and good. We are strategically adding some  dimensions to this company. We have mostly worked with traditional power generation projects, gas-related  power generation projects. Now, we have started a cooperation with an external company focusing more on the  Industrial segment. So a lot of process industries are also using high pressure valves and we are step-by-step  entering into this segment, and we are also establishing more of a formal foothold in China this year. So I think  strategically, this company will benefit from this and step-by-step build a more broad-based business.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: Similar story with Precision UK, an entrepreneur who started to design an assortment of medical gas  components, was successful in selling those, and extended his product range to also include more sophisticated  product and for their own systems, and now is a full-scale producer on medical gas component systems and  present in several markets internationally, and we will help him grow further in a profitable way, and again, an  engaged entrepreneur within the Indutrade family.

texts.speaker: Bo Gerhard Annvik
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Indutrade AB
texts.text: In terms of the business climate, I think it's still good and stable; perhaps only Finland, which stands out a little bit  in terms of less project activity. We see a little bit of hesitation regarding large capital investments in Ireland, in the  UK, I would say, linked to Brexit, but with limited effect on our businesses overall. So, still a good stable business  climate. Might be some seasonality in terms of Q1, so not perhaps sequentially as strong as we have been in  quarter four, in quarter one, but still optimistic about quarter one in 2019 and eager to move on.

texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV

texts.text: Now basically, we go one step further and we look at what are the internal sustainability KPIs of a company and  can we actually connect the margin to their progress on those sustainability KPIs. texts.text: On slide eight, you see how well we are positioned relative to the new Basel III requirements. texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: Turning to slide 7. As a bank, ING makes the most climate impact through our financing as you know in the  footprint of banks. The direct footprint of banks is generally managed well. It's also not big, but we can actually  make a big income through – well impact through the management of the indirect footprint, which is through our  customers and the money that we lend to our customers.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: We have a loan book of €600 billion across many sectors, and we will now be considering this towards meeting  the Paris Agreement's 2-degree goal. Now, we're able to start doing this by creating an innovative, accurate way  to measure the climate impact of our portfolio and – that we call Terra. This approach is being co-created by the  2-degree investment – investing initiative, and it's a leading global think tank. And Terra looks at the technology  shift that is needed across certain sectors to keep the risk of global temperatures to well below the 2-degree  Celsius.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: For example, in the automotive sector, it's not enough to lower the emissions by making fewer petrol-powered  cars. But you really need to produce more electric cars, right? Terra then measures the need shifted in technology  against the actual technology clients are using today and planning on using it in the future. And that's where  financing comes in, and that's where we can have a major impact by having that conversation with our clients. I  think it works basically on two sides. On one side, clearly, we are then together working on how we will comply  with the 2-degree ambition that we have. On the other side, from a risk management perspective, it gives you  control over mitigating the risk of ending up with stranded assets. So it works on both sides. It's an important thing  to do, but from both the bank's perspective as well as the society's perspective.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: Now, we clearly realize that we can't do this alone. We've made this Terra approach now open source. Many  banks have indicated their interest, and I hope they will join us on this one. Clearly, if new technologies will come  around or better methodologies are developed, we will move towards that as well, but we didn't want to wait for a  global standard and everybody to agree because it took already too long. So we launched our own in order to  start really having an impact on climate with this.

texts.text: Then zooming in on Wholesale Banking risk cost on slide 20. Risk costs in Wholesale Banking continue their  downward trend. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board

texts.speaker: Ralph Hamers

texts.speaker: Ralph Hamers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board
texts.text: Nevertheless, given the further decline of oil prices in the fourth quarter, the oil price risk in certain segments of  our oil sector has increased. That's ov erall risk  cost, overall on the total portfolio.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Executive Board ING Group, Management Board Banking, ING Groep NV
texts.text: Turning to sustainability and I'd like to remind you how important that is to ING. And I think the annual results is a  good moment to kind of give you an update. And that portfolio of Sustainable  Transitions Financed, as we call it, the STF, has increased to €34 billion now.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Executive Board ING Group, Management Board Banking, ING Groep NV
texts.text: In November, we launched the Sustainable Finance Collective Asia. And that's the first of its kind. It's a funding  initiative in the region where we basically group different parties together, look at different business models, and  see how we together can support the development of new circular models, climate neutral models and help each  other. At the same time, in our Real Estate Finance Netherlands activity, we decided that we will only offer new  financing to green office buildings going forward.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Executive Board ING Group, Management Board Banking, ING Groep NV
texts.text: As you've probably already read and seen in the different newspapers, we also get strong external recognition for  our sustainability policies. Leading sustainability and responsible investment magazine, Corporate Knights,  ranked us as the fifth most sustainable company in the world even. And we're pretty proud of that. And naturally,  we're also proud and specifically – all of our colleagues we're very proud to have been recognized as the Global  Bank of the Year 2016 by The Banker magazine.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Executive Board ING Group, Management Board Banking, ING Groep NV
texts.text: I have to mention that Industry Lending growth was flattered a little by higher oil and commodity prices with trade  and commodity finance. So, the underlying volumes keep coming strong.  It's a good signal there as well.

We're also committing €100 million to support sustainable scale-ups as well. The sustainability efforts are  recognized externally as we are ranked as one of the leading banks if it comes to the different SREP scores.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer and Chairman, Executive Board ING Group, Management Board Banking, ING Groep NV
texts.text: So we're very proud of that not only because we're charging ahead with climate change and sustainability and the  circular economy but also because these are the solutions that our clients really want and expect from us. One of the  examples that we have here is that we acted as a book-runner on a €600 million green bond for Toyota, also a  good deal. And personally, I'm inspired by the story of a town in the Netherlands where inhabitants created the  largest floating solar park in Europe. And it may not be a big deal. But the inhabitants had took the initiative. We  financed it. And it shows what is going on in society and what you can do together in order to improve. So it's  really inspiring.

file: INGA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 6February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: Turning the page, we got into an update on sustainability. One thing that we're already specifically very proud of is  the Terra approach. As you know, we launched the Terra approach, which basically is a methodology through  which we engage with our clients to see how we can decrease the footprint or the indirect footprint of our asset  base in line with the Paris ambition, the Paris Accord. We came to a specific commitment and we launched that in  Katowice together with four other European banks. And we're so happy with that because in the end it's all about  how do you create a industry standard.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: And we pledged our commitment to decrease our indirect footprint. And we pledged our commitment to this  methodology. And clearly, if there was better methodology in the future, we will certainly adopt that as well. But in  the end, for you or for many other stakeholders, it's important that we do that in a standard way and that we agree  on a standard. And therefore having the other European banks onboard kind of shows first that this is an open  approach, an open-source approach. And secondly that [ph] you know that (00:09:08) I think we can get going to  really influence the climate change.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV
texts.text: We do more on this. And we also issued the largest green bond to-date by European bank. And we got the IFR  2018 SRI Bond of the Year award for that. So that also shows that we can become more sustainable. So, it's not  only our clients, but ourselves as well. And so, this is another testimony to the fact that we take this very seriously.

texts.speaker: Ralph A. J. G. Hamers
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ING Groep NV

file: INVE.B - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 24April2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Börje Ekholm
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Investor AB
texts.text: To give you a quick overview of Wärtsilä, has three lines of business. One is the ship power, which is two-stroke  engines and four-stroke engines for use the – both liquid as well as gas-fueled. Power plants is a four-stroke.  These can be used for example for base load, where you have the weak grid, but it can also be used as a balancing  power source. For example, you have wind parks. As you know, if you happen to be an electrical engineer, like  myself, you know that there are a few problems with wind power. One is, of course, the very simple fact that you  don't have wind 24/7. That's of course a problem that needs to be balanced. But the other problem is even in a  strong wind, you may get actually frequency variations in the network. Therefore, you need a balancing engine or  balancing generation capacity to make sure you have a stable network. Same argument in solar power, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Börje Ekholm
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Investor AB
texts.text: Of course, we also supply to industrial sales generation as well as other areas where you need uninterrupted power  supply. They have a very large aftermarket and that's the services here, which is something we like quite a lot. That  provides us stability that the – or it creates a business that's much more stable than the other two divisions.

texts.speaker: Börje Ekholm
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Investor AB
texts.text: So why do we like this? It's a structurally very attractive industry and we see many growth opportunities in here.  Just to pick a few, if you look on the marine side, the ship power, that's really dependent on global trade. We think  global trade will continue to grow. You also see environmental regulation being increasingly important, a benefit  for Wärtsilä. We also see basically the global need for power increases. So if you take regions with a weak utility  system or electrical grid, there is a need to generate local power and they will continue to consume power. And if  you can't produce power in an environmentally good way, which is what you do with using gas for example, we  think that's a very important growth driver for Wärtsilä.

texts.text: Also if I have a look to the backlog that we have in this moment in incoming order, our backlog is basically the  same we had last year in the oil sector. And in Water Jetting Sector is 20% more than we had as of the end of first  quarter 2014. So, for what concerns sales, let me say, a nice picture.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: But even speaking of profit, of course, also we've – we had of the contribution of these sales, the margin are very  good. We had in the first quarter a total EBITDA of €43.5 million in comparison with €32 million over last year. So,  there is a growth of 35.8%. Excluding Walvoil and Inoxihp on a like-for-like basis, our EBITDA would have been  €36.6 million versus €32 million of last year. So, basically on a like-for-like basis, our growth is 14.4% and our  EBITDA margin is 20.1% versus 20% over last year. So, we've a growth in the EBITDA margin. The most  important growth we had, of course, in Water Jetting, as I told you, Water Jetting had an EBITDA margin of [ph]  €14.5 million (00:08:22). That represents 23.9% on sales with a growth of 25.6% over last year where the EBITDA  has been 14.7%. Regarding the oil sector, our EBITDA margin this year is €25 million versus the €17.3 million of  last year, so with a growth of 44.2% and on a like-for-like basis, a growth of 7.1%.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: But you know that Brazil means South America and so that for us, Brazil is a very important country where we  really want to become the point of reference in the hydraulic market.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: You know we already have in the hydraulic sector two company in Brazil. One is Takarada and the other one is  Walvoil Do Brasil. We have seen recently a very, let me say, good company, a company with a reputed position in  the market that is growing. This company is Osper. Osper is, by the way, also a dynamic entrepreneur that is a  fast growing company. And this company is manufacturing power take-off and hydraulic cylinders. So with the  decision of buying this company, today we are, by far, the most important manufacturer of power take-off in Brazil.  And we are, let me say, a very important player because with the product of the other plans, we already had in  Brazil, we have a very good portfolio of different products, and so that we are able in this moment to serve, to  supply many different market of hydraulic in Brazil.

texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA

texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Giving some details about this sales, we have the hydraulic sector that with the acquisition of Hydrocontrol in the  first half of the year is plus 4.2%. The first half result is €143.5 million versus €137.7 million last year. So for the  hydraulic division is flat 4.25%. Now it's almost at the same  level as last year. So practically there is still a small difference, but Hammelmann is growing.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: First of all, what is this company? This company, the name of this company is IMM Group. IMM Group is a  company active in the production of hydraulic hoses, pipes and connectors. I think that speaking with someone of  you many times, I gave you the idea that it was our interest to enter also in this business, because as you can  understand hoses are the elements that connects all the components all in every single component of an  hydraulic system. So there is no application in the work, there is no activity, no hydraulic activity in the work that  can avoid to use hoses. And what is that very important also to understand, hoses is, let me say, is the first  element that usually breaks during the use of the equipment. The big corporation, they all produce hoses, Parker  produces hoses, Eaton produce hoses. So really we targeted this kind of company for a long time because we  consider hoses a very strategic fit into the hydraulic system.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: In the beginning, we saw with oil and gas slowdown in upstream. Now, we see that there is also a slowdown in  downstream. As I already told you three months ago, in the U.S. domestic market, this was compensated for by  the ongoing shift from buying to renting. Since the beginning of the year, NLB total revenues are down 10%.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: The U.S. President was elected yesterday. Someone is happy, someone not. But anyway, let me say that  uncertainty is over. Also then the fall in oil price, I think, is over to say at least, and even rig account seems to  have inverted this trend. I don't know if exactly those are the best day to understand better this trend, but in the  last week, we saw a trend like this.

file: IP - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 8November2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Water-Jetting. Water-Jetting saw a total reported growth of over 20.8%, including an organic increase of 2.8%.  0.1% is the contribution from the exchange rate and 17.9% difference in perimeter, representing eight months of  Inoxpa and four months of Mariotti & Pecini.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: So, for example, earth moving is up 9% and, let me say, is stable. Agriculture is up 16%, but coming from – up  11%. Lifting, 9%. Construction is plus 25%, up from 18%. Truck are up 14%. It was 12% with direct sales to truck  and manufacturer registering as plus 37%, up from 32%. Cleaning is up at 7%. This is a little bit slower, it was  9%. And steel/aluminum grew by 40%, and it was 33%.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: So, you see a very good, a very strong trend. Of course, on the other side, you have oil and gas. Oil and gas –  sales in oil and gas are 33% less than last year, reducing our direct exposure to this sector to only 1.7%. So,  comparing the first nine months with the corresponding period of last year, lost sales in oil and gas amounted to  roughly €7 million, which is, if you want to settle it, a negligible number compared to our consolidated result. But  this €7 million happened to be almost entirely concentrated at NLB in the U.S. And so, in this way, adversely  affecting the Water-Jetting performance in North America.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: But be careful that while the dynamic of oil price is entirely out of our control, I'm very happy to report that the  remaining part of NLB business is healthy. The company has managed to keep its margin despite the drop in  sales and is extremely, extremely well-positioned to take advantage of any initiatives, whether government or  private in the field of infrastructure renewal.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: And on top of this, at least for this quarter, also for NLB contractors, contractors finally got rid of their correlation  with oil and gas. And so, year-on-year growth in sale to this customer category had finally returned positive.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: The consolidated year-to-date figure is 23.4%. Specifically, in Water-Jetting, the EBITDA amounted 26.5% on  sales, in the quarter it was 26.2%. In Hydraulics we reached the 21.6% and in the quarter it was 21.9% in  Hydraulics.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: The country is still in need of some major infrastructure renewal. And in time, this will allow our Water-Jetting  companies to express their full potential. China – China appears to be moving. And recently confirmed the  decision to build a new giant infrastructure such as the [indiscernible] (17:37). And now, you understand that a  project of that magnitude will certainly require the contribution of Western-style hydraulic components. So, our  components.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: For the time being, Walvoil is reporting major increases in sales of components for earth moving and construction  machinery, in both to OEM and distributors. And also, Water-Jetting division is doing its part, particularly [ph]  Hammelmann (18:09) with their cutting-edge paint removal technology for the shipyards. And on top of this, do  not forget that the incredibly large potential of the Chinese market for food processing components which are just  beginning – we are just beginning to tap into.

file: IP - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 7November2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: When we say, we are flexible, we really mean it. The same product that can be used across many different  applications. If you take a gear pump, a gear pump can be used in agriculture as well as in earthmoving or [ph]  releasing (00:07:48). The same for valves, and of course, even more for hose and fitting. Even if you consider  different products, different products share the same manufacturing process based on standard machine tools.  We have no need for dedicated production line as is typical, for example, in the car industry.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Now, let's take a look also at the trend in our main application sector for the first nine months of the year. So, at  this point, Earthmoving is up at 17%; Agriculture came very close at 16%; Truck is 14%, of which Truck  Manufacturers is plus 29%; Construction, plus 11%; Industry (sic) [Industrial] (00:12:23), plus 9%; Lifting, plus 8%;  Contractors, plus 7%; Food, Cosmetics & Pharma, plus 6%; Cleaning, plus 2%.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: And now it's time to talk about margin. You may remember that in the previous quarter, both Water-Jetting and  Hydraulic net of GS-Hydro has hit an all-time record, respectively, at 28% and 22.2%. Now, with the help of the  strong organic growth, in Q3, EBITDA margin for Water-Jetting rose even further, reaching 29%. 29%. In  Hydraulic, the 22.2% was substantially confirmed at 22% which became 20.5% when factoring in GS-Hydro. The  resulting EBITDA margin for the whole group is 23.5%.

file: IP - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 10February2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Now, if we go activity-by-activity, I would say, if we start from the Hydraulic side, we have – I'm talking now in  current exchange rates, okay. Then if you have questions, I tell you using constant exchange rates, but anyway,  Muncie increased its sales in the year, which adjusted out by 19.9%. Interpump Hydraulics, which are mainly  PTO's increased its sales by 21% and Cylinder by almost 23%, which makes that the overall increase of sales for  the Hydraulic Sector, Muncie, Interpump Hydraulics and Cylinders went up by 21.5%.

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Now going through the EBITDA of all the sectors and all these companies, , well, we have – Muncie reached the  level of 15.7% in terms of EBITDA, Interpump Hydraulics [indiscernible] (13:20) 13.5% and Cylinders went up to  11.1%. Last year, just as a reminder, the Cylinders were at 2%. So, we multiply it by 5 percentage-wise, the  EBITDA margin of Cylinders and we multiply it by 7.5 times the EBITDA – by more than 7 times EBITDA in  absolute terms [indiscernible] (13:48). So, all together, the hydraulic sector reached the level of 12.4% which last  year was 8.8%. Now, frankly, as you know, this lever is not yet satisfactory for us. I think if volumes will go up and  I think volumes will go up and I'll explain to you in a minute why, but if volumes go up, this margin should improve  and could improve substantially.

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Consider again that hydraulic was a sector among our sectors if you take industrial and hydraulic, hydraulic was a  sector which declined the most, suffered most, and it's not yet so close to the levels of 2007 and 2008. So there is  some recuperation to be made, which – recuperation which has been made, I don't want to say 0.5%, but in a  large part has been already made in [indiscernible] (16:04) pumps.

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Hammelmann recorded a very good level of 32.4% in terms of EBITDA so it's the highest among whole our  companies and this 32.4% comes from a level in 2009 of 24.7%. The increase in absolute terms is 53%. Energy  went from 13% in 2009 to 16.7% EBITDA margin in 2010, now here too a very good increase and an increase in  dollar terms of 61%.

file: IP - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 14February2013 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: So what we used to call in English Industrial Sector, now we are calling it Water Jetting Sector and the Hydraulic  has remained Hydraulic, while in Italian I'd tell you for the Italian you would see what was the Industrial Sector,  Settore Industriale has become Settore Acqua, so Water Sector. And what was [indiscernible] (00:08:15) has  become Settore Olio [indiscernible] (00:08:20).

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Now, if I take the Water Jetting Sector, which was, as I tell you, the Industrial Sector, total sales reached a level of  €269 million, which is very high. It is not higher than it was before the crisis we had in 2008. Just to give you an  idea, in 2008, total sales were €216 million. So they moved from €216 million up to €269 million in 2012. And here  [indiscernible] (00:08:55) on a like-for-like basis because there were no particular acquisitions in this sector. So at  the same time this sector also increased profitability because profitability, which was [indiscernible] (00:09:09)  EBITDA margin, was 24.6% in 2008, equal to €53 million. Now, it has been last year equal to 25.1% in 2012,  equal to almost €68 million.

texts.speaker: Giovanni Maria Cavallini
texts.profession: Chairman, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Now, if I move to the hydraulic sector, I have [indiscernible] (00:09:41) a total sales – well, we have divided it into  three different parts. One is the usual Hydraulic Sector, which we had in the past, which is the power take offs and  the gear pumps. And we are at €162 million in terms of sales, which compared in 2008 with €171 million. So, we  are not too far from what we were just before the [ph] current fiscal (00:10:08), and the EBITDA still is lagging  behind. It was €32 million in 2008 and it is €23 million. So, there is still room probably to grow somewhat the  results.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Co-Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: On the other hand, we have a lot certainties; certainties of the company, because we have new products both in  the water sector and in the oil sector. We have a new pump for [indiscernible] (00:14:30). We have a new cylinder  and new gear pump for Muncie. We are starting sales of cylinders in [indiscernible] (00:14:42) in Brazil, and we  are looking for interesting opportunity in Canada with the mining activities. Then we have even some new  customers. In India, we just started supply startup that we consider, as you know, the number one in that market.

texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Co-Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA

texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Co-Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA

texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Co-Chief Executive Officer, Interpump Group SpA
texts.text: Before speaking about profit, I would like to remind you, beside the two very important operations, the two very  important acquisitions, the acquisition of Hydrocontrol and I.M.M. that we had last year, I wanted to remind you  the big job we did in restructuring and reorganizing our activities particularly in Italy, particularly in the Hydraulic  Sector.

texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also, considering on a like-for-like basis, so that's excluding IMM and Hydrocontrol eight months, we are €147.7  million versus €139 million, so with a growth of 6.3%. texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have also a very good performance in the Water Jetting Sector. Water Jetting Sector that you remember, at the  beginning of the year, started a little bit slower than usual, but they recuperated during the year. Also, the backlog, t he  backlog that we are bringing for 2015 at the end of the year – at the end of 2014, is a very good one, is a strong  one, is more than 10%, and it is higher in Water Jetting Sector, let me say, is also higher in the Hydraulic Sector,  but a little bit even strong stronger in the Water Jetting Sector.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Positive, of course, also the result of the last quarter, we have in EBITDA amount of €30.4 million versus €25.5  million. So, there is a growth of 19%, and the percentage of EBITDA on sales is 18.8% versus 18.4% of the 2013.  This is, again, very good in the two sector. In the Hydraulic Sector, we got €14.2 million that represents 15% on  sales versus €10.2 million that was 13.3% of sales, so with the growth of 38.3%. And in the Water Jetting division,  we had €16.2 million that represents 24% against €15.2 million in 2013 that basically represent the same  percentage.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Even better our result in EBITDA, because in EBITDA we got the result of €136.1 million. That represents 20.3%  on sales versus €105.1 million of last year that represented 18.9%. So there is an important growth of 29.4%. Even  considering the like-for-like basis so that – with the same perimeter, our results would've been €121.8 million;  that represents 20.6% on sales versus €105.1 million that I told you before that represented 18.9%. Good result.  Very, very good result in the water – in the Hydraulic division because the Hydraulic division went this year from  14.1%, the percentage of 2013, to 17.5%, the percentage of this year. So, basically, we got €69.4 million against  €41.4 million last year. And let me say, there is, basically, the same result in term of the percentage if we are  considering a like-for-like basis.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek
texts.profession: Deputy Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But also very good the result of Water Jetting, let me say, as usual, because Water Jetting went to €66.7 million  versus €63.7 million, so basically, with the same percentage around 24.2%. So, I think that those are very, very  beautiful numbers. We are happy of this result and, as I told you at the beginning, very motivated for this year.

texts.speaker: Paolo Marinsek

This is what we have in the  basket of initiative for 2017, and this is what make us even more confident for the result of the year.

texts.profession: Okay, I’d like to propose that we get started.  We are five minutes late, but we just wanted to make
texts.text: So to be successful we can say today that the days where it was only a factor of quantitative scores  made on targeting physicians that can lead to a success of any pharmaceutical company, it’s not  the case anymore. In addition to this, the  specialty product pharma market is also creating new partner and stakeholders we have to manage  and deal with such as the specialty pharmacies that help the payors to navigate into the  reimbursement system.

texts.speaker: Jean Luc Bélingard, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Okay, I’d like to propose that we get started.  We are five minutes late, but we just wanted to make
texts.text: Turning now to slide 61, you will see that our COGS ratio was flat year-on-year at 22.1% of sales  but we completed in 2010 the shift of the manufacturing costs of our botulinum toxin active  substance from industrial development to cost of goods.  Excluding this shift, our COGS ratio has  continued to improve year-on-year thanks to our productivity effort and the favorable product mix  related to the growth of our specialty care products despite declining volumes in primary care.

texts.text: As you see, the upper side of the slide with the COGS and R&D are improving in percentage of sales with 0.8 point  lower COGS we show that the growth of the business is also improving the mix and Somatuline is o ne of the most  profitable product in Ipsen portfolio. So the more we are growing the Somatuline, the more we are improving our  gross margin, the more the COGS in percentage of sale is reducing. texts.speaker: Aymeric Le Chatelier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: As you see the rest of the business, which are all the other product, all the G&A and R&D invested during the  semester are at 25% and no impact on the margin. And then foreign exchange have some negative impact where  clearly we have more cost in U.S. dollar, which does not translate into COI or COI margin improvement as  compared to the sales, where we have clearly a very positive impact. So, when we'll turn our U.S. operation  profitable, then the dollar will be a big driver for margin expansion. But today we are still investing in the U.S. and  this is clearly impacting negatively our margin.

texts.text: Our cost of goods sold represented 23% of sales this year, slightly up compared with 22.7% in  2008. However, this increase is only due to a non-cash impact of a purchase price accounting, and  excluding those charges, our COGS ratio would have been flat at 22.8% like last year.

texts.speaker: Jean-Luc Bélingard, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

texts.text: Turning to the next slide, slide 26, we wanted to describe to you in very broad terms how much we  think the environment has changed since we announced our U.S. acquisitions in July of 2008, a  little less than two years ago. Even though we have made great progress and expect our growth  and profitability in the U.S. to continue to ramp up very significantly and dynamically, this last 18  months marked by a profound financial crisis and economic crisis, a tougher French Primary Care  environment led us not to confirm our 2011 and 2012 perspectives or at least their timeframe.

texts.speaker: Jean-Luc Bélingard, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Good afternoon. A very warm welcome to all of you and, of course, good afternoon or good
texts.text: We continue to believe that our strategic decision to enter the U.S. is the right one, as we have  doubled our addressable market and that the growth prospects there are absolutely fantastic. The corporate social  responsibility, the demands are increasing, so when you're outsourcing to subcontractors, also specialty services  [indiscernible] (00:25:50) for the clients or they outsource to somebody, but they know we'll be able to deliver the  services in the right way. texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, ISS A/S

file: ISS - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 5March2012 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jeff Olsen Gravenhorst
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, ISS A/S
texts.text: So, overall very happy with the results for 2011, strong performance and seen in light of relatively difficult  business environmental conditions like the public markets, the debt situation in the Eurozone and of course with  all the big events that we have gone through ourselves with the IPO in the beginning of the year, refinancing and  G4S in the end of the year, overall very, very good results and I'm very satisfied with that.

texts.speaker: Barbara Plucnar Jensen
texts.profession: Head of Group Treasury, ISS A/S
texts.text: If you turn to slide number 22, we would like to give you some additional information regarding how we work with  working capital. As both Henrik and Jeff alluded to 2011 was another turbulent year not only for ISS, but also  when looking at the economic climate and in general the access to liquidity. We like to be in control. We like to  have a top priority around the cash flows of the company and therefore we still continue to work very intense with  our working capital management, prioritizing workshops to ensure that we have best practices around the  company making sure that we exchange and learn from each other from the various regions because we can see  that the deterioration of the economic climate hits various places in the world around us. So definitely one of the  key priority and focused areas also ahead of us.

texts.speaker: Jeff Olsen Gravenhorst
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Coming up to through the 1970s up towards the 2000s, of course it's evolved to become more service oriented, i.e.,  going from number of hours to actually having clean environment and in 2005, Nordea actually wanted to get  some benefits of scale by consolidating this intra-regional contract and then Nordea became a key account of  multiservices where we took over more services and more geographical span, and gave the customer, the cost  benefits from that perspective.

texts.speaker: Jeff Olsen Gravenhorst
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But just to take a pause on that and say, what do we actually do? We've illustrated that with a range of services  that you can see on this, also a little bit busy slide. But at the low end of property maintenance, it's basic  maintenance like handyman work, changing fixtures, fittings, paint work, et cetera. At the higher end, it  incorporates maintenance of air-condition systems, UPS power supply, data rooms and ensuring 100% up time of  the client facilities. But at the more sophisticated end, it is the management of energy consumption, water usage,  emission, reducing cost for the client and helping them to achieve their [indiscernible] (33:50) commitments.

file: ISS - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 2March2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jeff Olsen Gravenhorst
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Thank you, Heine. Turning to slide 20, you can see some of the major developments for ISS in 2015, which  includes some of our largest integrated sewer services contract launches. These IFS contracts may result from  either expansion of existing relationship, by geography, for example, Vattenfall and UBS, or by service, for  example, Swisscom or Danish Danske Bank, other simply new contract with new customers such as Huashan  Hospital in China or Homerton in the UK.

texts.speaker: Jeff Olsen Gravenhorst
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Please turn to slide 24. Technology is becoming increasingly important tool in our service offering and a major  differentiator for ISS. And let me try to illustrate this over the next couple of slides. As a start-up, we have  developed an integrated IT platform we call FMS@ISS. This provides the end users with a single global portal.  Among other things, this allows them to make and track helpdesk requests. This could be booking meeting rooms  or request of technicians to adjust air conditions, requesting cleaning staff to clean up after slippage and so forth.

texts.speaker: Jeff Olsen Gravenhorst
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But in addition, we've also used FMS to lock the details of hundreds of thousands of customer assets. These assets  may include HVAC systems, lightings, elevators, escalators, fire alarm systems, power generators, et cetera. This  data and transparency then allows us to work proactively with our customers to optimize life -cycle planning and  scheduling of maintenance. This drives increased uptime, better compliance and lower cost.
