file: ITRKL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 3August2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As expected, we saw some margin erosion in our I&A division. The strong performance in Food, Agri and Business  Assurance was more than offset by the challenging trading conditions in oil and gas or infrastructure oil and gas  business. The I&A division delivered an operating profit of £25 million that was down 31% year-on-year,  essentially driven by the negative operating leverage linked to growth or declining revenue of 6.3%.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The resource business is, as you would expect, a more cyclical business and only represent today 10% of our profit.  From time-to-time, we have to cycle-through the phase where with low price on Resources, means that our  customers have to put their cash flow and reduce their CapEx investment. But based on our experience, we know  that investment and exploration and production of essential resource like oil and minerals will grow in the  medium to long-term to support the demand of a growing population on global basis. These are the reasons why I  believe that in a medium to long-term we'll benefit from a global GDP plus organic growth rate in the TIC  industry.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I would like to close this section of the growth drivers with a few comments on how we look at the current  challenging conditions in oil and gas. The recent oil price decrease has impacted the entire oil and gas industry as  we know so well. And let's look at what we've learned from the previous downturn. And the main insight, as you  can see on the slide, is that there is a lag between the oil price development and the oil and gas CapEx  development in the downturn.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In 2008, we saw three quarters between the peak and the trough of the oil price, and we saw exactly the same  pattern this time around with the oil price peaking in the second quarter of 2014 and troughing in first quarter of  2015. In the previous downturn, we saw five quarters between the peak and the trough of the CapEx activities in  our Moody business. That's why we believe we have not reached the trough in our CapEx activities, and we believe  that the second half will continue to be challenging in our oil and gas infrastructure business.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Let's now recap the outlook for the Group in 2015 and for the mid to long term. In 2015, we continue to expect  that the organic revenue growth rate will be better than 2014. This will come from continuing good growth in  Product and Trade-related divisions. As I've just said, we do expect the conditions in oil and gas infrastructure to  remain challenging for Industry Services in the second half.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Chemical testing is also growing very well. Our customers are concerned about the use of harmful chemicals in the  clothing manufacturing process and the impact these have on people and, obviously, the environment.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the EMC area for example, the Internet of Things industry is wanting our EMC teams to help them test and  develop new products to make sure that the connectivities between smartphones, automotive and home  appliances is developed properly to avoid unnecessary interferences between device. Our customers are also  looking at their global testing partners to support the new sourcing markets; and we've expanded our capability in  China and in India. Building orders are demanding high-quality and increased energy efficiency. Our  Environmental Certification Program is supporting the green building product sector which is growing well, as  you would expect.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Business Assurance was also strong and we're seeing good continuing demand for Assurance in quality  management, ISO 9001; data security is very important given the cyber threat, ISO 27001; environmental impact,  ISO 14001; and, of course, health and safety. Business Assurance delivered robust margin performance for us.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Industry Services, we continue to exit some of the low-value contracts and the impact of these in our revenue  was 5% for the division and 1.6% for the Group. Our oil and gas CapEx-driven revenue was 8% lower than last  year, due to the challenging conditions that we've talked about earlier in the presentation. Our OpEx business was  broadly stable. As you would expect, margin was a key focus for us in our Industry Services as we reduced our cost  to partially offset the impact of our lower revenues on margin. In H2, we expect the growth trends in Business  Assurance, Food & Agri to continue while Industry will remain challenging with negative growth. Cost discipline  with self-help initiative will remain an important priority for us.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving forward, we will continue to diversify our Industry Services in other industries such as chemical power  and renewable sectors. You might have seen recently that we have won a contract to provide corrosion monitoring  system and software for the construction of the new Queensferry Bridge in Scotland. Our BA business will  continue to leverage global client relationships, our clients who want to consolidate their global audit activities. In  Food & Agri, we'll focus our investments in growth market such as Asia, South and Central America.

file: ITRKL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 1August2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Resource business, which represent 21% of our revenues and 8% of our profit is, as we know, more cyclical.  And from time to time, we have to cycle through periods of low resource prices. During this period, our customers  will use their CapEx expenditure in order to protect their cash flow. Investments in exploration and production for  essential resources like oil, gas and minerals will grow in the medium term to long term to meet the demand of the  growing population around the world.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Transportation Technology delivered a double-digit organic growth across our main markets, being the U.S.,  UK, Germany and China. We continue to capitalize on our clients' investments in new powertrain as they strive to  adopt more stringent emissions and obviously look for fuel efficiencies.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We've delivered solid organic growth in Electrical & Wireless, driven by higher regulatory standards in energy  efficiency and by the increased demand for wireless devices. We continue to benefit from the increased focus of  corporations on food safety and delivered good organic growth in our Food business.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We saw solid organic growth in our Chemical & Pharma business as we continue to leverage the structural  growth opportunities in healthcare markets around the world. Our Building & Construction business delivered a  robust organic growth performance, driven by the growing demand for greener and high-quality buildings and the  growing infrastructure investments in the U.S. market.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We continued to invest in innovative solutions to drive organic growth performance and I'd just like to talk about  three innovations that really impressed me in the last six months. Our Building & Construction business has  implemented an innovative remote vibration monitoring system for our clients in New York City using specialist  sensory equipment, vibration levels caused by construction activities are recorded and documented throughout  the day.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Electrical & Wireless business has recently developed new services to help manufacturers of medical  electrical equipments assure that their products are environmentally conscious. 80% of the hospitals around the  world are expected to incorporate sustainability goals in their purchasing decisions according to a Harris Poll  made a few years ago.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In China, the Food Assurance Service businesses has launched a differentiated Food Traceability Programme.  Our total ATIC solution covers the producer's entire supply chain with the final products bearing our Intertek  trademark. For the full year, we expect our Product division to benefit from robust organic growth and from the  contribution of the acquisition made recently.

file: ITRKL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 1August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Investments in exploration and production for essential resources like oil and minerals will grow in the medium-to- long-term to meet the demand of the growing populations around the world. We also expect structural growth in  the renewables energy sector. The Resources sector today represent 18% of the Group revenue, and 6% of the  Group profit.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Let's just start with some of the most recent innovation in our Product divisions. Recently, Intertek partnered with  Nespresso to develop a unique assurance solution for their global capital recycling process. This gives Nespresso  confidence regarding the sustainability of their supply chains while customers are reassured that recycling efforts  of Nespresso are effective.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Given the importance of sustainability life cycle assessment for clients to determine the carbon footprint of their  products, process, and business operations, we have invested in a cloud-based assurance sustainability solution.  This innovative cloud solution allows our clients to benefit from the expertise of all our colleagues in terms of  sustainability through our global ATIC network.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Let's now discuss a few innovations in our Trade-related business. Horticultural lights are subject to complex  environmental conditions, such as high-temperature and high-humidity, and these are currently not covered by  any safety and performance standards specific to these products. Leveraging our lighting and agricultural  expertise, we have developed a Horticultural Lighting Certification Program to improve safety in this fast-growing  industry.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Mercury contamination increased the risk of corrosion for all infrastructure assets. Our Analytical Assessment &  Industry Services experts have developed an advanced technology to detect mercury particles up to the parts per  trillion level, either in oil and gas products or in the atmosphere. Our experts in Analytical Assessment &  Transportation Technologies have worked together with alternative fuel manufacturers and regulatory authorities  to develop new standards that provide clear safety solutions for alternative fuel components.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Let's now discuss industry-leading innovations in our Resources sector. Customers need assurance that critical  concrete infrastructures, such as road, rail tunnels, and bridge remain robust over their entire lives. Our experts  have developed sensor-based technology embedded into the concrete to allow customers to monitor the assets in  operation 24/7 with reliable data.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: We came to the conclusion that our clients need better insights to monitor the ageing of their equipment in  aerospace, oil and gas, power plants and automotive plants. We used 3D Metrology technology to detect any  deviation versus the original specs of the equipment in use to make sure that products do not deviate from the  intent design and performance.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our Building & Construction business delivered good organic revenue growth, driven by the growing demand for  greener, safer, and high-quality commercial building, increased investments in large infrastructure projects.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: In our Transportation Technologies, we delivered solid organic revenue growth, driven by continuing investment  of our clients in new models and new fuel-efficient engines, growth in the hybrid electrical engine segments and  increased scrutiny on emissions.

file: ITRKL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 7August2018 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Moving forward, our future growth outlook is global GDP+ organic revenue growth in real terms. We expect our  Products division that represent 76% of the group's earnings to grow ahead of global GDP. We expect our Trade  division that represent 18% of the group earnings to grow at a rate broadly similar to GDP through the cycle. And  the growth prospects of our Resources division, which represent 6% of the group's earnings, are linked to the  global growth drivers in the energy sector.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Another very strong area of growth is Sustainability and we've developed a comprehensive suite of services  across all areas of the supply chain of our customers, and our Sustainability approach is industry agnostic. We've  continued to expand our Inlight solutions that offers a trusted software-as-a-solution platform. Through this unique  platform, customers are able to gain greater visibility of their supply chain and build resilience in their global  operation to reduce risks.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: You might have noted that we've rebranded our Cargo/AA business Caleb Brett to strengthen our service  differentiation, leveraging more than 130 years of heritage in the industry where we have pioneered marine  surveillance. Another exciting example of innovations in the Trade business is what we've done with ExxonMobil  in Mexico, where we've created Mobile Laboratories to test fuel quality across their fast-growing network and  improved the capability and the skills of their staff. Another example of the Mobile solution is the unique Crop  Quality Toolkit that our experts have developed for small farmers in Sub-Saharan Africa making it easier for all of  our clients to get to the highest level of quality.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Another very interesting project is what we're doing with Greenlink to minimize the impact on the marine  environment. Our experts are providing vital support to the project ensuring regulatory compliance. In the Oil  Industry, we've developed the only database of near-infrared spectrum analysis of crude oil in the world. You  might remember that in 2017, we've launched PipeAware, an industry-leading software-as-a-solution that allows  pipeline asset owners to access real-time information on their asset inspections through the manufacturing  stages. Now, PipeAware 2 has extended its functionality and help customers track all aspects during the  construction phase too.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our Building & Construction business, largely focused in the U.S., had a very strong performance and we  delivered a robust organic revenue growth in the first six months of the year. We are seeing a growing demand for  greener and higher quality commercial buildings, and increased investments in large infrastructure projects in the  U.S.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our Transportation Technology delivered double-digit revenue growth, driven by the continuous investment of our  clients in new models and new fuel-efficient engines, and importantly, the increased scrutiny on emissions. We  generated robust organic revenue growth in our Food business. The Food business is a very exciting sector,  where we see continuous growth, driven by food innovations and increased focus on the safety of the supply  chain from both the regulator and consumers.

file: ITRKL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 2March2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Given the continuing challenging trading conditions in global oil and gas, we have taken, as you've se en this  morning, a £577 million non-cash impairment charge to reflect these uncertainties. Obviously, this charge has  impacted our reported profit but does not change the underlying performance of the group as you well know.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So we all have read about the shale oil revolution in the U.S., and obviously, from a strategic standpoint the U.S. is  totally independent. But what we probably don't fully appreciate is the fact that the infrastructure is really behind  all these drilling activities have been done by very small companies. And there's a lot of investments required to  make sure that the crude is transported in a safe and proper way.

texts.speaker: Edward Leigh
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: At 3.8%, Commodities saw a good rate of organic growth while the margin was up significantly by 220 basis  points, reflecting good operating leverage and the restructuring of the Cargo business. Industry & Assurance has,  as expected, experienced challenging conditions throughout 2015 in the oil and gas-related businesses of Industry  Services. And that is clearly reflected in the results reported here with organic revenue down by 5.8% and margin  down 260 basis points at constant rates.

texts.speaker: Edward Leigh
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Looking ahead, 2016 still faces many challenges and uncertainties with the oil price trend in the second half of  2015 and given the lag between the oil price and industry CapEx investments.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The resource sector, which represents 24% of the group revenues and 10% of group operating profit, is more   cyclical and from time to time we have to cycle through periods like now with low commodity prices. And during  this period, our customers, understandably so, reduce their CapEx investment to protect their cash flow.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Softlines business benefits from strong demand from our customers for chemical testing to reduce harmful  chemicals, but also from the expansion of their supply chains in new markets where we have opened new facilities  over the years. Our Hardlines business continues to take advantage of growth in new sourcing markets and also  growth with our existing accounts.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I just like to share with you a few innovations that I've seen when traveling around the business, which I felt were  quite important to share. We've launched in December a global Chemical Smart Screening service for textile,  apparel and footwear customers. This is a very important single screening test that can detect up to 400 harmful  chemicals and components before products reach the prototype stage. This is important for our customers  because it lowers the risk of extra production cost and reduces the turnaround times.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Next to our Commercial & Electrical business, which delivers strong organic growth of 6.1% with really good  margin improvement. Our Electrical & Wireless business continues to benefit from high regulatory standard in  energy efficiency as you would expect and from the increased demand for wireless devices.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The growing demand for greener and high-quality building infrastructure in the U.S. market is a major driver of  our growth in Building Products. And in Transportation Technology, we are capitalizing on our clients'  investments in R&D to develop new models and more truly efficient engines. Again, innovation is a very important  driver of growth in that sector.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: I'd just like to give you a couple of innovation in that division. In Hong Kong, Intertek is the world leader in [ph]  Qi (27 :43) wireless technology, which is basically technology that enables to charge wireless devices without a  cable. And we have been the first lab authorized worldwide for medium to low power true wireless charging  products. In Transportation Technology, [indiscernible] (28:00) in the UK, we are the first lab to offer what they  call portable emission measurement, which means we can test the emissions of our customers' car on the road  instead of laboratory.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Chemicals & Pharma division delivered also strong organic growth of 5.5% and with really good margin  improvement. We continue to benefit from good growth in the health and beauty sector as our customers invest,  as you would expect, in new product development to differentiate their brands. At the same time, the increased  demand in emerging market for health and beauty product is contributing to our global growth. Health,  environmental and regulatory assurance has seen some really strong growth in 2015 especially in the second half  as the companies are preparing for the next EU REACH chemical restriction regulation.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Minerals business delivered a resilient organic performance with a slight positive growth in the second half in  2015. Innovation and new services is also very important in that division. Just a couple of initiatives which I  believe are quite interesting. Our Cargo/AA business has been actively growing the business in Australia and we  support the first LNG Cargo bound for South Korea from the new Gladstone LNG export facility from Queensland,  so very good innovation, driving good business for us in Australia.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And also quite interesting, we are now the official fuel quality testing partner for FIM, the International  Motorcycling Federation. So, for events covering Superbike, Motocross, Supercross, Endurance including my  favorite, the 24 Hours of Le Mans, we are basically the fuel quality expert, believe or not, with our mobile testing  platform to provide quality testing on the track.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We continue to invest in growth in Industry & Assurance with the development of new services. For instance, we  have won a new contract in Turkey to basically support the construction of the TANAP pipeline that will connect  Azerbaijan to Europe via Turkey. And within our asset integrity management activity, we are providing corrosion  monitoring equipment and software that will be used to safeguard and protect the new Queensferry Crossing  opening this year in Scotland.

file: ITRKL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 7March2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: We have made three additional acquisitions in 2016. We've invested around £35 million. In January last year, you  would remember, we have acquired a very good business in Italy, FIT, a leading food assurance service provider  in Italy, a very important market for us. In October, we've completed the acquisition of EWA-Canada, a  leading  cyber security assurance business in North America with obviously customers also around the world. And in  November, very excited about that project. We've announced a partnership with ABC Analitic, and we now run the  market-leading environmental testing provider in Mexico, a tremendous business.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: In the medium to long term, we believe that the industry will benefit from GDP plus organic growth rates in real  terms. We expect our Products business to grow ahead of GDP, and we're already seeing that. Our Products  sector represent 57% of the group revenue and 73% overall profit. Our Product business will continue to benefit  from brand and SKU proliferation, increased regulations, as well as improvement in safety, performance, quality  and, let's not forget, the important role of sustainability these days.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Investments in Exploration and Production for essential resource like soil and minerals will grow in the medium to  long term to meet the demand of a growing population around the world. That's the megatrend in the energy  sector. As you know, Resources represent 20% of our revenue and 7% of our profit.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Another interesting innovation, in Africa, we've launched an innovative Soil Manager app, which enables farmers,  from all of Africa in remote location, to get access to a range of digital service. And this is the beauty of  technology today. With 3G and 4G networks, anyone can get access to online services. And now farmers can  now online in Africa, submit sample informations, track the progress of their testing, receive timely results, and, of  course, pay online. What a world we live in.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: So, a few examples of recent wins in transportation technology. We had a really successful ATIC presentation  with one of the global car manufacturers. And basically, they gave us additional opportunities beyond the test we  already do today in fuel consumption or engine performance. And they asked us to look at pre-production supplier  qualifications. So, that's a real issue in many industries, especially the automotive industry. When you launch new  models, you have to bring new parts and qualifying your new suppliers for new part is typically a root cause for  quality issue. So, they wanted to get some assurance on that.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: They've also asked us to look at their entire supply chain risk management. They are very interested with the  approach we take to end-to-end risk management, to take a risk-based approach to testing and inspections. And  obviously, this is very important these days in the automotive industry. They've asked us to start doing some  portable vehicle emission testing because, as you know, manufacturers now need to go and measure the  emissions and fuel consumptions on the road.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Let's change industry. A global toy retailer provide additional sales opportunity recently with the auditing of their  entire supply chain as well as with regulatory product evaluation to make sure they are up-to-date with new and  relevant regulatory standards. And this is a key examples of what's happening in the toy industry where toys  these days have a lot of technology. And in terms of regulatory, it's very, very complex. Each time you change  technology and you put more chemicals or you put a wireless technology, the entire regulatory environment  change overnight. And this is a huge need for our companies and they typically don't have the in-house expertise.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: A different industry, in the Cargo/AA, a global petroleum manufacturer, a very big company, just signed a  multiyear agreement to outsource their in-house quality assurance lab activities. Going back to the point,  independent expertise in-house is valuable to our customers.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our Transportation Technology delivered a strong organic growth  performance across our main markets: U.S.,  UK, Germany and China. We expect TT to continue to perform strongly this year. We are seeing continuous  investment of our clients in new models and fuel-efficient engines. The growth in electrical and hybrid technology  is obvious to everyone. And, as we all know so well, there is increased scrutiny from the regulator and consumers  and the press on emissions claims, which is a huge opportunity for us.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our Building & Construction business delivered a robust organic performance. And the integration of both PSI and  MT in the U.S. is doing very well. In 2017, we expect that trend to continue, while other trends here we are seeing  a growing demand for greener and higher quality commercial buildings. And as we know, there is an expectations  that the large investment in infrastructure in the U.S. will continue.

file: ITRKL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 6March2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: The growth prospects in our Resources divisions which represents 6% of the earnings are linked, as you know, to  the global growth drivers in the energy sector. It is our view that investments in exploration and production for  essential resources like oil and minerals will grow in the medium to long term to, of course, meet the demand of  the growing population. We also expect structural growth in the renewable sector.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: In our GTS business, for instance, our workflow, Astra ERP, gives our clients real-time intelligence on how their  certificates are progressing through this customer journey. Technology provides a central role to deliver superior  customer service. For instance, one of our latest innovation is InterPret, an algorithm that use big data analytics to  predict hydrocarbon composition providing our clients with real-time information. As you would expect, we make  investments in our labs with cutting-edge technology. For instance, in our Food business, we've recently invested  in a new equipment that detects the DNA of fish samples, believe it or not, to make sure that our retail customers  know that the fishes that you're going to buy at Tesco or Sainsbury are on spec.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: In terms of enabling our performance management approach, we have put in place, as you would expect, digital  tools to make it seamless and easy for employees. We operate several financial service centers which today is a  given in any global enterprise, and we continue to invest. We've just recently invested in a cloud-based tool to  track our carbon emission site by site around the world and to get real-time visibility where the operations are. So  I just touched base on a few of these innovations. In the appendix of the presentations, there is a bit more detail  on each of them and we are very happy to discuss these if you're interested.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our Business Assurance business delivered double-digit organic growth in the three regions of North America,  Europe and Asia, and we expect that to continue. We'll continue to benefit from the ISO standards upgrade,  increased focus of corporations on supply chain and risk management, and increased consumer and government  focus on ethical and sustainable supply. Our building and construction business delivered good organic revenue  growth, and we expect that to continue driven by the growth for greener and higher quality commercial buildings  in the U.S. as well as increased investments that we are seeing in large infrastructures.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: In our Transportation Technology business, we've delivered stable organic growth. And moving forward, we  expect the growth to improve to good. We are seeing continuous investment from our clients in new models, new  fuel-efficient engines. Obviously, you are seeing a news like we all see where cities are going to ban diesel, which  means more R&D investments will go in traditional combustion engine, but hybrid and electrical engines. And this  is definitely the growth areas in the industry at the moment. And in addition to that, you see an increased scrutiny  on emissions, that's why we bought KJ Tech last year.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Fuel tank inspections can be costly and risky for our customers. So, to make inspection more efficient and  certainly safer, we've partnered with a developer, a fuel tank inspection company, that produces robot to make it  obviously easier for our customers.

file: ITRKL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 5March2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Following the launch of PipeAware, a SaaS platform that allows pipeline asset owners to access real-time data  throughout the stage of manufacturing, we have extended reach of the solution with PipeAware 2 to help  customers track and monitor all aspects during construction phase too. To help our clients better leverage their  clients' feedback, we've launched Voice of the Consumer. This is a service that use big data analytics to quickly  identify the quality issues that our clients are seeing in their supply chain and develop good product quality  improvements.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Turning to innovation in high-growth and high-margins areas, our Working Condition Assessments audits are a  unique solution to support the clients with their CSR objectives. Our hardline and softline chemical testing offers  safety in rapidly developing regulatory environment. Intertek KJ Tech offers valuable road testing services so  important for OEMs. We have strengthened our cyber security offering with Acumen EWA and NTA. And given  the growing focus of customers on environmental and social impact, we have developed a comprehensive suite of  sustainable services.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Our business assurance business delivered a strong organic growth. And moving forward, we expect robust  organic growth driven by the increased focus of corporation on supply chain and increased consumer and  government focus on ethical and sustainable supply. Our building and construction business delivered robust  organic growth. And in 2019, we expect good organic growth driven by the growing demand for greener and high  quality commercial building and sustained investment in large infrastructure projects.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: In our transportation technology business, we've delivered double-digit organic growth and we expect robust  organic growth this year driven by continued investment of our clients in new models and new fuel efficient  engines, growth in the hybrid/electrical engine segments, and increased scrutiny on emissions. We generated a  robust organic growth in our food business and we expect robust organic growth in 2019 driven by continuous  food innovation, increased focus on the safety of supply chains and growth in the food service assurance  business.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: Moving forward, we expect solid organic growth driven by the gradual increased investment of oil and gas  companies in exploration and production. The demand for OpEx maintenance services remained stable in a  competitive environment and we expect the same trend in 2019. In 2018, we've seen robust organic growth for  testing activities in the mineral business, and we expect good organic growth in 2019. Overall, we expect to  deliver a solid organic revenue growth at constant currency in our Resources division, which contributed 6% of  our profit in 2018.

texts.speaker: André Lacroix
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Intertek Group Plc
texts.text: The structural growth drivers in the global quality assurance market are attractive. And at the group level, we  expect to deliver GDP-plus organic revenue growth in the real term that is margin accretive and strongly cash  generative. We expect our Products division, which represented 77% of the group's earnings in 2018, to grow  ahead of global GDP. We expect our Trade division that represented 17% of the group's earnings in 2018 to grow  at a rate broadly similar to GDP through the cycle. The growth prospect of our Resources division, which  represented 6% of the group's earnings in 2018, are improving with the increased investment in oil and gas  exploration and production activities as well as the development of renewable energies.

Product placement obviously takes time  because it's all about embedding it in the programs themselves, so obviously they follow the same lead time as the  programs. And I think probably importantly just to let you know we have created a new [ph] relevant (15:18) video  stream for SDN to market, which will bring in extra revenue as well.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: There has been a process of continuous improvement in cost efficiency, as we change the way we work and we  looked to cut out a lot of waste and a lot of complexity. We did more than deliver our targeted £15 million of  savings during the course of the year. In fact, we delivered £20 million of savings.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The Champions League draw wasn't as great as it might have been in terms of the excitement of the games,  Coronation Street was versus its 50th anniversary the previous year; and X Factor was reasonably well done and I  can't believe I'm even going to say this, but the snow, believe it or not played a part. Not leaves on the track, but  snow, because snow tends to drive people indoors, they watch a lot more television when the weather is bad and  particularly a lot more regional news to catch up on what's happening on their area, something that impacts not  just on us, but on other broadcasters. But by and large, a slightly disappointing end, but something that we're  working to address to make sure we get that right next year.

ITVL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 26February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-14.pdf

ITVL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 2March2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Adam A. Crozier
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: I'm often also asked in a number of meetings with many of you about the read-across from the U.S. to the UK and  other European markets. First of all, I think it's important to say that, structurally, they are very, very different  markets indeed. Clearly, the – free to air is incredibly strong in the UK and Europe compared to the U.S. 50%  penetration here, roughly, versus 84% in the U.S. It's also a very expensive market in the U.S., about two times to  three times more expensive. And that is partly what is driving cord cutting and cord shortening, as people realize  they're paying a lot of money for channels they're not necessarily using or watching.

file: ITVL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 1March2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Adam A. Crozier
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Executive Director, ITV Plc
texts.text: Finally in this area, we're making extremely good progress on the proposed repeal of Section 73 through the  Digital Economy Bill. Government have recently confirmed that the current draft over the bill does recommend the  repeal of Section 73 and has also said there is no requirement for a transition period. Ministers have also made it  clear that within the current regulatory framework, it should be left to the market to decide the levels of  compensation. And it's currently expected that this bill will go through before the summer recess this year.

We continue developing new initiatives in a fully integrated way as  Zara's recent animal print collection, 70's show collection, the dress time collection, the traveler collection and the  sustainable collection, Join Life, now available in all our concepts.

texts.speaker: Pablo Isla Álvarez de Tejera
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Industria de Diseño Textil SA
texts.text: In 2017, Inditex had a strong operating performance. We have had very satisfactory organic growth earmarked by  external factors, a strong volatility in key currencies and unusually warm temperatures in the autumn. In this  context, we have achieved a strong like-for-like sales and double-digit growth in local currencies, in sales, gross  profit and EBIT. We finished 2017 with operations on five continents through eight concepts, 7,475 stores and  online sales. We continue to see significant growth opportunities for Inditex globally.

file: ITX - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 13March2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Pablo Isla Álvarez de Tejera
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Industria de Diseño Textil SA
texts.text: I would like to start this presentation with two important points. In 2018, Inditex has continued developing the long- term and strategic initiatives that have made our business model increasingly differentiated and at the forefront of  fashion and sustainability. We are totally focused on providing our customers with a unique experience through  the execution of our global, fully integrated store and online model. We remain committed to expanding our  business with a strong focus on quality and our long-term principles.

texts.speaker: Pablo Isla Álvarez de Tejera
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Industria de Diseño Textil SA
texts.text: We continue developing new initiatives in a fully integrated way, as seen in Zara's 19 Campaign, the Collection  01, the Shades of Beige collection, the Kids Campaign, and the sustainable collection Join Life now available in  all our concepts.

texts.speaker: Pablo Isla Álvarez de Tejera
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Industria de Diseño Textil SA
texts.text: Sustainability is a key part of our strategy. This principle is embedded in all different activities of our business and  growth plans. For the third year in a row, the Dow Jones Sustainability Index has singled out Inditex as the retailer  with the best practices along the environmental, social, and economic dimensions. Inditex has been a member of  the Dow Jones Sustainability Index since 2001, consistently being placed at the top end of the retailing category.

file: JMATL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 24November2010 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Nov-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: The long-term legislative, environment and energy security drivers of our business remain very  much in place. And these together with our investment in R&D and global market presence have  positioned us well for the future.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Nonetheless, underlying profit for the first six months of this year was still a record for the Group,  and it has to be said, ahead of our expectations. Our activity picked up across the Group, and with  higher precious metal prices, revenue increased by 28% to £4.6 billion. The more important  measure that we track is sales excluding precious metals, and this too was well ahead of last year,  up 25% at £1.1 billion. The principle driver of this growth was Environmental Technologies division,  which grew sales by 29% to £724 million. But Neil will go through the performance of each of the  segments in a minute.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Looking first at Environmental Technologies, we have, as you know, not stopped any of our major  investments in new plants. These are now operational and performing well, albeit neither of them is  fully utilized. This will serve us well in the future and allow us to meet likely demand in Europe and  North America for some time to come.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Also, our fixed production costs at our PGM refineries are down around £2 million per annum. Fine  Chemicals has been remarkably successful in the U.S. in increasing the capacity of its current  plant. The division has increased production by around 50%, which corresponds to a reduction in  cost per ton of nearly 20%, an annual saving of around $5 million.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Neil Carson, Chief Executive  Thank you, Robert. I’ll now take a look at each of the divisions starting with Environmental  Technologies division. The division had a strong first half building on the recovery seen in the  second half of last year. Sales excluding precious metals were 29% ahead, and underlying  operating profits was 41% higher than in the same period in 2009/10.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: ECT’s sales were up 29% with good volume growth around the world in both our light duty and  HDD catalyst businesses. Process Technology sales grew by 25% with strong sales of its methanol  catalysts and improving demand for catalysts to generate hydrogen for all refineries. Davy Process  Technology had another strong half. The division’s return on sales improved in the period by 0.9%  to 10.6%, due in part to lower DPF substrate prices, but mainly as a result of the overall  improvement in the division’s performance.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Sales in Europe grew by 12% to £256 million and represented 61% of our light-duty catalyst sales.  This growth was partly due to increased fitment of diesel particulate filters as the manufacturers  geared up for Euro 5 light-duty legislation that comes into force on the 1st of January next year.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: 4 We’ve also benefited from a recovery in diesel’s share of the European market, which increased to  52% in the first half, compared to 44% in the same period last year when government incentives  favored small gasoline powered vehicles.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: We estimate that around 90% of diesel cars produced in Europe in our first half were fitted with  filters, and this will rise to 100% from the 1st of January with the implementation of the Euro 5  legislation.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: 5 Our HDD business had a good first half with unit sales almost double those in the first half of last  year. This was aided by the much tougher U.S. 2010 HDD legislation that came into force on the  1st of January this year and requires more catalysts per vehicle. This resulted – results in over 50%  more added value per vehicle for JM. Sales in the first half were up 72% on the same period last  year with North America counting for £83 million and Europe for £41 million.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: As you saw a little earlier, the recent growth in the U.S. and Western European truck markets has  fed through to our sales. Given the high cost of substrates and other raw materials in a large HDD  catalyst, about 75% of our HDD business’s costs are buriable. Our new HDD catalyst  manufacturing plants in Smithfield, USA, is now ramping up production, and its capacity utilization  is currently at around 40%.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Looking forward, with tight remission standards in existing markets, the addition of legislation in  emerging markets and the introduction of non-road legislation in North America and Europe, we still  expect the market for HDD catalysts to grow to about US$2.5 billion by the end of our 2014/15  financial year.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: 6 Moving now to Process Technologies. Process Technologies’ sales were up 25% to £153 million.  Our ammonia, methanol, oil and gas business, which, as you can see, represented about 56% of  sales, had a good first half with sales up 28% on the same period last year.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: The business benefited from strong demand for methanol catalysts, sales of which were more than  double those in the first half of 2009/10. A large portion of these sales were to customers in China  where a number of new methanol plants using technology licensed by DPT are coming on stream.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Sales of our ammonia and hydrogen catalysts were also ahead, driven by continued expansion of  ammonia production for the fertilizer industry, and a recovery in demand for hydrogen from oil  refineries.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: APICO, as you may recall, is our new industry leading methanol synthesis catalyst. The first half  saw the first commercial sales of APICO, one of which was to a world-scale methanol plant in the  Middle East.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Davy Process Technology continued to perform strongly in the first half with its sales benefiting  from good licensing and engineering income. The business is commissioning nine new plants in  2010/11, many of which are in China, and has successfully commissioned the world’s largest  methanol plant located in Baotou City in Inner Mongolia in China.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: During the first half, DPT agreed a further three new licenses, a substitute natural gas plant and a  specialty chemicals plant both in China, and a natural detergent alcohols plant in Indonesia.  Continued investments in R&D at Davy to develop new technologies for licensing is key to the long- term success of this world leading business.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: In early October, we announced that we’d agreed to acquire Intercat, and the deal completed on  the 1st of November. Based in Savannah, Georgia, Intercat is a leader in Fluid Catalytic Cracking,  or FCC, additives and addition systems. These are extensively used in oil refineries to optimize  yields and minimize emissions from the FCC process. In 2009, Intercat achieved sales of $58  million and a normalized operating profit of $8.4 million.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: This acquisition strengthens our position in refinery catalysts, a rapidly growing segment of the  global catalyst market, where we currently supply hydrogen catalysts and specialist absorbents  used to remove impurities from crude oil and gas. Growth in refinery catalyst is driven by demand  for transportation fuels and the industry’s need to process increasingly dirty feedstocks.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: PMPD’s manufacturing businesses all performed well benefiting from the continued recovery in  industrial demand for their products. All businesses saw good growth in both sales and operating  profit in the period. Noble Metals’ sales were up 20% with particularly good growth in demand from  the agrochemical and industrial sectors where our products are used, for example, as catalysts for  nitric acid manufacturing and nitrous oxide abatement.

texts.speaker: Neil Carson, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to our presentation of Johnson Matthey’s
texts.text: Overall, Environmental Technologies’ performance in the second half of this year is currently  expected to be ahead of the same period last year and broadly inline with the first half of this year.

file: JMATL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 23November2011 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Moving quickly on to cash flow, stronger cash flow in the first half of this year compared to last year, primarily due  to the impact of precious metal prices which I'll talk about in a second. But you can see that our working capital  days, excluding precious metal, have gone up from the year-end 60 days to 69 days. That increase is primarily  because of increase in rare earth inventories caused by higher volume within rare earths, but also, obviously, the  higher prices that we talked about before, and also from growth in our customers in China where there is slightly  longer payment terms. And we're working on that to reduce the payment terms slightly in China. And we would  hope that come the year-end, we'll be back within our 60 days to 65 days working capital target, excluding  precious metals.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And with that, I'll hand back to Neil.  Neil A. P. Carson  Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc  Thank you, Robert. And now the operating review starting with Environmental Technologies Division. Here are  the numbers for the whole division. You can see sales excluding precious metals, up 22%; underlying operating  profit, up 19%. And the pie chart there gives you the division of the sales. You can see that ECT made up about  three-quarters of the sales in this period, PT 22%.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: SEC is unfortunately continuing to underperform. And as you all remember, we set up to access the NOx control  market in China. This is a plate catalyst facility for the supplier to coal-fired power stations. Unfortunately, the  market hasn't developed as we hoped. We've got more competition and the legislation isn't being applied as  rigorously as we thought it would be. So we've restructured that organization.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: A couple of words also about fuel cells which also isn't going quite as well as we would have liked. Sales down at a  couple of the major customers and it's not really expected to improve in the second half. We have added to the  cost side in fuel cells. We have put some more R&D in, particularly targeted at the upcoming market for fuel cells  in cars in sort of 2015 to 2020. So we still believe in the long-term potential of fuel cells.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Europe, sales up 13%, so ahead of the market. And that was mainly down to the fact that diesel, which we  always talk about having a share of the total market, that share moved from 49% up to 55%. So that was beneficial  to us. As you know, diesel cars are worth about five times the sales of petrol cars for us.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Looking ahead in Europe, we've got some more legislation coming up, Euro 6 light-duty legislation is coming up  effective in September 2014. That will drive more catalyst fitment to particularly diesel cars. SCR and NOx  adsorber catalysts, which also add 15% to 20% to the value per vehicle of cars sold in Europe, diesel cars.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: If I can move on now to Process Technologies, it had a very good half, sales up 26%. And that would have been  17% if you strip out Intercat. So on the catalyst side, we benefited from the Intercat acquisition. Sales up 38% to  £120 million. You can see the breakdown of the sales on that pie chart. We thought that methanol demand –  methanol catalyst demand will be down a bit. This is due to the cycle of replacements in plants around the world  and it has been down, but hydrogen catalysts have been growing quite strongly.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And Cat and Chem, up 13%. Good sales growth. New products coming in, e+. This is the material that we stick on  labels and it removes ethylene from ripening fruits. That's being – doing pretty well in customer trials and we'll  start to see some decent sales from that in the upcoming years. And we've made some first sales from our brand- new catalyst plant – pgm catalyst plant in Shanghai.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So looking ahead in PMPD, services for the short-term outlook for precious metal prices remains a little uncertain.  And I think the investors in Platinum Group Metals are causing a little bit of volatility at the moment. But the  fundamentals, we remain robust. Many of you might have been to our Platinum book presentation earlier this  month. And refining intakes are holding up quite well.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So by division, Environment Technologies, yes, some uncertainty, but the pundits are still predicting growth in  our markets and we will do well in that situation. DPT has been exceptional and will continue good this year, so  we do expect ET to be well ahead of the first half and the second half.

file: JMATL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 21November2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Having delivered a strong performance last year, we've experienced a more difficult environment in some of our  markets in the first half of this financial year. However, we have maintained earnings per share in this difficult  market. And a couple of our divisions, Environmental Technologies and Fine Chemicals have done well and they  have grown their profits. This, of course, has been offset by a decline in profits from PMPD with lower precious  metal prices impacting. On balance, we expect more of the same in the second half.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Neil, and good morning, everybody. I'll just quickly go through a few slides on the performance and start  with the underlying results. You can see that in the half year compared to last year, sales were up 1% but operating  profit down 6%, but that was made up of growth, as Neil just said, growth in Environmental Technologies, up 17%,  Fine Chemicals up 14%, but then significant reduction in the Precious Metal Products Division, down 33%.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Return on invested capital still very important to us. As you know, we have a – we've been trying for some time to  get over 20%, which we achieved last year. It dropped a little bit this year in the first half, substantially due to the  reduction in precious metal prices, which impacted Precious Metal Products Division's return on capital. But we  did manage to increase the return on capital in both Environmental Technologies and Fine Chemicals. And as  we've said before, our intention is to try and keep the return on capital above the 20% target we had before.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Looking at capital expenditure, in the first half, we spent just under £60 million. I still expect the capital  expenditure for the full year to be roundabout £200 million. Key projects in the first half are the extension of the  Macedonian facility and the expansion of our UK diesel filter capacity, and both of those projects are really ahead  of Euro 6 legislation both for cars and trucks that Neil will talk a little bit more about, which comes into force in  the next few years. And as I say we'll talk more about that later.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Robert. And now the operating review, and starting as always with Environmental Technologies  Division. Here are the numbers, the key numbers for the division. So, you can see a small growth in sales of 3%, a  good growth in operating profit of 17% and, of course, an improvement in the return on sales for the division.  That's welcome.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We got some growth in process technologies. I'll tell you more about that. Fuel cells and net expense increased just  slightly. And we made an acquisition here. A bit excited about that. More detail a bit later and some even more  detail when we hopefully meet you in January. This is in the battery space. So, a slide on that a little bit later.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Europe, production was down 10%, our sales down 9%, but 7% down on a constant currency basis. So we  slightly outperformed the market there. And one key aspect, the reasons that these bars are bigger than the other  bars in Asia and North America is, of course, diesel cars. Diesel cars have shrunk a little bit as a percentage of the  market, just 1% down to 55% of sales.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Key dates for us, we'll mention them more, of course, Euro 6 for new model diesel cars. That starts to hit in  September 2014, and for all production of cars from September 2015. So, that's worth noting.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In the USA, well, the right revised numbers are pretty close to the previous numbers, and it's good to see that the  key drivers like freight miles, et cetera, are all positive and everybody expects at this point the 2013 and 2014 will  see pretty good growth in that market. Some lack of clarity, I guess, about the rest of this year in 2012 in that there  doesn't seem to be much of a trend in where the sales are going.  Let's move to Process Technologies. Sales up to £196 million, up 1%, and basically divided into the catalyst  businesses and the Davy Process Technology business. So there's the pie chart at the bottom there, £196 million of  sales. And the AMOG businesses, sales were down a little at £114 million, pretty good demand from the ammonia  catalyst. Of course, AMOG stands for ammonia, methanol, oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Purification products did well as did additives, but we had slower sales of hydrogen. The hydrogen mainly gets fed  into refineries, and there was a slowdown in the number of plants being built and the change out of hydrogen  catalysts which gave us a kind of slow performance in the period.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: But also a key milestone for us, we had a successful start-up of a major SNG, synthetic natural gas plant in China,  Datang Energy in Mongolia. We've got another six plants to get started up, so that was a good indicator for us  going forward.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, if I could just summarize, looking ahead for Environmental Technologies Division, just for the rest of this year,  if you like, we've obviously seen a weakening in the outlook for light duty catalysts in Europe, but we do see  further growth in the second half in Asia. Heavy duty diesel catalysts, while the long-term drivers are fine, but the  rest of this year, visibility is a little challenging; and that's probably mainly heavy duty diesel in the US market.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In process technologies, I don't think we'll see much of a change in the hydrogen catalyst market for the rest of  this year, so it will remain a little weak, but that will be more than offset by some good growth in other catalysts  and indeed in DPT. Again, some extra capital expenditure going in here in India and the UK and also in our  additives business in Savannah, because we've got customer demand for more products.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So longer term in this division, outside the rest of this year, if you like, the structural growth drivers for Euro 6  legislation are still there, and they'll start to impact next year in the heavy duty diesel area in Europe and then  they'll start to impact cars in future years. The off-road market is legislated to keep growing. And one day, there  will be HDD in Asia too. And we still see good growth in process technologies.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: The manufacturing businesses are slightly off, though we had a record performance last year. I'll give you more  detail on those, but generally pretty good performance, I think, in the environment for the manufacturing  businesses. And there, in the pie chart, you can see the split of services and manufacturing.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And despite some improvement in the prices over – from the lows of the summer, we've yet to see a substantial  improvement in the refining volumes. And longer term, of course, with trouble in South Africa and demand  becoming boosted by more legislation and the return to better sales of things like diesel cars, we can't imagine that  the price of platinum will stay where it is. I ought – there ought to be upside in that, of course. In manufacturing  areas, we're trading pretty much in line with last year.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So to give you some summary, if you like, of the outlook for this year, the rest of this year. So the outlook for light  duty catalysts in Europe has weakened, but there is still growth prospects in Asia. We've got some limited visibility  in the US in the short term on HDD market, but we expect that to grow in previous – in future years. And for  Process Technologies, more of the same really. So some continued weakness in hydrogen and that will be offset by  growth elsewhere.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Precious Metal Products, a slight increase in the precious metal prices, but we have yet to see any real feed  through to our refining volumes in the services business. And manufacturing businesses are expected to trade in  line with last year.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And as I've said, longer term, all the drivers are still in place for better – for growth in our business in heavy duty  diesel and in cars, And we're also confident of more growth in PT, in Process Technologies. And longer term in  Precious Metals, we have to expect one day the PGM prices to rise.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We're naturally disappointed that our results are down on last year, but in the circumstances, we feel that we've  done pretty well. And the weakness, if you like, is mostly concentrated in the PGM area. EPS has been maintained  in a difficult market. We've had a good performance in the conditions from Environmental Technologies and Fine  Chem, but we can't escape the lower – the effect of the lower precious metal prices, similar performance expected  in the second half.

file: JMATL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 21November2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Robert. So, the operating review and starting as always with Emission Control Technologies. Here are  the key numbers for you. Y ou can see sales excluding precious metals up 13%, profits up 16%, an increase in  return on sales and also return on invested capital already mentioned by Robert. So, a very strong half, first half  for ECT. So all regions grew their sales and the European heavy-duty diesel pre-buy very much benefited us and  more detail about that a bit later. You can see the split of sales on the graph between light duty and heavy duty.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So that's the data. And this is our sales of light duty catalysts. Y ou can see in North America, we slightly  underperformed the market in terms of sales growth, but we matched it in terms of volumes. This is the effect of  rare earth materials that are now a flow-through for us. So, volumes grew in line with the market, but sales fell  slightly short.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Let's move on to heavy duty diesel trucks. So here's the data. First half; first half as you can see, pretty dull picture.  Here are the sequential data where there's a bit more ac tivity in North America and sales are up in Europe, as you  can see there.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So let's look at the Chemicals business. This includes the Davy business and the catalyst businesses, those who  make things like methanol and ammonia. So there is the data. And you can see – and we have said previously that  we thought the Davy business was running a bit ahead of its run rate in terms of the number of contracts that were  getting signed. This has been a quiet period. We don't believe we've lost any market share. It's merely a feature of  a fact that particularly in China, there have been – there's been a bit of a slowdown in the signing of contracts. And  indeed, since the end of the first half we've signed a few small one s. So we expect to do better than that in the  second half.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And a really good performance from the catalyst business. Sales up 34%, and that will be 10% excluding Formox,  already mentioned Formox going well. The highlights was the methanol demand, which is up aggressively having  had a slightly quiet year last year, but ammonia also did pretty well.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Moving to Oil and Gas and our catalyst and additives business continues to grow. Good demand for that. We're  building the new plant that Robert mentioned, that's nearing completion. We also made a lot more progress in our  purification area this year, recovering from what wasn't such a good year last. And also, steady demand for  hydrogen catalyst. Y ou can see the breakdown there. And Tracerco, which services the o il and gas industry  continues to do quite well.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So looking at the Services businesses, and here prices are important to our volumes in Refining and important  also to our Marketing business. So not much activity with the pgm and gold price. Gold down a bit actually. And in  the Refining businesses, our sales were down. We had slightly higher intakes in pgms, but slightly lower in gold  and that's a note to mention that the management action has corrected the operational iss ues flagged last year.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And finally, on New Businesses. So you can see from this pie chart that the bulk of the sales are in Battery  Technologies, and those sales have been going pretty well. Lots of growth in sales for batte ries for E-bikes and for  powertools. Batteries will make a small – made a small operating loss in the first half but will also make a small  operating profit in the second half from those sales. And we remain on course, I think, to develop our battery  business into a materials business in the next period, the next few years.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
