texts.text: Fuel Cells, we continue to put R&D money into our Fuel Cells business and are pleased just to notice that we're  doing well with car companies in terms of trying to be their key supplier of membrane electrode assemblies, and in  the news today is news of the launch of fuel cell cars out in California, which is we think the first place where  legislation will actually drive the production of some fuel cell cars towards the middle of this dec ade.

file: JMATL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 20November2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Good morning, everybody. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Johnson Matthey's Interim Results  Presentation. A couple of bits of administration, first of all. Firstly, as far as I'm aware, there's no planning to be  any fire alarm. So if there is a fire alarm or something like that, the exits are just behind us on either side of the  auditorium.

texts.speaker: Den Jones
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Director
texts.text: In PT, we continue to invest in projects to expand our chemical catalyst manufacturing capacity in both Germany  and China. The work in our site in Germany is nearly complete, while in China, the board has approved  construction of an SNG catalyst plant there; and preliminary engineering work is now underway.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And also there's increased plant utilization across the world, too, marginal increase in plant utilization, but there's  a lot of things that we've been doing that made this difference. But the good news is, it's sustainable. We think  that, that will be sustainable into the second half of this year, and beyond.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Going into it in more detail, on the light duty side, our sales are up by 1 0% in the period, and that compares to  global light duty vehicle production of 3%, so somewhere ahead. In Europe – sorry, in North America, our sales  have grown roughly in line with the market. But in Europe, we're well ahead, and that's mainly driven by t his Euro  6b change, as we start to see more cars moving to Euro 6b. This is diesel legislation. And remember, that adds  about 20% more value per diesel car.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And as I've already mentioned, clearly, the margins have improved through all these efficiency improvements that  we've been working on across the Group. On the heavy duty diesel side, again, good growth. This time 23% up on  sales; and this time, we've got growth in all regions.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In North America, driven a lot by the growth in heavy duty diesel trucks, and this is a big – the big Class 8 trucks.  The fleet has been getting older, and we're now on a replacement cycle, and that growth has started to come  through of the larger trucks compared to just the smaller trucks.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to Process Technologies. Overall, our Process Technology business is performing broadly in line with  our  long-term expectations. Our good performance in the first half from our oil and gas business offset by little bit of  weakness in chemicals, and we'll talk about that a bit more in a second.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the licensing side, whilst income has been reasonable in the first half because we've been finishing off the  plants that we've been previously awarded on the SNG side, we have in China signed no new licenses in this first  half.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: This is a brief hiatus. If you heard just last week, I think it was President Obama and the Prime Minister of China  agreeing about air quality. We still believe SNG is a growth market in China. There's a little bit of a hiatus for these  new licenses over the next few months or so.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the oil and gas side, business has been much better. Sales are up by 15%, boosted by, in this case, we've got  good timing helping us. We've said before, that the hydrogen, there weren't very many new hydrogen plants, well  then, they've now started to come through, and our additives market has also been good.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Diagnostic Services, otherwise known as our Tracerco business, continues to do well supporte d by the growth in  unconventional oil and gas opportunities, particularly in North America.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But one consequence of the loss of the Anglo contract is our sensitivity to PGM prices and metal prices are much,  much lower than they ever were before. So it's become much less of an issue for us in the future.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the manufacturing side, sales were up by 12%. In noble metals 25%, partly helped by the transferring of this  small business from ECT that we talked about at year-end, but also improvement in demand for nitric acid  catalysts and relatively steady demand in our medical device business.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So the last division is our New Businesses division, where we continue to make progress, particularly in our  battery technologies area, where you've seen the two acquisitions we've done or are doing. Today, the business is  really around supplying battery materials – sorry systems for power tools and e-bikes, which continues to do well.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We have continued to increase our R&D investment, which has turned this business to a small operating loss. For  the two acquisitions that we've done, we really believe were complementary, and will give us a good base to grow  our battery materials business into the future. You'll hear more about our battery materials strategy at the  Investor Day, as Den mentioned back in January next year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our fuel cell business has been impacted by one of our key customers going into administration; which they did I  think at the end of last year, and – but the good news is that, they've come out, well they've been bought by a big  concern. And so we expect those sales to start recovering into the second half.

file: JMATL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 19November2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, start off with the key messages. I'm pleased to say that ECT has had a very good first half growing operating  profit by 16%. And we made some very good progress in our new business division, which we'll talk about a bit  more later. We have though had some challenges in other markets, the low oil price, slower growth in China, and  of course, lower pgm prices have impacted the business, so there's subdued trading particularly in PT and  Precious Metal Products division, and that's why we're taking actions to reduce costs as we've talked about in the  statement.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, looking at the light-duty market, as you can see, very good, way ahead of the market with sales up by 12% at  constant currency, and that compares to a reduction in global car production of 3%. Euro 6b's the main driver of  that, and that started on the 1st of September 2014 for new models, and the 1st of September 2015 for all models.  So, of course, we've seen that ramp-up of fitment of diesel exhaust systems. Because Euro 6b is mainly about –  primarily about NOx emissions for diesel cars, that brings the emissions much closer to those that come out of a  gasoline car, of course, that's in test cycle. And that added around 20% more value per car.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Heavy Duty also did well in the first half. Here, I'm really going to talk about the on-road side, but we also have  the off-road and stationary business too. And here is a bit weaker in the off-road mainly due to the agricultural  equipment slowdown a bit, and also stationary has really – impacted a little bit by the slowdown in U.S.  exploration activity for oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, there's clearly been a lot of focus on emissions control recently. And we thought it might be useful just to  spend a little bit more time going through the impact of some of the issues in emission control. And for that,  rather than hearing from me, I thought you better hear – it'd be more useful to hear it from John Walker. So,  John's going to say a few words.  John Walker  Executive Director  Thank you, Robert. So, as Robert said, since we spoke to you last, there's been an increasing focus on emissions  control. So, next couple of slides, I'd like to update you on some of the most recent developments and provide a  reminder of the relevant technology options. So, air quality, especially in relation to emissions of NOx from diesel  cars, remains the subject of much media commentary. However, there's been no shift in the share of diesel cars in  Europe to-date.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As you'll recall, we've said for some time that we expect the share of diesel cars in Europe to trend down in the  medium term mainly due to the fact that gasoline engines are becoming more fuel efficient. But it's really too early  to say when impact the recent news flow will have on this.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The two data points from the last two months don't signal any shifts but it remains to be seen what if anything will  happen in the longer term. That said, it's important to remember that CO2 emissions, standards in Europe, are set  to tighten from 130 grams per kilometer to 95 grams per kilometer by 2020. And diesel cars generally have higher  fuel efficiency and lower CO2 emissions than their gasoline counterparts.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And so, given the tightening standards, we say that it's clear, that these will remain an important part of the mix  going forward. What we've seen over the past few months, there's increased scrutiny on both emissions control  and emissions testing. In the last couple of weeks, we've seen a further clarification around the details of real  world driving or RDE.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, RDE is all about changing the test cycle, so it's more in line with the way that people actually drive their cars.  As such, it will come comprise rural, urban and highway driving sections as part of the test. And here, they'll be  doing the test with a portable emission control equipment on the back of the car rather than in a dynamometer in  a laboratory, so a very different test. It will be introduced from September of 2017, and the initial focus has been  on NOx.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As has been well publicized under some real world driving conditions, actual NOx emissions from diesel cars are  higher than legislative limits precisely because the current test cycle doesn't accurately reflect the way that people  drive. Conformity factors have been introduced to specify the maximum emissions during actual driving relative  to the current limits.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, the NOx factors will impact diesel cars from 2017, and they'll tighten further in 2020. So, we expect the  conformity factors for particulate number to be set early in 2016. And it's expected that this will lead to the  introduction of gasoline particulate filters.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, here, a lot of developments. So, as I've said, Johnson Matthey's technology is part of the solution. So, I just  want to recap on the NOx control technologies that we provide and the implications of these with regards to real  world driving. So, as you can see, there's three types of technology and Johnson Matthey is well positioned in all  three.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the left, you have what we call NOx adsorber catalyst, also known as NOx storage catalyst, also known as NOx  trap, a system of many names. This is a pgm-based system that requires fuel addition. So to be able to – you add  fuel as the reductant to be able to convert NOx. And hence, you have the penalty on fuel consumption with that  system. So, it's usually favored on small cars namely due to space constraints.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving to the middle, this is the selective catalytic reduction technology or SCR. This requires a urea injection  system and tends to be favored on larger vehicles and is more effective at higher speeds. And that's one of the  things that will be added to the European test cycle. You'll be driving a more and more aggressive driving cycle.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Then, on the right, as what we'll call the advanced SCR system. So, this is the most technically complex system of  the three. Then on demanding applications, an additional SCR-based technology can be added to maximize NOx  conversion. So, with tougher, more stringent limits required to meet real world driving, we do expect a shift  towards these advanced SCR systems.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, from a technology roadmap point of view, the NOx trap technology on the left there was an attractive system  for the United States as there was not an existing urea or AdBlue as European people might know the brand name,  infrastructure in the United States. So, that was an attractive technology that you could introduce that and not  have to add another fluid to the vehicle.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So then, we move towards, in the technology roadmap, some NOx traps and some SCR. That's where we were in  the beginning of 2014 when the European Euro 6b legislation was introduced. And today, the mix in Europe is  around two-thirds SCR, one-third NOx traps, something like that. And now we're getting ready for the  introduction of real world driving in Europe and we see OEMs moving away from the NOx trap systems and  towards the most advanced SCR system on the right. And again, that's a high speed, high-temperature thing  where NOx traps start to lose the ability to absorb NOx.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thanks very much, John. Hopefully that was helpful, but we'll also spend a little bit of time at our Investor Day  next year talking in more detail about not just our role in emission control but also our role with the powertrain  and how that's moving forward including electrification.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So moving on now to Process Technologies, as I've already said, it's pretty challenging, and to be honest,  somewhat more challenging than we expected. The tough first half is a result of the challenging external  conditions, principally, lower demand in China, and the low oil price. Low oil price particularly affected the  Diagnostic Services business, but it also impacts our customers' technology decisions, and their level of confidence  in putting in a new plant. Our catalysts sales held up but returns were significantly impacted by that whole  confidence issue that I've talked about.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the chemicals side, steady sales but a slightly less favorable mix. On the Syngas side, strong formaldehyde  sales, catalysts sales but this is a lower margin business. Ammonia and methanol are both ahead slightly. But  SNG, which is principally in China, sales were down due to project delays. Licensing income was also lower but we  did receive one oxo license in China. The slow activity generally continues across the world and there are fewer  opportunities today out there. But we're typically feedstock agnostic in many of our technologies and the long- term drivers are still in place.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the oil and gas side, it's a mixed performance in the first half. Good growth in catalysts, purification is strong  but slower in hydrogen following a strong new plant activity last year. Also a number of the change-outs are being  delayed into the second half of this year and that's because refining margins are very high at the moment, so our  customers are taking the benefit of cheaper feedstocks and deferring a little bit their change-outs of their catalysts,  but we expect that, as I said, to recover in the second half.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our Diagnostic Services business is the only part of JM that directly serves the upstream oil and gas industry and  hence is impacted by the oil and gas price directly. It's a relatively high fixed-cost business, mainly a people  business. And hence, it's posted unfortunately an operating loss in the first half. We have taken action to reduce  cost not just here, but as Den's already said across the division and to position it and the rest of the division for  growth in 2016, 2017 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally to New Businesses, and I'm pleased with the progress we've been making here. And you can see the losses  reduced in the first half. Particularly pleased with the progress we've made in Battery Technologies and as mainly  through – partly through the two acquisitions we've done in the battery material space. We've seen strong sales of  lithium ion phosphate in China, and we're developing relationships with a number of key partners in the supply  chain including LG Chemicals.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Atmospheric controlled technologies, we bought a business in May, as you might have seen, and the integration of  that is going well and going to plan. So, the outlook for New Business is positive, and we expect a modest  reduction in the operating loss for the year compared to last year.

file: JMATL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 17November2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: But there are strong structural drivers ahead and a big opportunity for us. Air quality, as you know, is a major  global issue, and Johnson Matthey has the robust number 1 position in technology for both emission control and  high-power lithium iron phosphate battery materials. And on battery materials, we are also broadening our  portfolio into high-energy materials to position us for growth as that market develops.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: JM is also a leader in catalyst and technology for the petrochemical sector, about 11% of our sales today. This is,  as you know, a cyclical market which right now is at a low point in the cycle, and we've taken actions as we talked  about last year to reduce our costs accordingly. But the medium to long term opportunity is attractive. The drivers  remain positive. Consumer demand for fuels, plastics and other everyday products will drive the need for  chemical intermediates which require our catalysts and technologies in order to be economic.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, in summary, we're well placed with strong positions in markets with sound medium term growth drivers. And  we are also investing in our business accordingly and driving efficiencies. And on that, we are expanding our  emission control capacity globally to enable our automotive customers to meet upcoming legislation. We're also  continuing to drive efficiency through focus on operational effectiveness and supply chain optimization, and you  can see that coming through our results in the return on sales in our ECT business. And as the trend towards  electrification continues, we're investing to expand our lithium iron phosphate capacity by 50% and we announced  that today.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And at the group level, our priorities remain, to invest in R&D [ph] of around (06:32) about 5% of sales to create  the sustainable technologies of tomorrow, continue our investment program in our business systems to drive  efficiencies and provide scale for the future, and we'll maintain our strong focus on capital efficiency which gives  us the capacity to invest for future growth and support long term value for shareholders. So, JM is in good shape  and our strategy remains robust.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And looking at the Light Duty business first. Here, we've had a great first half. Our Light Duty Catalyst business  has outpaced the market, and our sales were 9% up versus global Light Duty production growth of just over 4%.  Particular strong outperformance in Europe, as you can see, where our sales grew 16%, and that compares to a  3% growth in the underlying market. So, why is that? Well, that's partly driven by the continued benefit from the  tail end of Euro 6b coming through and also demand from customers shifting towards more complex high value  systems ahead of the introduction of real world driving emission standards in the future. It's interesting to note that  despite all the noise going on at the moment, the share of diesel cars produced in Western Europe was stable on  last year. And we're also continuing to work with our customers on products for Euro 6c which primarily, as you  know, impacts gasoline cars.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In North America, our sales were down a bit, but there's no real change in the competitive position there, just a  slightly less favourable product mix. Although this year, we have more sales of lower value catalysts compare to  last year. So, overall, continued focus on emissions around the world and a strong first half from us.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: On the Syngas side, catalyst replacement cycles have been pushed out. This particularly impacted our ammonia  business where the longer replacement cycle has come from our customers as a result of over capacity in their  end markets. In methanol, a similar story, but as a result of the sustained low oil price. Here, our customers are  seeing lower demand for methanol as their end users look to take advantage of cheap oil as an alternative fuel to  methanol.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Our Oil and Gas business continues to feel the impact on demand of the low oil price where sales down 14%, and  performance is mixed across our business. Our sale of hydrogen catalyst were weaker as our customers pushed  out their refills. This was due to lower demand in their end markets as refineries process sweeter crudes which  require less hydrogen for desulfurization.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: On the other hand, demand for our refinery additives was good. And our Diagnostic Services business continue to  see weaker trading as a result of the sustained low oil price. However, it did benefit from the reduced cost base  and broke even in the first half.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, looking at Precious Metal Product Services. Predominantly, the Pgm Refining and Recycling business. That's  impacted, as you know, by lower average metal prices when compared to the first half of last year, particularly  palladium, which was down about 9%. And we saw refining intakes fall sharply last year when the pgm price  dropped. Since then, intakes have been steady, but albeit at fairly low levels.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In particular, intakes of end of life autocatalyst remained low due in part to low scrap steel prices. Of course, the  economics of scrapping old vehicles aren't solely dependent on pgm prices and they aren't quite as attractive as  they used to be. And therefore, our outlook for intakes remain similar for the remainder of this year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We have, though, opened a new refinery in China which gives us capacity for when scrap autocat volumes come  through there. But in the meantime, we'll be recycling industrial catalysts, so it will take some time to fill our  capacity. And we don't expect to significantly impact on the numbers in this year or next. However, this is a  strategic investment for us to position ourselves in this important future market.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Battery Technologies delivered a small operating profit. And within that, Battery Materials is doing well,  maintaining its leading position in lithium iron phosphate where we've just approved an investment of around £30  million to increase our manufacturing capacity by about 50%.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And we're also continuing to progress the development of high energy, nickel rich materials, helped by the license  agreements we signed with CAMX Power and 3M. And we're making progress in our other new business areas,  too. And so, the division overall should see a much improved second half.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: But in the medium term, which is, of course, more important, Johnson Matthey remains well-positioned in  attractive markets. And then we move forward in our third century, we will continue to invest in R&D, our  infrastructure and our people to deliver growth for our shareholders and sustainable technologies that makes the  world a cleaner and healthier place.

file: JMATL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 21November2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Nov-17.pdf
JMATL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 21November2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Our Clean Air business continues to perform strongly and Efficient Natural Resources grew well. And in Health  and Battery Materials, we're making good progress as we position for breakout growth over the medium-term. We  increased the interim dividend by 7%, and our return on capital was 16%.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: First, looking at sales for the group, sales grew 10%, with growth across all of our sectors. This was driven in  particular by double-digit growth in Clean Air and both light duty and heavy duty businesses. Despite volatility in  the macro environment such as Europe and China autos, we continue to deliver exactly as planned, and we  expect this momentum to continue across the group as we continue into the second half.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Operating profit also grew 10%. The underlying businesses overall grew strongly, with Clean Air and Efficient  Natural Resources both performing particularly well. Health declined in line with our full-year expectations, and  New Markets operating profit was also lower.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Moving now to the sectors, Clean Air had a very good first half, with sales growth of 11%. We delivered double- digit growth in both light and heavy duty, well-ahead of growth in global vehicle production. In light duty, the  growth was driven by our European business. Our diesel catalysts sales grew 18% in a market that declined 6%,  as we've seen the share gains that we previously talked about ramping up.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Clean Air's operating profit grew 15%, with a slight increase in margin due to the volume leverage, particularly in  Europe, and tight cost control. I'm pleased with the first half results and we expect continued strong sales growth  in the remainder of the year as the rest of our share gains in European light duty diesel come through.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Looking to the full year, our outlook for Efficient Natural Resources is unchanged. We expect slight sales growth  and operating profit growth ahead of this, because of the operating leverage and restructuring cost savings on  top. If the current momentum continues, we could potentially exceed this.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In the period, we realized some cost savings from the closure of our Riverside plant in the U.S., but these were  more than outweighed by transition costs. We continue to expect a small net benefit for the full year and over the  medium term from this footprint optimization, which will, over the medium term, deliver significant benefits. The  full-year outlook is unchanged and we expect broadly stable sales with operating profit to be down.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In New Markets, we saw strong sales growth, driven by the Alternative Powertrain. This benefited from demand  for battery systems for e-bikes and our fuel cells businesses also grew well. We continue to make good progress  in the development and commercialization of eLNO. We incurred higher costs in Battery Materials as we invested  in strategic customer relationships to support the commercialization of eLNO, and so New Markets' operating  profit declined. In the full year, operating profit is now expected to be down, although profit in the second half will  be ahead of the second half of last year.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Precious metal working capital was significantly higher at the end of September – September, I think. This is  mainly due to downtime of one of our pgm refineries, which meant we had to go into the market to source metal  that we were contracted to refine and return. We're working hard to reduce this working capital, and while we  expect to have made significant progress by the end of the year, we will not yet be at normalized levels. You can  see from the chart that our precious metal working capital does fluctuate. This is due to metal prices and volumes,  and we have significant experience in managing this volatility.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Turning now to the outlook, we're confident in the outlook for the full-year and now expect the group to deliver  operating profit performance towards the upper end of our previous guidance of mid to high-single digit growth at  constant rates. This will continue to be led by Clean Air, as share gains in light duty European diesel catalysts  ramp up further.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Anna. As I said earlier, now I'm going to talk about our strategic focus and progress. But first, let me  remind you of what JM is all about. Johnson Matthey is a world-class technology company. We provide solutions  for cleaner air, improved health, and the conservation of the world's natural resources. And at the heart of our  business is world-class science.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We deliver our strategy through four sectors; Clean Air, Efficient Natural Resources, Health, and New Markets.  And over the medium-term, each sector will contribute to the delivery of shareholder value, which we define as  mid- to high-single-digit earnings per share growth per annum, expansion of our return on invested capital to 20%,  and as a result, a progressive dividend.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Clean Air, we will deliver sustained growth over the next decade, with share gains in Europe and tighter global  legislation. In Efficient Natural Resources, our focus on technology and higher growth segments will enable us to  deliver market leading growth, with efficiency gains driving profit growth ahead of sales growth. And in Health and  Battery Materials, we're positioning ourselves for breakout growth. In Health, our new generic product pipeline is  expected to deliver an incremental £100 million of operating profit by 2025, and in Battery Materials we're  progressing our plans to commercialize our next generation eLNO materials.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So that's our strategy, which we laid out at our Capital Markets Day last year. We are confident that this will  enable us to deliver on the promises that we have made and indeed, whilst the world is constantly changing  around us, we have and we'll continue to deliver successfully. Over the last six months, we've seen increased  concerns over global economic growth prospects and uncertainty in the outlook of China, given weak economic  data. However, rising oil prices provides us an opportunity for our Efficient Natural Resources sector.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: On the other hand, of course, the diesel share of the market in Europe continues to decline, but this decline is in  line with the forecast we made last year. Further developments in automotive powertrain over the next decade  and beyond provide further opportunity, as our technology leadership means we're well-positioned for success in  this dynamic landscape. And, of course, the global political backdrop is quite uncertain too.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: First, Clean Air, I'm pleased to say we're on-track to achieve our goal of sustained growth in this business. Our  strategy is underpinned by our global leadership, supporting our customers and meeting increasingly stringent  legislation requirements with the best technology and an efficient manufacturing footprint.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Taking all these factors together, I'm still confident that following a strong period of growth in European Light Duty  in the short-term, that element of our Clean Air business should be broadly flat over the next decade as diesel  declines and battery electric vehicle penetration increases.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: As I've mentioned, tightening legislation globally is a key driver of our growth in Clean Air. Our Asia business will  transform, led by tighter legislation in China across both light and heavy duty. We'll also see growth from India  and Southeast Asia as legislation is upgraded. On the Light Duty side in China, we're on track with platform wins  for China 6/VI, and we expect to maintain a constant share.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: To support our growth in Clean Air, we have taken steps to expand our manufacturing footprint and capacity in  Europe and China. Construction on our plants in Poland and China is underway, and we're likely to need further  additional capacity in India to meet increasing demand there. But overall, I'm really pleased with the momentum of  our Clean Air business. I'm confident in our ability to deliver mid-single-digit sales growth over the 10 years, with a  broadly stable margin.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Efficient Natural Resources, we're making targeted investments in higher growth segments. We've categorized  our portfolio based on the growth potential and we're aligning our CapEx and R&D investments to these  opportunities. For example, we've redirected resource to high growth segments, such as methanol, gas  processing, and areas of oxo alcohols. Alongside our investments, we're taking steps to increase efficiency. Anna  has given you the financial detail on this, but I wanted to add some context from a strategic perspective.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Firstly, our product portfolio review will continue to drive improvements across the business over the next couple  of years. And secondly, we have instigated a program of increased investment in our pgm refineries to improve  their safety and operating resilience. In an ever-changing world, the security of supply that these refineries  provide to Clean Air is a key element of our strategy.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We also continue to look at additional opportunities for long-term growth that will benefit from our science and  technology, and I've previously talked about our plans to commercialize newly developed technologies. For  example, we've won our first license for our recently developed mono ethylene glycol, or MEG, technology, which  enables the production of MEG from a variety of raw materials. And we've also recently commercialized our waste  to aviation fuel technology. So to summarize, I'm really encouraged with our progress to-date and we will continue  to grow sales and drive efficiency across our operations.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Moving on now to Battery Materials. In New Markets, we're positioning for breakout growth in Battery Materials  with our ultra-high energy density, next-generation eLNO materials. Over the last few years, we've been working  hard to develop our Battery Materials business. Our progress has been driven by our science and technology  leadership. That is what JM does best. Given this is such an exciting opportunity for us, I'm going to spend some  time on this topic over the next couple of slides. But let me start by saying that we've made tremendous progress  accelerating our Battery Materials strategy.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We're adding resources to further develop eLNO and we now have around 80 R&D scientists and engineers in  our Battery Materials team, which we scaled up significantly in the past year. And our total R&D investment in  eLNO has increased by 60% in the period. Customer sampling is still progressing well and feedback remains  excellent, and our commercialization plans are on track. All of this will lead to breakout growth.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: As we've previously talked about, eLNO is a significant development. It offers a step change in energy density,  lower cobalt, and lower dollar per kilowatt hour per cycle compared to current and future cathode materials.  eLNO's superior performance is attractive to our customers and will enable increased penetration of long-range  battery electric vehicles. This gives JM a sustainable competitive advantage. And today, I wanted to give you  some insight into the battery material production process and where we play in that value chain.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: On this slide, we've shown a simplified version of the overall battery production process, starting with raw  materials all the way through to the battery pack that is used by the OEM. JM's expertise and investments are in  the cathode material production, the blue box at the top of the slide, which can be separated into the wet end,  where we make the precursor; and the dry end, where we make the final cathode material.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We have chosen to operate across the entire production process from metal salts to eLNO, because this allows  us to differentiate and optimize eLNO through every step of the manufacturing process. This further enhances our  ability to maintain our technology leadership and deliver market-leading solutions for our customers. We're also  assessing the opportunity within Battery Materials recycling, which utilizes our core competencies. It'll be some  time before sufficient batteries need to be recycled, but we are looking at all areas of battery activities across their  lifecycle.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Our commercialization plans for eLNO are on track. We've come a long way and I'm excited about what we've  achieved so far. On this slide, you'll see our progress to-date and key milestones over the next 12 months. We  have developed the best-in-class next-generation battery material, eLNO, and we continue to receive positive  feedback from our customers. We've also progressed our scale-up activities. The dry end of our pilot plant is  operational and the wet end will be operational next year. Our full scale commercial plant, which will be built in  mainland Europe, is also on track and we received board approval for the initial CapEx in July. We're now  completing the front-end engineering design and progressing land purchase and permitting.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In summary, we're on track, and I'm really excited by the opportunity that lies ahead. There's a huge amount of  activity in Battery Materials, and I look forward to updating you on progress over the next years.

When volumes recovered in the  second half, we were able to respond without adding to the cost base.

texts.speaker: Ian Godwin, Director, Investor Relations and Corporate Communications

The HDD market sales,  ex PGM, should reach around $2.5 billion by the end of 2014.

Hydrogen demand usually grows by about 9% per annum.

License for the first world-scale synthetic  natural gas or SNG plants in China was concluded this year.

file: JMATL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 2June2011 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Jun-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We've taken costs out through this recession, and we continue to do so, as you'll see in these results. And we're  now getting the benefits of some big new markets like heavy-duty diesel where we maintain a very leading market  share.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And then Brussels – Neil will talk a little bit more about the closure of our Brussels plant. But of that £57 million,  around about two-thirds of it is in cash. And the majority of that, the vast majority of that cash will be incurred in  this financial year. And that is mainly to do with employee-related costs, slight remediation and environmental  costs.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: You can see here that the working capital increased, excluding PGMs, by £67 million, and that's reflected in the  working capital days. But also the precious metal component within working capital increased by £215 million.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Now interestingly enough, a large portion of that, about a £130 million of that balance, is in receivables. That's  just as we're invoicing our customers and awaiting for their payment, obviously, we invoice the precious metal  component. So, that's in the receivables balance. The rest is inventories primarily. And that's, obviously, increased  this year because of higher precious metal prices, but also increased demand and increased activity.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: The largest portion of the investment was in environmental technology division, as you can see. And the biggest  projects, as it mentions on the slide here, was principally in China. We're expanding the autocatalyst  manufacturing plant there. Also, additional process capacity in both the U.K. and in India, and then also a new  PGM catalyst plant in Shanghai. Those will be the principal projects.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Robert. The operating review. The picture here – I'll cover environmental technologies division first.  The picture here is our new shiny Macedonia plant. Although, someone reminded me that all our old plants are  shiny, too, so you wouldn't know from that. But let's move into Environmental Technologies division numbers.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, ECT grew well. Its sales were up 25%. More detail to follow on ECT. PT also had good growth aided by the  acquisition of Intercat. We made that acquisition in November. Intercat, to remind you, supplies additives into the  refinery sector, into the FCC unit. And we've integrated that together with our other refineries business supply  catalyst for hydrogen.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Fuel cells also did well. It grew its sales. Its customers are servicing the combined heat and power markets, 250- kilowatt units, residential units of 10-kilowatts, and a number of small markets like the leisure market, forklift  truck market, backup power for telephone masts. So, sales were up, and net expense was down £0.5 million to  £4.9 million.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, I'll talk about the markets in North America. A good recovery. Our sales grew in line with the growth in that  market. In Europe, diesel is moving back up as a percentage of the total sales. In the recession, it drifted down to  the high 40%s, now it's moving back up into the 50%s again. I think the record was 54% some time before the  recession. And why is that important? Well, many of you know the latest legislation in Europe means that diesels  are kind of five times the opportunity for us as petrol vehicles.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, looking ahead in Emissions Control Technologies but in the light-duty area. You've heard we are, sadly, going  to have to close our Brussels plant, and that's well underway. The process is well advanced because we've got too  much capacity in Europe. And without Brussels, we'll still have some headroom in it's generally sort of utilization  being around the 70% level. The Brussels closure will have a payback of three years, and I guess about a £15  million a year saving. And we'll get to most of that saving in this year; and, of course, in the future years.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Rare earths are a problem that you've heard of before. And last year, they cost us £5 million, mainly in the last  quarter. Next year, this current year, they'll cost us some more extra expense, but we're working with our  customers. Just to inform you, the rare earths only go into petrol vehicles. But we're working on substitution and  thrifting, and these tests and approvals take some time. And we're working on getting agreements with our  customers.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Here's the chart that forecasts what will happen into the future with heavy-duty diesel sales. These are March 2011  numbers. The line, again, shows the old October numbers and the bars, the latest outlooks. So, in Western  Europe, well, the outlook for 2011, '12, '13 is slightly better than before, and obviously very positive.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: The new outlook shows in 2013 a little bit of a pre-buy. You'll remember back before emissions legislation hit  trucks that there was a pre-buy, people bought trucks ahead of the more expensive trucks. That's a bit of an  element of that in Europe in 2013. But as you can see by these bars here, this is when the legislation that's now in  place in the U.S. broadly gets put into place in Europe.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In China, there's been a little bit of a delay. While the legislation says Euro 4 will start in 2012, the actuality will be  that it probably won't start until 2013 because they're a bit short on low sulfur fuel, which is a problem they'll be  addressing. So, that's the looking-ahead slide for ECT.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Moving now to Process Technologies. Well, the catalyst business, we've made lots of investment in R&D. You've  heard that from us. This has delivered new products to our customers with significant benefits to our customers;  and Apico is a great example of that, our new methanol catalyst. Sales up in the methanol catalyst area, 57%.  That's £49 million.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Lots of several – lots of repeat business we got in China, which shows that as we progress, we're making better  plants. And SNG, butanediol, methanol and oxo alcohols plants were all included in that 13, as you can see from  the chart.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Looking ahead in Process Technologies, well, the reputation for Apico grows, as I've said. And very soon, Apico  will be sold to some of the world's largest methanol plants. We're excited about Intercat. It's nicely integrated and  this, of course – this business in the refinery sector is driven by low sulfur legislation and the switch to diesel, too.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: DPT will be strong. They'll have another strong year this year, and we're adding to its portfolio of technologies.  And our existing portfolio really plays well in an environment where there's more gas available, more gas through  shale, cheaper gas. And, of course, our coal to products technology plays very well into places like China.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Refining also doing very well in the year. Higher throughputs, higher precious metal prices; and we've made some  operational improvements. This is – the chart there, the pie chart divides out the customers that we have for  refining. We're the world's leader in refining autocat scrap.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Research and Development. Talked about the increase, an increase by 20% to £110 million, a further increase of  about £15 million planned in 2011-'12. And this is fundamental to our longer-term growth – I mean in R&D. 70%  of it is spent in environmental technologies. That's where we can see the opportunity to make better products, the  opportunity to make higher margins, and the opportunity also to access new customers.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And one of the focuses in R&D is on sustainability. We're working hard in Johnson Matthey on our own  sustainability with some progress. But a more important feature is to design new products in the future, which will  help our customers be more sustainable. And we think we are in a very good position to do that.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: There's £5 million of funds targeted for new areas of growth. This is something we talked about in our Investor  Day in February. We're looking for new areas of business where – which have the JM attributes in terms of  businesses that we want to go after, but are in new areas with new customers and new markets. We're doing –  we're making some good progress there, and we'll talk more to you about it when we've made some decisions in  that area.  So, looking forward, the outlook. Environmental Technologies is well placed for continued growth. In ECT, for the  year ahead, our global car production will be higher, particularly in Asia. Maybe a short-term effect from Japan,  but this should reverse in our second half. The truck market is forecast to grow. North America is our most  important market in the next few years until Euro 6 comes into play in Europe in 2013.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We've taken action to control costs, and we're doing more in our – to optimize our capacity in Europe. Those  actions are well advanced. Whilst rare earth prices will add to costs, mainly in our first half, we see a way to – find  a way to make sure the customers pay the full impact of the increased prices. PT will benefit from a full year of  Intercat, and DPT will have another strong year in China and elsewhere.

texts.speaker: Neil A. P. Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Talking about precious metal products. Well, the services businesses will benefit from higher PGM prices, which  are already higher than the average last year and should go higher still. And the manufacturing businesses are  growing nicely and benefiting from new products like Iridium sparkplug tips and another one, e+, this is a label  that you stick on packaging for fruit and extends the fruit – the life of the fruit on the shelf.

file: JMATL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 6June2013 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Jun-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We move in to a new territory with them, and that will take sales away from us. But at that same time, we're  moving into the time when we get new legislation in heavy-duty diesel, which should boost our sales. So that's  what we mean by kind of transition. But we still make – we still think we're going to make steady progress in this  current year and well positioned for future growth, growth should then accelerate.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Return on invested capital, very important for us as you know and a measure that we take very seriously. We've  had, for many years, a target of exceeding 20%. We're going to keep that target despite the fact that the Anglo  work is lost, and that's very high returns as you know. This year, the return on capital went up in Environmental  Technologies. But the reason why the overall return on capital for the Group fell was mainly because of the  reduced profits in Precious Metal Products, which we've mentioned before, and that's the high return on capital  business. It still is a high return on capital business, but in the overall average for the Group, that's the reason why  the numbers fell.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thank you very much, Robert. Excuse me. So let me talk you through the operating review and we'll start, as  usual, with Environmental Technologies Division. Here are the numbers. You can see sales up and profits up 7%.  A challenging year. Mainly, the European market for cars didn't do very well as you're all very well aware. But on  the other side, heavy duty diesel did do quite well. And PT, again, was also ahead of last year. And a couple of  acquisitions have been added into the mix.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So here's our sales. This is light duty catalyst sales. And you can see that they were down 3%. North America was  flat, while the market was up. Now that's mainly a rare earth issue. We were charging more for rare earths in 2012  than we were in 2013, because they might more or less kind of passthrough now. Europe's our biggest market, that  was down; it wasn't down as much as the market. And Asia was fine. China still going well for us. Operating profit  down 4%.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So looking ahead in the light duty area. So Q4, the 1st of January in 2014, there is some legislation coming our  way, which will benefit light duty vehicles. Here's the details. The benefit is larger in heavy duty, which will move  on to next. But an interesting point in the middle there, there is some legislation now in Europe that will require  filters on petrol cars, not for a few years, but even so. That's the first time we've seen filters required on petrol cars,  not all petrol cars, but that's a very good trend for us. And a positive outlook for car demand, as I've already  mentioned. Legislation drives this business and as legislation tightening in the future on NOx on particulate and  on CO2, i.e., fuel economy, and all those things help our business.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Process Technologies is next, and this business did fine. It did very well really. Sales slightly ahead at £406  million. The usual mix of up in methanol and down in ammonia or the other way around, I think it was this time.  And we acquired here Formox. It's a company we've been looking out for a while. It's an extremely good fit with  Johnson Matthey. It sells the process and catalysts. It fits with the Davy Process Technology side and the catalyst  sales side. So we're really pleased to have acquired it right at the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So looking ahead, normal catalyst replacement cycles will be in place for the catalyst side. At some stage, of  course, all these plants that we've been building and licensing in DPT, they will need catalysts. And we've added  capacity to our facilities in Clitheroe and in Panki to manufacture those catalysts, because we're going to see an  uptick in our demand for catalysts in the future years to finish off the plants that we've been building and  designing.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So licenses for new alcohol plants will not be repeated at six or five a year, but will be maintained at a lower level.  But on the other side, unconventional gas, shale gas is providing us with a lot of opportunities looking forward and  also opportunities in America where we haven't had business for quite a while. Good drivers growing this  business.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So couple of words on our Battery Technologies business, newly formed with the acquisition of Axeon, and you  can read the details there. This really, I think, I wanted – I'd like to say is providing us a focus for our R&D on the  new materials in the battery space where we think we can make a contribution. But I also think that if we get the  opportunity, we'd be making some acquisitions in this area, in the battery materials space, if you like.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So here's some detail on the services business, and you can see the prices there. They were down year-on-year, but  it's a very unexciting picture and the platinum price basically tracks the gold price despite the fact that there were  strikes in South Africa, which usually causes some energy and the markets didn't do at this time.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Just one slide on non-financial performance, because this year we'll mark the second year that we've done an  integrated annual report. It's a fascinating read. It takes a lot of effort. I hope somebody does read it out there. But  what this says, and if you look at the detail, is that Johnson Matthey is a much more efficient place than it was five  years ago, mainly driven by the efforts that we put into sustainability for the last five years and also manufacturing  excellence in the last year.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Outlook. Environmental Technologies. Medium-term outlook is positive. In the short term, we've just got a little  question in our minds about ECT's business in Europe for understandable reasons. But new HDD legislation will  start to enhance our results. In fact, there are some signs of a pre-buy of Euro 5 trucks in Europe, which we can  talk more about in Q&A, I'm sure.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Process Technologies is also well placed to grow, and Formox will add to that growth. And we're quite excited  about our Battery Technologies business where sales are going to grow and where we're hopeful of getting a very –  a decently profitable business in the near – reasonably near term.

file: JMATL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 5June2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Jun-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Robert. So, the operating review. As always, we'll start with ECT, Emissions Control Technologies,  good set of numbers. As you can see, sales up 13%; operating profit up 25%; and I'd point to you that return on  invested capital, which is a very strong number, 21%, so good effort on lots of fronts by ECT.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: ECT exceeded our expectations for the year. And some of it was an improved product mix that we got in Europe. I  think diesel sale – car sales held up better than we were kind of expecting, and our share of those was strong.  Good growth in our Asian businesses, and the implementation, of course, the highlight, which is the Euro VI  legislation that benefited our HDD business in Europe. So, the pie chart shows you the split of the sales. And  interesting to note 35% of our sales now are in HDD, whereas in 2006, probably that was zero. So exciting area for  us.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We've done pretty well in China. We probably picked up some new business. But also, in the rest of Southeast  Asia, we've been doing well. So, operating profit well ahead and some good results from our process efficiency,  manufacturing excellence and sustainability efforts that have really started to impact the cost side in ECT.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, looking ahead for ECT, well, the situation in Europe looks a bit better on cars, some car sales – positive car  sales data which we haven't seen for a number of years and the legislation is going to get tighter. So, Euro 6b and  Euro 6c will add value to each car that we supply in the next couple of years. There's lots of talk about CO2  legislation and limits both in Europe and in North America, and they're broadly positive for us in that smaller  engines are more complex designs and that gives us an opportunity.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, let's talk about the Chemicals business first. Here's the makeup of the £339 million of sales that we make.  Sales up 13%. Of course, that was benefited by the addition of Formox, formaldehyde catalysts and technology,  we're very pleased with. It's gone very well. Methanol did pretty well, and we signed three new SNG licenses in  China.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: The Oleo/biochemicals side did well in a fairly flat market. And in the Petrochemical side, we've increased our  catalyst volumes, but the licensing revenue is down. And you can see from that bar chart the effect. But important  also to note here that in 2013, we sold five oxo licenses. They're particularly high earners for us in the oxo license.  And this year, in 2014, only one, but some SNG licenses were sold. But to note there, that the SNG license sale  benefits quite a lot on the catalyst sale side rather than the licensing income side.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We are developing some new technologies. The requirements for more and more oxo into the long-term future  will some time come to a bit of an end, but we have got some good new technologies in the pipeline, MEG and  VCM, two of them.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Oil and Gas business has done pretty well. Sales grew 9%. There's some action in the refineries in the U.S. for the  first time in a number of years, so that's boosted some hydrogen catalyst sales. You can see the split of the sales  there. Gas processing did well. And our Diagnostic Services business is also doing well on unconventional oil-and- gas opportunities in the U.S. and is adding some new technology to its portfolio for the analysis of the wall  thickness of pipelines.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, looking ahead in PT. We do expect progress in the Chemicals side in 2014-2015, but we would flag that the  timing of these orders, particularly for licenses, are really difficult to project exactly when they're going to hit us.  We haven't lost any business, but the timing of orders is slightly uncertain. So, it's not really appropriate to judge  this business on one quarter of its performance. We're still continuing to develop on new technologies and the  expansion of the petrochemical industry, so coal getting turned into products in China, that's a big driver for this  business and that will continue.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In the Oil and Gas area, we expect quite a robust year ahead, stronger demand from North America refineries and  some opportunities coming up and the increased use of shale gas in the U.S. Good drivers. So coal to products in  China and shale gas in North America are key upsides to this business in the future.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Precious Metals Products, so a year of transition, really, for Precious Metals Products. Sales flat and profits up a  little bit. So, sales in line with last year. You can see the splits on that pie chart between the services business and  the manufacturing businesses. So, you know the change in the Anglo Platinum arrangements will be an impact of  about 30 million in the coming year. And in the year past, there were some lower prices for precious metals, which  had a bit of an impact.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Here's the services business data. Precious metal management, sales down 12%. Actually, Anglo American had a  good first nine months in the year and did better than we expected them to do, but that didn't offset the £10  million hit, which was the one quarter's worth of the loss of the contract. They even see the average prices, not a  lot of movement there.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And on the refining business, sales were down a little bit. And in PGM refining and recycling, we had a slightly  lower average basket price for PGMs. Intake's pretty stable, though mix is slightly less favorable. We're investing  money in this area. It's a very strategically important area for us. We're the biggest PGM refiners of secondary  material, and that's a very nice place to be when there's uncertainty in supply from the primary producers. There's  the split of sales through the recycling side.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: If we look now at the Manufacturing businesses, sales up 11%. But actually, we've transferred in a little business  out of ECT that was much better fit with PMD. So, that boosted the sales, sales by about £24 million, lower  demand for nitric acid catalyst and N2O abatement technology on the industrial side, but much better demand for  the medical device components where sales were up.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Colour Tech did well. It's had a tough few years with lower car sales, particularly in Europe, but that's starting to  do a lot better, and we've closed the decorative side. Chemical Products also did well on the back of ECT. They  supply ECT with some raw materials in the precious metal side to make catalysts.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Fuel cells had a tough year in that its customers, which are all in the stationary power generation field, have not  developed as we expected, but we are very pleased with the way that they have positioned themselves alongside  car companies, and are hopeful that we'll get a share of the cars that are made for the Californian market in the  future.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Just a slide on non-financial performance, because we're pretty proud of what we've done in JM in terms of  sustainability and, particularly, in manufacturing excellence. So, we set ourselves some targets in 2007 to get to a  different place in 2017 when we're 200 years old. And here's a little bit of the data that I think you'll find  interesting. So, we've more than doubled our earnings per share since 2007. Our target was to double by 2017, and  we've also more than doubled our sales. But the rate of energy used per unit in sales is actually down 44%, global  warming potential down 50%, water use down 40%, just an indicator that we're a much more efficient company  now and much more sustainable as we enter our third century.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We do expect progress in Process Technologies, too. Chemicals has got a really good long-term outlook, but I just  put that warning out there that you shouldn't judge this business on one quarter. This business is a bit difficult to  predict on the exact timing of some of the large contracts. Oil and Gas, we expect to be robust. And the two long- term drivers, the key ones, being colder products in China and gas in North America, remained very positive here.

texts.speaker: Neil Andrew Patrick Carson
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Steady growth in Fine Chem. CCT and Research Chemicals, we'll also expect some growth in the coming year.  Pretty much similar in new businesses. This is a long-term investment for us. One of the big long-term  investments we made in the last 20 years has been in heavy duty diesel. That's now delivering us £570 million  worth of sales. We have aspirations for something else in this portfolio to do something similar in the future. So  for the group, underlying growth, strong, offset by some headwinds. We currently expect next year –  this year to  be broadly in line with the year we just reported on. We are really well placed for long-term growth.

file: JMATL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 4June2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Jun-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We are, though, investing in new areas that fit with our business model, and you've seen that we've done two  acquisitions in battery materials, but also one in, called StePac, we bought just a week or two ago in our  Atmosphere Control Technologies. I'm pleased with the progress we're making on the managing of our portfolio.  Going forward into the year we're now in, we expect good underlying growth from our c ontinuing businesses. And  I'm pleased to say the long-term drivers that we described went through in January of our Investor Day remains  strong.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Den. And I'll just start off, and before I go to the operating review, just a little bit about this picture.  It's a picture of two of our colleagues in Germiston, in South Africa, which is our one of our John's ECT plants  there. We've been doing a lot of effort and a lot of work on the operational improvements, particularly on energy  efficiency. And over the last couple of years, they've reduced energy by 25%, which has saved about £750,000.  That's just one example of all the things that John and his team are doing to drive the imp rovements to the  margins that I'll talk about in a second.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
