texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking at Light Duty, a good performance from our Light Duty business. Our sales were up 9% at constant  currency compared to a growth in global car production of 1%. In the U.S., our volumes are in line, but the mix  effect has been slightly negative, hence, the reduction in our sales. In Europe, we benefited from Euro 6b  legislation which came into force as you know and for new models in September last year, and for all models will  come into force in September this year. This gives us basically a NOx emission standard such that the NOx from  diesel is about the same as NOx from gasoline cars.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And it's around about half of new models now are fitted with a Euro 6b system. So we've got further growth in the  second-half of this year as we get towards full implementation. There's been lots of talk about the death of diesel,  as you know. John discussed that at the Investor Day last in January. And in the first in our year, about 52% of  cars sold in Western Europe were diesel, which is exactly the same as it was last ye ar. So we haven't seen any  impact yet of all this talk in the press, but of course we still expect and we talked about it before, a gradual decline  in the diesel penetration in Europe. But diesel is an important factor in the whole requirement by car compa nies  to increase their CO2 efficiency. So we still think it's an important part of the overall mix.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In Europe, the first-half obviously benefited from Euro 6, and we've now got full fitments of Euro 6 on diesel  trucks and the sales were good and grew quite a lot this year despite the fact that the market was actually very  weak. In Asia, we've now got about 35% of fitment of Euro IV trucks, but of course, remember, these are relatively  simple non-pgm catalysts that fit on a truck in China.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So looking ahead for ECT, air quality remains a global issue. Light duty, I think we still got further structural  growth ahead of us with Euro 6b I've already talked about. But in the medium term, Euro 6c will require filters on  some direct-injection gasoline cars and that will double the value for gasoline car in Europe. But we're also seeing  some early signs, encouraging signs, of increased diesel penetration in the U.S. which is slightly going against the  trend here in Europe.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the heavy duty side, there's no new legislation in the U.S. and Europe. So now what 's likely to happen going  forward is more likely to track the market for underlying truck reduction in the future. In the U.S., I've already  mentioned that we expect the Class 8 trucks to be relatively stable for the rest of this year. And in the EU, perha ps  we'll have, in a few years' time, when the EU starts recovering, perhaps, then maybe we'll have an old fleet and  we'll see the replacement cycle come through, but we're certainly not expecting that in 2015/2016.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to Process Technologies, they made progress in the year with growth in sales and profit of 7 %. So a  good performance overall given the change in mix, especially because of the lower contribution from licensing. So  we turn to Chemicals first of all, good growth in catalysts, but slower in the licensing side. Sales were up, as you  can see, as a division, as a sector, by 4% at constant currency with higher sales of ammonia and formaldehyde  technologies, but lower demand in methanol. And that's the normal cycle. It seems to work on a sort of a two -year  cycle, so last year we had low sales of ammonia and higher sales of methanol. This year, it's the other way around.  And in the year we're now in, it's probably going to revert back to high demand for methanol and slightly lower for  ammonia. So it's sort of two-year cycle and slightly out of – they seem to be out of phase at the moment.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And on the licensing side, that was also down. Although we won six new licenses, but it will be relatively low value  and not unexpected, but principally due to the slowdown in China where there's now sufficient capacity for many  of the petrochemical plants that we have our licensing technology. So we're working on a whole series of new  technologies such as VCM, but they take time to come into market and really the first challenge is getting that first  reference site, having one customer to have the confidence to build the first plant. Once you've got one plant, then  you're more likely to get others following. But the first reference site does take quite some time. And we're also  working on a number of bio-based feedstocks for licensing technologies too.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So for licensing, I think it will be lower again in 2015/2016, the year we're now in. But then in 2016/2017 and  beyond, we'll then start to see a recovery and return to growth. On the Oil and Gas side, they performed well  across all sectors with sales up by 11%. Now remember here, about 75% of our Oil and Gas business is to mid and  downstream sector, mostly catalysts and additives and not services, so relatively less impact ed by the lower oil  price.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So over the last year, we're seeing good demand supported by tighter field specifications and lower emissions for  refineries requiring our products. Hydrogen has done well this year supported by new plant builds, particularly in   the Middle East which has helped. And on the additives side, higher performance materials rather than emission  materials have allowed us to grow that business as well.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the Diagnostic Services side, that's our Tracerco business, they had a good year, b ut this is the business that  has the upstream exposure. A lot of the work they do is on asset integrity and asset performance improvements.  New products are going well and showing good customer demand. But the oil price fall has seen a reduction in  activity, and that will probably impact this business in this year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So looking ahead, as we said in January, we see a short-term hiatus. It's going to be tough for this business to grow  this year, but the long-term drivers remain good. So this year is really around good demand for catalysts. I think  we'll still see NPT. And the Oil and Gas business should continue to perform well, but the licensing side, as I've  already said, will offset that growth on the catalyst side. And we got three reasons here principally why the  licensing income is dropping, and it's really partly to do with the cold, wet and dew projects in China. Those have  been slowed down, but also the petrochemical capacity is pretty much in line with the market demand today.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the Services side, I've already mentioned the Anglo contracts, but it's been a mixed year for refining and  recycling. Volumes are slightly higher overall helped by the Stillwater contract, which has boosted our palladium  intakes. But we have seen on an intake basis some fall off in the fourth quarter, so the first calendar quarter of this  year. And that intake volume responding to lower prices will then start impacting our results in this first quarter  of this financial year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And also there our mix has been less favorable. There's been a lot more filters coming through our spent  autocatalyst feedstock inputs, or intakes I would say. And filters, if you think they started being fitted to cars about  eight years to 10 years ago. So now they started to be scrapped and they take quite a lot more time to process  through our refinery. And that's one of the reasons why we've had increase in our pgm balances  because we're still  working on that mix on how we improve the performance of the refineries and making sure that we deal with  these issues going forward.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the refining side, the shift in mix that I mentioned about will continue to impact us this year, but we are  looking for efficiency improvements and we are also investing in a refinery in China. That's about £15 million  investment; initially to support industrial products, but going forward it will be available obviously to us when  cars start being scrapped in China, but that's not for a few years yet.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, New Businesses made good progress in the year, principally as a result of the acquisitions they've done,  both in Battery Technologies but also subsequently in the Atmosphere Control Technologies acquisition we did  recently. Battery Technologies, the acquisitions we're working on integrating those into the business and we like  what we see so far and it provides us good opportunities to develop those business in the longer term. And with  Battery Technologies only modest loss in the year and the two materials acquisitions was slightly profitable.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking ahead, we continue to want to deepen the portfolio, and this is all about providing the next engines of  growth for the group. Battery Technologies this year, we expect to be breakeven if we exclude the integration  costs. Atmospheric Control, the acquisition of StePac that we bought just last month, expect sales as it says of  about £20 million with a small operating profit.

file: JMATL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 2June2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Jun-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Director
texts.text: So, given the challenging macro environment, we've performed a review of a number of our businesses. And as a  result, we have taken an impairment and restructuring charge of £141 million. Now this relates predominantly to  the previously announced action in Process Technologies and the completion of our review of the Fuel Cells  business. Y ou can see the detailed numbers on page 6 of the press release.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Director
texts.text: In Process Technologies, we've acted to reduce our fixed cost base in response to the reduced opportunities for  coal to SNG technologies in China and the fall in the demand for some of our products and se rvices in the current  low oil price environment.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Director
texts.text: In Fuel Cells, the prospect for significant penetration of fuel cells electric vehicles in the automotive industry has  been delayed until at least 2025. Whilst there remains a positive outlook in the longer term, we have decided to  restructure the business accordingly which has resulted in impairment of a number of our noncurrent assets. The  £42 million charge, which includes £2 million of cash costs, should result in savings of around £3 million per  annum from 2016/2017.

texts.speaker: Den G. Jones
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Director
texts.text: In ECT, we have spent around £10 million adding further autocatalyst manufacturing capacity in the UK to meet  demand from the new light duty legislation. In PMP, we have continued investment on our new pgm refinery in  China, spending £11 million in the year. This project will be completed in the current financial year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Thank you, Den. So I'll go through the businesses and starting with ECT, Emission Control Technologies; another  strong year, and John and his team have done a fantastic job. You can see sales up 7 % and underlying profit up  15%, driven mainly by the benefit from Euro 6b, full implementation there in Europe; and strong demand for  Class 8 products in the U.S., particularly in the first half, although that has been weaker in the second half.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking at light duty, strong across the whole regions with the business growing by 14% – and I'll talk about  constant currency going forward. 14% growth in sales in light duty catalysts mainly in Europe, where the sales  were well ahead of production, and diesel obviously, is the main factor here with full implementation of Euro 6b  products. Diesel, of course, has been much in the news. But so far, it hasn't made a big impact on the diesel share  in Europe, which has dropped from 52% last year to 51% in the year just finished. But we still expect diesel share  to drop to around 40% or so by 2025.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking ahead, emissions remains a major global issue. On the light duty side, we see Euro 6c and real -world  driving emissions legislation coming forward, but that's going to start to take effect in late 2017, but really not  really make a big impact on us until 2018. In the meantime, we'll see a continued shift towards SCR technology for  diesel cars, and that should benefit us as well.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In the U.S., we're starting to see more diesel penetration for pickup trucks, which currently is around 20% of  diesel, and we expect that to grow over the next few years, albeit we don't just wait to see any penetration of diesel  or any material penetration of diesel for cars.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Process Technologies. As Den's already  mentioned the challenging market conditions here, and you can see our  sales down and our underlying profits down further. Those challenging markets that we've talked about in the first  half have continued into the second half, and it's principally due to lower demand in China and the low oil price,  which has reduced licensing activity and impacted our Diagnostic Servicing business. And as a result of those,  we've taken action to reduce costs, as I say, that Den's already talked about.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the oil and gas side, a mixed year overall. Hydrogen was down after a strong year last year, partly because the  refineries are running really hard but also running more lighter, sweeter crude which use less hydrogen for  desulfurization and cracking. And as a result, the refineries were able to extend the time they take before they  have a refill charge of catalysts for making hy drogen. Refinery additives and our catalysts for gas processing are  ahead. But on the other hand, the Diagnostic Servicing business has been badly hit by the low oil price and as a  result, only just broke even in the year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Looking ahead, there are limited opportunities for growth in the division in the short term, particularly in relation  to licensing activities. However, the long-term drivers remain in place, including the U.S. because of cheap shale  gas, and we continue to invest in the business to ensure we remain well-placed for recovery in the chemicals  market. This year, the tough market conditions are expected to continue. But the actions we took the last – the  year we've just done will allow us to benefit our results in this year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: On the manufacturing side, we're also steady overall with growth for chemical products in the pharma market  being offset by weak catalyst sales for the manufacture of fertilizers. And going forward, for Precious Metals  Products, on the refining and recycling side, performance will continue to be adversely impacted by the current  pgm prices, which are still in the average of last year's prices.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fuel Cells, you heard from Den, we've taken impairment charges associated with our Fuel Cell business. And going  forward, that should – significantly reduces the losses that we make in our Fuel Cell business and they will be less  than £5 million in the year ahead. I'm very much – I'm pleased to say we're on track with our strategy with New  Businesses and the progress we're making.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And looking ahead, on the Battery Technologies side, we announced today that we've signed an agreement to  license high energy nickel-rich cathode materials. And that gives us the opportunity to access the high energy  market. It'll take some time before we develop customers and new products for customers, but at least it gives us  an opportunity to do that and it fills in a gap that we had in our portfolio and we continue to invest to broaden our  portfolio in this important area.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fuel Cells, I've already mentioned, but on Water Technologies again, we announced today a couple of small  acquisitions, which gives us a foothold in this new market. These two acquisitions complement each other well  and this year, they'll have a small loss, I expect, but that'll turn to profit in next year in the years going forward. So,  overall, we're in line with where we expected to be, but we expect to break even for the division as a whole not this  year, but next year and then we're on track to deliver the targets we've already talked about.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now going into the longer term, the sustainability drivers that we've talked about before do provide opportunities  for superior growth for Johnson Matthey. Our particular focus is on air quality and the emissions factors there.  And we talked a lot about that in the Capital Markets Day, so I'm not really going to go into that anymore. But I'm  also very excited about the opportunities for our Fine Chemicals business, as we continue to see the push for ever  greater use of generic pharmaceutical products; and Johnson Matthey's investing a lot there and I'm sure we'll  make some really good progress.

file: JMATL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 1June2017 CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Jun-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, let me start with ECT. Sales in ECT were up 4% for the full year, outperforming vehicle coproduction in the  majority of the markets in a year which had limited changes in legislation. The biggest driver of growth was sales  in our higher value Light Duty Catalyst in Europe across both diesel and gasoline. Euro 6b was fully phased in  and car companies have begun to respond to real world driving emission standards. In addition, we benefited  from the business wins that we have already secured.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We've continued to develop our presence in nickel-rich high energy battery technology, leveraging our existing  capabilities in nickel. And I'm really pleased with the speed of our progress. Robert will cover this further later.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We will continue to benchmark all of our activities to identify opportunities for efficiency. This year, we had an  additional £26 million of efficiency-driven cost savings following from the £8 million we delivered last year, and  we're targeting a further £25 million of annualized savings.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Therefore, going forward, as you can see, we will have sectors aligned to these global priorities. So, ECT  becomes Clean Air, and John Walker, who most of you have known for years and is doing a fabulous job, will  continue running this business. Process Technologies and [ph] precious metal (00:24:48) products are combined,  except for medical device components, to create our Efficient Natural Resource sector. This will be run by Jane  Toogood who joined JM last year.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Now, for some detail of the key growth areas ahead of us by sector, firstly, Clean Air. This sector clearly focuses  upon the global need for improved air quality. Tighter CO2 emissions standards and an increasing focus on  emissions generally in big cities is requiring significant changes to the powertrain from automotive OEMs.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And, of course, emission control is in its early stages in emerging markets. We are very confident that the  increasing focus on air quality in Europe will drive growth in our European light duty business in the medium term.  There are also significant growth opportunities for us in Asia.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, let's look at our North American and European business in more detail. Firstly, our European light duty  business. As you know we have a strong position in diesel catalyst systems in Europe. This strength is the result  of our strategy to pursue the highest value opportunities. We focused our R&D resources and development spend  on catalyst systems for diesel cars, and won more than our fair share thanks to our excellent technology and R&D  teams.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: That investment has had high returns as Anna showed when describing ECT's results. It's worth talking  specifically about diesel here just for a minute. Diesel share of total production in Western Europe was 51% for  2016/2017. But this figure includes light commercial vehicles, which are likely to stay diesel for much longer.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: If we were to exclude these vans, the diesel share of cars was around 45%. As we all know, diesel shares  trended down gradually over the year. But recent trends have seen much sharper reductions. So, what are the  consumers moving to? For smaller engines, which of course have smaller catalyst systems and hence are of  lower value to us, the shift away from diesel has happened already.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: For larger cars, the move away from diesel is happening more slowly. Should consumers move away from large  diesel cars, it is highly likely at least in the medium term that they will move to gasoline cars instead. These will be  quite large cars and therefore they will have more valuable catalyst systems than the current smaller gasoline  ones. Firstly, because they are larger, but also as they're more likely to require gasoline particulate filters to  satisfy the requirements of Euro 6c under real world driving standards.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We have already started to evolve our R&D focus by putting more resources into systems for gasoline vehicles.  We have made some early business wins for new Euro 6c systems and I'm confident that we'll will win a similar  share in the gasoline market as we currently have today in the diesel market.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: The huge change in the environment in Europe recently has meant that we have had to introduce many new  products very quickly to satisfy our customers. This has stretched our R&D as well as manufacturing teams. We  have had to be very agile, learning quickly as requirements have changed rapidly. We've learned a huge amount  about our business during this period and this sets us up so well for the future in this fast moving world.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So what does all this mean for our business in Europe? In the medium term, our European light duty business will  continue to grow strongly, supported by new business wins in both diesel and gasoline, with these platforms  already secured, tighter legislation and the increased focus on tighter emissions from OEMs where they are  moving beyond the minimum regulatory requirements.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Outside of Europe, a recovery in the U.S. Class 8 truck market is expected to happen this year and the early  signs are encouraging. And our heavy duty diesel business across Europe and North America is expected to  perform well.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Looking to the long term, the importance of air quality remains a focus. We are investing today to make sure that  we have a flexible cost base and manufacturing footprint so that we can respond to changes in the external  environment very quickly and maximize the value of our business for shareholders.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Now, looking at our Asian business, which are currently around 20% of our Clean Air sector. This proportion will  grow over time given the growth potential ahead of us, particularly in China and India. We have great businesses  in both countries and are winning contracts with local manufacturers as well as our international customers too.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Moving on to our next sector, Efficient Natural Resources. The growing population and the need to use fewer of  the world's natural resources plays to our strengths. Key raw materials will come under greater pressure as  populations expand. And world energy consumption will increase by over a third between 2014 and 2035. This  sector is all about helping our customers make more efficient use of scarce natural resources including, of course,  JM ourselves as this sector supplies the rest of the group with a number of key raw materials and intermediates.  Jane Toogood will bring renewed focus across these markets, and we will think about this sector as a whole when  we consider our manufacturing footprint and where we spend our R&D.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: The chemicals market is relatively weak at the moment, particularly in new plant builds. But these markets will  come back once the surplus capacity that is available today is used up. And we have continued to invest in R&D  through the cycle to ensure we are well positioned when the recovery comes.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: On the other hand, our oil and gas business, if we exclude Diagnostic Services, is performing well. Jane has only  just taken over running this sector. Before then, she and her team have already done some great work in  improving the performance of our Precious Metal Products division. In particular, they've improved the  management for our PGM refineries and are focusing upon how we run them more efficiently. This is yielding  benefits as you can see in our results. In addition, our PGM manufacturing businesses continue their solid  performance.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: On to New Markets, looking firstly at our alternative powertrains business, which includes battery technologies  and fuel cells and, of course, aligns with our Clean Air focus. We have a strong position in high power LFP  materials and have broadened our portfolio this year into high energy nickel-rich materials. We acquired two  licenses in this space last summer and are actively developing new products. We are making good progress with  samples already taken to potential customers. And we have made faster progress than I had originally anticipated  given the deep understanding in Efficient Natural Resources of nickel-based chemistry. And we have reallocated  nearly 30 people from across the company to this area.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Also, our Fuel Cells business has seen significant improvement and is moving towards breakeven, which we  expect to achieve this year. In other potential new markets, we are looking into areas such as agrochemicals and  medical device components, both of which where we have existing market entry points. These also fit within our  overarching areas of focus.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Firstly, looking at R&D. We need to ensure that our R&D spend is driven by longer term market needs, insight  driven rather than spending too much in reactive short term customer need. You can see here that we've  increased our level of spending in Health over the last few years whilst constraining Efficient Natural Resources  for obvious reasons.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Beyond next year, growth will be stronger as the actions we are taking build on the improved momentum we are  seeing across our business and drive expansion and margins. Clean Air will remain a key growth driver over the  medium term driven by the need to enhance air quality, and we are evolving our business to ensure that we have  the right level of flexibility to adapt our business to the gradual evolution of the powertrain over time.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Our Efficient Natural Resources sector is well placed to take advantage of recovery in the chemicals market. As  you have heard, I'm excited by the prospects for our Health business and we continue to invest like we have  always done in potential new markets for the future, and in particular I am pleased with the progress we have  made this year in developing new high nickel battery materials.

file: JMATL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 31May2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Sales grew 7%, which was slightly ahead of our full-year guidance of 6% and an acceleration in the second half. It  was led by strong growth in Clean Air supported by continued growth in Efficient Natural Resources and Health.  And for the group, as a whole, I expect this strong momentum to continue into the next year.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: During the year, we've taken action to improve the quality and efficiency of our business, which has delivered cost  savings, which is also, in some cases, come with some additional cost in the short-term. I'll go into these in more  detail as I go through the sectors. But, for example, in Efficient Natural Resources, we've delivered cost savings  through restructuring to simplify our organization whilst incurring costs through improving our inventory  management and destocking. While in Health, we started to optimize our manufacturing footprint.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Clean Air performed strongly delivering sales growth of 9%, outperforming global vehicle production in both Light  and Heavy Duty in a year with minimal benefits from legislation. I'm pleased with the performance of our  European Light Duty business, which was flat for the full year. Here, we saw growth of 3% in the second half  having been down 3% in the first half. Growth in gasoline was ahead of our expectations, up 23%, with increasing  sales to customers with large and more complex platforms. It was offset by a 4% decline in diesel sales. The  diesel market was flat year-on-year and our sales declined due to lower pass-through substrate costs, which we  talked about at the half year.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We did not see the half two growth we expected in diesel as one customer slightly delayed a platform launch from  December to March, but we do remain on track to reach our 65% share of European Light Duty diesel vehicles by  March 2019. Our Light Duty business in both Asia and the Americas outperformed their respective markets.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Our Chinese business continue to grow strongly from a low base supported by strong growth in the Asian truck  market, the Chinese truck market, as it continues to adjust to the enforcement of the truck loading weight limits  though growth was lower in the second half. Our European Heavy Duty business also outperformed the 5%  growth in the market helped by the continued ramp up of our business wins. Margin in Clean Air was maintained  and operating profit grew in line with sales.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Efficient Natural Resources. Sales here were up 4% with good growth across the majority of the business. As  expected, within Catalyst Technologies, our licensing business was significantly down. Demand here is driven by  new plant builds, and that has been subdued. Licensing income has now reached the bottom. And while there are  early signs of improved activity in some markets in which we operate, we don't forecast the recovery in licensing  income in the near-term.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We also had various additional costs in the year associated with improving the efficiency of our business  principally in relation to destocking as we better manage our inventory. This more than offset the benefit of higher  precious metal prices, transactional FX, as well as the expected cost savings associated with the de-layering  across our business.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Looking at New Markets. LFP battery material sales continue to be lower impacting New Markets overall. This  was principally due to changes in electric vehicle tax incentives in China, which has led to the increased  substitution of LFP with high-energy materials. We continue to make really good progress in the development of  our next-generation ultra-high-density battery material, eLNO, and Robert will talk more about this later.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Precious metal working capital was higher throughout the year given the higher metal prices and reduced liquidity  in the market. In this environment, we held greater safety stock and our customers stored less metal with us, and  we saw an increase in refinery backlogs as customers sought to refine more scrap. We've made improvements in  our metal working capital cycle although this was not sufficient to offset the external pressures we faced.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We continue our disciplined investment to support future growth with CapEx of £217 million in the year. This was  below our previous guidance for two reasons. Firstly, lower-than-expected spend on our Clean Air plant in Poland  due to permitting delays; and secondly, more rigorous capital allocation across the group. For 2018 and 2019, I  continue to expect a significant increase in CapEx, up to £390 million, as we increase our CapEx on growth  projects.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Clean Air, we will invest in Poland and China. We will continue to invest in the Health pipeline and on our eLNO  demonstration and commercial plants. Spend on improving business systems continues with the first Go Live of  SAP scheduled for later this summer. This of course will be the trigger for us to start depreciating our investment.  And overall, we expect the group depreciation charge to increase next year by around £7 million.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Disciplined management of working capital. As I've talked to you about earlier, we've made significant  improvements in this area, and I'm really pleased with our progress. Increasing business-wide efficiency is  something that is delivering results across a number of the sectors already. And there's more to come over the  medium term as we start to see the benefits of the manufacturing optimization, the procurement program, and the  implementation of SAP. This will help us maintain our margins in Clean Air next year, the margin in Efficient  Natural Resources will improve, and Health margin expansion will take a little longer but will benefit from the  actions that we've taken on our manufacturing footprint.

texts.speaker: Anna Manz
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, moving to the overall outlook for the next year. For 2018-2019, we expect to deliver mid- to high-single-digit  growth at constant rates. This will be led by Clean Air, which will continue to be strong as diesel share comes  through in Light Duty Europe. We will deliver this group performance despite an increase in cost associated with  group efficiency programs, some of which sit in corporate costs and some of which are within the sectors. We will  see a stronger second half with our normal seasonality as well as Health being weighted to the second half as I  mentioned.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We deliver our strategy through our four sectors where we have clear visibility for sustained growth in Clean Air  where share gains in Europe and tighter legislation across the world will provide good growth while we navigate  the changing powertrain landscape. Focused investment and an improved business will allow our Efficient Natural  Resource sector to grow ahead of its markets and our focus on efficiency will enable profit to grow ahead of sales.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, now I'll move on to our progress by sector. And what we are showing here is how we are progressing against  the milestones we set out last year. Not all are green but on the whole, we're making huge strides in improving the  company to deliver what we promised.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Clean Air, we delivered our strategy through our global leadership working closely with our customers to meet  tightening legislation. For example, our agility and technical leadership enabled us to move quickly to serve our  customers at a key point in time when the market was going through a lot of change. This technical leadership  and agility was a key driver for the share gains we have made in Europe and continues to be one of our key  differentiators. And, of course, we have to have a highly-efficient manufacturing footprint behind this.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Firstly, on the share gains in European Light Duty diesel, we expect to gain around 20 percentage points of share  over the next year to reach around 65% share by the end of 2018-2019. It's worth talking here to the share of  diesel for the market as a whole in Europe. Our strategy for Clean Air, as set out on our Capital Markets Day,  assumes the decline in Western European Light Duty diesel sales to 25% in 2025. But looking at cars alone, that  equates to 20% in 2025.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In the last year, diesel sales of new cars in Western Europe declined from 49% to 42%. And in April, the first  month of our new year, diesel sales were just 37%. The current period of volatility has required the OEMs to  rapidly adjust their platform mix, but it's important to note that these recent trends are consistent with our  assumptions on diesel share. And you will have seen that we're also doing well in gasoline. We still expect to gain  around 5 percentage points in gasoline as the adoption of Euro 6c ramps up. The business we have won gives us  confidence that we will deliver these gains though they come through over time by 2021.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In addition to these, there are further value drivers, including good growth in Heavy Duty and significant growth in  both Light and the Heavy segments in India. So, good progress for Clean Air, reflecting the momentum for  delivery we have in this business. All of this delivers mid-single-digit CAGR sales growth over the next 10 years  while keeping margins broadly stable. On margins, I'm very pleased with the work that John and his team have  done on efficiencies plus procurement benefits will enable us to keep margins broadly stable next year, ahead of  our original expectations.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: In Efficient Natural Resources, we deliver our strategy through our leadership positions in almost all of our sub  segments, our target investment by segment and region, focused R&D in areas of high returns, and a continued  focus on efficiency. You can see here four key milestones that we're making good progress with more benefits to  follow as the work Jane is doing continues to improve the business.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: And we continue to look at additional opportunities within this space, looking at new and adjacent areas that can  benefit from our chemistry and technology. One example here is the work we've done on turning waste into  aviation fuel. Early days but this could be an interesting area for license and catalyst income in future years.  There are plenty of other examples, and we look forward to providing more updates in time.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, mainly green as we continue to improve the quality of our business. Some of the benefits from our actions  take a while to come through. In fact, some incur additional costs in the short run, but we're setting up the platform  for the medium and long-term. So we're on track in Efficient Natural Resources to deliver the sales and operating  growth we have promised.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So on to Battery Materials and our progress in developing and commercializing our next-generation eLNO  materials. I'll spend some time on this topic as it's such an exciting opportunity for us. I will update you on our  focus on the market for ultra-high energy density materials that will help enable the mass adoption of pure battery  electric vehicles and I'll provide some further evidence of the leading qualities of eLNO.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We're making good progress working with our customers and feedback continues to be excellent. We're also  progressing well with our scale-up plans. The board has approved the building of a 1,000-tonne demonstration  plant in the UK, and this is larger than we originally planned and should come on stream in late 2019. Our plans  for a full-scale commercial plant are also on track, and we're working towards full board approval this summer as  we previously outlined. And, of course, we're already thinking about capacity beyond our first plant, above 10,000  tonnes, though the detail on that will follow in time.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: eLNO is the next-generation material. It is beyond what's in the market today and will help enable the mass  adoption of pure battery electric vehicles. Most materials today end up in the mild to plug-in hybrids. We want to  help customers move to the next stage. The chart on the left illustrates how the market is moving to high-energy  densities. The current landscape is dominated by NMC 532, NMC 622 and NCA. eLNO competes against  materials not yet available in their markets including NMC 811 and advanced NCA. These form the ultra-high  energy density market.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: We've given on the right here some indication of the size of the market. By 2030, we expect the ultra-high energy  density market to be around 500,000 to 1.8 million tonnes per year amounting to around a third to two-thirds of  the total cathode market. This is our focus. We are not seeking entry into today's market. We could easily produce  a copycat product and move faster, but we are doing what JM does best, maximizing the value of our chemistry.  This should enable us to earn higher margins and returns.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: eLNO offers a step change in energy density over current materials and lower cobalt content. I know many of you  want more validation of its performance, and, obviously, we're limited in how much we can give you for  commercial reasons. So what we are showing you here today is the results of independent testing carried out for  us by Qinetiq. This shows the performance of eLNO compared with the current materials in the market and the  next generation materials. eLNO's relative performance improves when we look at cycle life and how it performs  over time, a key metric used by our customers. So, not only do we have the material with the highest energy  density today, but eLNO's performance continues for longer and helps enable a lower total cost over the useful  life. It is this overall performance that is attractive to our customers.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: Now throughout the sampling process, we will see sales as these are sizable quantities that we will be providing  to customers, and they are prepared to pay for that. Supporting all of this is the scale-up of our manufacturing  capability, including completing the expansion of our pilot plant this summer. And this will give us the capacity to  make up to 10 metric tons per year, building our demonstration scale plant which will be in the UK, and as I've  said, have 1,000 tonnes capacity, double the 500 tonnes that we originally intended, which should be completed  by late 2019.

texts.speaker: Robert James MacLeod
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Johnson Matthey Plc
texts.text: So, to recap on eLNO, we are focused on the ultra-high energy density market, a market that doesn't exist today,  but one that will be a key enabler of growth in the BEV market in the future. Customer testing and early validation  is progressing well. Our demonstration scale plant has been approved by the board and is on track. We are  progressing the commercial plant and formal approval is expected by the board this summer. And as I said, we're  building that in Europe and we're developing our plans beyond 10,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Alan Johnson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Jerónimo Martins SGPS SA
texts.text: The operating costs growth in the quarter reflect the significant increase in energy and fuel costs both in Portugal  and in Poland. And I should also mention that the significant activities in Poland, with the stores converted being  closed around two days, together with new store openings and the building of new distribution centers have  increased the operating cost ratio in the quarter, but we would expect the effects to reduce in the next two quarters  as we progress towards completing the store conversions.

texts.speaker: Alan Johnson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Jerónimo Martins SGPS SA
texts.text: We have noticed in recent months that many of our Portuguese suppliers of perishables were having problems in  accessing credit lines to finance their businesses. And this was putting pressure on their activities and, of course,  potentially on our own supply chain. So we decided that for a period of 12 months starting at the beginning of  May, we would accelerate payments to around 400 of these suppliers, reducing the payment term to ten days. This  will have an impact of between €80 million and €100 million on Pingo Doce's working capital. But we believe very  strongly that in these very difficult times, this is a necessary investment to protect the integrity and sustainability  of our supply chain and to support our critical suppliers.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Jerónimo Martins SGPS SA
texts.text: I will now conclude with our outlook for the year. In Poland, the environment is more challenging today than it  was a year ago, but it remains, in our view, a strong growth story which we have identified for Biedronka and this  story remains intact.

So we showed up from 89 to over  100 to 104 in the fourth quarter. But to the extent that we won’t see any kind of heavy floods or  heavy storms in the next period, that should be rather one-time phenomenon.

texts.speaker: Luc Popelier
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, KBC Group SA/NV
texts.text: We continue to look at our CDO exposure in an opportunistic way. texts.text: But let's go back to what we've been up to recently. On slide 5 I would like to talk to you briefly about one of our  main pillars of our story. That EP2002 is the best- seller product of ours, and faces little – very little competition in the market. And we improved this product by  including deceleration control systems delivering consistent break distances that is very important for manless  train operation and break disc temperature monitoring, which improves the vehicle availability even in case of a  fall. This is something that frequently happens, especially in fall conditions that the conductor gets the signal that  break disc is overheating in one of the wagons. And this can be now completely localized with EP2002 and the  train conductor can then continue its journey by adjusting the speed appropriately.

texts.speaker: Pekka Ilmari Lundmark
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Konecranes Oyj
texts.text: And there is another innovation, which actually comes from the elevator industry. We are using counterweights,  which make the load of each lift about 25% lighter. These counterweights balance the weight of the spreader,  which is the red device that you see there that holds the container. That's called spreader. And the counterweights  weigh as much as the spreader, which means that they eliminate each other, which means that we are lifting only  the weight of the container, not the weight of the spreader. And this eliminates about 25% of the load in every lift  and saves about 8% in the fuel cost, 8% saving in the fuel cost which is a significant operational saving to the  customer on top of the already attractive price for the product.

texts.speaker: Pekka Ilmari Lundmark
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Konecranes Oyj
texts.text: So we have innovated the product structure, the fuel consumption of the product and also the delivery concept,  and all of this now gives us a product which is targeted at the Asian mass markets, and of course mass markets in  the other emerging parts of the world as well. This is a market segment from which we have more or less been  absent from so far and we have quite high expectations for this product.

One more comment about the markets which is affecting especially component volumes  negatively is the Middle Eastern market, which is showing signs of weakness because of the low oil prices and that  is affecting the level of investments in the Middle East at the moment.

texts.speaker: Panu Routila
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Konecranes Oyj
texts.text: The growth was led by Business Area Port Solutions, which booked a significant order for the greenfield Hadarom  container terminal in Israel. As I discussed already in February, the order consists of a complete line of automated  container cranes and software intelligence, including our own terminal operating system and Equipment Control  System. The Hadarom project is a landmark case for Konecranes and demonstrates well our capabilities of our  Solutions business unit established already in last autumn.

texts.speaker: Pekka Ilmari Lundmark
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Konecranes Oyj
texts.text: The automation – automated container yard projects that we have done so far have all been greenfield projects  and the technology used in those automations has been so-called automated stacking cranes that where the cranes  are moving on rails. This changes the picture quite fundamentally because now this makes the benefits of  automation which, obviously, are operational cost savings and productivity in general and an increase in  predictability of the container moves and the safety of the container moves. Now all these benefits of automation  will become available to existing container yard operators as well. And we believe that many container yards will,  once the time comes for them to replace their RTGs on the container yard, when they come to the end of their  lifetime, and there's a lot of such RTGs out there, when they decide to replace them, they will consider  automation. So, this is the first in the world that Konecranes now introduced, the first time RTG automation  becomes a viable alternative.

texts.text: In general, if I comment, the effects of the oil price, the net effect to us is clearly positive. texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Municipal & Industrial segment revenue was at the level of last year. So, anyhow, also volumes here increased  not so much as in Paper, you now, and remember that especially municipal water business is quite stable and  there are not so big fluctuations in volumes. But, anyhow, EBIT went up by about 60% from €10 million-level to  close to €17 million, meaning also that the profitability improved a lot.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then Oil & Mining, in Q1, revenue increase was 22% with much higher volumes than last year and it came  basically from [ph] ore (07:58) drilling and oil and gas, chemicals and also metal industry as the customer  segment demand was higher. Just want to remind you that this segment is all about water, because we are selling  the same water chemicals that we are selling to other segments, so it's water business in our case. But very good  progress and demand is really picking up quickly.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Now when Tikkurila separated in late of March, so we are now really focused on water treatment business, we are  not fully yet that meaning that 75% of our business is water treatment business, and meaning that we are now  much, much more focused company to water than earlier.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Revenue certainly has declined to level of €2 billion. But then [ph] it's good to (10:47) understand that we have a  good growth options now in the future. And our vision is to be a leading water chemistry company.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Before I close, I would like to emphasis that the Kemira established in – during March new research and  development center called Center of Water Efficiency Excellence as we call it SWEET with VTT that is a research  institute here in Helsinki, and we will invest within next four years €120 million and try to really innovate something  totally new solutions for in water technology area. It is one of the most significant investments ever done in  environment of technology area in Finland, and it will occupy around 200 people per annum or continuously and I  hope that really it will also – this is not finally a four-year program, I hope that it can be continued and I'll also hope  that it will boost all environmental business here in Finland.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And the goal of this program is [ph] to gather to current (12:19) a bit fragmented water competencies together and  develop new unique competencies here that we can utilize globally and hopefully also open new – totally new  market and create new business opportunities. And this is totally aligned with our strategies, so that the organic  growth is the most important thing and this is a strong indication that we are really doing something also in  practice.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 3May2011 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Profit before tax reached close to €50 million, based on the fact that we had also lower financial  expenses and our titanium dioxide joint venture with Rockwood called Sachtleben improved also  during Q1 their result, meaning that these three issues: operative EBIT, financial expenses and  income from JV Sachtleben, were the main reasons that we had a very good profit before tax.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number five demonstrates the different reporting segments profitability, development plus the  Kemira Group, indicating that when we started this Kemira’s Water Strategy in 2008, we had pretty  low EBIT percentage, 3.3%, and it has been every year increasing reaching now the level of 8%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Paper segment has improved a lot as well; also Oil & Mining. That is certainly [ph] a Water  Treatment (4:34) business and most of the Paper segment business and Municipal & Industrial  segments stayed at the level of Q4 2010 profit, meaning profitability. I will come back a little bit later  in more detail.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Before I go to this short segment presentation, I would like to summarize these main activities  during last – during Q1. We opened new research and development center in Brazil and the target  really is to look at biomass, bio-refineries and bioethanol issues and research programs, but it’s  also an essential part of our SWEET program that we call this Center of Water Efficiency  Excellence. So it’s an important and significant step forward in developing South American market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So in that way, the conditions still look quite okay. Demand should continue, but we have, of  course, risks, especially, again, this raw material prices that I think we [ph] patterned (13:10) very  well in Q1. We need to fight every every day because Q2, there are of course risks now depending  on where the – like oil is moving, yesterday it came down a bit, but it has stayed at a very high  level. That certainly is the biggest risk for Kemira, as for any company.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For Kemira, the high energy and oil price also has some positive impact like that when energy  prices are high we are benefiting with oil and gas production and oil and gas production goes  through resources that are more difficult to capture and also to new countries, new areas that I see  that it will benefit, certainly Kemira.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: There are many industries that we are serving in water treatment business like food and beverage,  sugar and so on. In those customer segments we estimate that they will certainly very much be in  line with economic situation globally, it looks still be more positive in this year. And in municipal and  city the demand is stable, predictable and there should not be big surprises.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In this point, I would like to remind you that when Kemira is focusing on water and we are following  the same phenomenon in every customer, industry, and including municipalities, we are in raw  water and drinking water treatment, wastewater treatment and certainly in selected industrial  customers in their cleaning and reusing their processed waters. Meaning that we have a little bit  more than 75% of our business is water treatment, synergistics business and there is this others  like specialty chemicals is not bad, and part of the Paper segment but the rest of the business are  water business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: There are still two slides where I would like to end up this presentation. Certainly, our business in  long-term will be very much driven by megatrends. If you look at water, so world population in 2050  is estimated to be slightly over nine billion people, which means that there will be 100% increase in  water both in urban and industrial use. The same 100% increase is estimated to be also in energy  demand. So it means a lot of possibilities for Kemira Global.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And if you look at the last slide, so if I start and continue with saying that profit continues to grow on  water and energy demand is certainly driving business opportunities for Kemira. We are not in  every place – perhaps we are not – never to ever be, but there are many industrial segments that  Kemira has not yet penetrated but could be. What we have done now during two-and-half year  period of running this water strategy, we have developed strong balance sheet, giving flexibility  over different strategic options and good market position that we can demonstrate that we have that  based on Q1 result. We are building new competent space, and in long term the corporate culture  is the most important and critical. That’s why we are establishing values.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: So we have a massive program to run the profitability improvement. And when we are doing that,  we certainly can look at growth where very strategic element is this program called SWEET where  we build up new competencies around water chemistry, new applications, new products, new spin- offs. We are looking at how to develop and penetrate more in emerging markets and we certainly  should more localize business there, like in Asia, like in South America, to be able to grow in  profitable way. But I think that we have now good elements in place and our Q1 result indicates that  we are in good way to step-wise go towards our vision.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 24April2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Paper and Oil & Mining were performing well. The M&I market was weaker than anticipated, so M&I was well  below our expectation. And ChemSolutions was slightly falling short due to a too warm weather, so the deicing  season was lower than our anticipation. That is in a nutshell where we are standing; details will be later on shown  by Jyrki Mäki-Kala, our CFO.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I want to give you now a little bit of guidance, what based on these results our plans are, where we are heading,  and what we are going to do. Our water strategy is a unique strategy in the industry, and this is something we  employees which have a unique vision how this water strategy can be developed, and that is a real competitive  advantage and a differentiator in the market which we want to embark on.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And thirdly, we want to further sharpen our strategy in a way that we get to a proper roadmap, including  comparable resources, in order to in a faster and more accelerated way develop our water strategy and ultimately  our position. So these are the three pillars which we want to deal with in the near future and we want to align our  organization along and towards these three pillars.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Why is APAC, and to a certain extent South America, so relevant? If you look to the distribution of the water  market, which accounts for some €28 billion in 2010, you already today see that the European part is smaller than  APAC. So even in 2010, APAC accounts for a bigger water market. And going forward, the growth in APAC is  substantially higher than the growth in Europe. So in other words, the relevance of the Asian market for water is  growing year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also have topics like lake restoration, which is not that much an issue in Europe and in United States. We have  already some good experience in South America, where we are currently engaged in lake restoration projects. But  this is getting a very big issue also in Asia, in particular in the Peoples Republic of China, and we want to benefit  from this upcoming and developing market.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In a nutshell, when it comes to strategy, we are focusing on three strategic pillars when it comes to water. The one  segment. We will continue to out-branch from United States, where we have meanwhile a very good position, and  particularly in shale gas.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: There was always a discussion on ChemSolutions. Here you see the development of ChemSolutions.  ChemSolutions consists mainly of the three sub-segments, chemicals and pharmaceuticals, it's the feed and food  industry, as well as deicing.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Clearly, in this business we are focusing on different industries and we have to understand even better the  dynamics of these industries. And clearly, we have to think about how we are budgeting going forward the de-icing  business, because you might recall that also Q4 2011 was much weaker than expected due to the weather. So that  is something we're going forward. We might see a change that the relevance of de-icing in that part of Kemira will  slow down over the time.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And the reason why it went up are the changes in the fair values of our electricity forward contracts, and that's  basically so-called mathematical issue, because that has to the do with the fact that the system price in the Nordic  markets, meaning the average price in Norway, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Estonia, is much lower than the local  price here in Finland.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And that's just mainly due to the fact that we don't get enough electricity from Sweden at the moment because of  the transmission line is broken. So that's just issue that we have the physical deliveries of electricity going forward,  and they are based on the Finnish market price very efficient. But when looking for the system price, they are not  efficient. So that makes the €4.6 million difference basically in our financial expenses.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This graph is about on annual basis always 12-month rolling figures behind how we have developed our sales  prices, meaning the green graph and then – green line, and then the blue one is corresponding how the raw  material prices has developed. You'll see that on a yearly basis the swings are quite a lot and quite a big one from  €100 million minus to €100 million positive.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And currently, we are in the phase that our sales prices are in very good level compared to raw material prices. So  that's why, for example, our margin level, gross margin is better than last year, very clearly coming out of this  graph. The raw material prices, certainly, basically grow for Kemira.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If we go briefly through the three – this time four segments. Starting with the Paper segment, the graph that was  earlier shown is that Paper segment has done a lot of thing in their business, reaching 8.6% EBIT margin this  quarter with higher sales prices, slightly lower volumes basically globally. And of course, affecting in the sales line  is the divestment we made last November in Maitland with the hydrogen peroxide.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining then, like mentioned, the best quarter performance in their roughly four years historical impact. We  had certain issues with the low margin contracts that we give up. So actually behind the sales growth is 8% sales  growth when we take this into account. So it's again closer to the double-digit growth that this business has been  doing the last years, very favorable pricing in the background. But like mentioned earlier, little bit careful how the  raw material prices will change going forward.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 23April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining was disappointing. The overall and underlying strategy is correct, but nevertheless, revenues  decreased by roughly 10% to €76 million. 4% of that was attributable to exited business. We have guided last year  that we want to exit another €10 million in 2013, and then the exiting of underperforming businesses is  accomplished. The rest is largely to a very weak market demand in the mining industry because the global mining  industry is still very, very depressed.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: On the other hand, we saw an upswing in polymer demand, the gas prices in the United States has come up. We  see an increasing demand for polymers for the oil and gas production. So from that point of view, some positive  signals, but overall in the first quarter the negative signals were still dominating the performance of the segment.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: A major impact was the raw material prices, because our offering to the market in Oil & Mining is largely polymers  and from that point of view, we are highly depending on propylene and ethylene as the key raw materials and their  prices as I said were going up tremendously still in Q1. Fortunately, that has now changed and we start to see a  relief. Operative margin was 6.7%, after 9.8% a year earlier.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The growth drivers of Kemira going forward will be Paper and Oil & Mining. The water business is supposed to  substantially improve profitability and generate cash in line with disappointing market potentials in the emerging  markets. The ChemSolutions business remains non-core and is clearly supposed to go and optimize profitability  as well as cash. So in other words, we have two growth businesses and two cash-driven businesses going forward.  We believe and we want to grow above the market as Kemira in general, and we are convinced that Paper, as well  as Oil & Mining allow us short-term, mid-term and long-term with above-the-market growth.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining will focus besides the mature markets on largely Argentina and Brazil when it comes to oil and gas as  well as Chile and Peru. You will have more details from Randy Owens later on and it will focus on Africa when it  comes to mining.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have clustered the time horizon until 2020 into four different categories. We are currently still in the redesign  phase and the redesign phase is largely accomplished by the end of 2013. Fit for Growth is one element. However,  as a consequence of the strategy and the assessment of where our future needs are, as part of the redesign phase,  we also have announced today that we are planning to enter into co-determination negotiations with respect to  our paper chemicals site in Vaasa, Finland, because we do not see that this site is needed in the long run of the  paper chemicals business.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This is a way of looking into Kemira in the future. If you look to this picture, it's a little bit more loaded on the left- hand side than it is on the right-hand side. This is on purpose. So it's not a big mistake or an unfavorable way of  drawing. Process chemicals play a much stronger role in Kemira going forward. So the industrial part of the  company, Pulp & Paper, Oil & Mining, plays a much stronger role than what it did in the past. And the traditional  water treatment business, be it drinking water or being municipal wastewater treatment is less important in  comparison to the other industrial segments.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So in a nutshell, we are rebalancing Kemira from a very strong focus on drinking water, water purification into  making Kemira an important partner of our customers when it comes to raw materials, water and energy  efficiency. We believe that we have the capabilities; we believe that we have the products to contribute to the  chosen industry in the short, mid and long-term with our innovation capabilities as well as with our existing  portfolio. We, of course, also play in the industrial part of water cleaning, water treatment, because in the  industrial business, water reuse is a very important part as part of the efficiency of individual technologies.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Water reuse in the municipal area is rather at a distance, you might have heard that there are some attempts in  Singapore, but the so-called new water is more a marketing aspect at this point in time than a real approach.  Again, we're monitoring how the markets for municipal water treatment and for drinking water preparation are  developing; if the emerging markets put respective legislations in place, if the potential comes we are there, but  you clearly see that there is a stronger focus on the industrial processes going forward.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So we have made clear choices.
