We've nailed them down and with this, we believe that by 2016, we're able to grow  our share in the emerging markets from 14% to 16%, and then depending especially what the market for water  treatment chemicals is doing and how it is developing thereafter, we will see what's happening there.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: A similar success we have in Oil & Mining, when we are talking about friction reduction, there we also have  launched quite a substantial portfolio in order to help the industry to save energy. Friction reducers are making  liquids more fluid and from that point of view reduce the required pressure which is otherwise provided by  pressure trucks in a CapEx-intensive approach at every well.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Without going into too much details, we also were successful in launching the first product for customer trials. We  are not yet in the commercialization for wet shale and we hope that by year's end, the customer trials have been  successful so that we then are not just depending on shale gas, but we also then will have competitive non-guar- derived products for wet shale applications, but if there are questions, Randy Owens can give more details.

texts.speaker: Petri Olavi Helsky
texts.profession: President-Paper Segment & EMEA Region, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If we then have a look at some of the trends in pulp and paper industry, if you look at the bullet points there,  increased use of recycled fiber, hardwood becoming evermore important in the total mix of the pulp. It does not  mean that the long fiber would by no means be diminishing, but relatively speaking, the hardwood becomes bigger  component. Third bullet is being about lightweighting of packaging and board grades, but including in fact the  paper grade and higher filler loads in graphic papers. They all have to do with the need then to improve the  strength properties or the material by some other means. And those you can only affect by adding chemicals. And  we, as Kemira, we really are very well positioned in both strength and sizing chemicals which are the ones growing  the fastest.

texts.speaker: Randy Owens
texts.profession: President, Segment Oil & Mining and Region NAFTA, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So let's jump directly into the presentation. This is a look at the market size overall in our total product line  basket. We see the market growing at a CAGR of 4.7%. These are all – we've discussed this before. Of course, high  oil price, also this global growth of shale, not only it started out in its infancy in dry gas and now it's moving to wet  gas, it creates another area for innovation that we want to look at.

texts.speaker: Randy Owens
texts.profession: President, Segment Oil & Mining and Region NAFTA, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The same holds for these declining reserves. As reserves decline, more and more water is used and that's where  our differentiated chemistries come in. And then, of course, environmental pressure and that's whether you're in  the North Sea or your mining operation or you're really operating around the world, there's more pressure on not  only how do you deal with water, but then how much water you're consuming and using. And so, all of that will  drive these chemistries that we have in our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Randy Owens
texts.profession: President, Segment Oil & Mining and Region NAFTA, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And this is – this is the element of differentiated products. As Wolfgang said, we're now opening those up to you,  and this is the history since 2010 with differentiated chemistries in oil and gas, and this is where we've been  putting our focus. We've talked to you in the past about different commodity-type products that we've been  exiting, but this is where we're spending our energy. And we've had a nice track record, roughly double what the  market's been growing in this area. It's roughly around €250 million of turnover in 2012. But the key there is that  this is where we're going to make our innovation moves and that's why we're expecting to see faster growth in this  area.

texts.speaker: Randy Owens
texts.profession: President, Segment Oil & Mining and Region NAFTA, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Some of the examples I have here before you – I won't go through too deeply into the slide, but innovation in this  – in these differentiated chemistries, we are targeting €100 million in 2016. And we've got lots of opportunities to  see that through. For instance, in the antiscalant areas for stimulation and production, we're there helping these  operators reduce their cost. We're helping them keep their wells extended, extend the life of those wells so they  don't have to go in and re-treat and clean out. All of that is an example of where they're willing to pay if you can  help them keep their production up.

texts.speaker: Randy Owens
texts.profession: President, Segment Oil & Mining and Region NAFTA, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Of course, we're very active in the hydraulic fracturing world. We see numerous examples now where we're able to  save our customers with the amount of trucking and disposal cost that's required in order to fracture a well. It's a  very logistic-intensive process where you need massive amounts of water. You have to get that water to the site.  You also have to get other things such as sand and proppants. And anything we can we can do to minimize the  energy associated with that or reduce their logistics cost or help them consume more of the water that's there on  site, again another example of their willing to pay for that benefit.

texts.speaker: Randy Owens
texts.profession: President, Segment Oil & Mining and Region NAFTA, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And then also in this declining ores, iron ore, very classic example, the reserves are declining. And the miners are  moving with more impurities in the iron ore. And we're there to help them find their techniques so that they could  use this lower-grade ore and be able to push that into the market.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Let's talk a little bit on the turnaround in M&I. We have a broad and proven portfolio of commodity products for  basic water and industrial water treatment, as well as for sludge treatment, its polymers largely and its coagulants.  Ongoing structural profitability improvement is underway, but needs to be taken even further and measures to  achieve that is the asset footprint, rationalization which is part of Fit for Growth, but it's also customer base and  process optimization. This is what is now part of the turnaround story in order to get M&I back to the profitability  levels we had years ago.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I think this is a very important picture because the business with Municipal & Industrial, and largely with  Municipal is a rather cyclical business. And from that point of view, if you compare basically Q1 2013, we made  substantial progress in comparison to the first quarter of 2012. The business is ramping up in the course of the  summer and autumn, and then when it's getting cold again and when snow falls, then in the winter, the last  quarter, the business is deteriorating again simply because the volume demand is lower. So this is the nature of  the business. And we opened that for you in order to make you better understand what quarter to compare with  what quarter.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So if you look what we are doing, Fit for Growth will bring us to roughly 9%. That's the closure of nine sites, two  production plants and still one site being under review. We have reduced manufacturing costs, we have harvested  energy synergies, and we have disposed underperforming businesses. As part of our new strategy, we are also  moving out of India because we do not see any opportunity at this point in the water business to generate profits  in India.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In order to get to above 10%, additional measures are required which you see on the right-hand side. It's enhanced  customer-to-plant allocation to optimize logistics costs in a given coagulants manufacturing network. It's a  continuous site optimization approach. It is the disposal of underperforming product lines which historically have  been part of that business but are not really relevant for a successful operation of either a municipal or an  industrial wastewater treatment plant. An R&D focus which is in line with the strategy and new service levels to  customers who are willing to pay. We've put a customer segmentation project to life and that will help us to align  our services very much with respect to the needs and the readiness to pay of the individual customers. These  measures will ultimately then lift us in the course of 2013 with a full run rate of 2014 to above [ph] E10 (1:10:50)  with M&I. Again, this is a turnaround story. We are getting there and new management will be responsible to  make it happen.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Our statement so far, water is the connection, is not strong enough to support and to embrace Kemira's new  strategy. That's why we decided to change our statement from 'Water is the connection' to 'Where water meets  chemistry' because this is in the repositioned Kemira what it's all about. Water and chemistry are an indirection,  be it in the drilling well, be it in the wastewater treatment after drilling, be it in the paper machine, be it in M&I,  it's water and chemistry meeting together and jointly developing benefits for the customer.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 23April2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. With the divestment of our formic acid business, which closed on March  6,  2014, we accomplished transformation of Kemira into a water pure play. The formic acid business was also the  biggest swing factor when you compare Q1 2013 with Q1 2014 because we had a very strong de -icing season in the  winter 2013, but we had literally no de-icing season in 2014. And it has an impact on our reported figures.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We will see growth clearly in Oil & Mining also in the coming quarters. This business is back on track, and we also  have now appointed the new president for the Oil & Mining segment. The release came out this morning, and we  have hired on purpose an industry expert. I will elaborate on that later on in more detail.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: If you look to the Paper part in a breakdown, clearly, the two major pillars which we already have attributed and  referred to in the past are the pulp business, where we have bleaching chemicals for the pulping process with a  strong focus on Europe, North America and South America, and growth coming largely from South America,  depending on our success in participating in new pulp mills, which ask for on-site establishment of the respective  bleaching chemical facilities.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: What you can see here is the breakdown of our Oil & Mining business. Clearly, the mining business remains  challenging. We have discussed that a couple of times. The minerals' prices are depressed and the  RBU minerals  and metals contributes approximately 20% of our sales at this point in time. And the growth is clearly driven by  polymers, which are sold by the RBU oil and gas. That's where the market dynamics comes from and that's where  the growth is coming from. And we are not seeing any change in the future from this pattern. We are not expecting  a major recovery of the mining business in the immediate future.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The big step for us in Oil & Mining as the next major target is now to move into EOR. We successfully managed to  get from dry shale into wet shale. We are now well positioned in those types of fracking technologies. And the next  step is now to go into enhanced oil recovery, which is starting to make bigger inroads in various geographies. And  this is clearly something we have earmarked to be. And the 3F acquisition allows us, from a manufacturing and  from a product position point of view, to actively participate in that business. And that will be the next major  growth driver for our oil and gas business.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, in order to support this, we obviously were carefully selecting the new President for Oil & Mining. And we  decided not to go for somebody from our peers or from internal. We hired somebody from the customer industry.  And Tarjei Johansen, who will join us on May 5, has an extensive experience with Schlumberger, which is  amongst the largest operators in the oil and gas space.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And now, we are about 45% differentiated products versus 55% commodity. If you actually take into account the  last piece of the formic acid down here, down in the picture, we are both balanced, we're bo th 50-50 in – between  differentiated and commodity products. So, well in our way towards the targeted 60% in differentiated versus 40%  of commodity products.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: When we look at the raw material pricing environment, we see a fairly stable environment. There were some  impacts that were against us, but that's largely offset by other raw material impacts that were working for us. So,  no big changes there. The 3F synergies in terms of us being more backward-integrated now are coming back and  helping us in the raw material prices.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In Oil & Mining, sales volumes, as well as the 3F acquisition is now driving growth. And the 21% organic growth –  I'm sorry, 21% reported growth was actually more than 30% in North America in dollar terms. So clearly, this is a  result of increased activity. So, when we watch and everybody else in the industry watches the key indicators, the  oil rig and the gas rig counts, we see that there is actually increased activity in the drilling and stimulation, and we  have been able to participate in it.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And in Europe, which is 7 0% of the business, profitability improvements continue as we are getting more efficient  in our operations. Having said that, we still continue to have some challenges with our business in North America,  to a tune that is it has been a bit disappointing, combined with a kind of a normal seasonal pattern that we see  particularly in North America. And this year actually amplified by the very dry weather or dry weather season in  California. So, our North America was somewhat of a – or quite a bit of a disappointment to us. Having said that,  still, operating margin improved for the [ph] fifth (23:20) quarter in a row.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And here, the key components are really the – either the closure or the selling of some 20 plants or facilities  within the last year-and-a-half or so. And in general, better asset efficiency. Like I said, this is a key metric that we  will be watching. And we expect that we will be seeing some further improvement in this r atio in the coming  quarters.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 24April2015 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: All right. Thank you, Tero. Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, on my behalf also, ready to report. Our first quarter  went according to plan. We knew we were getting into a different environment looking at currency exchange rates  and oil price situation. But regardless of that, the entire group went according to plan. Let's look at a bit more  detail how it went.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our revenue in the first quarter was €553 million compared to €530 million last year. And our volume decline in  Oil & Mining or especially oil and gas products was offset by the growth in our Paper segment. Favorable currency  exchange impact obviously helped us, but it also had some negative impacts. And in the €530 million last year, we  had about €20 million of the formic acid business in there. So the comparable number is actually €510 million.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our operative EBITDA was a bit over €66 million compared to a bit over €57 million last year, nicely up 15%.  Obviously, variable costs were affected by some of the raw materials that are oil related, but from the raw  materials there a mixed bag also, [ph] not of – (2:02) everything is positive. Also, the lower raw material prices  affected our top line, meaning, there is some pressure on sales prices as also our competitors enjoy the same raw  prices.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The construction work for the chlorate plant in Brazil for Klabin new pulp mill is ongoing and it's going per  expectations. We are looking to start the ramp-up next year, first half of next year or middle of next year  depending on how the customer project proceeds. And again, we get a component that's contributing into growth  and profitability.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lower oil prices obviously impacted demand in Oil & Mining segment. However, we do have the U.S. dollar  compensating that because lot of the Oil & Mining business comes from North America or U.S. dollar- denominated countries. We did have help to the polymer prices from the lower raw material prices. However, on  all segments, as said in the last quarter reporting, we don't expect that tailwind to last too long because all of our  competition in the market knows this. Obviously, we'll try to retain as much as we can, but that's where the  situation is.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, uncertainty around the U.S. shale operations is expected to continue. You're well aware of the rig count, which  is in the blue curve – dark blue curve there, has come down quite rapidly over the first months. And also the WTI  grade oil has come down, has it now bottomed remains to be seen. In this picture, it's slightly coming up  nowadays.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Less than half of our Oil & Mining segment revenue comes from the shale business. The currency is obviously  helping us; the raw materials are helping us a bit. But what we can see now is that, as the oil companies also in  traditional drilling and seeking for new fields have deferred their investment plans, I think the announcements are  between €80 billion and €100 billion already, and they are focusing more on their existing oilfields.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, we have seen a lot more chemical EOR opportunities coming up. Those are not short term, but those are kind  of investments from the customer where they will exploit more oil from where they know there is oil. And so, that  can come up. And typically also, those type of cases are such that they start the polymer floods, they will see one  year or two year down the road only being increased of production from those fields.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So we've been told by the customers that they're not looking at short-term oil price development. They're looking  rather a year, two or three down the road. And they seem to be confident that this oil price level will normalize. So  we are in increasing our sales and marketing efforts cooperation with those customers and also our R&D efforts  there.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also, I'd like to point out that the rig count is a [ph] drop (7:44) of active rig counts. They haven't been  demolished. They haven't gone away. They're in a parking lot somewhere. Most of our revenue comes from the  fracking in the shale fields, so we get some from the drilling phase, which is this rig count, and then we get from  the fracking phase a larger part of [ph] our things (8:02). And as you've been reading the news, the backlog of  fracked holes are going up. Some estimates are between 3,000 and 5,000 holes that have not refractured yet. And  once that starts again, that's a business opportunity for us. So let's see how that develops and how that goes  forward. We do see it challenging to grow the business this year, but midterm to long term, we still think the  fundamentals are good for our oil and gas business.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also see the operating leverage start to come through with a stronger EBITDA margin from that development.  So M&I is delivering on its role in the strategy of cash generation and steady operation to finance our other  investments into pulp and paper, and eventually into oil and mining, when we see that situation turn. Our paper  segment continues on the track, 4% organic growth and we're pleased on that. We are looking to close the  AkzoNobel deal and pushing our ongoing investments forward. Oil and mining is obviously now suffering from  the drastic drop on the oil price, but we see that , that trend should change in the coming quarters and then  normalize and demand coming back. The overcapacity in oil production is not that great. So, it should balance  itself out, but this year we don't see a huge growth opportunity in there. So all in all, I am quite pleased on how our  first quarter went for the group.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: EPS, earnings per share if one compares to last year first quarter, one has to note that the Q1 in 2014 included the  €37 million gain from the sale of the formic acid business.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So then drilling deeper, so paper segment organic growth was at 4%, oil and mining 11% negative, driven by the  really – the more fast decline in the shale activity in North America whereas Municipal and Industrial revenues  were roughly flat. There was some volume increase, but that was offset by price. So 8% currency impact clearly  more than offset the impact of the 4% coming from – that we lost due to the formic acid business.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Next, I'll focus a little bit more on the raw materials and the impact of what has happened from the oil-based raw  materials. So again, you have seen these charts before. So some 30% of our raw materials of variable costs are  [indiscernible] (16:37) correctly, meaning they are formula based or indirectly linked into oil price and, there, we  clearly have seen the benefit of – of Q1 – in Q2 and Q1 compared to Q3, even Q4, so consequently, that alone,  comparing to year-ago levels. And this raw material benefit is really impacting our polymer business mostly. So it  has the margin uplift mostly for oil and mining, as well as Municipal and Industrial.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Paper segment, the picture is a lot more mixed like Jari was referring to. Some of the base chemicals like chlorine,  caustic soda, hydrochloric acid, they actually have – there's tightness, at least regionally, if not globally. And so,  the Paper segment has not really benefited of the margin uplift in the same way as the – as the other two segments  have.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Final message on the CapEx, regarding our polymer expansion plans, which we have talked about in the past, we  continue to be careful and carefully review those opportunities, those decisions in light of the today's sort of  market pricing the oil and gas. But as Jari said, we remain optimistic and see the opportunities in mid- to long- term in that [indiscernible] (20:11) business area as well.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 26April2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Thank you, Olli. Good morning, everyone. Our first quarter started as expected. No major changes in FX or raw  material prices. Obviously, changes year-on-year, but I am more thinking of previous quarters. So steady  development. Oil price during the quarter obviously stayed low with the bottoms of $28. And that has an  improvement effect to our raw materials, but a basic effect to our Oil & Mining, especially shale business.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The Pulp & Paper segment had a rather good start for the beginning of the year, with improved growth 15%  without acquisitions and 3% organic growth. Municipal & Industrial, steady continuation. So we can see the Q4  was not the representative quarter as we said in the beginning of the year. Oil & Mining took actions to mitigate –  dramatically changed the market conditions, but still keeping a focus on the longer-term perspective. And we  started in the beginning of the March, the Klabin Ortigueira new chlorides plant in Brazil. And as planned, it's been  under construction for two years. It's ramping up with the ramp-up of the customer site, but we completed the  project in budget and without injuries and on planned time.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So let's look at how first quarter went. Revenues up 5% to €583 million. And growth was driven by acquisitions.  However, Pulp & Paper had 3% organic growth, which is double the market; 15% growth in Pulp & Paper with the  acquisitions. Oil & Mining, we can see the dramatic change from last year quarter one, where we really didn't see  any effect of the new dropping oil price environment. Municipal & Industrial, 1% organic growth; volumes grew  about 3%. So development there quite good. Raw material prices affected our top line.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In Oil & Mining, the adverse market conditions continued. We were able to mitigate the cost base and we really  look after cost discipline. We are protecting existing business. And we are investing into new application in putting  marketing and efforts in R&D into that, meaning, oil sands and EOR applications.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also are looking after our structures. And last year we said we closed one plant called Longview in Northwest  U.S. That's now closed in March and that fixed cost is out. We also announced that we are investigating how we  can bring efficiencies to our Netherlands plant, which is quite a big plant. And we will do some automation  modernizations there and upgrade our existing AMD technology to a bio-based technology. This will bring  efficiencies. We have works council discussions ongoing. So it will lead to some headcounts, but those are  ongoing. So we will conclude those during Q2.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In M&I, delivered a good execution from EMEA. We still have some pockets buckets that we can improve in  EMEA. Also good performance in APAC, but I have to remind you that APAC base business is still rather small  compared to Europe. In North America, we continue to react to the adverse development when we lost one key  supplier by them surprisingly closing down a titanium oxide plant late last year. That will take still in Q2 and part of  Q3 to react to that. So besides in North America, I'm quite pleased with M&I performance.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In M&I, we also continue to look at our footprint. In Q4, we informed that we will be closing a plant in Northern  Spain. This has been in the planning for long time as our HCL supply there will end as a plastics 53 manufacturer  will close down their plant. So that's not a surprise; that's been in planning. But now in Q1, we also will do some  consolidation of footprint in Canada. And in Ottawa, we will close a coagulant plant and consolidate it to another  plant. Those capacities which is – other plant is 150 kilometers away.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Now, this is a bit of an update. No major changes in the business outlook long term. Global megatrends continue  to support our business, and growth drivers still remain the same. But when you look at the growth estimates to  2020, we have now updated this from last year. Again, no huge movements, but a bit coming down, partly coming  down because of the raw materials coming down. So that will affect the top line of the industry. So, therefore, in  all areas coming down. And obviously this Oil & Mining situation or oil and gas situation and the deferred  investments from the industry will not bring that growth as we predicted. But as you can see, we're talking over  €10 billion market. So our market share is rather small. So we have definitely room to work with.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So all-in-all, we are working and advancing to be the first choice in chemistry for water intensive industries. And  we are growing organically, granted oil and gas is hindering back, but two of the other segments, 85%, 87% of our  revenue is growing organically. And we are executing diligently the acquisition integrations that are in the pipeline.  So we continue to improve profitability through leveraging the growth and the margin coming in with tight cost  control and capturing synergies from the acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So very strong momentum in the segment. However, I like to caution that in Q2, we will have a number of our own  sites going under maintenance break. So five of our main lines impact, mainly chlorides and even peroxide  business will undergo maintenance shutdowns, which are typically above a week – actually some are even longer  than a week. So those will have some impact in Q2. So perhaps don't take a ruler from the chart on the right.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then moving onto Municipal & Industrial, very strong performance in Europe; struggles in North America. As we  said in after Q4, most of that difficulties were caused by the supply chain disruption when one of the titanium  dioxide producers closed a plant and we lost site stream or the byproduct stream from the plant. And we needed  to replace that with another stream. And that's sort of a transition, it's taking some time. The situation is month-by- month improving. But as we said, after Q4, there was impacts still in Q1 and there may be some impact in Q2 as  well. But we are moving better direction month-by-month.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I think now when you look at it, one has to be sort of careful, now we are starting to see signs that this trend will  be reversing. We've seen oil price recover from the lowest of – that it touched on February. And if this trend  continues, we'll see some recovery in raw material prices, probably, impacting the second half of the year. Not so  much in – I wouldn't be so much worried about Q2 impact yet, but there will be some impact in second half of the  year. That's our expectation.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I took a deep dive on electricity this time. So electricity is some 15% of our input cost or our variable costs. And  about half of that in Finland. And about half we get from the TVO- and PVO-owned assets, or assets that we own  in PVO. And the other hand is sourced from the market. And this is just an example or illustration of how the  electricity prices have developed over the last couple of years. So this is a particular forward. I think it's 18  delivery forward. But it shows how the market over the last couple of years has come down. And this is a forward  market that goes over next five years or so. And we are actually participating in that. But it also shows that even in  Q1 the electricity prices have come down, another almost €5 per megawatt, which is significant.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Obviously helps us, because electricity is big input costs. It helps with a latch. We don't buy so much on spot; we  buy typically forwards, even the open position. But it helps with a lag. But it has an impact, which I mentioned in  my opening that we revalued our electricity assets in other shares of TVO and PVO.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 26April2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Tightness especially ethylene and propylene, our base products, which we do not buy directly but are raw  materials to our suppliers, they increased clearly; but we will elaborate that a bit more later. And last February, we  said that that we're not worried about oil-related products. But now, oil price has been flat, but ethylene and  propylene has come up quite a bit.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Largest investments in Pulp & Paper area are going well. The new bleaching plant in Brazil for Klabin is now  running well and our expansion in Finland for bleaching chemicals in Joutseno, the project is proceeding on time  and budget, and we'll be up and running during the fourth quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Mining, especially the fracking activity has really rebounded. When you look at the rig count, which is an  indirect indicator, that's been in line and our volumes have doubled from the bottom now, and profitability is still  under pressure. The ethylene-propylene hits Oil & Mining polymers which is most of the products that are being  sold in this business, so that's still there but pricing is clearly still below and we have now increased price  increases.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil sands is a positive development, we've been able to grow that business in Canada and in the CEOR, we do  have field trials ongoing with one major player, and as before we cannot comment this too much, but things are  proceeding well in that test run.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Municipal & Industrial, solid performance. Some issues there also Huntsman issues hits this area. Volumes grew  3% which is good and prices are specially on the polymer side, below last year. We have introduced price  increase. This North American business has now improved but still a lot of work ahead of us to get it to a  reasonable level and ethylene and propylene hits here too.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then in the beginning of March, we announced that we will merge oil and mining and municipal industrial  segments to Industry and Water segments. After this change, we will have two, roughly equal sized and critical  mass having segments with less complexity in a way we operate. This change is expected to bring €15 million to  €20 million savings and we'll reach the run rate by the end of the year. We are not exiting any businesses or we  are not changing any strategies. We will execute our strategy just through these two segments.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We will continue to report the oil and gas business revenues separately also in the future under the Industry and  Water segment reporting. The main objective of this change is to simplify Kemira's way of working and further  improve our capability to serve our customers.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, how does the business roughly look like? If I start from the upper left-hand corner on the application area,  15% from last year's combined numbers is oil and gas-related business, 75% is water treatment and mining  business is mostly water treatment of dewatering and treating the dewatered waters in concentrates. And then  10% are other miscellaneous applications.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: All of our coagulant plants and all of our polymer manufacturing units will be managed by this new

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, organic growth 2% really driven by volume growth across the board, but oil and mining 20% was the biggest  contributor. Volumes grew in other segments as well but in the oil segments – M&I and Pulp & Paper, the  declining prices on a year-on-year comparison was still offsetting much of the volume growth.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Profitability was impacted by the turn in raw material prices. As we compare raw material prices year-on-year,  they were about flat but there's sort of a U-turn, U-shape that we are clearly seeing, and on a sequential basis, the  raw material prices during the quarter clearly turned up and I'll elaborate that a bit more when I show my  traditional raw materials slide.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Profitability was disappointing as one would have expected the additional volume would have really flowed better  to the bottom-line. Oil & Mining business, particularly for oil and gas customers, is really polymer business. And  polymer business uses heavily oil-based raw materials like acrylonitrile and various assets.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The pricing of these raw materials is typically formula-based and the base in the formula is often propylene and/or  ethylene. As you will see couple of slides later, there was a sudden, if not even a dramatic increase in these  prices, particularly in North America. If you remember carefully, I warned that in after Q4 the impact was even  greater than what we expected in after January. We have now offset this by announcing price increase, but,  obviously, the impact of price increases comes with a delay and so there.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The story and perhaps the surprise for the quarter is the propylene price hike, particularly in the U.S. As I said, we  saw it coming in January, but really the magnitude caused a surprise to us. So 68% was the increase in the  propylene price between December of 2016 and March of 2017, so dramatic increase. And this increase was if  not, what is important to remember, the oil price is actually down in the same timeframe. So this is not oil-driven,  but it is a temporary constraint which are caused by increased demand for downstream derivatives like  polypropylene, ongoing cracker turnaround and production issues limiting supply, and particularly the delay in  start-up of a one new production facility.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Now, let's go to the bit more on the Huntsman fire impact. The raw material that Huntsman supplies to us is  copper, and as Jari mentioned, it's a key raw material for production of iron coagulants. We also sell electricity  and steam and other chemicals. Huntsman has official or has themselves said that they expect to gain full  capacity of the facility by end of 2018, or actually around the end of 2018 and with output around 40% by end of  Q2 or within Q2 of 2018.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: As of Q1, first of all, the impact was only two months rather than three months. And secondly, we have raw  material storage and now the raw material issue is starting to be more problematic starting from Q2 onwards.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 27April2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We did have in January some winter weather upsets in North America that resulted to some shutdowns, and then  also at the same time a price spike in propylene in North America. This has now settled down as of March and  April. The currency impact was a big one, bigger than normally, and impacted minus €7 million to our operative  EBITDA and came mostly from United States dollar and Swedish krona. Therefore, the reported EBITDA was  only slightly better than Q1 last year.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Oil & Gas momentum continuing strong, especially in sale. And pulp market is strong and that's good for our  bleaching plants which are running well. As said, operative EBITDA was only slightly better than last year due to  the €7-million impact from FX. EPS up and we also sold some non-core minority joint venture assets of power in  Finland.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Let's look at Pulp & Paper, organic growth 5%, reported top line was flat due to FX. We have major differences in  Q1 on how our regions are operating. As said, Pulp business is strong. We make bleaching chemicals in EMEA,  in United States, in South Africa. And from these, we also ship to APAC and South Africa.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And we have a strong track record on helping the customers on the conversions as making printing and writing  paper and board paper is a different ball game. And so we can supply – support our customers in that. Also,  there's the plastics dilemma around the world, which is driving then more to paper-based packaging materials,  and that's obviously working toward our business goal.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Let's look at Industry & Water, strong 11% growth – organic growth, driven by Oil & Gas, and especially shale,  and shale market remaining strong. CEOR deliveries are ongoing but still diluting our profitability. Water treatment  market also steadily and slightly growing. Further price increase is needed, and we are pushing through when  contracts are rolling over, that's especially in the water treatment. In shale, we've been able to pass or get prices  through.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We're also approaching the Water business in a different way of looking at that if we can't get good enough  margins from customers, we might let the business go and direct those volumes to better paying customers. So,  Industry & Water is all about profitability improvement rather than growth, especially in the water treatment.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In CEOR, we've been talking about a deal that we made last year. And back of that year – deal, I'm sorry, we  decided to invest into a €30-million specialty polymer plant into Rotterdam. We have not been able to talk about  the deal more but now we can do so. So, the customer is Chevron and their oil field in the North Sea of United  Kingdom. We have a multi-year delivery deal of polymers, which will gradually grow as Chevron starts to put more  and more polymers with water. This way, they can prolong the life of the field. They've been pumping only water  and pushing oil out. That doesn't work anymore. So, they need to add polymer and that will improve their  productivity from their field.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Moving on to the raw materials. So, the big picture is that the raw material increase trend has continued. It  probably started somewhere in mid-2016 and it has continued. There was a sort of a period where we expected  that it would be leveling off in 2017, but clearly we saw a somewhat of an acceleration in Q1.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: EMEA performing well, steady results also coming out of South America. North America is having a challenging  market with a decline in paper production, but also there was a raw material or not raw material but wind or  weather-related harsh conditions that really increased our production costs in North America. So that resulted in  an unsatisfactory result for North America.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The good thing about or the positive side of that is that we will catch up some of that during Q2. Some of you may  remember that electricity is the largest component – cost component for chloride and electricity cost really  jumped, spiked one would say in January and February. And as we have pass through pricing claws with most of  our – or majority of our chloride customers in North America, this is a North America specific issue, we will recoup  or recover majority of that excess cost as we [ph] sell (19:16) in Q2 to these same customers.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: China had some issues also. Jari mentioned raw material issues. There were also some regulator imposed  production limits. Somewhat weather and environmental or pollution related issues where the whole industry was  asked to slow down production. So clearly, that resulted nothing but lost sales but it resulted in increased  production costs.

texts.speaker: Petri Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Head of Region Americas, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Industry & Water reported growth €7 million, but really strong underlying growth. And this underlying growth is  driven by Oil & Gas, and particularly in our shale business in North America. And this really, one could say that  the pickup in volume and pickup in demand in shale, that's driving the [ph] about (20:19) more than 100 basis  points improvement year-on-year and sequential quarters as well, as the rest of the business is still struggling with  the raw material pressure at this time.

file: KEMIRA - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 26April2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then looking at Industry & Water and really good start to the year. Solid water treatment market. Oil & Gas  performance really good. Organic growth moderated as expected to 26%. That's nothing to worry about. Revenue  from Oil & Gas, €62 million. We will also see the gross easing off to more normal levels in Oil & Gas and our  capacity utilization remains on a high level. Coagulant raw material prices will increase this year from last year,  but we are much better positioned to take on that challenge at this moment than we were a year ago this time.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: As said, polymer prices especially in Industry & Water helped a bit with new price increases kicking in also in Pulp  & Paper but also Industry & Water. In January, this raw material thing can be a temporary one. For looking out for  Q2 and Q3 and Oil & Gas and Industry & Water, we will start the seasonal deliveries for oil sands this month.  They will continue until September-October time. And that has a dilutive effect on our margins but we'll bring  euros to the bottom line, so that's good to keep in mind. A really good start for I&W for the year, EBITDA margin,  operative EBITDA margin 16.8%.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: As a reminder, we have four core product lines in our portfolio: bleaching, coagulants, polymers, and sizing  chemistries. And these have been the areas also where our main growth investments have been going and are  going. So, that's good to keep in mind, this form about 80% of our total revenue.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Chairman of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have been investing into pulp. We have been investing into sizing and coagulants not so much because that's  in a better situation mostly. We will be continuing with our special polymer investment in the Rotterdam area and  ramp it up during the second half of the year, targeting the improvement of performance and growth in our CEOR  applications at the North Sea. And our Chinese AKD wax joint venture manufacturing side is under completion.  We also will ramp that up during the second half of the year. And as you might remember in the beginning of the  year, we announced the new €60 million emulsion polymer capacity increase in United States, and that's mainly  targeting our shale market which continues to grow in the future but can be utilized in water treatment and Pulp &  Paper applications also.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Operative EBITDA bridge, now, this shows the magnitude net sales impact of €24 million which is the raw  material. Cost inflation versus the price increases that we have been able to implement, obviously a great  outcome for Q1. In this context, I think it's fair to remind that Q1 last year was really difficult quarter. We had a  very severe raw material price inflation in Q1. Also, we had severe winter weather in North America which actually  increased the electricity costs dramatically and even we had to shut down our plants in some areas for a few  days. So relatively easy comparison in Q1 but nevertheless this should not take away anything from the huge  improvement that we made in Q1.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: oil-based raw materials that go into the polymer product actually declining. And clearly, that benefited particularly  our I&W business, which is predominantly has a higher share of polymer business.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This year, it's sort of exaggerated with the oil sands business where we have a – sort of we have a summer  season when we are actually selling to the Canadian oil sands. However, we continue to build up inventories for  this season throughout the year. So, we're – right about now, we are at the peak inventory level of finished  products that go into the Canadian oil sands.

texts.speaker: Petri Eero Castrén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Management Board, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Few comments on ratio. So, operative – return on capital improved now above 10% and really driven by Industry  & Water profit improvement. Regarding our reported debt, the IFRS 16 impact was to increase net debt by €129  million. On a comparable apples-to-apples comparison, actually, the debt would have come down. The net debt  ratio, as we report, increased to 2.4%. And again, accounting standard here has a sort of a side effect that  exaggerates this as we always take the last period debt level. But then

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 29July2010 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So we had a very good Q2 result, as you obviously have seen very strong improvement in result and profitability.  And I'll try to run through how – where it's all about and what it's all about. And starting from slide 3, just to remind  you that we are – today Kemira is focusing on water technology, water treatment and serving water-intensive  industries and we have – 75% of our businesses are water related. And we have this year earlier divested or  separated our paint business and earlier done many other things. And at the moment, really, because the water  treatment business is very global, a still fragmented business, but anyhow global, certainly Kemira is one of the  key players and top players globally in this business and we have really very well established ourselves all over.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So if we go to slide number 5, where we can see the summary of second quarter and starting with saying that  revenue increased by 12% compared to previous year same period and especially, Oil & Mining, different  industrial water, from our point of view [indiscernible] (03:32) segments, and Paper, which mostly is water  treatment as well, certainly in those areas, demand recovered. That is very positive and volumes increased.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And operative EBIT has increased as well. Last year, we had very good Q3 in especially municipal water  business where we benefit from price increases, low raw material costs and our EBIT margin in that business was  even 16% of sales. But this shows how the operative EBIT has increased, meaning also improved profitability.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Let's go to slide number 9, it shows that every segment has the same story, improving profitability, but especially  Oil & Mining and Paper have about doubled the profitability, and Oil & Mining is close to 10%; but also Paper, it's  very nice to see that improvement of profitability is significant.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And especially, if you look at Q2 this year, Q2 last year, last year operative EBIT was €8 million and this year, €18  million. So, it's big improvement. We have had two divestments in Paper business lately, sulphuric acid production  in Kokkola, Finland and optical brighteners, meaning FWA business in Germany we have divested, and they are  not water related businesses and actions have been totally according to our strategy.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Perhaps there is, at this point, worth mentioning also that, we divested – not divested, but established with  American Rockwood a joint venture concerning titanium dioxide business. Titanium dioxide business for a long  time ago was one of the core businesses Kemira had. But as you know, we have decided to focus on water. And  this joint venture, established somewhere in autumn 2008, had a very, very difficult year. 2009, perhaps the worst  in the industry ever, but we survived. However, Kemira booked minor losses last year in, how to say, under EBIT  line.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The industry, however, has recovered during previous months. Prices are higher, demand is higher, supply- demand very healthy, and now we have been able to book positive results to Kemira's books and that indicates  also that all-in-all, in global economy, the world is slightly coming and recovering because titanium dioxide  business has always been like a [ph] thermometer (16:30) and been a cyclical business showing where the world  is going to.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I will end up very shortly saying that we established during spring in Finland, announced a big research and  development investment, biggest ever done in an environmental business in Finland and said that we will invest  €120 million in coming four years, additional totally new water technology capabilities together with a research  institute research institute called VTT. And we have started during two, three previous months, one-third of those  activities and it has started very well and some other companies are joining to the program.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We also have tightened cooperation with the University of Alberta, especially in the oil sands activities. As you  saw, our oil and gas business is doing very well, it's growing with improved profitability, demand is growing and  it's good to focus on that. We are not strong at all yet in oil sands, but it gives a big opportunity for Kemira to  develop business in that field as well.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And now some weeks ago, we also announced a cooperation with Nanyang Technological University in  Singapore. That is the most recognized [indiscernible] (19:03) technology university in the world. That's also a  research and development cooperation where we look at how we could decrease energy in [indiscernible] (19:16)  technology that is used for water reuse and desalination. And this is part of the story of putting an emphasis on  research and development activity.

texts.speaker: Harri Lasse Juhani Kerminen
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And I will close this short presentation on slide 18 and saying what will be the key focus areas in the coming  months. Certainly, a focus on costs and tight cash flow management will continue, so that we will not ease up in  those areas where we have built also very good discipline in the company during last two years. That will continue  and it also certainly enables us to look at profitable growth and looking at implementation of our water strategy  where we have a lot of opportunities globally to do. But anyway, as a final statement, Q2 was a very strong month  and good improvement compared to last year.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We divested some petrochemical product lines last year based on our strategy to focus on the water and water  technologies. We have at the moment above 75% of total revenues is related directly to water treatment.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The next slide, I guess it will be 11, so there is a more – looking at balance sheet from 2008 and we can see that  gearing has decreased, being now at the level of 37%, it was more than 100% in 2008 when we started this water- focused strategy, at the same time also, our return on capital employed has increased, so in a very positive  direction. I can say that, looking at all our segments and businesses, every business has a return of capital  employed better than our average capital cost, so making positive – creating positive value [ph] for the LMS,  (11:50) so we don't have any negative business in Kemira's portfolio.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: In Kemira, we also have outside water business, so called specialty chemicals. I should call as a business unit  very solid stable business in the previous two, three years, but also there we had a very significant raw material  price increases that impacted negatively to EBIT margin, so it was close to 9% compared to last year close to 13%.  And that is basically all are coming from higher variable costs.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And when we look at slide number 20, there is growth from very simple picture telling about where, which kind of  industries really are growing and what our growth expectations during this year. Certainly oil and gas drilling is  one of those areas, where big growth is expected like metals and mining industry. And Kemira is in both cases  there in water treatment business, nothing else, but water is the issue there.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Also water utilities and paper products, they are expected to grow this year. So, the message is that we are well  positioned at Kemira both in water but also in those segments, which are expected to grow.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: But there are some key reasons for this, first of all in 2008, when Rockwood and Kemira made strategic decision  to combine their businesses, I think that was very successful effort. And this combination created, there was  leading specialty producer of TiO2 including old Sachtleben, barium sulfate, zinc sulfide [indiscernible] (20:38)  Kemira's contribution in specialty TiO2 was line printing inks and cosmetics in specialties. And combining these  two businesses, it is a big globally big really specialty TiO2 business.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And finally, we have the last slide basically, it's strategic chart more or less, so again Kemira is focusing on water  treatment and water business, where we have about 75% of the business today. And water is continuously growing  business area and it's very much connected to energy demand as well. We have been successfully strengthening  our balance sheet, I can say that [ph] all in out (23:46) is strong and market position is such that even this times  when raw material pricings have really significant to increase we have been able to compensate more or less, this  showing also that we have a pricing power.

texts.speaker: Harri Kerminen
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The water business is very different that Kemira used to be in all times, so we are creating new corporate culture  to meet different competencies and so that's an internal issue, but very critical long-term to be successfully  growing and increasing profitability. And this profitability even we have – we didn't improve in Q2, now this  profitability, it is our main item to still continue to work heavily with that and we have lot of activities not only  pricing and raw material side, but also in product customer mix area and we have really massive product portfolio  increased profitability outside this areas.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 26July2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: On an earnings per share basis, we remain flat at €0.20 per share. We are continuing to evaluate options. There  was a lot of speculation in the media going back and forth what we might do or might not do regarding our joint  venture Sachtleben. We have confirmed that have retained Lazard. Lazard is working and we will discuss with  Lazard shortly together with Rockwood, what they recommend us to do, but additional comments I would not like  to make because again we are the minority shareholder and therefore it's on Rockwood to discuss what is going to  happen with Sachtleben.  We also announced today a plan to restructuring program for Kemira which we have called Fit for Growth and I  will outline in my presentation what's behind this program. First of all, we are strategically on the right track. Our  share of water-related business is continuing to grow. We have meanwhile reached year-to-date 2012, 78%, so we  are on the right track and we are continuing to implement our strategy.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are well positioned to address key global challenges, which we have identified for Kemira as the growing  concern regarding the environment. And you might have heard, for example, recent articles regarding the Baltic  Sea that the warming of the Baltic Sea poses new threats, new issues with the growth of bacteria, which might  trigger health risks. So there is a growing concern not just in Europe but also in other parts of the world.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Water scarcity is getting more of a challenge, perhaps not equally in all geographies. Britain was literally stopping  from watering the gardens at the end of last year and the beginning of this year, now they are drowning in water,  so it's quickly changing once in a while but generally water scarcity is getting a quickly growing concern. And we  have a growing demand for energy, metals and minerals especially in the emerging markets. And there is a need  for addressing also environmental concerns related to the production of minerals and metals. And this is clearly  market potential for Kemira under our strategic orientation.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have discussed couple of times that water quality and quantity management is the strategy goal for Kemira.  And all these three pillars I have outlined are providing opportunities for us to develop our business further to  grow, to grow profitability and it's now on us to demonstrate that we can translate these opportunities into real  business.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Clearly, we are focusing on the efficiency in industrial water and energy and raw material management. And we  are getting ever bigger inroads at a rather high profitability. We are working intensively on renewable biomass  resources, which are replacing increasingly packaging, in packaging metals and plastics.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Desalination is getting an ever quicker growing market for making drinking water available not just in the African  region or in the Middle East but also Southern Europe and in Asia. And the improved environmental status of our  waterways, lakes, rivers, seas is on the global agenda. And I have last time elaborated on what we are doing, for  example, lake restoration in Brazil and we are getting increasing enquiries to what extent and how we can help  also in other geographies.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Efficient natural resource recovery is also an ever increasing theme. And we are developing our inroads also on the  R&D side in order to be a partner of the respective industries.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Our key innovation topics in this context are for the time begin the yield increase in desalination because it's, as  you know, very energy intensive and whenever you can produce more drinking water at lower energy rate, it is on  the one hand an economical benefit but it's also at the same time an ecological benefit.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Microbe scaling and corrosion control is in a lot of water processes as well as in industrial processes. A key topic,  which has a direct impact again on energy consumption and the reduction of energy is a business case and is not  just an [ph] ecological (7:39) case. Water reuse is becoming a prime topic especially in the emerging markets and  you are not just trying to clean the water and release it as it's typically the practice in Europe and United States  but they immediately use water for other purposes and we are active in this business.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are having quite a number of developing projects underway in the context of SWEET in this context.  Membrane bioreactor is a very interesting methodology for emerging markets to combine water treatment with  energy generation especially as membrane bioreactors can be very efficiently operated also in smaller units.  So you can consider [ph] future decentralized (8:36) concepts based on such technologies. And energy from  sludge is also getting ever more important because on the one hand landfilling of sludge, disposal of sludge is only  doable when the sludge from quality perspective is suitable and is not ecologically harmful to the environment and  obviously not in every geography that's the case.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Secondly, not in all the geographies you have the circumstances that you can use the sludge for example, for  landfilling. So therefore the key question is how to not just burn the sludge, but use the sludge for energy  production in order to reuse the sludge. And we are very active here. This is just a few highlights in order to accept  the tone what SWEET is focusing on.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are clearly very active in the polymer field. I indicated already in my last investors briefing that polymers are a  key product group for Kemira in the quarter – in the context of water quality and quantity management. And we  are working intensively on different polymer technologies in order to improve the extraction of resources from  unconventional locations like deep sea or oil sands.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We are currently mostly in the upstream oil and gas business and in the mining applications. Approximately 80%  of our business in oil and mining is in the reach area meaning drilling, cementing, stimulation and liberation of  oil. Some 15% is in the production area, meaning production and injection, suspension or in the concentration of  the produced oil and just 5% is used in refining the oil.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We want to substantially grow and strengthened our position in the emerging markets. But at the same time, we  want to do that in a profitable manner. So E10 is the target the management of Kemira is fully committed to  deliver. And we have also indicated that we want to further sharpen our strategy with focus on water quality and  quantity management in order to make growth above market average possible.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The new organization will accelerate, will help us to accelerate the growth especially in the emerging markets. We  have discussed last briefing that clearly APAC is the largest market for water going forward. South America is the  largest market for pulp going forward. And literally at this point in time, both regions play a rather smaller role in  our portfolio and we intend to change that.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Of course, the disclaimer as usual is that current exchange rates and oil prices prevail for the rest of 2012. And  that we do not see a fundamental change in the overall economic situation, which you can or cannot, put a  question mark on right now; there is some uncertainty, but this is of course the underlying basis for this outlook.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: But then on the negative side, like maybe outlined in several places in our interim report is that our raw material  prices were still very high and our fixed costs were too high. And then on the cash flow side, we still have work to  do with our net working capital, it's still too high compared to our sales.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Paper and pulp business for us is one of the key elements of our water quality and quantity management strategy  going forward. We have started to move more towards tissue and packaging and board already back in 2008.  2008 represent roughly 22% of the sales of this segment and currently it's already at the level of one-third. And  the point here is, of course, that packaging and board and tissues, they are the most growing parts of the Paper  segment. And this is exactly what we are focusing on.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Again Oil & Mining, it was about higher sales prices. But we saw, for example, the natural gas price in USA  affecting the top line growth. So there are issues also in the sense where the markets are with Oil & Mining. But  overall the financial results there were very good.  The last four years basically with Oil & Mining ever since we started this segment, it has been a growth story in the  terms of sales and in the terms of profitability. Going from 6% to 13% today in Oil & Mining is a good  achievement. Demand is, of course, very favorable. Oil and gas, metal and mining, there are areas where a lot of  activities globally, if you look where the business [ph] setup (36:10) is today. But we have to be on the growth  mode with this business because this is one of the cornerstones for Kemira's strategy going forward.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Then we go to this mixed area of other and really like mentioned earlier ChemSolutions will be one segment that  we are going to report starting 1st of January next year. ChemSolutions had a rough quarter in quarter two, mainly  affecting by two major factors coming from the high raw material prices, mainly heavy oil and also some raw  material for [indiscernible] (36:51) and also formic acid and also we had extended maintenance break in Oulu that  affected our figures in quarter two.

texts.speaker: Jyrki Mäki-Kala
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Joint venture renewed there facility agreement in June. And we as Kemira and also Rockwood, the other partner,  received dividend and paid-in-capital in June, we got roughly €40 million. And then Sachtleben also acquired  assets in June in Germany of a company called Crenox GmbH. So in a way, they have further strengthened their  position as a specialty titanium dioxide producer globally. Basically we are at this point when our investment in  bank Lazard is evaluating the possibilities. So basically, we have no other news, in that sense, concerning this  [indiscernible] (39:20). Right, that's basically from my side.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 23July2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I would like to basically quickly go through again on the structure, Where water meets chemistry. I would now  then switch to give you an overview on the Q2 results, give you an outlook, and then I'm open to take your  questions regarding our activities.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
