texts.text: We have immediately after the presentation of the strategy, in a stringent manner, started to implement the  defined activities for the different segments. And just to recall we are focusing on processed water and processed  chemicals in mining, oil and gas, as well as in the pulp and paper industry. And we are focusing on drinking water  as well as wastewater reuse or wastewater treatment in our traditional M&I segment.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have also announced meanwhile which is again in line with our strategy that we are looking for opportunities  for our ChemSolutions business. Just to clarify one thing when we are talking ChemSolutions, we are talking the  formic acid and derivatives part. We are not talking the sodium bicarbonate. So it's only part of ChemSolutions  which is up for divestment, and not all of it. And I'm explaining that in order to get your valuations for that  business right.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The figures which are currently in the market are unrealistically high. And I want to avoid that we get into the  same discussion we had with titanium dioxide. And if you think about [indiscernible] (07 :16) failed to sell this  business, the market has not recovered. So from that point of view, I just want to do some expectation  management that you get the right idea on potential proceeds. If both transactions would happen, mean ing we  would divest our formic acid and derivatives business, plus we close the deal with 3F as planned, our share of the  differentiated products would increase from 40% to 45%. So we would clearly move into the right direction to  focus on where the differentiating potential and where the growth potential for the company lies.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The other element that always influences our second quarter is electricity prices. You might be aware that we are a  large electricity consumer, in particular in Finland. And in Finland, the nuclear power stations go for turnaround  in June and from that point of view, the electricity prices in June are always higher for us. And that impacts our  second quarter electricity cost.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: The problem child currently is Oil & Mining. We are in a very challenging business environment overal l.  Nevertheless, the volume increase continued, so we are gaining back business in the shale gas environment. How  this is going to continue, we have to see because you might be aware that shale gas prices have started to come  down again. And as the industry is rather volatile, it stays challenging. We are not yet at the levels we had in the  first half of 2012. But if you look at the low point was in the first quarter 2012, we in the first quarter already had  an improvement, and in the second quarter continued our improvement.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This is something we are watching very closely. The other part is also challenging, that's the mining industry. The  mining industry is currently in the doldrums. The raw material prices have come down dramatically, the mineral  prices have come down and the prospects for the mining industry are not too optimistic. At this point, we are  trying by gaining position in the emerging markets to mitigate that to a certain extent, but we have to see how this  industry is developing mid and long term.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: I think with this slide, you'll get an overview on where the challenges in detail are: process efficiency, increased  energy demand is clearly a basic underlying feature of the industry. So, horsepower reduction is key. Wet and dry  shale hydraulic fracturing will stay in the focus of the markets, and the respective chemicals are needed. Oil sands  is a growing business in Canada, where so far, we are not yet really having found our market entry. We have  products in trial, but we are not currently a real player there, and this is where our immediate focus is.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We have declining reserves. And we have in the mineral side, ores with less and less metal content. We have  introduced this year a new pelletizing agent for iron ore, which is making quite good inroads and b ased on the first  commercial use, we have already gained additional customers. The other big topic is EOR. EOR, you can imagine,  is a rather competitive business because it's large volumes, and we are trying to participate with the differentiated  niche product in [ph] this game (33:48). From our backward integration point of view, we cannot play in the large  volumes where you are talking 50,000 tonnes to 60,000 tonnes [ph] per field (33:58). That's beyond our  capabilities.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Water scarcity remains an issue. And from that point of view, scale, microbiological control is a core topic, as well  as shale water management. The first discussions are intensifying in the United States, that shale water  management will take place on site, rather than the water being tr ucked. How quickly this really turns into  business, we have to see. But at least the fact that the big pumpers are engaging themselves in discussions means  the environmental pressure is starting to mount. And from that point of view, we are preparing ourse lves for this  opportunity.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: And overall, there is environmental concern. And from that point of view, we expect that on the one hand, tailings  management will be enforced sooner or later. Question is how quickly it comes. Y ou might recall we have  discussed a couple of times in shale gas and in shale oil, as well as in oil sands that a lot of companies just take the  water, the effluent and put it in ponds. And it's sitting there untreated. And there is now mounting pressure that  this water is treated so that the ponds are cleared.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Shale water re-use is, at least, something we are discussing currently which then means that the water could be re - injected directly at the site after it has been cleaned. That's something which is on the radar screen of the  pumpers. And contaminants removal is getting an issue in the mining industry, which [indiscernible] (35:46)  discussed. How quickly that really is put into place considering that the minerals prices are currently coming  down, is of course, to be seen because these industries are on the one hand very dynamic when it comes to price  changes, but they are also very sensitive with respect to their actions depending on the price level, high or low of  their respective markets.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: ChemSolutions is as you might remember, a twofold story. This is a business which consists of a very well- operating formic acid and derivatives business. And then we have on top of that the percarbonate business which  turns out to be an ever increasing challenge.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Percarbonate is used in powder detergent as a bleach agent and it's currently only used in Europe. There are three  competitors, Solvay, Evonik and Kemira. It's a structural overcapacity and the markets are shifting from powder  detergent to liquid detergent, where you are not needing percarbonate anymore. So from that point of view, the  situation is difficult. There is no simple solution for this problem, but what you see here in the figures for the  operative EBIT of ChemSolutions is largely influenced by the impact of the percarbonate busin ess on the very  good-performing formic acid and derivatives business. We, nevertheless, could improve from last year 0.7 % –  €0.7  million in the second quarter to €1.1 million. And we are expecting that the percarbonate business is doing  better again in the third quarter. So, the figures will go up again. And we are also looking now into efficiency  improvements on the percarbonate side.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Generally, just to give you also a guidance the same way we gave it for the M&I business, from a seasonality point  of view, the highest quarter profitability-wise is, normally in ChemSolutions, the first quarter because you also  have the de-icing business at the highest pace. The second-best quarter is the fourth quarter of the previous year  or of the respective year because there the de-icing business starts, whereas the second and the third quarter are  largely driven by silage additive. And therefore, also to a certain extent are influenced by weather conditions.  When you have very wet environment, you need more silage additives than when you have very dry s ummers. We  have no de-icing business naturally in the second and the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Büchele
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So, obviously, the highest allocation of CapEx is for the growth businesses, whereas obviously the businesses  earmarked for profit orientation – profit optimization have to fight and have to demonstrate overproportional  returns in order to be allocated respective CapEx. And from that point of v iew, the CapEx in ChemSolutions is just  a little bit of debottlenecking. And the CapEx in M&I has come down substantially in line also with our  streamlining of the operation.

file: KEMIRA - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 22July2014 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We drive for growth in Pulp and Paper and Oil & Mining, and our M&I  business continues to be an important cash  flow producer for us in the future. Our financial targets for our Strategy 2016 and 2020 are still in place, and those  are what we are driving for.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking at our paper business, and packaging and board is really the area, and tissue, where the growth comes  from. We all know the printing paper is going down, but our main focus is capturing the growth in packaging,  board and tissue. APAC continues to be a really – also nice growth area for us. And when we look at the recycling  fibers and making packaging more stronger, but yet lighter. So that's a demand for further chemicals and further  growth for Kemira.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: We then look at Oil & Mining, mainly driven in the second quarter and year -to-date with business coming from  the Americas and oil and gas, and nice double-digit growth there. We already announced the new Head of Oil &  Mining segment and he started in May, so an important step. And we also opened the Houston, Texas, Oil &  Mining head office in June to get our people and our organization closer to the oil and gas customers right next  door, and that's already providing good feedback and good business opportunities through that move.

texts.speaker: Jari Rosendal
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Increased activity is seen in Enhanced Oil Recovery. That's not a big revenue generator fo r us right now yet, but  that's coming in the future, next few years, and is showing us really promising signs with the activity in the  market.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: So where is the business mix going? So clearly, we see high growth, double -digit growth in our differentiated  chemicals. This is consistent with our strategy. The polymers growing at 15% year-on-year and also paper  chemicals in the sizing and strength area. We saw the decline in coagulants, the divestment is the primary cause  for that, and I already mentioned some of the pricing impact, and there were also some maintenance breaks that  impacted the bleaching and pulping chemicals decline on a year-on-year basis.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: What's important to note is that, when I started about less than a year ago, we were abou t 40% differentiated  chemicals and 60% commodity chemicals, we are now already 50%-50%. And pro forma, the AkzoNobel paper  chemical acquisition, we will be 55% differentiated chemicals and 45% commodity chemicals. So we are on that  strategic metric or strategic initiative, we are actually progressing very well and faster than I think we  communicated when we started following this metric a couple of years ago.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: This year also – not this year, but also, we see typically in May or in Q2, the maintenance shutdown for the nuclear  power plants, and we are a large consumer of electricity here in Finland. And while the nuclear power plants are  being maintained, we resort to market price electricity and that always has some impact to our Q2 results. Then  this year, we had a tri-annual, i.e., a maintenance break that we do in our Helsingborg site, our biggest site every  three years so that it has some impact, additional impact on paper profitability along with increased c osts and  depreciation from the Nanjing operations. So those are the reasons why EBIT on reported basis is below last year.  On an EBITDA basis, the segment was still ahead of last year. EBITDA margin data point.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: Looking at the Oil & Mining; so clearly here, the highlight is the continued strong demand for our polymer  products for North American oil and gas. Last time we looked at the rig count, the rig count was again up by 7%.  So this seems to be a good solid trend that the market is growing and clearly we  have benefited. So 17% organic  growth during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Petri Castren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Kemira Oyj
texts.text: On the mining side, the market continues to be soft. We don't foresee a quick recovery on that and also in the oil  and gas in EMEA where we operate mainly in the conventional oil and gas, we don't see the same progress that we  have seen in North America.
